Smoking vs. Life Expectancy
LEAD: A Federal study blames cigarette smoking for 315,120 deaths around the nation in 1984, which represents a loss of 3.6 million years in terms of shortened lifespans, the researchers say.

BUTOH: DANCE OF DARKNESS
LEAD: BUTOH IS NOT FOR THE FRAIL.
THE AVANT-garde dance form that today is Japan's most startling cultural export does not aim to charm.
Instead, it sets out to assault the senses.
The hallmarks of this theater of protest include full body paint (white or dark or gold), near or complete nudity, shaved heads, grotesque costumes, clawed hands, rolled-up eyes and mouths opened in silent screams.


CORRECTION
LEAD: An article last Sunday about the Old Dutch Church in North Tarrytown misstated the amount of a state grant to help restore the church.
The state provided a matching grant of $120,000 toward the project, which is expected to cost $500,000.

WILDE IN NEW YORK: BEAUTY PACKED THEM IN
LEAD: THE Arizona docked in New York Harbor on the evening of Jan. 2, 1882.
It was too late to clear quarantine until the following morning.
The press, avid to see Oscar Wilde, could not wait.
Enterprising reporters ''came out of the sea,'' as Wilde picturesquely noted, their pens still wet with brine.
In fact, they chartered a launch to bring them aboard.

Pretoria Acts to Improve Ties With Zimbabwe
LEAD: The South African Government made an unexpected move this week in an attempt to improve its icy political relations with Zimbabwe, its black-ruled neighbor.


THE ECONOMIC HISTORIANS' VIEW: Comparing the Collapses; John A. Garraty: Contradictory Signs
LEAD: AT first glance, there are many similarities between the extraordinary collapses of stock prices that occurred in October 1929 and the declines we have recently experienced.
Both hit after extended bull markets and amid general prosperity that tempted investors to ignore underlying weak spots in the economy: agriculture, coal mining and textiles in the 1920's, agriculture again and the smokestack industries today.


A SHIFT BY SOVIET TOWARD SUBTLETY ON ARMS FORESEEN
LEAD: The Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, has left Washington after raising the possibility that Moscow may be adopting a new strategy for limiting President Reagan's program for a space-based anti-missile defense.


Market Turmoil: 2 Vital Concerns
LEAD: As the markets fluctuated wildly last week, the debate over stock market volatility intensified.
Questions focused on the role of program trading and portfolio insurance and on the sophisticated instruments called stock index futures that make those techniques possible.
The debate raises an issue that goes right to the heart of capitalism: How to insure that the speculative element inherent in financial markets does not overwhelm the entire system.


Commercial Property: Warehouses; An 'Ugly Duckling' Starts to Get Investors' Respect
LEAD: LONG shunned for their lack of glamour and grandeur, warehouses now produce some of the highest annual returns in the nation's real-estate market.

Practical Traveler; Calming the Jitters About Tipping on Cruises
LEAD: It takes no graduate student of body language to see how awkward many people feel about tipping.
They go through pockets and purse, pulling out handkerchiefs, house keys and credit cards, but never come up with a bill of a suitable denomination for the bellman poised by the door.
Eventually, they find a crumpled bill, or mumble something about catching the employee later, and retreat in embarrassment.

Washington and Managua: A chronology
LEAD:  July 1979 Sandinistas oust Somoza regime; Carter Administration starts economic aid.
January 1981 U.S., disillusioned, suspends $75 million in economic aid.
March 1982 C.I.A. plans to give covert aid to Nicaraguan opposition groups are disclosed.
May 1982 Nicaragua announces $166.8 million Soviet aid pact.

PREPARATIONS FOR SPRING
LEAD: RAKE, rake, rake, blow, sweep or whatever to get the leaves off the lawn; if not kept off the grass, they will smother it and mat; what is more they will be extremely difficult to remove in spring and may even kill a lawn.
If finished using hand tools, wipe them and clean blades by rotating them in a box of sand; rub metal parts with oil or rust preventive.

But, given Miss Lilly's skills, she has the edge in such a situation.

Guest Observer; A Magazine Junkie
LEAD: I'M HOPELESS WHEN IT comes to books.
I can't go past a bookshop without slipping in to buy some classic I've never read before -one of those handsome Penguin editions of Dickens or Jane Austen, a volume of Henry James's correspondence or the poems of Wordsworth.
The old-fashioned illustrations on the cover, the crisp pages, the unbroken spine: they give off powerful emanations of culture, promise self-improvement, a subtle deepening of the mind.

Concert: Barattelli Group
LEAD: THERE is always a danger of provincialism on the new-music scene.
New York performing groups naturally tend to favor local or at least American composers, with only occasional representation from abroad.

Looking Ahead, With Statistics and Tea Leaves
LEAD: ON Wednesday, when car makers report their sales for the last 10 days of October, those seeking to divine the course of the economy will pore over the figures as never before.
As the first solid piece of statistical evidence of consumer behavior since the stock market collapse, the numbers, depending on their strength or weakness, are sure to be seen as harbingers of continued moderate economic expansion or impending malaise.

Cash-Rich Funds Hold Out for Fire Sale
LEAD: MONEY managers who had built substantial cash positions as a defensive strategy before the stock market's collapse were in no hurry last week to return to buying common stocks.
Even in the face of prices that would have appeared irresistible a month ago, the prevailing feeling among some of the country's more conservative investors, some of whom had as much as 50 percent of their portfolios in cash, was that the risk of a further decline outweighed any opportunity.

THE ECONOMIC HISTORIANS' VIEW: Comparing the Collapses; Eugene N. White: Parallel Dilemmas
LEAD: THE parallels between the crash of the stock market in 1929 and 1987 are too strong to ignore.
Nevertheless, the recent collapse does not necessarily portend a new Great Depression.
The 1929 crash shook the economy, but it was other problems - some similar to today's dilemmas - that caused the collapse.

CAN THE CONTRAS GO ON?
LEAD: James LeMoyne's article ''Can the Contras Go On?'' (Oct. 4), was an impressive portrayal of a sad band of young people who are neither ''freedom fighters'' nor terrorists but, rather, the inevitable dispossessed losers in a long-finished revolutionary war.
They are not unlike the Loyalists of our own Revolution, who were forced to flee to Canada and elsewhere.

HOW TO MAKE IT A SUCCESS
LEAD: THIS IS THE TIME of year to think about festive gatherings of family and friends.
But it is also the time when holiday chores and social and business commitments can reach daunting proportions.
An entertaining success, then, lies less in creating ''the perfect party'' with the maximum amount of time and resources than in working out a plan to bring pleasure and a sense of celebration to the party giver as well as to the guests.

A DIFFERENT INDEPENDENCE DAY
LEAD:  For many black Americans, the anniversary of the day their ancestors were freed from slavery is an independence day meriting at least as much to-do as the Fourth of July.
In O FREEDOM!
Afro-American Emancipation Celebrations (University of Tennessee, $24.95), William H. Wiggins Jr., a fellow of the Folklore Institute at Indiana University, brings much-deserved scholarly attention to the longstanding black American tradition of emancipation celebrations.

LEAD: SOMETIMES after the theater or movies, it is more fun to eat at home than in a restaurant.
The menu given below is perfect for a late-night meal, not too heavy and easy to prepare ahead of time.
It also makes a pleasant weekend lunch.
Ducks are roasted with thyme, ginger, garlic and soy sauce and served at room temperature with a salad made from yellow split peas and collard greens.

Ethnic Strife in Yugoslavia
Acts of violence by ethnic Albanian nationalists are increasing in Yugoslavia, leading to fearful talk of civil war.

Question Of the Week; What Will The Yankee Changes Mean?
LEAD: If the Yankees go into the next season with the same team as last season Billy Martin won't last the year.
If they get a pitcher and a frontline catcher he will.
But he better take the dugout phone off the hook because we all know someone will be calling.
ROBERT A. NISSEN
New York

LEAD: Borough President David Dinkins of Manhattan will present awards for excellence in the arts in a ceremony tomorrow night at 7:30 in Davis Hall at City College, Convent Avenue and 134th Street.


FINDING GRACE IN THE AWKWARD HUMANITY OF PEOPLE
LEAD: HELEN LEVITT WAS THE FIRST American photographer to fully comprehend the essence of Henri Cartier-Bresson's photographic message and put it into practice.
Like Cartier-Bresson, she understood how to combine intuition and intellect to forge sophisticated, lyrical compositions from commonplace events.


Soviet Survey of Moscow Residents Finds a Wide Range of Political Views
LEAD: Moscow residents approve of giving exit visas to Soviet citizens who want to emigrate, but they disapprove of releasing dissidents from prison or exile.

DON'T RULE OUT TAX INCREASES
LEAD: AN arcane, theoretically fail-safe procedure called ''program trading,'' in which investment decisions involving hundreds of millions of dollars can be taken and implemented without human intervention, has been indentified as a factor in the stock market collapse.
Computer-driven program trading raised the peaks, deepened the valleys and compressed market cycles.

POSTINGS: New Complex for Trenton; Bullish on Offices
LEAD: As more and more corporations settle in the New Jersey suburbs, Trenton, the state capital, is making its own push to become a first-class office center.
Already, about 10 office buildings - with two million square feet of space - are under construction, a bullish pace considering that the entire private sector now occupies only a half-million square feet.

Exchange Is Facing Clerical Staff Strike
LEAD: Officials of the New York Stock Exchange, trading companies and the New York Futures Exchange, who are facing a possible strike by most of their clerical workers, continued contract negotiations with union officials yesterday and are scheduled to resume their talks tonight, a spokesman for the exchange said yesterday.

LEAD: Douglas H. Ginsburg, President Reagan's new choice to fill the vacancy on the Supreme Court, is best known in Washington as an advocate of a conservative philosophy of government regulation, prodding agencies to decide regulatory questions according to a strict comparison of the social costs and benefits.

India Is Battling Pornographic Movie Posters
LEAD: Dozens of policemen swept through the capital's movie theaters last week, pulling down movie posters showing semi-nude women and sexually explicit scenes, to show the authorities' determination to enforce a new law on obscenity.

LEAD: Three years and three months since his last victory, Tom Watson played just well enough today to maintain his four-shot lead going into Sunday's final round of the richest golf tournament, the $3 million Nabisco Championships.

LEAD: The engagement of Linda Patrice Bradshaw to David Karim Lakhdhir, the son of Noor and Ann Hallan Lakhdhir of Westport, Conn., has been announced by her parents, Gail Bradshaw of Derwood, Md., and Thomas T. Bradshaw of Rockville, Md.
The couple plan to marry in April.

LEAD: A Texas safety, John Hagy, returned both an interception and a punt for touchdowns as Texas defeated Texas Tech, 41-27, to remain atop the Southwest Conference.


Bottle Bill on Ballot in Capital
LEAD: A ballot initiative to require deposits on beverage containers sold in the District of Columbia could spur action in other states because of the high profile of the nation's capital, proponents say.


TRENDY MOUNTAIN BIKES POSE UNEXPECTED THREAT TO WILDERNESS TRAILS
LEAD: THE bicycle once seemed the environmentalist's dream machine, a solution to air pollution, traffic jams and flabby muscles.
But that was before bicycle makers here in Marin County added gears to some old fat-tire Schwinns and launched the latest rage to roll out of California: the mountain bike, a machine capable of climbing trails and scaring hikers as it roars like a roller coaster in a cloud of dust.

Dr.
K.
J.
Lee suggests that plaintiffs' lawyers are bringing too many groundless medical malpractice cases and are being unjustly enriched in the process.
I disagree.

LEAD: VOTERS will go to the polls Tuesday to elect all 120 members of the State Legislature and scores of county and local officials, and to decide six statewide public questions, including three new spending proposals that could be affected by the stock market decline.
The polls will be open from 7 A.M.

LEAD: A senior Soviet envoy on a peace mission in the Persian Gulf criticized the United States Navy's presence here today, saying that one nation acting alone cannot bring about a cease-fire between Iran and Iraq.

Jakarta
LEAD: To the Editor: I appreciated reading Barbara Crossette's ''A Neighborhood Tour of Jakarta'' since I returned a year ago from having lived in Jakarta for nine months, and because of the truth in her comment about its seeming inexhaustibility for ''unadvertised corners.'' Unfortunately, I didn't visit all of the sites she described.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  Tennis  Lendl vs.
Mecir: Ivan Lendl struggled past Pat Cash and Miloslav Mecir overwhelmed Mats Wilander yesterday to advance to the final of the $923,000 European Community Championship in Antwerp, Belgium.
Lendl relied on stamina to power him past Cash, 6-4, 7-6.
Mecir, ranked fifth in the world, used a variety of daring strokes to beat Wilander, 6-1, 6-3.


Estate Affairs
LEAD:  To the Editor:


The Woman Who Beat The Klan
LEAD: IN HER DREAM, THERE was a steel-gray casket in her living room.
Who was the dead man laid out in a gray suit?
She couldn't tell.
And every time she moved closer to the coffin, someone she didn't know said, ''You don't need to see this.'' But Beulah Mae Donald knew that she did, and so she woke from her dream at two in the morning in Mobile, Ala., on March 21, 1981.


UP IN ARMS IN ARIZONA
LEAD: THE NOTION OF CON-servative Barry Goldwater, the most prominent politician in Arizona history, calling for the resignation of an Arizona Republican Governor would once have seemed less likely than a blizzard in Phoenix.
Yet when he did so, on Oct. 9, nobody was deeply shocked.

The Tango Meets Jorge Luis Borges
LEAD: TWO BROTHERS, SO CLOSE IT was said that to quarrel with one of them was to reckon with two enemies, fall in love with the same woman, who comes to live with them in their shack.
They try to share her, but jealousy begins to fester between them.
They try to get rid of her, selling her to a whorehouse - but each sneaks off to visit her in secret, so the brothers finally buy her back, the trust between them now tainted by mutual deception.


Chicago Mother Traded Her Child for Cocaine
LEAD: The authorities have started paper work to deny a pregnant drug addict custody of her two babies.
The work began one day after the mother looked through a glass partition and identified a 22-month-old boy as the child she had traded for $50 worth of cocaine.


Rebels Burned Bus Passengers, Survivors in Mozambique Say
LEAD: Survivors of an ambush on a convoy said rebels burned buses that were crowded with passengers, the national press agency reported today.
At least 211 people were reported killed.


Americans in Philippines Face Security Curbs
LEAD: President Corazon C. Aquino flew to Clark Air Base today to demonstrate her concern over the killing of three Americans on Wednesday, as Americans in the Philippines faced heightened security restrictions.

Dance: By Linda Mussmann
LEAD: LINDA MUSSMANN'S ''Blue Scene Grey,'' performed by her Time and Space Limited company on Friday at the Marymount Manhattan Theater, operates on a number of levels.
The first part of a four-part piece called ''Civil War Chronicles,'' the cantata jogs through 80 years of American history, from 1781 to 1861, in a manner that often makes schoolroom history come alive.

DOCUMENTARY
LEAD:  World Without Walls: Beryl Markham's African Memoir  Narrated by Diana Quick and Lyle Talbot.
Wild Wing Productions. 60 minutes. $29.95.
Beryl Markham, who in her youth looked as striking as Vanessa Redgrave, died last year in Nairobi.
Suddenly, she is more acclaimed in death than in life.
Her memoir, ''West With the Night,'' rediscovered and reprinted after 40 years, has been on the best-seller charts all during 1987, with a half-million copies in print from North Point Press of Berkeley, Calif.

Film Is the Weapon, Apartheid the Target
LEAD: IT WAS SPRINGTIME IN PRETORIA, THE SOUTH African capital, a time when the city is ablaze with the purple of jacaranda trees, the air on the highveld clear and crisp.

FOR A PLEASANT REPAST, DUCK, SALAD AND MOUSSE
LEAD: SOMETIMES after the theater or movies, it is more fun to eat at home than in a restaurant.
The menu given below is perfect for a late-night meal, not too heavy and easy to prepare ahead of time.
It also makes a pleasant weekend lunch.
Ducks are roasted with thyme, ginger, garlic and soy sauce and served at room temperature with a salad made from yellow split peas and collard greens.


ANSWERING THE MAIL

We want to remove the paint and restore the natural brick.
What is the best way to do this?


Train Crash Kills Crewman
LEAD: A slow-moving freight train struck a tanker truck filled with 8,000 gallons of gasoline Friday, killing a train crewman and injuring four other men, officials said.
The crash ignited an explosion and fire that shot flames 100 feet into the air; smoke could be seen 16 miles away, witnesses said.
The truck was straddling the railroad tracks, waiting to turn onto a highway, when the train hit it, splitting the vehicle in two, the authorities said.

Symbols That Matter
LEAD: A financial world fearful of incompetence in the American Government is looking desperately for reassuring symbols.

Two Worlds in the South Seas
LEAD: The South Pacific archipelago of Vanuatu is charmingly schizophrenic: some people wear gowns or three-piece suits, others wear only grass skirts or grass sheaths.
Some carry gold cigarette lighters, others carry smoldering sticks.
Some drink Bordeaux, others drink kava, a local intoxicant with less cachet but more effect.

CRIME
LEAD: By now Jonathan Valin's series about Harry Stoner, the Cincinnati private eye, is well established.
It started in 1980 with ''The Lime Pit,'' and the new FIRE LAKE (Delacorte, $14.95) is the seventh Stoner case.
Stoner is in the classic tradition of the American private eye.
He is a big, tough man who does not throw his strength around but nevertheless is not one to be trifled with.

FOR A PLEASANT REPAST, DUCK, SALAD AND MOUSSE
LEAD: SOMETIMES after the theater or movies, it is more fun to eat at home than in a restaurant.
The menu given below is perfect for a late-night meal, not too heavy and easy to prepare ahead of time.
It also makes a pleasant weekend lunch.
Ducks are roasted with thyme, ginger, garlic and soy sauce and served at room temperature with a salad made from yellow split peas and collard greens.

Cole Porter's Lyrics Depend On the Music, But Even Solo They're So Easy to Love
LEAD: IF YOU'VE FORGOTTEN WHAT it's like to leave a theater walking on air, a remedy lies ready to hand.
The revival of ''Anything Goes'' at the Lincoln Center's Vivian Beaumont Theater is wonderfully exhilarating and euphoria-inducing; Patty LuPone's Reno Sweeney is only one - though the most memorable - of an array of fine performances, and whatever minor imperfections the production may have are soon lost sight of in the glow cast by its energy and joie de vivre.

Opera: First 'Boheme' of Met Season
LEAD: FRANCO ZEFFIRELLI'S ''Boheme'' returned to the Metropolitan Opera Friday evening for its first performance of the season.
The director's six-year-old staging of the Puccini opera remained the most striking characteristic of the production.
Rodolfo's garret continued to pose a challenge for the singers, who had to project their voices from far back on the stage as well as engage in some uncomfortable swordplay on some uncomfortable swordplay on the rooftops of Paris.


'MOBY DICK' MEANINGS AND MISQUOTATIONS
LEAD: When Herman Melville, in ''Moby Dick,'' attributed the line ''I only am escaped alone to tell thee'' to Job, he was referring to the Book of Job, and not to the character.
Actually this line was uttered in the Bible by four separate messengers to Job.
There is quite a difference between having the victim cry that he has escaped alone and having a servant tell the victim of the latter's losses.

Whose Words Are They, Anyway?
LEAD: IN the past 20 years, J. D. Salinger has undoubtedly become the most famous - as well as the most read - recluse in the world.
He has rarely been sighted in public, has not given an interview since 1953 and, although he continues to write fiction, hasn't published any of it since a short story appeared in The New Yorker in 1965.

By Steve Heller. (Chelsea Green, Paper, $9.95.) ''On his sixty-fifth birthday Frank Kellerman locked himself inside an old stone schoolhouse filled with honey bees,'' begins Steve Heller's subtle first novel.
For the next seven days, Frank (or Lucky, as he was called before old age, diabetes, injury and loneliness took their toll), tells his life story to his only friends, the bees.

Winner Laments
LEAD: THERE is more than one way to win a driving championship, and Nelson Piquet of Brazil, who won his third Formula One title yesterday, was lamenting that he could not have found a better way to his.
Piquet, who came to the Grand Prix of Japan with 73 points, 12 more than his teammate and closest rival, Nigel Mansell of Britain, captured the title by default when Mansell, who could have taken the championship by winning the Japan and Australian races, was injured and forced to withdraw from the Japanese race.


Staging an Open House
LEAD: AN OPEN HOUSE IS NOT YOUR everyday kind of affair,'' said Roulhac Toledano, as she rushed around her family's 10-room apartment, trying to tie up loose ends before her 60 guests arrived. ''But it's good for lots of different people who may not know each other.'' She might have added that it is also good for hosts: Because people tend to arrive at different times, it's possible to entertain large numbers in the space of a day or an evening.

An Elegant, Low-Calorie Feast
LEAD: HOLIDAY FARE IS GENERALLY laden with richness - and calories.
With a microwave oven, however, you can create a low-calorie meal so festive and delicious that no one will miss the usual indulgences.
Because microwave cooking requires no fat, and allows vegetables and herbs to retain their flavor, and fruits their sweetness, you won't be tempted to add extra butter, salt or sugar.

THE ECONOMIC HISTORIANS' VIEW: Comparing the Collapses; Moses Abramovitz: No Panic Now
LEAD: EVERY serious depression in business, and virtually every recession in American economic history, has been accompanied by a serious decline of stock prices.
Not every serious decline of stock prices has led to a depression or even a recession.
Moreover, when the two came together, it cannot be said that the stock market collapse was the cause of the business contraction.

About Men; One Man's Kids
LEAD: I TEACH FIRST GRADERS.
I LIVE in a world of skinned knees, double-knotted shoelaces, riddles that I've heard a dozen times, stale birthday cakes, hurt feelings, wandering stories and one lost shoe (''and if you don't find it my mother'll kill me'').
My work is dominated by 6-year-olds.
It's 10:45, the middle of snack, and I'm helping Emily open her milk carton.

LEAD: SOMETIMES after the theater or movies, it is more fun to eat at home than in a restaurant.
The menu given below is perfect for a late-night meal, not too heavy and easy to prepare ahead of time.
It also makes a pleasant weekend lunch.
Ducks are roasted with thyme, ginger, garlic and soy sauce and served at room temperature with a salad made from yellow split peas and collard greens.

LEAD: WHEN my mother needed to escape from the noise and confusion generated by five children, she would go out and work in the yard.
She couldn't have picked a better refuge.
We children considered trimming, raking and mowing akin to torture.
We always offered to help, though, knowing full well that Mom would decline the offer.

LEAD: Mr.
LeMoyne discounts the possibility of the contra leaders' returning to Managua, saying, ''The fight for popular support inside Nicaragua promises to be extremely risky, testing the rebels where they have been weakest.'' In other words, the contras have little support inside Nicaragua.
Mr.
LeMoyne forgets that guerrillas with popular support inside their own country do survive on scant funds.

LEAD: Like most stocks, many mutual funds have taken a battering as the market tumbled.


DISSIDENT JUDGE SLAIN IN PANAMA
LEAD: A Supreme Court justice who frequently criticized human rights abuses under Panama's Government has been shot to death, relatives said today.


Prosecutors Say Tapes Show Mob Infiltrating Carpenter Union
LEAD: Secretly recorded conversations show how members of the Gambino organized-crime family infiltrated one of New York City's largest carpenters' unions, prosecutors say.


Hunt Tax Trial to Start Today
LEAD: The Internal Revenue Service is seeking more than $350 million in taxes from the Hunt family of Dallas in connection with write-offs the family claimed from its buying binge of silver futures in 1979-80.

One-Party Strength Likely to Continue in 3 States
LEAD: Voters in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut will select the officials who run their counties, towns and villages tomorrow in elections that will very likely confirm the one-party domination of most areas in the three states.


Midland Bank Closure
LEAD: Britain's Midland Bank P.L.C. is closing its off-shore banking unit in Bahrain in a move to rationalize its operations, a bank official said today.
The unit, which has operated in Bahrain for 11 years, is the bank's sole branch in the Middle East and has a staff of seven, according to Collin Pettit, the manager.


Rate of Violent Crime Reported on the Wane
LEAD: The rate of violent crime nationwide has declined substantially in recent years, according to a report made public today by the Justice Department.

LEAD: As they raced under the digital timers and across the blue finish line yesterday, the runners in the New York City Marathon stepped into a zone known as the chute.

LEAD: The building, with its circumscribed rink dimensions and intimate overhangs, is renowned for inducing claustrophobia in opposing teams.

They plainly had forgotten how to win.

LEAD: ALTHOUGH I enjoy a venison steak singed on the outside and red in the middle more than any other fare save rare wild duck, most of the deer meat I eat has been given to me.


Labor Talks Continue at Exchanges
LEAD: Officials of the New York Stock Exchange, trading companies and the New York Futures Exchange, who are facing a possible strike by most of their clerical workers, continued contract negotiations with union officials last night, a spokesman for the exchange said.


Chargers Triumph On Overtime Kick
LEAD: Vencie Glenn, a free safety, intercepted Bernie Kosar's first pass attempt in overtime today to set up a 33-yard field goal by Vince Abbott that gave the San Diego Chargers a 27-24 victory over the Cleveland Browns.

Plunge Unnerves Hong Kong
LEAD: Stock markets fell everywhere last month, but in Hong Kong the crash was the steepest, most palpable and perhaps most telling.
On Oct. 26 prices fell by one-third - among the worst session-to-session plunges of any stock market in history.

LEAD: The Financial Corporation of Santa Barbara said Friday that a Los Angeles couple had acquired a 9.9 percent interest in it, making them the company's largest shareholders.

Hebrew Union's Temple Gets a New-Style Ark
LEAD: Not much is traditional about the Minnie Petrie Synagogue of the Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion.

Results Plus
LEAD:  Tennis  Graf Tops Mandlikova: Top-seeded Steffi Graf of West Germany swept past second-seeded Hana Mandlikova, 6-2, 6-2, yesterday to win the $150,000 European Indoors women's tournament in Zurich.
Graf opened the match with a service ace and never looked back in winning the $27,000 first-place money.

Recital: Lynn Harrell, Cellist
LEAD: LYNN HARRELL'S evening of cello solos at the Metropolitan Museum on Saturday night had a sandwichlike symmetry to it - Bach suites at the beginning and end and in between, two 20th-century pieces.


New and Mighty Piano Makes Carnegie Debut
LEAD: Yesterday's Carnegie Hall concert of the Leningrad Philharmonic, conducted by Aleksandr Dmitriev, was completely traditional.
But not so the instrument upon which Lazar Berman played the Liszt Piano Concerto in A. It was a Fazioli F 308 concert grand, a 10-foot-2-inch monster with four pedals, a tripartite lid propped by three sticks and a fighting weight of 1,518 pounds.


Taiwan Trade Curbs Urged
LEAD: The House-Senate Joint Economic Committee today called on Taiwan to assess ways to cut its trade surplus to help end world trading imbalances that are threatening the global economy.


New York State's Curriculum on AIDS Criticized
LEAD: New York City's Health Commissioner criticized state education officials yesterday for approving an AIDS curriculum that does not advocate the use of condoms to slow transmission of the deadly virus.


TASS SENDS REPORT ON PARTY DISSENT, THEN CANCELS IT
LEAD: On Saturday evening Soviet newspapers received a report from the press agency Tass that Boris N. Yeltsin, head of the Moscow party organization and a nonvoting member of the Politburo, had threatened to resign at a recent party meeting.


Dance: Robert Banta
LEAD: THE tumult of Halloween Parade merriment raged outside on Saturday night.
But in the Nikolais-Louis Choreospace there was gentle humor under quiet contemplation of human foibles as Robert Banta set about establishing a charming little world of his own.

Stage: From Gershwin, 'Reaching for the Moon'
LEAD: THIS year's many theatrical commemorations of George Gershwin on the 50th anniversary of his death have already brought us the Brooklyn Academy of Music's concert productions of ''Let 'Em Eat Cake'' and ''Of Thee I Sing,'' the American concert premiere of the English musical ''Primrose'' at the Library of Congress and a spiffy revival of ''Lady, Be Good!


Sports of The Times; The Psyching Team to the Rescue
LEAD: SURE, he had trained hard for the New York City Marathon and was fit.
And, yes, he had figured out a strategy regarding time and he was confident.
But he had a serious problem.


Relationships; After A Child Is Molested
LEAD: THE plight of women whose mates have sexually abused their children is painful and poignant.
Rage, bewilderment and a sense of helplessness were palpable as six women in that situation gathered in Brooklyn to discuss their trauma and its aftermath.


A Folksy Dukakis Marches on South
LEAD: He verged on folksiness in Texas, where he stood on the steps of the Gregg County Courthouse and thanked the ''good Lord'' for clear skies.


Lives of a Backstage Dresser
LEAD: During his nearly 50 years in the theater, Harry Edwards has worked with Sir Noel Coward, Sir Laurence Olivier, Rex Harrison, Marlon Brando, Judy Holliday, Richard Burton, Barbra Streisand, Jim Dale and Jason Robards.
But he has never been on stage with them.


Hanna Nickel to be Sold
LEAD: The United Consolidated Companies of Fremont, Ohio, plans to buy the Hanna Nickel Smelting Company, reopen its smelter here and produce a steel-making agent instead of mining nickel.
United Consolidated has signed a contract with the M.A.
Hanna Company of Cleveland to buy Hanna Nickel's assets, most of which will be sold, Bill Niggemeyer, United's president, said last week.

Jury Awards Former Student $30,000 for Hazing Injuries
LEAD: A jury has awarded a former University of Delaware student $30,000 for burns he suffered when a caustic oven cleaner was poured over his head in a fraternity hazing rite in 1980.

LEAD: New York State voters will decide tomorrow whether to enact two amendments to the State Constitution, one dealing with ski trails and the other with civil service examinations.

Shot Into Apartment Kills Boy, 5
LEAD: A 5-year-old boy was killed yesterday when a friend of the child's mother, angry that he had been locked out of their apartment, shot a .45-caliber pistol into the apartment hitting the boy, the police said.

LEAD: The Federal Environmental Protection Agency has decided to burn all the dioxin-contaminated soil taken from sewers and creeks around the former chemical dump known as Love Canal.

Rise in Prices Flattens Out
LEAD: The sharp move to lower interest rates that coincided with the Oct. 19 break in stock prices seems to have lost some momentum in the past week as the enthusiasm that carried bond prices straight up last month is being leavened by the skepticism and caution of institutional investors.


British Sporting Art Fails to Sell at Auction
LEAD: The auction of 25 British sporting paintings in Sotheby's sale of 19th-century art last Thursday fared poorly; 18 of the works did not find buyers.
However, the most important paintings in the collection, which art dealers have said was owned by Nelson Bunker Hunt, brought higher prices than Sotheby's had expected.


European Officials Leave Exchange Rates Intact
LEAD: European officials decided this weekend not to realign their currencies, but several officials said a falling dollar might make re-evaluation necessary.

Rene Levesque, Separatist Leader And Quebec's Ex-Premier, Is Dead
LEAD: Rene Levesque, who led an often bitter and ultimately unsuccessful struggle to separate Quebec from Canada and who served as the province's Premier from 1976 to 1985, died at his home in Montreal today after a heart attack, a police spokesman there said.
He was 65 years old.


DENG STEPS DOWN AMID SIGNS POLICY WILL SURVIVE HIM
LEAD: Deng Xiaoping retired in triumph today from the Central Committee of China's Communist Party as part of a sweeping overhaul that seems to promise continuation of his policies for economic change.


Academic and Parental Pressure
LEAD: According to a Brandeis University researcher, a drug commonly used to control high blood pressure may also relieve the extreme anxiety that paralyzes some students when confronted with a test.
The finding could mean welcome relief for those few young people who are profoundly afflicted.
But it also raises a disturbing question about parental pressure to achieve.


A Break for Debtor Nations
LEAD: One unexpected result of tumult in the stock markets is the help it is giving developing countries in coping with the debt crises.

LEAD: Frank C. Carlucci, President Reagan's national security adviser, confirmed today that the Soviet-American treaty to eliminate medium- and short-range nuclear weapons is now all but completed.

BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 2, 1987
LEAD:  The Economy


Soviet Flight Of Armenians Heads for U.S.
LEAD: A flash flood of Soviet Armenians seeking to move to the United States has deluged the American Consulate here in the last six months, reaching new high levels as the month of October closed.


Dawkins's Wife Dies
LEAD: Police were investigating the death this morning of the estranged wife of Darryl Dawkins, the former New Jersey Nets player, authorities said.


6 Upstate Teen-Agers Die as Train Hits Their Car
LEAD: Six western New York teen-agers returning from a Halloween party died when a freight train slammed into their car as its driver apparently tried to beat the train past a crossing early today, the authorities said.


Fraud Charged in Sale Of Steel to Atom Plants
LEAD: Federal prosecutors have charged three companies and three executives with intentionally selling ordinary steel as nuclear quality, forcing its removal from some power plants.


Contraction Is Wall Street Theme As Industry Plans for Major Cuts
LEAD: Wall Street, shaken by the turmoil in the stock market, is slamming the brakes on what had been the greatest boom in American financial history.
After a decade of unprecedented growth, fueled by a huge flow of profits, a new word is working its way into the financial lexicon: contraction.


Egg-Throwing Results In a Death in Flushing
LEAD: A Queens teen-ager was arrested and charged yesterday with the fatal stabbing of a man who threw eggs at the youth's van on Halloween night, the police said.


Gibraltar Loss Of $155 Million Special to The New York Times
LEAD: The Gibraltar Financial Corporation said it had a third-quarter net loss of $154.6 million, after taking a $147.1 million write-down and adding $92 million to its loan loss reserves.
A year earlier, Gibraltar earned $13.3 million, or 69 cents a share.


Futures Shock, Misplaced
LEAD: What caused the Black Monday stock market crash on Oct. 19?
The search for reasons, and scapegoats, has turned to ''portfolio insurance,'' ''program trading'' and other computer-paced investment strategies linked to hybrid securities called stock index futures.


The Art of the Chinese Scholar
LEAD: A man sat at a desk and wrote down what he considered the essential conditions for a full and happy life:


An Iran Affair Is Emerging in France
LEAD: In an affair that echoes the furor over the Reagan Administration's secret arms sales to Iran, French Defense Ministry officials have charged that a Defense Minister in the former Socialist Government approved sales of 450,000 artillery shells to Iran in violation of French law.


The U.N. Today: Nov. 2, 1987
LEAD:  GENERAL ASSEMBLY

Girl, 3, Undergoes 4-Organ Transplant
LEAD: Surgeons completed the transplant of a liver, a pancreas and part of a stomach and intestine today into a 3-year-old girl who has never eaten solid food because of a defect in her digestive system.

LEAD: ''The leadership role that has been played by Comrade Deng Xiaoping has not been determined by his post.
Though he has left the Party Central Committee now, his prestige and wisdom will insure him a major role in the work of both the party and the state.''  - Zhu Muzhi, a spokesmanfor the party congress.

Ronald Reagan's Luck
LEAD: The President's famous faculty for coming up a winner seems to have deserted him.
His party lost the Senate last year, just as the Iran-contra story started trickling out.
He bet a pile on Robert Bork for the Supreme Court, and lost.
World stock markets crashed.
Waves of criticism surge in daily.
Just when a sound, inspiring leader is needed, he appears more out of touch than ever.

McGill 3d of Simsbury, Conn.

Nationwide's Mortgage Bid
LEAD: First Nationwide Bank, in a move to increase its reach to 24 states and double its mortgage business, said it plans to buy the mortgage subsidiary of the Imperial Corporation of America.
Terms were not disclosed.
First Nationwide said its acquisition of the ICA Mortage Corporation of San Diego would not affect its continuing interest in acquiring the Financial Corporation of America, the parent of American Savings, the nation's largest savings and loan association.


Ballet: Joffrey Performs 'La Fille Mal Gardee'

Recital: The Kavafians
LEAD: IDA and Ani Kavafian have an aggressive, deep-in-the-strings, excited way of playing their violins that is intended to please a crowd, but what they provide is a shallow, unrewarding pleasure and it quickly wears thin.
The sisters' dual recital Saturday evening at the 92d Street Y - at which Ida played both violin and viola - included lots of energetic, virtuosic bowing and emotionalism of an easy, general sort.


Police Checkpoint Use Is Upheld in California
LEAD: The California State Supreme Court has upheld the authority of the police to use checkpoints to detect drunken drivers.

Theodore R. Weiler
LEAD: Theodore R. Weiler, a founder and former president of the Boar's Head Provision Company of Brooklyn, a manufacturer of delicatessen products, died of coronary disease Thursday in White Plains Hospital.
He was 85 years old and lived in Larchmont, N.Y., Manhattan and Palm Beach, Fla.

British Sporting Art Fails to Sell at Auction
LEAD: The auction of 25 British sporting paintings in Sotheby's sale of 19th-century art last Thursday fared poorly; 18 of the works did not find buyers.
However, the most important paintings in the collection, which art dealers have said was owned by Nelson Bunker Hunt, brought higher prices than Sotheby's had expected.


Anthony S. Accurso
LEAD: Anthony Salvatore Accurso, an artist and illustrator best known for his courtroom sketches on television, died of a heart attack at the Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn on Oct. 23 shortly after returning from a news assignment in Florida.
He was 47 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

No Offer for Calmat
LEAD: - A group of companies led by Industrial Equity Ltd. said it had decided not to make a takeover bid for the Calmat Company.
Industrial Equity of Hong Kong already owns 19.1 percent of the common stock of the Los Angeles cement maker.
Industrial Equity said its decision is a result of the stock market's volatility and litigation brought by Calmat against the group.

LEAD: Tomorrow is Election Day, but closings vary.
Following are holiday schedules:  NEW YORK  Parking: Alternate-side parking rules suspended.
Sanitation: No collection or street cleaning.
Governmental offices: Federal offices open; state and municipal offices closed.
Post offices: Regular deliveries.

LEAD: The Maxwell Communication Corporation P.L.C. said it had agreed to acquire Alco-Gravure Industries, an American commercial printer, for an undisclosed amount of cash.
Maxwell Communication, which recently changed its name from the British Printing and Communication Corporation P.L.C., said the acquisition was being executed by its American subsidiary, the Maxwell Communication Corporation.

The U.N. Today; Nov. 3, 1987
LEAD:  GENERAL ASSEMBLY


Greyhound Begins Rural Bus Service
LEAD: Greyhound Lines Inc. began a pilot program for rural bus service in Tennessee that is expected to spread nationwide and revive the flagging public transportation industry, its officials said.
The project links vans from eight rural transportation agencies statewide with Greyhound buses in larger cities, similar to the hub system used by airlines.

19 Children of Muslim Leader Battle a Bank for $5.7 Million
LEAD: Nineteen children of Elijah Muhammad, the late Black Muslim leader, have squared off against the world's largest bank in a legal dispute with a $5.7 million bank account at stake.


Suspect Indicted in Slaying Of Woman With a Crossbow
LEAD: A Brooklyn grand jury yesterday indicted a 21-year-old Staten Island man in the crossbow slaying of a woman last month.


Philharmonic Ensemble At Merkin Concert Hall
LEAD: The most affecting piece on the program by the New York Philharmonic Ensembles on Sunday afternoon at Merkin Concert Hall came just before intermission with C. G. Rex's four unpublished songs for soprano, string quartet and piano.
Based on poems about love and death by A. E. Housman, they date from 1945 and reflect in their touching sentimentality the spirit of a society emerging from war.


Market Place; Trading Range Seen for Dow
LEAD: AS might be expected after the market's October massacre, estimates in the investment community vary widely as to where the Dow Jones industrial average might be headed.


Takeover Activity Resuming; SINGER GETS HOSTILE OFFER
LEAD: Paul A. Bilzerian, a Florida investor with a history of unsuccessful takeover bids, offered $50 a share yesterday for the Singer Company.
Analysts and some arbitragers said they believed that Mr.
Bilzerian's aim was to elicit a higher bid, enabling him to make a big profit on the 9.99 percent he already owns.


Jackson Is Pleased
LEAD: ''It's still there,'' Bo Jackson said of the speed, quickness and power that won him the Heisman Trophy as college football's best player in 1985.
His comment came after he had played his first football game since the 1985 season, for the Los Angeles Raiders in their loss on Sunday against the New England

Texas City Journal; Where a Chemical Leak Seems an Accepted Risk
LEAD: Morris Galloway came home today to find his beloved grapevines an eerie dead thicket, turned from green to brown by the hydrofluoric acid leak that caused the evacuation of 3,000 residents from their homes last weekend.


After Delays, Sessions Becomes Chief of F.B.I.
LEAD: After two postponements due to a stomach ulcer, William S. Sessions was sworn in today as the new Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
He succeeds William H. Webster, who left the post to become Director of Central Intelligence.


Accounts
LEAD: * Victory Optical, Newark, to Franznick &amp; Cusatis.


Abominable Snowman Wins Another Believer
LEAD: MOST of the unicorns, griffins, sea serpents and other fabulous creatures that once tinged the everyday world with romantic mystery have succumbed to the withering touch of rational inquiry.
But the Himalayan yeti (and his American cousins, sasquatch and bigfoot) die hard, and an English physicist is offering skeptics what he considers to be fresh evidence that abominable snowmen may, in fact, exist.


Driver Takes the Stand In Howard Beach Trial
LEAD: Dominic Blum, the driver of the car that struck and killed Michael Griffith last December in Howard Beach, Queens, testified yesterday that he heard a ''big bang'' and that his windshield shattered at the moment of impact.
But he said he left the scene because he did not know what he had hit.


G.M. Holding Engine Talks
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation said it was nearing a decision on whether to combine its diesel engine operations with another manufacturer. ''I would have hoped to have it done a month ago,'' said Ludvik F. Koci, the general manMger of G.M.'s Detroit Diesel Allison division.
Mr.
Koci said the company had been talking with parties, which he would not name, since a venture with Deere &amp; Company fell through in March.

The authorities said the driver apparently tried to beat the train to a crossing.

Corrections
LEAD: An article on the Washington Talk page on Oct. 22 about the opening of the Bahai lobby misstated the office's plans and the status of Bahais in Morocco.
The office has no plans for public demonstrations.
There have been no arrests of Bahais in Morocco since 1983.

Corrections
LEAD: A Denver dispatch on Saturday about the trial of four members of a white supremacist organization in connection with the killing of the host of a radio talk show, incorrectly described a contention in the case.
It is lawyers for the defense, not the prosecution, who say the victim, Alan Berg, was murdered by another white supremacist, who died in a shootout in 1984.

The concert was given by the Leningrad State Symphony of the U.S.S.R., at Avery Fisher Hall.

City Opera: 'Zauberflote'
LEAD: THE New York City Opera's current production of ''Die Zauberflote'' remained a pleasure from beginning to end despite the uneven cast that occupied the stage at the New York State Theater Sunday evening.
Here was a case of the total being greater than the sum of its parts: most of the singers were replacements for last summer's opening night ensemble and though a couple of principal roles fell to unsteady voices, the cheerful good spirits of the entire affair managed to carry the day.


Volcanoes and Ships
LEAD: ON Oct. 11, an undersea volcano erupted directly under the research ship Melville, making the ship tremble and resound as giant bubbles of volcanic gas burst against its hull.
Oceanographers, including those at the Scripps Institution of Oceanography in San Diego, which operates the ship, were unable to recall any other such occurrence.

Election Day
LEAD:  NEW YORK  Polls: Open 6 A.M. to 9 P.M.
Parking: Alternate-side parking rules suspended.
Sanitation: No collection or street cleaning.
Governmental offices: Federal offices open; state and municipal offices closed.
Post offices: Regular deliveries.
Banks: Option to close.
Financial markets: Open.

Pace Halts Trading
LEAD: Pace Securities Inc., a small brokerage, has temporarily ceased doing business because of financial difficulties, but the firm said that it expected to be back in operation soon.
The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday morning that Pace had shut down, but Pace officials said later that they had brought in more capital to meet the Big Board's net capital requirements.

Boxer's Widow Wins 7-Year-Old Legal Fight
LEAD: A lawsuit filed by the widow of Willie Classen - a boxer who died of head injuries after a fight at Madison Square Garden in November 1979 - was settled out of court yesterday for a ''substantial six-figure'' sum, according to attorneys and court officials involved in the case.

Savannah Electric
LEAD: The Southern Company said that its board had agreed to buy the Savannah Electric and Power Company for stock in a deal valued at more than $230 million.
Southern said that 1.05 shares of Southern common would be exchanged for each of Savannah Electric's 10.6 million shares.
The deal must be approved by the Securities and Exchange Commission and the shareholders of Savannah Electric.

A Guide to the National Horse Show
LEAD:  The 104th National Horse Show runs today through Sunday at Madison Square Garden, with competition in several categories and three types of exhibition performances.
There are sessions at 9 A.M. (except Friday), 1:30 P.M. (1 P.M. Thursday) and 7:30 P.M. daily, but the most interesting events for the non-specialist are in the afternoon and evening sessions.

LEAD: The Office of Government Ethics said today that it would open an inquiry into the conduct of Judge Douglas H. Ginsburg, President Reagan's nominee for the Supreme Court, in handling a major case for the Justice Department bearing on the cable-television industry while he held stock in a cable company.

Sports People; Price Files
LEAD: San Francisco's Joe Price, the winning pitcher in Game 5 of the National League playoff, and three other players filed for free agency yesterday.

Japanese Chip Dumping Has Ended, U.S. Finds
LEAD: The Commerce Department said yesterday that Japan had ceased dumping computer chips, a finding that Administration officials predicted would allow President Reagan to lift by the end of the week many of the sanctions that he imposed on Japanese electronic goods in April.

Stage: Kafka's 'Trial,' By Cocteau Repertory
LEAD: JOSEPH K. sleeps on a narrow plank, the size of a coffin, between two high walls; he works in an equally confined space.
Even before a couple of pseudosinister types come to arrest him, he is a prisoner in a deeply shadowed world.
That is basic to the Jean Cocteau Repertory's intelligent new production of ''The Trial,'' Franz Kafka's novel, dramatized by Andre Gide and Jean-Louis Barrault.


Texaco Loses in Texas High Court
LEAD: The Texas Supreme Court today rejected a request by Texaco Inc. for a hearing to overturn the Pennzoil Company's landmark $10.3 billion award against Texaco.

U.S. Frigate Fires on Boat Moving Near Gulf Tanker
LEAD: A United States Navy frigate opened fire Sunday night on a suspected Iranian patrol boat that was speeding toward an American tanker, American military officials announced today.


Duro-Test Offer
LEAD: The Duro-Test Corporation said its board rejected as inadequate a $13 a share offer from William P. Lyons, a Yale University professor, and the TCA-IV Limited Partnership.
The company also said it had filed suit in Federal District Court in Newark against Professor Lyons and TCA-IV, seeking the enforcement of Securities and Exchange Commission disclosure requirements and of Federal Reserve Board margin requirements regarding the investors' purchase of Duro-Test shares.





Aide to Nicaragua Defense Chief Is Reported to Defect to the U.S.
LEAD: A senior Sandinista military officer apparently defected to the United States last week, diplomats and politicians said today.


Rise in U.S. Drilling Rigs
LEAD: The number of oil and gas drilling rigs working in the United States last week rose by one, to a total of 1,131, Baker Hughes, the Houston-based oil tool maker, said today.
The rig count was down by four the previous week, the company added.
A year ago, the count totaled 860.
The count reflects the number of rigs working as of last Friday.

TV Review; Story of Panama Canal
LEAD: THE title, ''A Man, A Plan, A Canal, Panama,'' is a famous palindrome, reading the same way front and back.
That's clever, and the documentary itself is even better.
The ''Nova'' presentation, on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock tonight, uses scope and imagination to tell a compelling story: the Panama Canal is infinitely more than a ditch.

Don't Let the Amnesty Door Slam
LEAD: Congress passed the Immigration Reform and Control Act last year to make it harder for new illegal aliens to stay in this country - and easier for old ones.
The act provided amnesty for aliens who had been here since at least 1982.
But they were given only 12 months to apply, and even that time has been constricted.

LEAD: AGRICULTURAL engineers at Cornell University have devised a new system for treating sewage that can produce reservoir-quality water at little or no cost, according to researchers here.


Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Q. What happens to the bullet when a warning gunshot is fired in the air?
Could the bullet kill or injure someone on its way back to earth?
A.
Theoretically, if you fired a shot straight up, the bullet would fall right back down on you, according to Officer Frank S. DiMario, master firearms instructor at the New York City Police Academy.


Yankees Acquire Rangers' Slaught
LEAD: Last winter, the Yankees passed up a chance to sign Rich Gedman as a free agent, explaining that Joel Skinner was their catcher of the future.
Skinner proceeded to hit an anemic .137 and needed a refresher course in the minors during the season.

LEAD: Nelson Bunker Hunt and Caroline Hunt went to Tax Court today in a dispute with the Internal Revenue Service, which is seeking $358 million in back taxes and penalties related to the crash of the silver market in 1980.

Has Marathon Reached Peak?
LEAD: From his vantage point in a fire-engine-red convertible, Fred Lebow could see nothing but success.
For those who subscribe to his theory that more is better in the New York City Marathon, Sunday's race was indeed the most successful of the 12 that have been run through the five boroughs.

Days Inn Sale
LEAD: The Days Inn Corporation said that its principal stockholder, the Reliance Capital Group L.P., might periodically buy up to one million Days Inn common shares in the open market or in privately negotiated purchases.
The company also said it had agreements to sell 10 hotel and motel properties to two investor groups for about $97 million.


Average Raise Under 5%
LEAD: The average salaried worker received a raise of 4.8 percent this year and can expect an increase of 4.9 percent in 1988, according to a survey of more than 1,200 American companies released today.
This is the first year since the early 1970's that salary increases have been below 5 percent, said Bill James, chief compensation consultant for Hewitt Associates of suburban Lincolnshire, which issued the report.


Worries About Intimacy Are Rising, Therapists Find
LEAD: INTIMACY, that combination of self-disclosure and emotional closeness, is carrying more of a premium than ever.
Since the 1950's, surveys show, more and more people have come to see intimacy - in friendship, at work and at home - as increasingly important to their sense of satisfaction with life.

High Finance
LEAD: Following are 1987 baseball incomes for players who were on major league rosters or on the disabled list Aug. 31.
Figures, obtained from management and player sources, include base salary, pro-rated share of signing bonus, other guaranteed money and bonuses earned during the season but not bonuses for post-season awards still to be announced.


Bill Rates Advance Sharply
LEAD: Treasury bill rates rose sharply yesterday as fears of a financial crisis diminished enough for some investors to sacrifice the safety of Treasury bills for the higher yields available on other securities.


Seoul Journal; A Whiff of Fall, Not Tear Gas, in the Campus Air
LEAD: It is quiet for a change at Yonsei University.


Pro Basketball Notebook; Richardson Question Looms
LEAD: In less than four months, the National Basketball Association and its players' union will be confronted with a problem they would rather avoid.
And that problem will have nothing to do with discussions on a new collective-bargaining agreement.

He was 68 years old and lived in Charlotte.

LEAD: Negotiations between Congress and the Reagan Administration to reduce the deficit ran into problems today as Democrats charged that the White House was being inflexible and Republicans worried about achieving significant spending reductions.

Paine Webber Gives Up Unit
LEAD: Paine Webber Inc. is handing over its profit-starved commercial paper business to Citicorp, the two financial service companies announced yesterday.


Factory Orders Posted 1.1% Gain for September
LEAD: Orders to factories for manufactured goods jumped 1.1 percent in September, rebounding after an August setback, the Government said today.


Arbitrager Had Loss of $100 Million
LEAD: Comdisco Equities is one of the biggest arbitrage houses in the country, and Martin A. Weinstein, its head, is truly a big spender, quick to buy 300,000 shares or more of a takeover stock at a clip.
In the volatile market days of the last two weeks, Mr.
Weinstein and Comdisco lost $100 million, or half the firm's capital, then quickly made back $20 million.


Gary Cummings Dead; Former CBS Executive
LEAD: Gary Cummings, a former vice president and general manager of CBS's Chicago television affiliate WBBM and an Emmy award-winning broadcaster, died of complications resulting from melanoma, a type of skin cancer, on Saturday at the University of Illinois Hospital in Chicago.
He was 46 years old.


New Ads From Nynex
LEAD: In a couple of weeks Nynex, the telecommunications and information systems company, will start running a fanciful set of three 30-second commercials from Young &amp; Rubicam that should leave a residue of awe in the viewer's mind.
That's a handy ploy when a company is out to impress senior and middle managers at potential corporate customers coast to coast.


Quest for Slice of Comet
LEAD: IN an important engineering milestone toward sending an unmanned spacecraft to explore a comet, a prototype of an instrument-bearing projectile designed to take a bite out of an icy comet nucleus has been tested successfully at the Sandia National Laboratory in New Mexico.

Gorbachev Presses as Far as He Can
LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's stated vision of a more open and democratic Soviet Union has emerged from two tests in recent days somewhat battered by the realities of the Communist system.
The two tests - Mr.
Gorbachev's review of Soviet history Monday and the handling earlier of Boris N. Yeltsin's threat to resign as head of the Moscow party organization - have demonstrated the limits of openness and served as a reminder of how different Mr.


The Stage: 'Sing Hallelujah!,' a Gospel Musical
LEAD: GOSPEL, like every other popular style of vernacular music, reflects the whims of pop style and the evolution of pop technology.
What gives the music its special classic quality is its unchanging subject matter: praising the Lord.
While today's evangelical Christian music movement has begun to produce gospel songs that address contemporary social problems, the essence of the gospel message - jubilant spiritual and physical exaltation - hasn't changed over half a century.

LEAD: PEOPLE magazine, which averaged 3.3 million in weekly sales in the third quarter, will begin a trade campaign on Monday with the theme ''Nothing grabs people like People.''


HEIRESS SEEKS HOLDINGS OF CHURCH SHE SUED
LEAD: A chain store heiress who is trying to get $6.6 million back from a fundamentalist church offered $1.8 million today for the church headquarters.
The property, appraised at $6 million, was abandoned after a Federal Bankruptcy Court held that undue influence had been exerted to get her to donate the money to the church.


Art Bidders at Christie's Wary, but Not Scared
LEAD: Two Francis Bacon paintings brought the highest prices in Christie's contemporary art auction last night.
Overall, the auction showed the market for postwar art was reacting with tremors - not shock waves - to the turbulence that has characterized the stock market since the collapse on Oct. 19.

LEAD: A foundation headed by former President Jimmy Carter and the Houston philanthropist Dominique de Menil announced today that the annual $100,000 Carter-Menil human-rights prize would go to La Vicaria, a Roman Catholic group that aids political prisoners, torture victims and their families in Chile.

LEAD: The Supreme Court heard arguments today on the emotionally charged issue of how far states may restrict minors' access to abortions so as to promote consultation with their parents.


Officials Said to Ignore Pleas for Abused Girl
LEAD: Neighbors and co-workers of a Manhattan couple charged with attempted murder in the beating of their 6-year-old daughter say that repeated calls were made to the police and a child-abuse hot line over many years.
But to their knowledge, they said, nothing was done to separate the couple or to protect the children.

LEAD: Tokyo stock prices dropped 1.3 percent today after the sharp decline on Wall Street on Tuesday.
Dealers said large securities firms had stepped in with buy orders to stabilize the market.

Market Place; Plunge Derails New Offerings
LEAD: THE October plunge in stock prices has brought the new-issue market to a virtual standstill.
Few deals have reached the public.
And prices are off sharply for corporations that had made initial offerings just before the market collapse.

Cambridge Journal; After the Vote is Cast, Where Does It Land?
LEAD: By the time the votes from Tuesday's City Council and School Committee elections are counted, many voters may have long since lost track of which candidates they voted for.
For Cambridge, a city known for the intellectual giants of Harvard University and Massachusetts Institute of Technology, uses a controversial voting system that challenges even the strongest intellect.


Sports People; Chin Quits Amateurs
LEAD: Tiffany Chin, who in 1985 won the United States women's figure skating championship and finished third in the world competition, has retired from amateur competition and signed a two-year contract worth more than $1 million with Holiday on Ice, according to a report yesterday in The Los Angeles Times.

LEAD: The Government announced today the detention without trial of another member of the opposition Democratic Action Party.


NEW MAXWELL DEAL
LEAD: The Maxwell Communication Corporation said it had agreed to buy a 70 percent stake in Nimbus Records Ltd., a privately owned company, for $:24 million, or about $42 million.
The deal marks the British printing and publishing group's third acquisition this week.
Maxwell on Monday announced the purchase of United Trade Press Holdings Ltd.


Film: 'Broken Noses,' From Bruce Weber
LEAD: BRUCE WEBER, known for his photographs of athletic looking fellows posed sexily in underwear advertisements, demonstrates in ''Broken Noses'' that shorts do not make the man.


Brazil and Banks Near Agreement on Interest
LEAD: Brazil and its creditors appeared close to agreement last night on a plan for the country to resume interest payments on its $100 billion foreign debt nearly nine months after the Government suspended them.

Hart and herself.

Sippican to Be Sold
LEAD: The Plessey Company said it planned to acquire Sippican Inc., a maker of oceanographic products based in Marion, Mass., for about $80 million.
Plessey, an electronics company based in Ilford, near London, described Sippican as a leader in the construction of antisubmarine equipment.
It said it had agreed to pay $18.50 for each Sippican share.

LEAD: How do you demonstrate to investment bankers a new drug delivery system that uses a patch on the skin to slowly release nitroglycerine to patients with heart disease or antibiotics to a wound?

Devils No Match For the Islanders
LEAD: After slightly more than four years in the National Hockey League, Pat Flatley of the Islanders says he believes he has learned at least one lesson.
Whatever you do, never take the game home with you.
It's an admirable maxim, but it gets a little difficult to employ when you've got nowhere else to take it.

LEAD: Five members of the Warsaw Ballet Company will seek asylum in Canada after defecting during a North American tour, it was reported today.

LEAD: A Federal grand jury in Asheville, N.C., indicted two Japanese businessmen and two Hungarian diplomats today, charging them with diverting an American-made laser system used in making semiconductors to Hungary in violation of United States export control laws.

Challenges for Jordan: New League Rule and New Role
LEAD: Through the years, rule changes in basketball have often been made with a particular player in mind.
George Mikan's dominating center play was responsible for widening the lane from 8 to 12 feet.
When Wilt Chamberlain was piling up points, the lane was widened again, this time to its present 16 feet.

LEAD: *
Alco Standard Corp., Valley Forge, Pa., said it had sold two of its gift and glassware companies for an undisclosed amount of cash.

How We Got Into This Economic Gridlock; In Defense of Deficit
LEAD: To the Editor:


The U.N. Today; Nov. 4, 1987
LEAD:  GENERAL ASSEMBLY


McGwire Gets Rookie Award
LEAD: Mark McGwire, the Oakland first baseman whose 49 home runs set a major-league record for a first-year player, was unanimously selected as the American League rookie of the year yesterday by the Baseball Writers Association of America.


MacGregor Avoids Bankruptcy Action
LEAD: MacGregor Sporting Goods Inc. said a Federal Bankruptcy Court had ordered the dismissal of an involuntary bankruptcy motion filed against the company by three unsecured creditors.
The company said that, in connection with the dismissal, it had agreed to pay 20 percent of the debt owed to unsecured creditors on invoices that were past due as of Oct.


Nathan's to Open 23 New Outlets
LEAD: Nathan's Famous Inc. and two New York restaurateurs, Irving and Murray Riese, said they had signed an agreement to open 23 franchised Nathan's fast-food restaurants in Manhattan in the next five years.
The new units would more than double the number of Nathan's restaurants.


3 Fannie Mae Offerings Yielding 8.40% to 9.57%
LEAD: The Federal National Mortgage Association yesterday announced yields for three issues of debentures totaling $2.3 billion.
As expected, the yields on the quasi-government agency's debt were higher than for Treasury issues of similar maturity.


Soviet Seeks to Enhance U.N. Peacekeeping Role
LEAD: The Soviet Union is pressing the General Assembly to help it draw up ''a new comprehensive system of international security'' that would give the United Nations an enhanced role in preserving peace, according to diplomats here.


Ousted Merrill Trader Hired
LEAD: Bear, Stearns &amp; Company said yesterday that it had hired Howard A. Rubin, the mortgage securities trader who was dismissed by Merrill Lynch &amp; Company earlier this year after Merrill experienced a $377 million trading loss.


Sports People; Smith Suspends Reid
LEAD: Dean Smith, coach of the University of North Carolina basketball team, has suspended two players, J. R. Reid, center, and Steve Bucknall, forward, from its season-opening game against Syracuse after the players' arrests on assault charges.


How to Protect the Global Economy
LEAD: The task of governments now is to protect the ''real'' economy - production, income and employment - from the downward pressure exerted on private spending by the shocking loss of recently acquired financial wealth (about one trillion dollars in the United States alone, $14,000 per family).
That small reductions in wealth have typically caused only very small reductions in spending offers no ground for complacency.


A Suicide Dilemma
LEAD: To the Editor:


New Wave Ballet Delayed
LEAD: The first performance of ''Elena's Aria'' by Anne Teresa de Keersmaeker, an experimental Belgian choreographer, in the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Next Wave Festival was canceled last night.
The New York premiere of the work was rescheduled for 8 o'clock tonight.


Man Held in Threat On Cabinet Member
LEAD: An unemployed chemist the police say was armed with three guns and at least 600 bullets was arrested today after a report that he had told his mother that he was going to kill Secretary of State George P. Shultz, the authorities said.


3 Top U.P.I. Editors Quit, Citing Doubts On Assuring Quality
LEAD: The three top editors at United Press International resigned today after less than a year at the news service, praising its staff but saying they could no longer assure the quality of its report.


Vast Changes in Environment Seen
LEAD: Changes in the environment brought about by human activity are now occurring globally or over broad regions at a speed that may exceed the ability of people and their institutions to respond, according to and social scientists who attended a meeting last week.

LEAD: THE painters.

East Bloc Seems Divided on Speech
LEAD: One day after Mikhail S. Gorbachev's Kremlin speech on the Bolshevik Revolution, Moscow's closest Eastern European allies appeared to be applying a selective approach to its message, depending on whether their own policies reflected or clashed with Mr.
Gorbachev's campaign for political and economic change.


Voters Approve $68 Million Jail For Westchester
LEAD: Westchester County voters tonight approved a $68 million bond issue to build a 530-bed jail intended to relieve overcrowding at the county's correctional complex at Valhalla.


MICROWAVE COOKING
LEAD: ONE of the most endearing qualities of the microwave oven is its ability to make risotto perfectly with a minimum of stirring.
I have friends who have bought an oven just because they tasted my risotto.
Although I love this traditional dish of Italian arborio rice slowly cooked to creamy succulence, it had almost dropped out of my repertory because I didn't like the fussiness involved in standing and stirring for 40 minutes as


Reagan Names Ex-Government Aide to Labor Post
LEAD: President Reagan today named Ann Dore McLaughlin, a veteran of many Government public relations posts, to the job of Secretary of Labor.


Corrections
LEAD: A Boston dispatch yesterday, about the dean of the College of Communciation at Boston University, misstated Osborn Elliott's affiliation with the Columbia University School of Journalism.
He is its former dean and remains a professor there, on sabbatical.


Growing Up to Be Queen of the Rodeo
LEAD: Sawdust flies when Joni James gallops into an arena.
Wearing a cowboy hat and fitted western shirt and pants, she has smiled through years of interviews and modeling sessions.


Star Role for Hollywood Offices
LEAD: Dawn Steel, the new president of Columbia Pictures, does not have David Puttnam's job, but she will probably use the former Columbia chairman's office.
And when Ms.
Steel moves onto the studio lot, she will undoubtedly put Mr.
Puttnam's Biedermeier burlwood sofa into mothballs and remodel his recently remodeled suite.


Quebecers Pay Their Respects to Levesque
LEAD: A mourner passing the open coffin of Rene Levesque yesterday in Montreal.
A state funeral for the former Premier and separatist leader, who died Sunday, is to be held tomorrow in Quebec City. (Reuters)


Younger Chefs Add Fitness to the Menu
LEAD: GARY FUMICELLO was cheered to victory as he ran in an event here in 1986, holding a pan of eggs in one hand and waving aloft his other hand, which was swathed in bandages after an encounter with a kitchen knife.
The injury was work related.
Mr.
Fumicello is a student at the New England Culinary Institute.


Shutdown of Nuclear Plant Is Rejected by Maine Voters
LEAD: The beleaguered nuclear power industry won a victory in Maine yesterday, where voters rejected an effort to shut down the state's only nuclear power plant.


Scholars Say Gorbachev Fell Short on Objectivity
LEAD: The speech Monday by Mikhail S. Gorbachev on the 70th anniversary of the Russian Revolution provoked sharply differing interpretations among historians and political scientists who specialize on the Soviet Union.


Clash of Police And Fire Dept. Brings Warning
LEAD: First Deputy Mayor Stanley Brezenoff, warning that continued clashes between New York City police officers and firefighters ''could be a prescription for disaster,'' summoned the heads of both agencies to City Hall yesterday to ease the tension.


G.M.'s Progress On Job Reductions
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation said it had eliminated 12,000 American salaried jobs in the first nine months of 1987, putting it well ahead of schedule in its plans to eliminate 40,000 jobs by the end of next year.
The company, which said the job cuts would save it $2 billion a year, said it expects to reduce salaried employment by another 7,200 in the final three months of the year.


The Reactions To Gorbachev
LEAD: A day after Mikhail S. Gorbachev's speech on the Bolshevik Revolution, American scholars drew sharply differing lessons about its meaning.


Recital: Jean Deis, Tenor
LEAD: JEAN DEIS, a tenor and professor of voice at Indiana University, gave a recital at Merkin Concert Hall Monday evening that marked his return to performing after a protracted struggle with cancer.
When Mr.
Deis was first reviewed in these pages 31 years ago, he was praised for ''wonderfully assured upper tones,'' and he has them still.


Zulu Chief Defends His Role In New South African Panel
LEAD: The paramount chief of six million Zulus in South Africa, Gatsha Buthelezi, today defended his participation in the South African Government's experiment in interracial administration here.


Music: St. Paul Orchestra
LEAD: GOOD ideas never die, but they do change faces.
The two most fertile instrumental groupings to develop out of the Classical period, the symphony orchestra and the string quartet, each spawned its own rich literature.
Inevitably, the thought occurred to composers to unite the ensembles in one piece.


G.E. Discloses Irregularities
LEAD: The General Electric Company said today that it had notified the Pentagon of accounting irregularities in contracts involving nuclear missiles.


Pepsico Agrees To Buy Calny
LEAD: Pepsico Inc. has agreed to buy Calny Inc., the operator of 142 Taco Bell restaurants on the West Coast, for about $36.2 million, Calny said.
Under the agreement, Pepsico would pay $11 for each of Calny's 4.8 million shares outstanding, valuing the company at $52.8 million.
Calny said the Taco Bell Corporation, a subsidiary of Pepsico, already owns 31.5 percent of its common stock.


THE TIGER ROARS
LEAD: Mr.
Carlucci, is a graduate of Princeton University, an institution with the motto: ''Princeton in the Nation's Service.'' Whether you believe in conspiracy theories or are just keeping score, Mr.
Carlucci as Defense Secretary would put Princeton graduates in the nation's top three economic and national security posts.


Assault on the Ice
LEAD: In hockey they call it a cross-check, but if Dave Brown had done what he did to Tomas Sandstrom anywhere except on the ice, it would be called assault.
Mr.
Brown has been given a 15-game suspension without pay, while his team, the Philadelphia Flyers, may sign another player to replace him.
Both player and team got off too lightly.


Reagan Plans Sanctions End
LEAD: President Reagan is likely to soon lift some of the trade sanctions imposed on Japan seven months ago during a dispute over Japanese dumping of computer chips, the Administration said today.
The White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said $84 million of sanctions would be lifted ''probably this week,'' leaving $165 million in sanctions.


Dollar Up After Fall To Lows
LEAD: The dollar rallied on world currency markets yesterday after traders pushed it to new lows against the West German mark and the Japanese yen.

LEAD: Although the White House has yet to announce it, official Washington is sure Mr.
Weinberger will step down and Frank C. Carlucci, the national security adviser, will take his place.
Like many others in the drama, Mr.
Carlucci is holding his cards close to the vest.

LEAD: United States officials said today that they were intensively questioning a Nicaraguan military defector to determine his value to them.

Professors Study the Plunge
LEAD: On Monday, Oct. 19, when most of the investing world saw disaster, two professors of finance at Cornell University saw opportunity - the chance to test out fundamental market analysis theories in a free-falling stock market.

LEAD: The New York Public Library has opened the Robert Moses archive, containing 160 linear feet of papers and photographs dating from 1912.

Sports People; Canucks' Fine Reduced
LEAD: The British Columbia Supreme Court has reduced by $300,000 the fine that the Vancouver Canucks were assessed by John Ziegler, president of the National Hockey League, over the signing of Pat Quinn as general manager.
The Canucks were fined $310,000 and Quinn was suspended on Jan. 9 from coaching in the league until 1990.

Stage: Goethe's 'Stella' In New Directors Project
LEAD: ''STELLA'' begins in a cloud of mystery.
A wife, long ago abandoned by her husband, arrives with their daughter in a small town where the daughter is about to begin working as a servant to a baroness.
The baroness (the title character) lives alone in a mansion.
She, too, has been abandoned - in her case, by her lover.


Schwab Gets Loan Waiver
LEAD: The Charles Schwab Corporation said today that it had been forced to obtain a waiver of a provision of its bank loan agreement because the stock market downturn had put it in danger of violating the minimum-capital requirement.

LEAD: CLEARLY, Daniel Mann, the director of ''The Man Who Broke 1,000 Chains,'' had a strong contract.
Nestled in the opening credits, right between the names of the stars, is the following statement: ''After director completed director's cut, final version was supervised by production company.'' In short, there was trouble in the editing room and this may account for some of the film's nagging shortcomings.
