Cans, a Man, a Plan: New Redemption Center Struggles
LEAD: Guy Polhemus had an idea of how to help the poor that was almost too good.
It is helping them, but for a period it nearly left him bankrupt.


PENTAGON'S STYLE LIKELY TO CHANGE AFTER WEINBERGER
LEAD: The resignation of Caspar W. Weinberger as Secretary of Defense, which is expected to be announced later this week, seems likely to change the chemistry of policy making during the final 14 months of President Reagan's term.


Caps Continue Mastery of Canucks
LEAD: Bob Gould scored his first goal of the season with 2 minutes 53 seconds left in the third period tonight, giving the Washington Capitals a 3-2 victory over the Vancouver Canucks.

Deaver Jury Hears Why He Was Hired
LEAD: Tobacco industry witnesses at the perjury trial of Michael K. Deaver said today that their key reason for paying $250,000 to obtain Mr.
Deaver's ''political influence'' was to counter the formidable lobbying talents of another former Reagan Administration official.

Reagan Plan For Banks
LEAD: The Reagan Administration has decided against pushing for new real estate and insurance powers for banks, focusing instead on persuading Congress to grant banks permission to underwrite securities, a top Treasury Department official said today.


The Abuse of History
LEAD: An American lawyer in Moscow in 1965 asked his Intourist guide-guards the way to the men's room, slipped out the back of a restaurant and took a taxi to an address he had been given by a Canadian newsman.
The politically defunct lawyer was seeking a rendezvous with a former Soviet leader he had spoken with in a kitchen six years before.

Beber, Silverstein Gets Humana Promotion Job
LEAD: Humana Inc. of Louisville, Ky., a major company in the health-care field, is giving all of its hospital promotion business to Beber, Silverstein in Miami, which already works for it.


Kerkorian Gain Seen On Pan Am
LEAD: Four of the principal unions at Pan American World Airways have decided to support Kirk Kerkorian, the West Coast investor, in his effort to take over Pan American World Airways, union sources said yesterday.

Citicorp Rates Down Again
LEAD: Interest rates declined at Citicorp's regular weekly commercial paper auction yesterday.
It was the third consecutive week of declines, totaling more than a percentage point in that period.


Adopt-a-Monument Program Takes In 13 Statues in New York City
LEAD: Thirteen monuments that New York City put up for private adoption last spring have found benefactors, but six orphans remain - on Staten Island, in the Bronx and Queens, and in the heart of Manhattan.


Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''If all internal party matters are discussed by one and all, then there will be no sense in having a party.
This, I think, is understood.''  - Aleksandr N. Yakovlev, a member of the Soviet Politburo.  [ A12:5. ]


Economic Scene; Rescuing The Dollar
LEAD: THE stock market had a worrisome day yesterday, and analysts rounded up the usual suspects: Some feared that the dollar might plummet if the central banks were unwilling to support it.
Others worried that, in Washington, cutting the budget deficit was stalled.
Still others feared the budget cuts might be too little (to rally the markets) or too much (for the economy to sustain).


METROPOLITAN DIARY
LEAD:  DEAR Diary:


STADIUM LOSES IN JERSEY; DEMOCRATS KEEP SENATE AND GAIN IN ASSEMBLY
LEAD: New Jersey voters yesterday rejected a proposal supported by Governor Kean to spend $185 million for a major league baseball stadium, and elected all 120 members of the State Legislature.


Treasury Bond Prices Rise
LEAD: Treasury bond prices rose nearly a point yesterday, cutting the yield of the 30-year issue to slightly above 9 percent.


Ginsburg Faces Queries Over Cable TV
LEAD: Concern grew among Republican senators today that Judge Douglas H. Ginsburg's nomination to the Supreme Court could be imperiled by charges of conflict of interest, and the Senate Republican leader summoned the nominee to the Capitol to explain his involvement in decisions affecting regulation of the cable television industry.

Falwell Quits as Moral Majority Head
LEAD: The Rev.
Jerry Falwell, founder and leader of the fundamentalist Christian political group Moral Majority, announced today that he was giving up politics and returning full time to his church and television ministry.


Kasparov Wins Game 8
LEAD: Gary Kasparov incisively won the eighth game of his world championship chess match against Anatoly Karpov in Seville, Spain, yesterday to level their series.

Kentucky and Mississippi Pick Democratic Governors
LEAD: Democrats won governorships last night in Kentucky and Mississippi, completing a shutout of the Republicans in this year's gubernatorial elections.


60-MINUTE GOURMET
LEAD: FRESH tuna has become something of a national passion -a pleasantly surprising development, since until a decade or so ago most of the tuna eaten came out of a can and went into tuna salads.

LEAD: It's been quite a season at the Bronx Zoo.
New York City's two most distinguished - and cuddly - visitors downed 6,800 pounds of bamboo, 736 eggs and 2,208 apples and carrots.


Khrushchev's Son-in-Law Is Elated With 'a Wind of Change'
LEAD: When Mikhail S. Gorbachev's speech ended Monday, Aleksei I. Adzhubei got an excited phone call from his youngest son, a biochemist.


Sports People; Knicks Waive Huston
LEAD: The Knicks trimmed their roster yesterday to the required 12 players by asking waivers on two veterans and placing two others on the injured list.
Geoff Huston, a guard, and Leo Rautins, a forward, were released after practice at the team's camp at the State University of New York at Purchase.


Celtics Confident Despite Key Loss
LEAD: It has become rather fashionable in recent years to dwell on why the Boston Celtics won't be as strong as they were the previous season.
About a year ago, Larry Bird's uncertain health, especially his back and elbow, was the trendy topic of concern.
At other times, the issue may have been Robert Parish's age, Dennis Johnson's poor shooting, Danny


West German Jobless
LEAD: The number of West Germans out of work fell slightly last month, but the job market has apparently stagnated, the Federal Labor Office said today.
The office said the total number of jobless, adjusted for seasonal factors, fell to 2.25 million in October, from 2.26 million in September.
The Labor Office president, Heinrich Franke, told reporters in Nuremberg, ''Taking all the data together, my overall verdict for October is stagnation.

From Papp, All of Shakespeare
LEAD: The New York Shakespeare Festival will present all 36 plays in the Shakespeare canon, in a six-year, $33 million series that will also include television and book adaptations of the stagings, Joseph Papp, the producer of the festival, announced yesterday.


2 Sides Still Far Apart In El Salvador Conflict
LEAD: Despite recent efforts to seek reconciliation under a new regional peace accord, El Salvador today appears as deeply polarized as ever.


Bucks to Retire Bridgeman Jersey
LEAD: The Milwaukee Bucks will retire the uniform of Junior Bridgeman, who played in more games with the National Basketball Association team than any other player in its 20-year history.


2 Policemen Slain in Frankfurt Protest
LEAD: Two policemen were killed Monday night during a demonstration at the Frankfurt Airport, and this appears certain to stiffen demands by conservatives for tougher measures against violent radicals.


Caspar Weinberger's Mixed Legacy
LEAD: With Caspar Weinberger's expected departure after seven years as Secretary of Defense, President Reagan will lose a loyal counselor who tirelessly championed greater military spending.
But Mr.
Weinberger leaves a mixed legacy.
He strengthened America's defenses, yet with enormous profligacy.
He had little appreciation for the positive role of arms control in Soviet-American relations.


INDONESIA DROUGHT TOLL
LEAD: Indonesia's vital rice crop has been saved from drought, but other cash crops have suffered and the nation may have to import some crops, Achmad Affande, Agriculture Minister, said today.
Indonesia, which has the largest farm area in Southeast Asia, anticipated the cyclical drought and took some preventative measures, Mr.


Price of Crude Drops Again
LEAD: Crude oil prices fell for the second consecutive day yesterday, to the lowest level in about a month, hurt by what traders called speculation of growing friction within OPEC and renewed stock market volatility.

BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 4, 1987
LEAD:  The  Markets


How We Got Into This Economic Gridlock
LEAD: To the Editor:


An Updated Boot and a Breakfast-Table Whimsy
LEAD:  1.
Boot for Today  This updated classic black leather boot has tiny metal studs on a patchwork design, stylishly created with strips of black suede.
The boot, which has a gracefully shaped low heel, costs $240 at Maraolo, 782 Lexington Avenue (61st Street) and 1321 Third Avenue (76th Street).


JAI ALAI: AN IMPORTED SPORT FOR ALL-AMERICAN DREAMERS
LEAD: It was Halloween night, but the strangest sight at the Milford Jai Alai Fronton was simply the size of the crowd.
Most evenings this time of year, the courtside stands are freckled with fans.
The house was packed, though, crammed all the way up to the smoke-choked $2 seats with some 6,000 screamers, dreamers and get-rich-quick schemers.


FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
LEAD: The Valley National Corporation is offering $100 million of 9 percent notes, due in 1989, at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.


DOW FALLS BY 50.56 AS FIVE-DAY RALLY ENDS FOR WALL ST.
LEAD: The stock market lurched downward yesterday as a return of volatile trading ended a fragile, five-day rally.


Sports News Briefs; Lions Trade Giles For Draft Choice
LEAD: The Detroit Lions traded Jimmie Giles, the disgruntled tight end, to the Philadelphia Eagles yesterday for an undisclosed 1988 draft choice.
Giles played in four games this season for Detroit, catching six passes for 62 yards and no touchdowns.
He complained publicly last week about a lack of playing time.


Stage: A 'Kismet' Revival
LEAD: THE Equity Library Theater's ''Kismet'' is always exuberant and often hilarious, but at times the pedestrian direction of Russell Treyz reduces its whimsies to mere absurdities.
People who like this musical, dreadful rhymes and all, will believe anything, and the higher a director lets his imagination fly, the better.


Britain Sees 4% Growth
LEAD: Britain's economy will grow about 4 percent this year despite the recent stock market plunge, but growth may slow to 2.5 percent in 1988, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Nigel Lawson, said today.


Poland's $8 Billion Pact
LEAD: The debt rescheduling accord struck last week between Poland and its Paris Club group of creditor governments covers more than $8 billion, a Polish Government spokesman, Jerzy Urban, said today.
The amount covers almost a quarter of Poland's total $35 billion foreign debt, two-thirds of which is owed to Paris Club members, he said.


NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 4, 1987
LEAD:  International A3-13


Bringing the Movies to Life
LEAD: MOVIES today boast spectacular special effects, the latest in sound systems and ever-improving color and clarity.
But Douglas Trumbull is not impressed.


Debt Swaps In Mexico
LEAD: Mexico is reviewing its debt-for-equity conversion program to assess the inflationary impact, but the program has not been suspended, the central bank governor said.


Who Was Who in Weekly Reader's Early Days
LEAD: To the Editor:


New Violence Erupts in Haiti As Election Council Bars
LEAD: Violence flared again today in Haiti hours after a dozen associates of Francois and Jean-Claude Duvalier, the former dictators, were rejected as presidential candidates.


Monroe Nominated to Hall of Fame
LEAD: Earl Monroe, who spent almost nine seasons with the Knicks, was one of four players and five coaches nominated today for election to the Basketball Association Hall of Fame.


ABC Joins Venture With Weintraub
LEAD: The Weintraub Entertainment Group and ABC News said they would pool their news film archives into a single library.
The joint venture, called ABC/ Weintraub Pathe, will use the film archives to develop new programming for home video cassettes and cable television, the companies said.
They declined to disclose specific applications or terms of the deal.

Bridge: Pair and Team Competition: The Gulf Between Strategies
LEAD: As all tournament players know, there is a considerable gulf between the strategy called for in pair play, scored by match points, and team play, scored by imps, or international match points.
The pair player is concerned with small profits and losses, but when he shifts to a team event, his focus is on large ones.


Charles F. Bonilla, 78, a Professor at Columbia
LEAD: Prof.
Charles Francis Bonilla, who retired in 1978 after 30 years on the faculty of Columbia University's department of chemical engineering, died of a heart attack Saturday at Morristown (N.J.) Hospital.
He was 78 years old and lived in Tenafly, N.J.


Koch Keeps Embassy Busy, But Sandinistas Are Wary
LEAD: At the American Embassy here, a political officer had a tired greeting for a visitor a few days ago.


PERSONAL HEALTH
LEAD: CHANGES in American society are drawing new attention to the form of sexual expression most widely practiced, yet least talked about: masturbation.
Compared with the 1940's and 50's, when Alfred Kinsey did his studies, many more people today say they approve of sexual self-stimulation and perform it fairly often.


His Honor, the Diplomat
LEAD: What better place for New York's Mayor Koch to be now than Central America?
The stock market crash and the city's impending financial difficulties, the search for a new Schools Chancellor, the quarrel between the Police and Fire Departments on handling emergencies, NBC's renewed threat to leave the city - all apparently can wait.


THE DIFFICULT BIRTH OF THE LOTUS AGENDA
LEAD: MITCHELL D. KAPOR, the man who introduced spreadsheets to the computer industry, was grappling with a particularly vexing problem in 1985 when he was chairman of the Lotus Development Corporation: little slips of paper.
The little notes intended to help him organize his life were everywhere - on his desk, stuck to his telephone, stuffed in the pockets of his brightly patterned Hawaiian shirts.

LEAD: The author William Styron has been awarded the medal of the Commander of the Legion of Honor, the highest degree of the highest honor the French Government can bestow on a French or foreign citizen.

LEAD: Edwin L. Cox Jr., a Dallas businessman who was under Federal investigation earlier this year for loans received while a director of the Interfirst Bank of Dallas, said today that he has repaid the remaining $36 million owed the bank.

LEAD: Putting an end to months of speculation, the International Business Machines Corporation said today that it would begin to ship the first release of its OS/2, the next generation of its personal computer operating system, in December, a few months ahead of schedule.

Gulf Fisherman Says U.S. Fired at Him
LEAD: The vessel hit by a United States Navy frigate on Sunday night was an unarmed Arab fishing boat, not an Iranian patrol boat, a fisherman who said he was aboard the fishing boat asserted today.
He said an Indian on the boat had been killed.

Enforcing of Height Limit Is Urged for Tower
LEAD: The Manhattan Borough President and the mid-Manhattan community board have called on New York City to enforce the height limit for the nearly completed Cityspire tower, which is almost 11 feet taller than approved and the subject today of a City Planning Commission review.


Calling Mr. Baker
LEAD: Relations between President Reagan's chief of staff, Howard H. Baker Jr., and Congressional conservatives have never been particularly warm, but in recent weeks things have grown downright frosty.
Viewing Mr.
Baker as something less than a faithful guardian of the Reagan doctrine on such issues as tax increases, military spending and the nomination of ideologically correct Supreme Court justices, conservatives these days rarely bother to hide their frustration.


Pragmatic Revolution in China
LEAD: The distinguishing mark of China's 13th Communist Party Congress was its steadiness, the legacy of a decade under the skillful hand of Deng Xiaoping. ''The Big 13,'' as the Beijing press called it, brought few real surprises.


Wells, Rich Is Losing Two of Its P.&amp;G. Brands
LEAD: The Procter &amp; Gamble Company, which rarely moves accounts except as a form of discipline, has switched two brands out of Wells, Rich, Greene and into the Leo Burnett Company and N. W. Ayer, which joined its roster last year when it acquired Cunningham &amp; Walsh.


Taste and Nutrition
LEAD: To The Living Section:


Senate Backs Renewal Of Special Prosecutors
LEAD: The Senate voted 85 to 10 today to renew the law authorizing special prosecutors to investigate allegations of wrongdoing by senior government officials after rejecting, by a vote of 49 to 46, an attempt to make the bill apply to members of Congress.

Furor Growing in France on Iran Arms-Sale Case
LEAD: A political scandal involving the illegal sale of artillery shells to Iran deepened today as a Paris daily published the full text of a secret Defense Ministry report that directly implicated President Francois Mitterrand.


Two Children, Trapped in a Refrigerator, Die
LEAD: A 3-year-old girl and her 4-year-old brother died yesterday evening shortly after their grandfather, who had been searching for them for nearly three hours, found them trapped unconscious in an old refigerator in the backyard of their home in Jamaica, Queens, the police said.


Army Accepts Copters Despite Some Problems
LEAD: The Army has accepted delivery of 285 new Apache helicopter gunships even though it is still working with the manufacturer to correct a number of problems on the aircraft that were identified two years ago, officials say.

5-Transplant Child Better
LEAD: The 3-year-old Kentucky girl who received five new organs in experimental transplant surgery was taken off a respirator today, a sign of steady improvement, hospital officials said.
The child, Tabatha Foster, was able to breathe on her own and talk for the first time since the 15-hour operation began Saturday, said a spokesman for Children's Hospital of Pittsburgh.


Wood Radiator Covers Can Add Sitting Space
LEAD: NOAH BLOCK, a co-owner of the Building Block, a cabinet shop, says that customers find plenty of reasons to order his custom-made radiator covers.
The covers can create extra sitting space, cover up unsightly radiators, protect skin and clothing from hot coils and provide additional shelf space.

Dr.
R.B.Y.
Scott, an Old Testament scholar and former William H. Danforth Professor of Religion at Princeton University, died Sunday at a home for the elderly in Toronto, where he had lived for several years.
He was 88 years old.

LEAD: On the eve of a crucial two-month period for carrying out a Central American peace plan, the Reagan Administration has decided to seek $30 million in new non-lethal aid for the Nicaraguan rebels, Administration and Congressional officials said today.

HOME IMPROVEMENT
LEAD: MALFUNCTIONING floor or desk lamps are dangerous.
If a lamp flickers, won't light, has a frayed cord, requires delicate positioning to operate or frequently burns out bulbs, you should repair it immediately or discontinue using it.

Reagan Fantasies, Budget Realities
LEAD: The stock market crash, President Reagan now says, two weeks after the fact, was a warning ''we can't afford to ignore.'' What counts is what the President now does.
And so far, he and his aides have shown little fire in the negotiations with Congress on reducing the budget deficit.
They're simply using the meetings as an opportunity to rehearse old arguments over priorities and old nostrums against tax increases.

LEAD: Thomas M. Messer, the director of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation and of its museums in New York and Venice for 27 years, has announced his retirement.

Belgium's Jobless Rate
LEAD: Belgium's unemployment rate fell to 12.1 percent in October, from 12.2 percent in September, the National Labor Office said today.
Belgium's jobless rate is one of the highest in the European Community, surpassed only by Ireland and Italy.

Decision on Harmon
LEAD: Based on a ruling by an arbitrator, John Culver, a former Senator from Iowa, Ronnie Harmon does not have to repay Norby Walters most of the money he received from the agent with whom he had a contract from March 1985 until August 1986.
According to a report yesterday in The Atlanta Constitution, Culver voided the contract that Harmon signed on the ground that Walters and Lloyd Bloom, an associate, had violated regulations of the National Football League Players Association regarding agents.

Surgery for Well's Victim
LEAD: Jessica McClure, the 19-month-old girl who survived 58 1/2 hours stuck in an abandoned well, underwent her fifth operation today at Midland Memorial Hospital.
The surgery was to help repair a severe scrape on Jessica's forehead.
Skin grafts were also taken from the little girl's thigh to be transferred to her right foot, which was wedged in an awkward position and suffered reduced blood flow.


New York City Begins $600 Million Offering
LEAD: New York City is offering $600 million of new bonds in a financing that does not seem to have suffered noticeably from fears that the city's economy would be hurt by the recent declines in stock prices and employment cutbacks at securities firms.


Exchanges Giving Chicago a Lift, Too
LEAD: Just as New York has flourished in recent years from the boom on Wall Street, so has Chicago prospered from the rising fortunes of its options and futures exchanges.


Williams Rejects Job
LEAD: Miffed after learning that he was not under consideration to become the new manager of the Chicago Cubs.
Billy Williams, the Hall of Fame outfielder, has told the Cubs he will not manage in the club's minor-league system as planned.
Williams, who played for the Cubs nearly all of his 18-year major-league career and served as a coach with the team for six years, has talked with John Madigan, the club's new chairman.


Issues, Money and Reagan Helped Democrats
LEAD: A combination of local issues, attractive and well-financed Democratic candidates and signs of disillusionment with President Reagan combined to make Tuesday's local elections in New York State a Democratic triumph, Republican and Democratic politicians agreed yesterday.

LEAD: SMITH-CORONA, which has restricted advertising for its portable word processor to magazines for the last year, is now prepared to return to moving pictures.

SENDING PAINTINGS ABROAD HELPS RAISE PROFITS AT HOME
LEAD: Vincent van Gogh's ''Irises'' - a glowing study of a patch of purple irises and one white bloom - was returned to New York last week after a four-week, 17,500-mile journey to Tokyo, London, Geneva and Zurich.


Index Futures Tied By Ruder to Plunge
LEAD: David S. Ruder, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said today that various forms of index futures trading played a significant role in the recent collapse of the stock market.


Nixon Injured Again
LEAD: Norm Nixon, the veteran guard who missed the 1986-87 season because of an injured left knee, ruptured his right Achilles' tendon during practice yesterday and will be sidelined for the 1987-88 season, the Los Angeles Clippers announced.
Nixon, a two-time All-Star guard, was injured near the end of the practice session after he passed the ball and made a quick cut.

LEAD: A Congressional investigation has found no evidence that Dr.
James C. Fletcher, the Administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, or other space officials violated conflict-of-interest regulations in 1973 when they chose Morton Thiokol Inc. to produce the solid-fuel booster rockets for the space shuttle.

LEAD: A man who counterfeited money to help finance a white supremacist group, the Order, testified today that Jacob K. Javits and Armand Hammer were on a ''hit list'' of leading Jews targeted by the extremists.


Bank Merger Set In Pennsylvania
LEAD: Pennbancorp and the Union National Corporation said they had agreed to a merger that would create a $6.5 billion institution which would become the sixth-largest bank holding company in Pennsylvania.
Under the terms of the agreement, Pennbancorp and Union National shareholders would each receive about 50 percent of the common shares of the new parent on a fully diluted basis.

British Banks Cut Key Rates
LEAD: British banks cut key interest rates today by half a percentage point, to 9 percent.

Gilford: Jack Gilford At Ballroom
LEAD: JACK GILFORD is in the tradition of the great silent clowns, the comic masters of the early days of films.
He may be the last of them, and even he depends on speech and song for most of his performance at the Ballroom, 253 West 28th Street, where he is making his first cabaret appearance in 39 years.


A Rescue Devised for Specialists
LEAD: The Reagan Administration is devising a plan to rescue a critical group of stock exchange firms - known as specialists - in the event of market plunges like the one on Oct. 19, according to a senior Treasury official.

LEAD: Prosecutors said yesterday that Larry Davis, who faces trial on charges of killing four suspected drug dealers in the Bronx, mailed a threatening letter from jail to the mother of his 2-year-old child to deter her from testifying against him.

LEAD: Suffolk County Democrats stunned Republicans on Tuesday by capturing the County Executive's office for the first time in 16 years, upsetting two longtime Republican Town Supervisors and gaining a plurality in the County Legislature.

It was signed in 1972.

LEAD: THINGS may have seemed a little noisier than usual at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday, with whistles and tumultuous applause at the start of the evening and whoops and cheers at the close.
Garth Fagan's Bucket Dance Theater is back in town.


Emigres Reunited in U.S.
LEAD: Two Jewish families were reunited in Capitol Hill ceremonies today after long battles to leave the Soviet Union.
Lev Pevzner, 73 years old, a Russian-born resident of Indianapolis, was reunited with his son, daughter-in-law and granddaughter after eight years.
Keith Braun, 28, a Detroit lawyer, was reunited with his wife, Svetlana.


An Arrest in German Killings
LEAD: A 33-year-old man was detained on suspicion of killing two policemen in a protest near the Frankfurt airport two days ago, the Government said today.
The man, Andreas Eichler, was arrested hours after the killings, during a protest by extremists wearing masks.

Tougher Student Loan Rules Planned
LEAD: Calling the rate of default on student loans intolerable, Secretary of Education William J. Bennett said today that he planned to draw strict new guidelines that could make hundreds of schools ineligible for Federal student aid.


Advertising; Omnicom Rebounds And Earns $2.9 Million
LEAD: The Omnicom Group Inc., parent company of BBDO Worldwide and DDB Needham, reported third-quarter earnings of $2.9 million, or 12 cents a share.
The results mark a turnaround from the period a year earlier, when the company lost $29.8 million because of a restructuring.
Omnicom said its revenue increased 4 percent, to $185.6 million, from $178.5 million in the third quarter last year.


Spain Rejects U.S. Deal on Bases, Foreshadowing the Treaty's End
LEAD: Spain has turned down a last-minute compromise proposal by the United States to salvage the 34-year-old defense treaty that permits American military installations on Spanish soil.

LEAD: The Nations' Cup, a horsemanship contest among international teams from the United States, Britain, France and Canada, had to be decided by a timed jumpoff between France and Canada last night at the National Horse Show.

Dimitrova and Luis Lima in San Francisco.
Major opera stars have been canceling their appearances this season with leading American companies at a distressing rate and are doing so even at the risk of ''burning their bridges in this country,'' according to company directors and officials.

I.B.M. Is Optimistic Despite Problems
LEAD: The chairman of the International Business Machines Corporation predicted today that ''we should return this company to operating margins in the range of 20 percent,'' the strongest indication yet that I.B.M. now believes its three-year slump is ending.


Exhibit of Art Against Apartheid Opens at U.N.
LEAD: New Yorkers will get their first chance to see part of a small but unusual art collection this week at the United Nations Headquarters.


State Department; LITTLE REPORT, WITH RIGHT SPIN, MAKES BIG SPLASH
LEAD: When the State Department's Bureau of Intelligence and Research issued a slick, intricately documented study last August on Soviet disinformation techniques, hardly anybody in Washington took notice.
It bore the title, ''Soviet Influence Activities: A Report on Active Measures and Propaganda, 1986-87.

CBS Asks Advice on Cronkite Show on Apartheid
LEAD: CBS News, concerned that a secretly taped Walter Cronkite documentary about apartheid in South Africa might jeopardize the organization's news bureau there, has taken the unusual step of getting the opinion of an independent South African lawyer before approving the program for broadcast.

Rams Suspend Irvin
LEAD: The Los Angeles Rams have suspended the All-Pro cornerback LeRoy Irvin for conduct detrimental to the team.
He will not play Sunday when the Rams meet the New Orleans Saints, but Coach John Robinson said Irvin's status would be re-evaluated after he meets with the eight-year veteran next Monday.
Irvin, who has been complaining about his contract since early in training camp, called in sick with the flu last Thursday and the Rams responded by placing him on the inactive list and cleaning out his locker.


Washington Talk: Briefing; An Actor on the Hill
LEAD: E. G. Marshall, the actor, had some advice this week for the top negotiators from the White House and Congress who are struggling to reach a compromise on a deficit-reducing package.

NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 5, 1987
LEAD:  International A3-14


30 Are Indicted in Miami in Drug Smuggling
LEAD: After a three-year investigation, Federal agents today arrested more than a dozen people accused of belonging to a sophisticated ring smuggling drugs in Colombia, the Bahamas and Florida.


Election Panel Officials in Haiti Flee New Violence in the Capital
LEAD: Several members of the Haitian electoral commission were in hiding today after a second night of arson attacks against election officials.


Ancient Boats Still Ply a Tense Gulf
LEAD: Visibility in the shipping lanes of the Persian Gulf was dropping in the amber dusk.
Suddenly, a young, twangy American voice came over the marine radio: ''Unidentified dhow one mile off my port bow, this is a U.S.
Navy warship.
State your intentions.'' The admonition was repeated once, then again, and each time the sailor's voice grew more insistent.


U.S. AGENCY REOPENS INQUIRY INTO MERCEDES ACCELERATION
LEAD: The National Highway Traffic Safety Ad-ministration, citing numerous com-plaints, has reopened its investigation of problems with sudden acceleration in 35,000 late-model Mercedes cars.


Yields Are Mainly Off
LEAD: Yields on certificates of deposit and money market mutual funds were down for the week ended yesterday, while bank money market accounts remained unchanged.


BOOKS OF THE TIMES
LEAD:  THE TOMMYKNOCKERS. By Stephen King. 558 pages. Putnam. $27.95.

Europe Jobless Rate Up
LEAD: The jobless rate for nine member states of the European Community, excluding Spain, Portugal and Greece, rose to 10.9 percent in September, from 10.8 percent in August, the community's statistical office said today.
The figures are seasonally unadjusted.
The total number of job seekers for the nine countries rose to 12.62 million, from 12.53 million.

McCray Reaches Terms
LEAD: Rodney McCray, the 6-foot-8-inch small member of the Houston Rockets' starting front line, reached agreement with the team yesterday on a six-year contract for an undisclosed amount of money.
McCray, who led the Rockets in assists, field-goal percentage and free-throw percentage last season while complementing the Twin Towers - Ralph Sampson and Akeem Olajuwon -said that contract negotiations picked up speed after he changed agents, replacing Howard Slusher with David Falk.

Raphael Soyer, Social Realist Artist, is Dead at 87
LEAD: Raphael Soyer, an artist whose gently rendered portraits of New York artists, dancers and the city's lonely and dispossessed won him fame that lasted from the 1930's to the present, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Manhattan.
He was 87 years old.


Brain Graft on Elderly Tested
LEAD: Researchers operated today on the first elderly person to undergo an experimental brain graft technique against Parkinson's disease.
The operation was the first of six intended to see whether the new technique, already tried on younger patients, could help older victims of the disease.

Advertising; Lorillard to Remain At Saatchi &amp; Saatchi
LEAD: After a three-month search, Lorillard Inc. has decided to keep the creative work for its True cigarettes at Saatchi &amp; Saatchi DFS Compton.
The company does its own media work in-house.


Vehicle Sales Up 10.8% Despite Wall St. Plunge
LEAD: Domestic auto makers today reported strong sales for the last 10 days of October.
Buyers appeared unaffected by the stock market's 508-point plunge on Oct. 19 and the subsequent turmoil.


Baseball Notebook; It's No Off Season on a Wide Variety of Fronts
LEAD: Jack Morris is trying again, but Dale Murphy decided not to try free agency at all.
Benito Santiago won, as expected, but the San Francisco Giants lost, which was not expected.


Georgia Power To Appeal Ruling
LEAD: The Southern Company said its Georgia Power Company unit would appeal a regulatory agency's decision to disallow a portion of its investment in Unit 1 of the Vogtle nuclear power plant.
The Georgia Public Service Commission denied the utility's request to reconsider its decision to disallow $951 million of investment in the plant.


U.S. Proposes to Fine Shipbuilder
LEAD: Federal officials today proposed fines totaling $4.2 million against the Bath Iron Works for conditions that safety inspectors said endangered the thousands of workers at the shipyard.
The conditions included exposure to asbestos and to raw sewage, the inspectors said.


FINANCE BRIEFS
LEAD: *
Hadco Corp. has signed a $10 million revolving credit agreement with the Bank of Boston Corp.


BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 5, 1987
LEAD: THE MARKETS  The stock market continued to slump in another session marked by wide price swings.
Selling by institutions helped drag down share prices, analysts said, but there were indications that some stability may be returning.
The Dow Jones industrial average tumbled more than 50 points early in the day, then rose as much as 17 points above Tuesday's close, but ended down 18.24 points, or 0.93 percent, at 1,945.29.

Suffolk County's Evolution
LEAD: The rare election of a Democrat, Patrick Halpin, as Suffolk County Executive, adds weight to the party's triumphs in Tuesday's election.
Governor Cuomo, who campaigned for Mr.
Halpin, was quick to claim credit.
But it's also important to heed the county's changing character.


Swapo Denies Pretoria Fight
LEAD: The South-West Africa People's Organization said today that its guerrillas were not involved in a battle in Angola in which South Africa reported its forces suffered 12 fatalities and killed 150 guerrillas.
The South African military command initially announced that its troops had overrun two Swapo bases in southern Angola and killed 150 guerrillas, and later released news of casualties.

House Calls for Voiding Of a Biaggi Conviction
LEAD: The House of Representatives yesterday asked a Federal judge in Brooklyn to set aside, on constitutional grounds, Representative Mario Biaggi's conviction for unlawfully traveling across state lines to accept an illegal gratuity.


Corrections
LEAD: A Paris dispatch on Friday about a device used in French taxis to deter muggers misstated the electric charge involved.
It is 52,000 volts of current at a very low amperage -0.02 amperes - not at low tension.

Europe Check on Japan
LEAD: The European Community will continue to monitor Japanese exports for violations of American trade sanctions until Washington lifts all punitive tariffs, a community official said today.
The statement came as President Reagan announced that some sanctions against the Japanese were being lifted.

LEAD: The House voted 254 to 158 tonight for a bill to impose a sweeping ban on the use of lie detector tests by most private employers.


Gang Wars At Center Ice
LEAD: WATCHING two National Hockey League players drop their gloves, skate in small circles like partners at a square dance, then engage in a pushing, grappling and punching match - featuring a clumsy attempt to undress one another - is so absurd that sometimes it is actually funny.
That is the most benign aspect of a hockey fight.


N.A.M. Called Hopeful on '88
LEAD: American manufacturers are still confident about economic prospects for next year despite the stock market plunge, Jerry Jasinowski, chief economist of the National Association of Manufacturers, said today.


LAUREN'S FULL TAFFETAS
LEAD: WITH perfect pitch, Ralph Lauren showed a low-key collection that should will women to keep cool but still acknowledge the current fashion rhythm.
Oscar de la Renta unleashed a whirlwind of ruffles and devastating black dresses in a Spanish-inspired collection, and Arnold Scaasi continued his longtime love affair with flowers and poufs.


French Honor Levesque
LEAD: Members of the French National Assembly stood to observe a minute of silence today in honor of the Rene Levesque, the Quebec nationalist who died in Montreal Sunday.
Speaker Jacques Chaban-Delmas will represent France at Mr.
Levesque's state funeral on Thursday.


EXECUTIVE CHANGES
LEAD: *
Bank One, Lexington, an affiliate of the Banc One Corp., Columbus, Ohio, elected William R. Guthrie president and chief executive.


In Texas, Contempt by Court
LEAD: By refusing to hear the $10 billion dispute between Texaco and Pennzoil, the Texas Supreme Court offends federalism and fairness.
Contempt of court is one thing; this refusal amounts to a contempt by a court.

Landscapes That Recall Rural Simplicity
LEAD: THE landscape architect Michael Van Valkenburgh recalls first fantasizing about the land as a boy when he brought the cows home from pasture in the Catskills to his family's modest dairy farm in Lexington, N.Y.
Today, his work retains what he sees as ''the deliberate simplicity of that remembered agrarian landscape,'' as in the way a plantation of trees is angled into the hillside.

LEAD: Immigration officials said today that they had detected fraud in thousands of the applications for legal status filed by illegal aliens who said they had worked in the United States as farm laborers.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Restoring Baronial Splendor in Pittsburgh
LEAD: ''I WANT to put back as much as possible - the smells, the sounds, the flowers,'' said Thierry Despont, the architect who is restoring Clayton, home of the coke and steel baron Henry Clay Frick. ''I want the telephone to ring.''


Bridge: League Begins a Hot Line, Not for Questions on Play
LEAD: A hot line to solve the problems of bridge players might be expected to be popular, especially if it is an 800 number.


Comegys Traded To Nets
LEAD: In an effort to strengthen their injury-riddled front line, the Nets obtained Dallas Comegys from the Atlanta Hawks yesterday for a second-round draft choice in 1989 or 1990, depending on where the Nets finish.


Kerkorian Bid Opposed in Poll
LEAD: An overwhelming majority of Pan American World Airways pilots in New York are opposed to having the pilots union pursue a proposal made by Kirk Kerkorian to take over the airline, a union official said yesterday.
The New York base accounts for about half of the carrier's pilots, and the official said sentiment was running 20 to 1 against the proposal in a poll of the pilots.


Program Trading Getting a Rebirth
LEAD: After dropping off sharply because of New York Stock Exchange restrictions, program trading is on the rise again.
That is partly because the Big Board lifted some of its curbs, but also because program traders have improvised to make up for the continued ban on automatic execution of stocks through the exchange's computers.


Comdisco Ends Arbitrage Unit
LEAD: Comdisco Inc., a computer sales and leasing company based in Rosemont, Ill., said yesterday that it had decided to discontinue its risk arbitrage business because of heavy demands from stockholders and big institutional investors.

Rauschenberg Painting Sets Record
LEAD: Robert Rauschenberg's ''Backwash,'' an abstract study of paint and lettering from 1959, was sold last night for $814,000, a record price at auction for the artist that almost doubled the previous high.
The painting was bought by an unidentified collector in a sale at Sotheby's that totaled $17.7 million, the second highest total ever for an auction of contemporary art.

Avco Financial
LEAD: Avco Financial Services is offering $100 million of noncallable 9 3/8 percent notes due in 1992 at a price of 99 5/8, to yield 9.47 percent, through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley &amp; Company.
The five-year notes are rated A-3 by Moody's and A by S.&amp;P. and were offered to yield 1.2 percentage points more than Treasury notes of similar maturity.

Hanging A Vivid Jungle
LEAD: MOST of the jungle of plants and hanging baskets filling the abundant number of east windows in my house are foliage plants: true ferns, various asparagus ferns (which aren't ferns at all, but are close kin to the tasty edible kind) and spider plants.


Advertising; Ladies' Home Journal Promotes Its Editor
LEAD: Myrna Blyth, the editor in chief of The Ladies' Home Journal, has been promoted to publishing director.
The move means that Ms.
Blyth, 47, will continue as the chief of editorial and will also have the publisher, Roert D. Thomas, reporting to her, while she reports to James A. Autry, president of the Meredith Corporation's Magazine Group.

A DANCE ABOUT LIVING WITH AIDS IS PLANNED
LEAD: ''Daily Living'', a dance about liv-ing with AIDS, will be performed by Loren MacDougal on a program of solo pieces on Friday and Saturday at the Triplex at Manhattan Community College, 199 Chambers Street.
The dance was choreographed by Lee Connor, who died of AIDS in September.


Reagan Lifts Some Of Japan Sanctions
LEAD: President Reagan today announced a further partial lifting of trade sanctions against Japan.
They were imposed last April after Japan failed to comply with a 1986 agreement on computer memory chips.

Gorbachev Fills In Some Blank Pages
LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's speech on the 70th anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution was a microcosm of the reform process he has been leading.
The speech shows how far he has come in his willingness to tell the truth about Soviet history, and how far he still has to go.
It also raises serious doubts about whether he can get there - the same sorts of doubts that arise concerning his prospects for reforming the


Q &amp; A
LEAD: Q. My year-old fir deck was stained with a semisolid stain instead of a deck stain.
As a result it is now peeling, bubbling and splotchy and looks 10 years old instead of almost new.
The cost of sanding off this stain so the deck can be restained properly is exorbitant.
What can be done now and next season to correct this problem?

Turning the Ordinary Into the Unusual
LEAD: NANCY HYON paints paper lamp shades and wood lamp bases in tortoise shell, rose quartz and lapis lazuli.
She makes simple or intricate designs that duplicate any fabric pattern.
A plain shade can also be turned into what seems like parchment.
By using gold, silver or aluminum leaf, she can create antique finishes.

LEAD: A brand of nonalcoholic beer will be sold instead of regular beer at Saturday's Maryland-Penn State football game, city officials have announced.

Airline Ticket Fraud
LEAD: Ticket fraud costs the world's airlines up to $500 million a year, according to estimates by the International Air Transport Association published today.
In its latest quarterly magazine, the I.A.T.A. said it had begun a training program to help staff from its 168 member airlines spot fraudulent tickets.

Tisch of CBS, according to people familiar with the investigation.

A STRONG BEAR CAN LIFT A SHADOW
LEAD: When James S. Brady, the newly appointed press secretary to President Reagan walked into his White House office on Inauguration Day, Jan. 20, 1981, he found a bulletproof vest.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD: TENNIS  Wilander Upset by American: Jim Grabb of the United States used a strong serve-and-volley game to upset second-seeded Mats Wilander of Sweden, 7-5, 6-4, last night in the second round of the $525,000 Stockholm Open-Scandinavian Championships.
Grabb, a 23-year-old former all-American at Stanford who is ranked only 76th, eliminated another Swede, Thomas Hogstedt, 7-6, 7-6, in the first round Monday.

LEAD: A Palestinian guerrilla group has reached a peace agreement with its Shiite Moslem opponents in Lebanon, but skirmishes continued today around a southern district near Sidon.

LEAD: Three years ago this week, the president of Hunter College, Dr.
Donna E. Shalala, ignited a debate about the New York school system by declaring the problem was not with the apples.
Rather, she said, the whole barrel was rotten.
Since then, reading scores have improved.
The dropout rate has been reduced.

Keep the Anglo-Irish Pact
LEAD: The Protestants and Catholics of British-ruled Northern Ireland agree on one rare point: Both would do away with the one-judge, no-jury courts that now try terrorist cases.
They would accept as a sensible alternative the system that is used in the Irish Republic: three judges, one usually of a different faith from the accused.

The one- and two-processor models will be available in May and the bigger ones in June, Unisys said.

Import Quotas
LEAD: An international trade tribunal has ruled that some Japanese import quotas on food are illegal, and the United States is expected to use the ruling to put pressure on Tokyo to end other farm-trade barriers, American trade officials said today.
The ruling by a three-member panel established by the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade was said to have been quietly conveyed to Tokyo and Washington this week.

What Should the Neighbors Do?
LEAD: It's all too common to hear the sounds of fierce battle in a neighbor's home - and not know quite what to do.
Does one call the police?
Or respect the family's privacy?
The brief life of Elizabeth Steinberg, age 6, who died yesterday in New York, makes clear the answer: One calls the police.

Art: Fernand Leger Paintings at Acquavella
LEAD: THE loan show of ''Fernand Leger'' at the Acquavella Galleries is a remarkable achievement.
For the two rooms upstairs, the gallery has been able to borrow no fewer than 28 paintings that are dated between 1905 and 1921.
From the beginnings of Leger's Cubism in the ''Compotier'' of 1909, through a great series of ''Contrastes de Formes'' and some incisive allusions to Leger's later preoccupation with the factory, the level crossing, the circus, the machinist and the big city as a whole, the standard is remarkably high.

Results Plus
LEAD:  Tennis  Curren Upsets Mecir: Kevin Curren used his big serve to upset the No. 1 seeded player, Miloslav Mecir of Czechoslovakia, in the second round of the $840,000 Paris Open yesterday.
Curren, a native of South Africa now living in Austin, Tex., beat the world's fifth-ranked player, 7-5, 6-4, serving nine aces and numerous service winners.


Suprema Picks Agency
LEAD: Franznick &amp; Cusatis has become the first agency for the Suprema Specialties Company, which makes Suprema Imported Parmesan and Pecorino Romano grated cheeses.
Both products are distributed nationally.
The promotion budget, the agency said, will be about $1 million.
Print advertising, particularly in food publications, will be used, the agency said, and perhaps radio and television.

Piecemeal Peace in Central America
LEAD: Never mind the conflicting signals buzzing around Central America as the first phase of a regional peace plan came into effect yesterday.
No single piece of good news or pessimism can do justice to what is now happening in five nations, three of them bloody battlegrounds.


Film: Attenborough's 'Cry Freedom'
LEAD: THE mantle of greatness does not fall lightly onto the heroes of Sir Richard Attenborough's epic film biographies.
It is placed there by a heavy hand.
A great statesman, as in the director's ''Gandhi'' or his new ''Cry Freedom,'' about the murdered South African leader Stephen Biko, is apt to be bathed in beatific light as he delivers important speeches, and to be making speeches even when he talks with intimate friends.


U.S. Is Sending Stinger Missiles to Chad
LEAD: The United States has agreed to supply Chad with Stinger missiles and has sent an American team to Ndjamena to train its army to use them, Administration officials said today.

In Poll, Confidence Slips Little
LEAD: Despite widespread fear that the stock market collapse will lead to a recession, overall public confidence in the national economy has slipped very little in the last two weeks, a New York Times Poll shows.


Patlex Wins Suit On Laser Patent
LEAD: The Patlex Corporation, in the latest of a string of victories, said it would take control of a Florida company that infringed on its laser patents as part of a court-approved settlement.
Patlex's agreement with the Control Laser International Corporation of Orlando should make it easier for the company to reach agreements with other companies that have resisted signing agreements to license its laser patents.

LEAD: A pair of camels led the way for circus animals being taken for a stroll through Lincoln Center yesterday.
The animals, part of the Big Apple Circus, were there as the circus was being set up in Damrosch Park.

Sports People; Nordique Suspended
LEAD: Gord Donnelly, a Quebec Nordiques defenseman, has been suspended for five games by the National Hockey League after a match penalty he received in a game against the Boston Bruins Oct. 29.


Big East Pact Extended
LEAD: Madison Square Garden and the Big East Conference announced a three-year extension of their agreement to hold the conference's postseason basketball tournament at the Garden.
The extension assures that the Garden will continue to host the popular four-day tournament through the 1990-91 season.


MONTANA SPECTACLE A DUD
LEAD: The annual spec-tacle of hundreds of bald eagles con-verging on Glacier National Park to feast on spawning salmon is proving to be a dud this year, park officials said, with the number of eagles down 80 per-cent and salmon almost nonexistent.
Riley McClelland, wildlife biologist for Glacier Park, cited the unusually warm fall.


Liang Shih-Chiu, a Shakespeare Translator, Dies
LEAD: Liang Shih-chiu, a popular Chinese writer who devoted about 30 years to the translation of all of Shakespeare's works into Chinese, died Tuesday in a hospital here after suffering a heart attack, family members said today.
He was 86 years old.

STOCKS, BONDS GAIN
LEAD: In the first strong sign of international economic cooperation after a month of turbulence in the financial markets, West Germany ordered reductions in interest rates today to speed up its economy.
The Reagan Administration and other governments had urged Bonn to lower its rates because they feared the onset of a worldwide recession caused partly by high interest rates.

LEAD: American steelmakers, who have enjoyed higher prices and a return to profitability for much of this year, face a downturn in demand because of the collapse of stock prices, some steel analysts and economists predicted yesterday.

M.I.T., Pressed by U.S., Won't Buy Computer
LEAD: The Massachusetts Institute of Technology said yesterday that it was canceling plans to buy a multimillion-dollar supercomputer after Federal officials strongly objected to the prospect that the university might buy Japanese technology.


15 Horses Die in Gary Fire
LEAD: At least 15 horses were killed Wednesday when fire swept through a stable, but as many as 18 others were led to safety by nearby residents, fire officials said.


Washington Talk: Briefing; 99 Cents on the Dollar
LEAD: Joseph R. Mehrkens, who recently left the United States Forest Service after 17 years, today fired a broadside at the way it manages the Tongass National Forest in Alaska.


Albert W. Luhrs
LEAD: Albert W. Luhrs, a civil engineer and executive in the paperboard container industry, died of cancer on Oct. 25 at the Heritage Hall Health Care home in Leesburg, Va.
He was 89 years old and lived in Purcellville, Va.


U.S. ACCUSES MAN OF NAZI CAMP PAST
LEAD: The Justice Department announced today that it had begun deportation proceedings against a Chicago man accused of working as a guard in three Nazi concentration camps.
It cited evidence that he ''participated in the Nazi program of persecution'' of Jews and others in World War II.


Utilities Panel Won't Let Lilco Raise Its Rates
LEAD: The State Public Service Commission said today that it would not grant the Long Island Lighting Company a rate increase this year and suggested that Lilco abandon its effort to open the Shoreham nuclear power plant.


New York City Raises Offering to $750 Million
LEAD: Strong investor demand led New York City to increase the size of its bond sale to $750 million, from $600 million, and allowed securities dealers to reduce interest rates a tenth of a percentage point for some maturities.


Dollar Dips Still Lower In Tokyo
LEAD: Despite repeated intervention by the Bank of Japan to prop up its value, the dollar dipped briefly today to a new postwar low of 134.40 yen.


Deal Signed To Fill Tower At Union Sq.
LEAD: A major financial services concern, Integrated Resources Inc., signed a long-term lease yesterday to occupy all of the office space at Zeckendorf Towers, the 27-story office and apartment complex that dominates the Union Square area.


Corrections
LEAD: A book review yesterday misstated the price of Stephen King's novel ''The Tommyknockers.'' It is $19.95.


Appointee to Security Post Is Praised
LEAD: Hardly anyone has a bad word for Lieut.
Gen.
Colin L. Powell of the Army, who is about to become President Reagan's new national security adviser.


A Money Manager's Long Day
LEAD: J. Richard Walton, a professional money manager who invests in American stocks, is now beginning his business days with a 6 A.M. telephone call to London from his home in Irvington, N.Y.
Yesterday he learned that Japanese institutions were selling American stocks and that the dollar was once again under attack in the currency markets - factors he would have to consider in deciding whether to buy or sell stocks during one of the most turbulent times in financial history.

LEAD: ONE of the new productions on the Broadway theater district's Restaurant Row is called Grand Sea Palace (346 West 46th Street, 265-8130).
The theme of this pleasant-looking turquoise-colored establishment is Thai, although the plot gets awfully muddled when they offer everything from pasta primavera to salade

Sleep may come, but the dream is gone.


A Chronicler of Revolt, Defiant Behind Bars
LEAD: Govan A. Mbeki, the 77-year-old former chairman of the African National Congress, wrote his last book on tissue paper and smuggled it to a publisher.
He will not need to be so secretive with future manuscripts, for he was freed yesterday after 23 years in a South African prison.


Big Money Fund Influx
LEAD: Assets of the nation's 412 money market mutual funds increased $2.45 billion, to $260.52 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
Assets of the 112 institutional funds were up $2.47 billion, to $73 billion.
Assets of the 207 general purpose funds were up $61.2 million, to $79.41 billion.


Rate Cuts Push Dow Up by 40.12
LEAD: Stock prices rebounded strongly yesterday, encouraged by interest rate cuts in the United States and West Germany.
Stocks also closed higher in Tokyo.


From Balmy to Blustery in a Day - Ah, November!
LEAD: Autumn blew back into town yesterday, taking some hairdos with it at Broadway and 39th Street, and abrubtly ended a brief Indian summer. (NYT/Dith Pran)


Black Youth Is Beaten Outside a High School
LEAD: A black high school student in Brooklyn was beaten Wednesday during what the police are describing as a racially motivated attack.


Banks Cut Prime Again, To 8 3/4%
LEAD: The nation's leading banks yesterday lowered their prime lending rate by a quarter of a percentage point, to 8 3/4 percent, reflecting the Federal Reserve's continuing efforts to contain the negative effects of last month's plunge in stock prices.


Ladbroke Group's Offering Lags
LEAD: Ladbroke Group P.L.C. said that only about 1.68 million of the 70.4 million new shares that it offered at 378 pence a share, about $6.61, had been taken up.
The British property and leisure group's $:256 million, or about $448 million, offer was to help finance its $:645 million (about $1.13 billion) acquisition of the Hilton International Company hotel chain from the Allegis Corporation.

Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article on Oct. 27 about the views of writers and scholars from Communist countries on recent changes in the Soviet Union and China incorrectly described the circumstances under which a Budapest statue of Stalin was removed in 1956.
It was torn down by demonstrators, not by the authorities.


Senator Icon
LEAD: ''Teddy came to see me the other day and he said he was really tired of being referred to as the younger brother of the President,'' John Kennedy grinned during a talk in Boston in October 1963.
The new Senator from Massachusetts, the President said, was ''going out on his own.
Instead of being Teddy Kennedy, now he is changing his name to Teddy Roosevelt.


Vice Chairman Named At Coca-Cola Bottling
LEAD: The Coca-Cola Bottling Company Consolidated named as a vice chairman Frank Harrison 3d, the 32-year-old former vice president and son of the current chairman, Frank Harrison Jr.
The appointment, which took effect on Oct. 30, comes at the end of a tumultuous year for the company, which saw a wide staff shake-up in response to major losses in the last quarter of 1986 and the first quarter of 1987.


Treasury Issues Rise Sharply
LEAD: Treasury note and bond prices rose sharply yesterday, as prospects of a more generous Federal Reserve policy and lower interest rates created strong demand by investors.


Washington Talk: Briefing; Down to a Dime
LEAD: There was a public outcry earlier this year when the Interior Department imposed a dollar admission fee at the Statue of Liberty.
Congress quickly passed a bill to repeal the fee and, on June 20, the department set up donation boxes at the site for voluntary contributions.

LEAD: The number of baseball players filing for free agency grew to 47 yesterday when Bill Almon of the Mets, Steve Garvey of the San Diego Padres and Dennis Martinez of the Montreal Expos added themselves to the list.
Martinez, the former Baltimore star, made a strong comeback with an 11-4 record for the Expos.


Fending Off Burglar, Dog Is Killed in Dryer
LEAD: A 4-year-old chihuahua died trying to protect her owner's property when a burglar threw her into a dryer and turned it on, Tompkins County sheriff's deputies said.

British Army Stung by Tales of Brutality in Ranks
LEAD: After outbreaks of violence in two of its proudest regiments, the British Army is facing criticism that it has allowed a culture of brutality to develop in enlisted ranks.


A Pan Am Suitor Plans Huge Outlay
LEAD: One of the groups seeking control of Pan American Airways plans to spend $320 million for an initial restructuring program if it wins control, one of the investors said yesterday.

LEAD: He didn't get a promotion, but David Robinson got a big, a very big, raise yesterday.

LEAD:  A Group Effort


FINANCE BRIEFS
LEAD:  Debt


Moseley Set To Shed Unit
LEAD: The Moseley Holding Corporation said yesterday that it would quit the retail brokerage business and seek a buyer for that part of its operations because of mounting trading losses.


FUN AND COLOR BY MARC JACOBS
LEAD: The audience was yipping and yodeling along to the country and zydeco soundtrack as Marc Jacobs showed a spring collection Monday that was one of the season's most exuberant.


Adams's Goal Topples Flyers
LEAD: Greg Adams's second goal of the game with only 11 seconds left gave Vancouver a 4-3 victory over the slumping Philadelphia Flyers tonight, breaking the Canucks' seven-game streak without a victory.


College Football Notebook; Two Running Backs Who Are Making Big Gains
LEAD: Mike Gottfried, the head coach at Pitt, is not one to fuss.
He is indifferent to Craig Heyward's weight, although he suspects it may be more than the advertised 260 pounds, maybe as much as 275.

Film: 'Steel Dawn'
LEAD: EARLY in ''Steel Dawn,'' a mysterious fighting man (Patrick Swayze) arrives at a hardpressed frontier farm run by a beautiful widow (Lisa Niemi), who has a spunky little son (Brett Hool), who soon grows attached to the stranger.
No, the mysterious fighting man's name is not Shane; it is Nomad.
And it is not the Old West; it is the new post-nuclear-war world beloved of new movie makers.

LEAD: The conventional wisdom holds that the Pittsburgh Penguins will go as far as Mario Lemieux takes them.

BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 6, 1987
LEAD:  The  Markets


Iran-Contra Committees Approve the Final Report
LEAD: The Congressional committees on the Iran-contra affair approved a final report today concluding that President Reagan was responsible for allowing the normal processes of Government to be disregarded, committee members said.


A Cautious Approach to the Ice
LEAD: Anchoring almost every step with a grip on the boards, youngsters, many of them on the ice for the first time, slowly circumnavigated the Wollman Rink in Central Park.
The youngsters were part of a group of 200 public school students who were invited for a ceremony marking the opening for the season of the Wollman and the city's five other skating rinks.

Philip C. Katz
LEAD: The nation's oldest Medal of Honor winner, Philip C. Katz, who was awarded the medal for rescuing a wounded comrade under fire in World War I, died here on Oct. 29, a month short of his 100th birthday.

AIDS Memo Stirs Both Parties
LEAD: Democrats today released a memorandum purportedly from a Republican consultant, saying Republicans should exploit public fears to help their party in 1988.
The purported author, Charles Rund, a poll taker, vigorously denied that he had written it.


Army Defector Arrives in U.S.
LEAD: Pvt.
Wade E. Roberts, an American soldier who defected to the Soviet Union last April, arrived early today in the United States, where he faces charges of desertion, officials said.


Film: 'Slamdance,' With Tom Hulce
LEAD: WAYNE WANG, the gifted Chinese-American film maker (''Chan Is Missing,'' ''Dim Sum''), goes straight if quite gracefully to the bottom with his first mainstream movie, ''Slamdance,'' a Los Angeles-based tale of corruption and cover-up that's less interesting for its characters than for its fancy decor and images.


Rabid Calf Causes Shortage Of Vaccine in El Paso, Tex.
LEAD: Health officials said Wednesday that they used up the city's supply of rabies vaccine to inoculate more than 100 people who might have come in contact with a school farm's rabid calf.

LEAD: Representative Mario Biaggi was sentenced to 30 months in prison for taking an unlawful gratuity and obstructing justice.

Lebanese Begin a General Strike
LEAD: Lebanese began a general strike today to protest the 12-year-old civil war and the nation's economic crisis.


Deaver Hired to Influence Dole, Witness Says
LEAD: A former vice president of Trans World Airlines testified today that a few weeks after Michael K. Deaver left his top White House post in 1985, T.W.A. hired him as a lobbyist to ''make direct contact'' with Secretary of Transportation Elizabeth Hanford Dole.
Mr.
Deaver was a former White House deputy chief of staff.


Elsa de Brun Is Dead; Signed Art as Nuala
LEAD: Elsa de Brun, who painted under the Gaelic name of Nuala, died last night at her home in Manhattan.
She was 91 years old and had suffered from Alzheimer's disease.


Sports of The Times; WHERE FLUTIE BELONGS
LEAD: IN the fourth quarter of last Monday night's game, Ed (Too Tall) Jones deflected two of Phil Simms's passes as the Dallas Cowboys rallied for a 33-24 victory.
Too Tall was too much for the Giants' quarterback.
But as Doug Flutie watched television in his Natick, Mass. home, he shook his head.


Sports People; Slaney Set to Go
LEAD: When Mary Slaney begins her attempt to come back from an injury next Jan. 23 in the 2,000-meter run at the Pacific Northwest Bell indoor track meet in Portland, Ore., it will mark her first competitive race in more than two years.


Soybeans Up Sharply; Soviet Rumor a Factor
LEAD: Soybean oil and soybean meal futures soared at the Chicago Board of Trade today on rumors that the Soviet Union had bought a large quantity of American soybean meal.
Meal for December delivery jumped $6, to $183.60 a ton, off its high for the session of $186.50.

A COUP IS REPORTED IN TUNISIA
LEAD: President Habib Bourguibia was deposed today by his Prime Minister, Zine el Abidine Ben Ali, who named himself President of the North African nation of 7.4 million, the Tunis radio reported.


More Saurian Than Simian
LEAD: Another strange clue has been added to the mystery of what killed off the dinosaurs.
It seems that the air in Cretaceous times was 32 percent oxygen, half as much again as air today.
If the ponderous beasts were accustomed to inhaling such rich stuff, no wonder they perished when the air grew more rarefied.

LEAD:  N.H.L.
Red Wings 3, Whalers 1: Brent Ashton scored the go-ahead goal midway through the second period and Joe Kocur added a goal in the third last night as Detroit defeated Hartford, 3-1.
Greg Stefan turned back 28 shots for the Red Wings, who broke a four-game streak without a victory and moved to 6-5-2.

Senator Helms's Callousness Toward AIDS Victims
LEAD: ''We have got to call a spade a spade,'' said Senator Jesse Helms in offering an amendment to the fiscal 1988 appropriations bill for the Departments of Labor, Health and Human Services, and Education, ''and a perverted human being a perverted human being.'' New York City's Jobless Rate Rises While Jersey's Declines
LEAD: Unemployment in New York City rose to 5.8 percent in October, the regional office of the Federal Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.


Pension Ruling In Texaco Case
LEAD: A Federal bankruptcy judge ruled today that state employee pension boards holding Texaco stock could represent the company's equity shareholders committee as nonvoting, ex-officio members of the board.


N.I.T. Shifts To the Garden
LEAD: The Big Apple National Invitation Tournament's semifinal round, originally scheduled for Nassau Coliseum Nov. 27, has been shifted back to Madison Square Garden that night.
The move to Long Island originally was made because the Garden was holding the date for a possible rock concert, but the event did not materialize.

G.M. Solar Car Winner in Race
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation's experimental solar-powered car, the Sunraycer, has won the World Solar Challenge, a 1,950-mile race across the Australian continent.
The company said the Sunraycer averaged about 40 miles an hour for the five-and-a-half-day event and finished 600 miles in front of its nearest competitor.

New Exxon Wells
LEAD: The Exxon Corporation said it planned to increase its drilling activity in West Texas, with 350 new wells over two years.
Randall Meyer, the president of the nation's largest oil company, said Exxon was trying to gradually rebuild its drilling program after the 1986 price collapse.
While prices have ranged between $18 and $20 per 42-gallon barrel in recent weeks, they dipped below $10 a barrel last year.

LEAD: In the men's room of a small coffee shop, a mannish-looking woman peeks from inside a stall and sees a burly security guard nuzzling a young blond waiter.
These three will become central to the action of ''Blind Trust,'' an intelligent thriller by Yves Simoneau, a Canadian director, and the confusions of gender in the men's room give a clue that the story will resonate with tangled relationships and thwarted plans.

Argentina Gets Waiver For Emergency Loan
LEAD: Argentina yesterday was granted a a waiver from meeting economic performance targets set by the International Monetary Fund, Treasury and international monetary officials said. , The waiver would allow Argentina to receive a $500 million emergency loan from governments around the world.

Boulton's absence from his office.
Mr.
Boulton was 43 years old and had been suffering from AIDS, according to colleagues.

Instead, he called the game ''another learning process.

LEAD: A report in the Business People column of Business Day on Thursday, about General Electric's sale of assets of its venture capital operation, misidentified the company that arranged the financing.

CORRECTION
LEAD: An article in Business Day on Thursday about the International Business Machines Corporation's profit expectations incorrectly described the company's estimated relationship between revenue growth and earnings growth.
Revenues would need to grow 4 to 6 percent next year before each dollar of revenue would result in an additional dollar of profit, the company said.


With Prague, Glasnost Comes in a Fainter Echo
LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's advocacy of extensive change in the Soviet Union is finding an echo even in Czechoslovakia, where until recently the very word ''reform'' had been under unofficial but rigorous ban.


Persian Gulf Attack
LEAD: Damaged hull of the Panama-registered tanker Grand Wisdom after an Iranian rocket-grenade attack off Dubai.
No casualties were reported and a resulting fire was put out.
In an attempt to put new life into his peace mission, Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar of the United Nations has sent messages to Iran and Iraq asking them to send emissaries to New York to begin peace negotiations with him immediately.


U.S. Court Dismisses Charge On Iran-Contra Arms Dealer
LEAD: A Federal appeals court set aside a contempt citation today against an arms dealer who refused to give the special counsel, Lawrence E. Walsh, records of eight foreign companies involved in the Iran-contra affair.

Gay Culture Seminar
LEAD: A symposium on New York City gay and lesbian history and culture will be held Nov. 17 at the City University Graduate Center auditorium (lower level) at 33 West 42d Street.
The symposium is sponsored by the faculty Committee for Lesbian and Gay Studies at the school and will include a lecture on ''Creating Cultural Legacies'' and talks on the history of lesbians in Cherry Grove, Fire Island, and of relations between the state and New York City gay bars.

LEAD: A Federal judge dismissed a lawsuit today that contended the arbitrager Ivan F. Boesky was liable for investment losses suffered by two people because of his illegal insider trading.

Lebanon Strike Vow Issued
LEAD: Labor leaders vowed today to step up a two-day-old nationwide strike to protest runaway inflation, but some merchants and enterprises defied the stoppage, saying it was harmful to an already crippled economy.
Some grocers, butchers, vegetable vendors and larger businesses resumed work in Beirut and other cities.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Prison Term for Mother
LEAD: A woman was sentenced here today to four years in prison for leaving her 3-month-old twins unattended in a car where they died of heat stroke on a summer day in 1986.
The 26-year-old mother, Beverly Jean Ernst, was convicted of child endangerment in April.
According to testimony at the trial, Ms.
Ernst left Adam and Ashley in her car on the morning of July 20, 1986, when she went into a shop where her boyfriend lived and fell asleep with him.

David Starobin
LEAD: David Starobin, a guitarist and composer, is to present works by Michael Starobin, Schubert, Lukas Foss, Norma Beecroft and others tomorrow at 3 P.M. at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue.
He is to be joined by Patrick Mason, a baritone; Susan Palma, a flutist; Linda Moss Eddy, a violist, and Timothy Eddy, a cellist.


Dead Sturgeon Puts an End to Monster Tales in Washington State
LEAD: A 900-pound sturgeon in Bellevue after it was pulled from Lake Washington.
The 11-foot-long fish was found floating Thursday.
State officials estimated it was born sometime around the turn of the century and may have died of old age.
Tales have persisted of a monster in the lake that sometimes eats ducks.


Johnson Powers Lakers in Stretch
LEAD: Magic Johnson scored 10 of his 26 points in the fourth quarter, and A. C. Green added 21 tonight as the Los Angeles Lakers opened the defense of their championship with a 113-109 victory over the Seattle SuperSonics.

LEAD: As trading surged wildly in stock markets around the world in late October, American investment firms found that the already formidable job of settling trades in foreign stocks had become even more difficult.

Rhetoric vs. Reality In the Ginsburg Case
LEAD: The disclosure by President Reagan's nominee for the Supreme Court, Douglas H. Ginsburg, that he smoked marijuana in the 1960's and the 1970's has caught the President in one of the most difficult of political snares: the conflict between rhetoric and reality.

LEAD: David Robinson, the top pick in the 1987 National Basketball Association draft, signed a contract with the San Antonio Spurs yesterday that reportedly will pay him at least $24 million in eight years.


Analysts Differ On Gold Safety
LEAD: OCTOBER'S stock market plunge brought gold to center stage once more as individual investors and their advisers argue for and against it as an investment medium.
Gold has traditionally been considered a safe haven when there is turmoil in the financial world and expectations of rising inflation - and some advisers therefore believe that this is the time for investors to begin or augment a gold buying program.

LEAD: For ''Oil City Symphony,'' Circle in the Square (Downtown) has been transformed into a high school gymnasium, complete with basketball hoops and hardwood floor.

Dr. Henry Young
LEAD: Dr.
Henry Young, a physician who practiced in Manhattan for more than 50 years and was an assistant professor of medicine at New York Medical College, died of a heart attack Monday at his home in Bloomingburg, N.Y.
He was 74 years old.

'88 Growth Forecasts Cut
LEAD: The 49 economists surveyed monthly by Blue Chip Economic Indicators have lowered their consensus forecast for 1988 economic growth to 1.9 percent, from 2.8 percent in early October, Blue Chip said yesterday.

Judging the Judge, and the President
LEAD: By acknowledging that he has smoked marijuana, Douglas Ginsburg neither adds to nor subtracts from his qualifications for the Supreme Court.
Whether or not he now withdraws from consideration, the episode tells a great deal about the President.
Mr.
Reagan has been more interested in pushing politics and punishing opponents than in appointing judges of compelling merit.


In the Surreal World, Fashion Imitates Art
LEAD: Like Montague and Capulet, high art and fashion are not supposed to keep company.
Among people who see themselves as the guardians of high art, ''fashionable'' is the universal, boilerplated, multipurpose insult. ''Unfashionable,'' by contrast, is a brevet of integrity and can be conferred upon enterprises no matter how dingy.

Recital: Elly Ameling in Works of 18 Composers
LEAD: Elly Ameling is that certified rarity, a singer who knows what she does best and spends virtually an entire career refining a special talent.
Although the Dutch soprano has occasionally ventured afield (Ilia in Mozart's ''Idomeneo'' in the 1970's, programs of concert arias and, more recently, a misguided recording of American popular tunes), her gifts have been mostly spent on the song recital.

New-Look Knicks Open With Same Old Result
LEAD: The new-look Knicks delivered everything they promised tonight in the much-awaited debut of the Rick Pitino regime.
Relying largely on Pitino's pressure-defense style, they kept in check the likes of Isiah Thomas, Adrian Dantley and Bill Laimbeer, the all-star trio of the Detroit Pistons.
And they found themselves on the verge of achieving a surprise in their season opener.


Illegal Aliens Slowly Finding Path to Citizenship

'Death Wish 4'
There is oddly enough, a philosoph ical premise to ''Death Wish 4.'' ''Anyone connected to drugs deserves to die,'' says a rich man who wants Charles Bronson to wipe out all the drug lords in Los Angeles. ''I need a few days to think about it,'' Mr.
Bronson replies, as if he's a coy job applicant holding out for more money.

LEAD: Arnold Markle, the State's Attorney for New Haven since 1968 and the prosecutor of several members of the Black Panthers in the 1970's, died Thursday, apparently of a heart attack.

LEAD: The British financier Gerald Ronson was allowed today to remain free on bail of $:500,000, or $892,000, after being charged in a case arising from Guinness P.L.C.'s takeover of Distillers P.L.C., the police said.

Debt Plan Allowed In Placid Oil Case
LEAD: A Federal Bankruptcy Court judge has allowed the bank creditors of the Placid Oil Company, the Hunt brothers' company that owes $803 million, to file their own debt reorganization plan for the company.
But Judge Harold Abramson said the banks could not solicit bids without Placid Oil's support because it would drive down the bid price.

LEAD: A Manhattan grand jury indicted a Greenwich Village lawyer yesterday in the murder of his 6-year-old adopted daughter, who died Thursday of a brain hemorrhage and other injuries suffered last weekend in what authorities called a savage beating.
