BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 7, 1987
LEAD:  The Economy


NEWS SUMMARY SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 7, 1987
LEAD:  International 2-6


49ers Say No
LEAD: A trade last Tuesday between the San Francisco 49ers and the Seattle Seahawks has been voided because Dave Wyman, a linebacker who had been sent to the 49ers, was suffering from a chronic shoulder injury that prevented him from passing San Francisco's physical examination.


Financial Corporation Draws a Citicorp Offer
LEAD: Citicorp, the nation's largest bank holding company, has submitted an offer to acquire the Financial Corporation of America, the troubled operator of the nation's largest savings and loan institution, a spokesman for the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today.


Mbeki Renews Old Friendships
LEAD: Govan Mbeki, a leading figure in the African National Congress, reaching to accept the hand of a supporter yesterday in Port Elizabeth, South Africa.


New Stock Strategies Abroad
LEAD: In the wake of the October stock plunge that had a shattering effect on markets around the world, global money managers have been devising new strategies.


Obstacles to Budget Compromise: the Case of the Harrier Jet
LEAD: The word swept a Capitol Hill party Thursday celebrating the Marine Corps' birthday: Democratic and Republican leaders of the Armed Services Committees in both houses of Congress, meeting privately, were planning to end production of the corps' primary attack plane.

Hooker Gets Rest of Altman
LEAD: The Hooker Corporation, the Australian real estate developer that earlier this month bought a controlling interest in B. Altman &amp; Company, said yesterday that it had acquired the remaining equity.


Beene and Karan End Shows on High Note
LEAD: In a dazzling display of the art of dressmaking, Geoffrey Beene made the jump suit the newest fashion look.
Immediately after the Beene show at the Pierre, Donna Karan presented an ultra-feminine version of her sexy separates look in her Seventh Avenue showroom.
Her plunging neckline jackets, lace skirts and stretch fabric evening dresses give a new slant on provocative dressing.


TV: 'Kids Like These,' About Down's Syndrome
LEAD: The parents are told their newborn child is mentally retarded.
The signs include slanted eyes, simian skin creases, flabby muscle tone.
Using the term mongoloid, the doctor urges immediate institutionalization of the baby.
Later, a specialized nurse describes an ''early intervention'' program intended to help victims of Down's syndrome, a chromosomal accident that occurs in one out of 800 births.

Piano: Tcherepnin Program
LEAD: To commemorate the 10th anniversary of Alexander Tcherepnin's death, the Tcherepnin Society sponsored a program of the composer's piano music, performed by Bennett Lerner, Wednesday evening at Merkin Concert Hall.
Tcherepnin, born in St.
Petersburg in 1899, lived in Paris, Chicago and New York and spent time in the Far East, marrying a Chinese pianist, Lee Hsien Ming.

Tunisia's Premier Seizes Power, Declaring Bourguiba to Be Senile
LEAD: Prime Minister Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali took power in Tunisia today on grounds that Habib Bourguiba, its President for life, was too ill and senile to govern any longer.


Reserve Mobilization Begins
LEAD: About 34,000 members of the Army Reserve, National Guard and civilian employees were moving out this weekend for a two-week test of their ability to mobilize for war.
Mari M. Perrotti, spokeswoman for the 99th Army Reserve Command, based near Pittsburg, said the exercise would cover 12 states from Maine to Virginia.


A FEW IMPORTANT CHORES FOR THE SEASON
LEAD: LAST call to plant bulbs, especially tulips; use fertilizer at the base of planting holes and water bulbs if the ground seems dry.
Continue raking leaves and don't forget to use a bamboo rake or power blower to brush them off groundcovers such as myrtle and pachysandra; shake shrubs and young trees so leaves filter down to the ground; leave them there.


The Politician As Educator
LEAD: WHEN Robert F. Wagner Jr. was a young New York City Councilman at Large he suggested, only half jokingly, that a fire alarm be set off at 110 Livingston Street, the turn-of-the-century building in downtown Brooklyn that houses the city's Board of Education.
The offices would be emptied and the doors locked, and the school bureaucrats should never be allowed to return.

LEAD: BLANCHE DuBOIS is one of the most extraordinary creations of a playwright's art, and it is gratifying to report that Ellen Barry is offering an enlightening, lucid view of this most cherishable role.


NEW YORKERS, ETC.
LEAD: TRY to get Celso Gonzalez-Falla on a horse on Good Friday.
Try, but there's no way it's going to happen.
That's the one day of the year that the tax and securities lawyer, who commutes between New York and Texas, won't even consider riding.

LEAD: THE rare stamp department of Christie's/Robson Lowe, international auctioneers, conducted three sales of stamps and covers last month.
The sales, dominated by hard-to-find material that collectors seek, drew active floor and mail bidding which resulted in a $2,484,454 total for the 1,500 lots.

LEAD: LIMESTONE demons with wicked smiles decorate the landmark Beaux-Arts facade of the Ansonia Hotel on Broadway at West 73d Street.
The faces are fitting symbols of discord for this building, which has been a battleground for tenants and landlords for several decades.
Squabbles have revolved around rents, services and repairs, and now a possible conversion to a condominium.

GREAT NECK PLAZA SUES NASSAU RENT BOARD
LEAD: THE Village of Great Neck Plaza has filed suit against the Nassau County Rent Guidelines Board, accusing the board of discriminating against renters in a cooperative or condominium building.
The board has allowed owners of co-ops and condominiums who lease the apartment units to charge higher rents than landlords of other rental units.

NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, NOVEMBER 8, 1987

MODERNIZING ELECTRICAL WALL OUTLETS
LEAD: IN many older homes, electrical wall receptacles possess only two slots per outlet.
Modern three-slot receptacles, which have a semicircular hole centered beneath each pair of slots, are more convenient.
And because they provide better grounding for plug-in appliances, they are safer.


Talking: Co-ops; Updating Clauses On Usage
LEAD: CONTROL of New York City co-ops -who lives in the apartments and how they are used - has long been a prime concern for tenant-shareholders.

THE VIEW FROM AXE CASTLE: OPTIMISTIC
LEAD: DESPITE the tumult on Wall Street, the Axe Castle in Tarrytown is not under seige.
In the Great Hall, beneath its beautiful rose window, the research department is quietly at work.
And it is business as usual in the formal ballroom below, now used by the Axe computer department.
The 18th-century Oak Room, unchanged since it was brought intact from a Paris mansion, is being readied for a meeting.

Roommates 101: Course of Adjustment
LEAD: THIS FALL there is at least one pair of happy freshmen roommates at Brandeis University in Waltham, Mass. ''It was a perfect match,'' said Melissa Telzer, a New Yorker, about her roommate from Mount Vernon, N.Y. ''We were both assistant managers at Benetton stores.
We both enjoy going to parties and sleeping late.


CORRECTION
LEAD: An essay on the Opinion page on Oct. 25 about the radio drama ''War of the Worlds'' misstated the year it was first broadcast.
It was 1938.


Music: Leinsdorf Offers Britten and Debussy
LEAD: BOTH ends of the New York Philharmonic's Friday night concert at Avery Fisher Hall brought us to the edge of the sea.
But we were shown it from very different sides.
People share equal billing in Britten's ''Peter Grimes'' (we heard the Passacaglia and the four ''Sea Interludes'').
Debussy's ''La Mer'' rises beyond human passions and depicts the sea itself.

Canadian Wins Grand Prix
LEAD: The $50,000 Mercedes Grand Prix, the first of the two major jumping competitions at the National Horse Show this weekend, was captured by Ian Millar of the Canadian equestrian team last night on his towering 11-year-old Belgian-bred gelding, Big Ben.
The pair staged a repeat performance of their victory in this event here last year.


BISTRO MAESTROS
LEAD: THE FRENCH BISTRO - A small, traditional family restaurant - has become synonymous with hearty, no-nonsense food.
Celeri remoulade, giant bowls of herring in cream, terrines of gamey pates, french fries and grilled steak, hearty cassoulets, beef stewed in red wine, chocolate mousse and tarte Tatin are served in an equally unpretentious atmosphere.

Appeals Court Restricts Immunity For Congressmen on Defamation
LEAD: A Federal appeals court panel has ruled that a member of Congress may be sued for defamatory statements made in a letter to the executive branch even if considers the comments part of his official duties.


UPWARD PRESSURE ON THE U.S. MINIMUM WAGE
LEAD: SINCE 1981, the Federal minimum wage has been frozen at $3.35 an hour, which translates to an annual income of less than $7,000.
Fearing inflation and opposing Government encroachment on the marketplace, the Reagan Administration has been dead set against increasing the figure.


Alabama Upsets L.S.U.
LEAD: Bobby Humphrey ran for 161 yards and a touchdown to lead Alabama to a 22-10 upset of previously unbeaten Louisiana State tonight.


Science Writing
LEAD:  To the Editor:


Glittering Creatures Great and Small
LEAD: SNAKES, BUTTERFLIES and tigers - encrusted with jewels, carved of stone or crafted in gold - coexist handsomely in ''Antique Animal Jewelry: 1700-1940,'' at the gallery of J. Mavec, 52 East 76th Street.
The exhibition, which opens Wednesday, will be on view through Nov. 21.


A REPORTER'S REPORTER
LEAD: PIERRE-MARIE DOUTRELANT DIED earlier this year while jogging in the Bois de Boulogne, in Paris.
He was 46 years old, left a wife and a couple of kids, and may have been the best wine journalist of our time.


Broadcast TV
LEAD: A heady assortment of films awaits buffs this week - from more recent fare such as ''Altered States'' to long-absent classics like ''The Lost Weekend'' and ''La Dolce Vita.''


Q AND A
LEAD: Interhostel  Question: I understand there is an organization called Interhostel that is similar to Elderhostel but specializes in overseas programs.
How can I get its catalogue? - E. E. O., Chevy Chase, Md.
Answer: Both Interhostel and Elderhostel offer travel and educational programs for older adults.

Democrats Stress Differences in Final Push in Iowa
LEAD: Gathering here in the names of Thomas Jefferson and Andrew Jackson, Iowa's Democrats today celebrated their party's six Presidential candidates and the happy news that in just 94 days, campaigning for one of democracy's most unusual exercises would be over.


The Streaks Are Over
LEAD: Bergen Catholic, which had been unbeaten and unscored upon in nine games since Thanksgiving Day last year, saw both streaks end yesterday in Ridgewood.

Gorbachev Speech: Playing to a Wary Public
LEAD: MIKHAIL S. GORBACHEV gave a politician's speech last week on the troublesome topic of his country's history.
It did not play very well in the West, where many expected a historian's speech, but it was probably not intended to.
It was a speech for domestic consumption, crafted for a society with a willful reverence for its version of the past.


Ben Itkin
LEAD: Ben Itkin, a co-founder and past president of Itkin Brothers Inc., a distributor of office furniture, died Friday at the Miami Heart Institute after heart surgery.
He was 78 years old and lived in Palm Beach, Fla., and Hillsdale, N.Y.


MODERNIZING ELECTRICAL WALL OUTLETS
LEAD: IN many older homes, electrical wall receptacles possess only two slots per outlet.
Modern three-slot receptacles, which have a semicircular hole centered beneath each pair of slots, are more convenient.
And because they provide better grounding for plug-in appliances, they are safer.


CARLUCCI'S FIRST PROBLEM IS A PARALYZED MILITARY BUDGET
LEAD: WHEN Frank C. Carlucci succeeds Caspar W. Weinberger as Defense Secretary, his most pressing problem will be to untangle the budgetary gridlock that has practically immobilized the Pentagon's planning, say senior officials in the Administration and Congress.

Where to Watch the Great Whales
LEAD: In the mid-19th century, when the slaughter of the California gray whale was in full swing, whalers called them ''devil fish.'' Like monsters sent straight from hell, the 40-ton creatures would charge straight down the muzzle of a harpoon gun and, even mortally wounded from harpoons, defend their young until their last breath, holing many a stout whaling boat with their huge bodies.


Paving a Way for Train Tunnel Repairs
LEAD: Workers positioning metal plates at the intersection of Park Avenue and 57th Street.
The plates were being installed to allow repairs to be made on Metro-North train tunnel below, while still allowing traffic to use the avenue.
As each block is completed, repair crews will move one block further north, working their way to 96th Street.


SOVIET YOUTH UNIT SEEKS TO REIN IN POLITICAL GROUPS
LEAD: Officials of the Komsomol, the 40-million member youth arm of the Soviet Communist Party, have drafted a proposal to assert control over independent political groups that have sprung up in answer to Mikhail S. Gorbachev's call for a measure of democracy.


THE COMBUSTIBLE LAWRENCE, STILL SMOLDERING
LEAD: WHEN ''Women in Love'' was first published in 1920, it was the book of a man who had been burned. ''The Rainbow,'' Lawrence's previous novel, was suppressed by the Government in 1915 and his frightened publisher actually incinerated, or cremated it.
Lawrence chopped ''Women in Love'' in a last-minute attempt to make it less combustible and it was riddled with errors of transcription as well.

Violin: Grigory Zhislin
LEAD: THIS season, Town Hall and Classical Artists International have been co-sponsoring a series of concerts entitled Russian Nights, featuring prominent Soviet musicians unfamiliar to American audiences.
The first installment came last month with a recital by Vladimir Krainev, a pianist, and the second concert took place Friday evening with the debut of Grigory Zhislin, a violinist.

LEAD:  CHRISTINA KATERINA  And the Time She Quit the Family.
By Patricia Lee Gauch.
Illustrated by Elise Primavera.
Unpaged.
New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $12.95. (Ages 5 to 9)


Another Face Of Argentina
LEAD: ARGENTINA is a lot more than Buenos Aires, its cosmopolitan capital.
Its million square miles stretch from the Tropic of Capricorn almost to the Antarctic, and from the Atlantic deep into the Andes.
The two-hour air journey from Buenos Aires to Salta, where the mountains meet the tropics, is a voyage into a different geography, climate and culture.

Jacqueline Anne Leavitt to Lieut.
Scott Latham Stafford, U.S.N., has been announced by Dr. and Mrs.
Frederick Carlton Leavitt of Washington and York Beach, Me., parents of the bride-to-be.
Her fiance is the son of Jim Stafford of Seattle and the late Alice Stafford.


Cutting At the Core
LEAD:  To the Sports Editor:


Black Quarterbacks Find A Smoother Path to the Pros
LEAD: ONCE the effects of pro football's recent power struggle between the owners and the players subside and a new National Football League champion is crowned, the current season will most likely be remembered for strikeball, as well as the sudden demise of the Giants.
But in future years it might also be remembered as the season when pro football showed signs of overcoming its most lingering phobia: apprehension over the use of the black quarterback.


Schools in Chicago Are Called the Worst By Education Chief
LEAD: Education Secretary William J. Bennett says Chicago's public schools are the worst in the nation and parents should consider private schools for their children.


CRIME
LEAD: If THE BLACK DAHLIA by James Ellroy (Mysterious Press, $16.95) were a play, it would be reviewed as overwritten, overdirected, overproduced and overwrought.
It is a big, sprawling novel about the relationship of two cops - Bucky Bleichert and Lee Blanchard -in the 1940's.
Both were highly regarded professional boxers before entering the Los Angeles Police Department.


18-Year-Old Man Is Arrested In Slayings of Three in Bronx
LEAD: An 18-year-old man has been arrested and charged in the slayings of three men at a building in the South Bronx, the police said yesterday.

Connor's own battle against AI

Reagan Asks Filipino Military To Back Aquino Government

Alvin Dewey Dies; Investigated Killings Depicted by Capote
LEAD: Alvin A. Dewey, chief investigator of the 1959 killings chronicled in the book and movie ''In Cold Blood,'' died Friday at a hospital here after suffering a stroke at his home.
He was 75 years old.


Midwood Rallies, 20-19
LEAD: Chris Davila scored two of his three touchdowns in the fourth quarter as Midwood rallied yesterday to beat South Shore, 20-19, in a game that broke a first-place tie in the Public School Athletic League's Brooklyn A Division I. Midwood's record is now 7-1, and it has a berth in the playoffs that start in two weeks.


What Happened to The Market?
LEAD: ON BLACK MONDAY, crash was the word most frequently used at first to describe the 508-point drop in the Dow Jones industrial average that occurred Oct. 19, 1987, a day that many investors think will live in infirmity.
Donald T. Regan, former Treasury Secretary, called C-Day ''black and blue Monday,'' a nice play on the battered image of ''black and blue'' with the traditional bad-news sense of ''black  [ whatever ]  day'' and the don't-want-to-go-back-to-work sense of ''blue Monday.

Jet Hijacking Suspect Said He Feared Mafia
LEAD: A man who took control of an Air Canada jetliner here for three and a half hours Friday before surrendering to the authorities is being held at the city jail on charges of attempted hijacking, a spokesman for the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today.


Spain
LEAD: To the Editor: According to the letter about Spain on Aug. 30, there is ''nothing'' doing in Madrid, Cordoba, Granada, Seville or the Costa del Sol.
The writer compiled a long list of grievances during a short stay.
Not only did the Spaniards speak Spanish, they closed a national monument on the flimsy pretext that a national election was being held that day.


Army Worker's $8.70 Gadget Could Save $6.3 Million a Year
LEAD: A civilian who works at a National Guard base has created a device that could save the Army more than $6 million a year, military officials say.


College Students Take Up Cause of Homeless
LEAD: College students across the country are attending forums, signing petitions and staying outside in sleeping bags in an effort to focus college campuses on the plight of the homeless.


New &amp; Noteworthy
LEAD:  GREAT AND DESPERATE CURES: The Rise and Decline of Psychosurgery and Other Radical Treatments for Mental Illness, by Elliot S. Valenstein. (Basic Books, $10.95.) In 1949, Egas Moniz, a Portuguese neurology professor, won the Nobel Prize for helping to invent the prefrontal lobotomy, an operation that became so popular as a treament for mental illness that it was sometimes performed as an office procedure, using an ice pick thrust through the bony socket behind the eyeball.


STUFF AS DREAMS ARE MADE ON
LEAD: GUESTS at the recent opening of the ''Fashion and Surrealism'' show at the Fashion Institute of Technology really dressed for the occasion.
Forget Fendi.
Never mind Lagerfeld.
Lacroix?
No way.


NONFICTION
LEAD:  WHITTLE: The True Story.
By John Golley with Sir Frank Whittle. (Smithsonian Institution, $24.95.) Frank Whittle, the Englishman who fathered the jet engine, is to airplanes as Robert Fulton was to ships: he made them less glamorous but a lot faster and more reliable.
Born in Coventry in 1907 to a working-class family, he joined the Royal Air Force at the age of 16 in the hope of bettering his prospects.


Japanese Leader Urges U.S. to Reduce Deficit
LEAD: Noboru Takeshita, Japan's new Prime Minister, urged the Reagan Administration and Congress today to move quickly to reduce the United States budget deficit.

Knussen's one-act opera, ''Where the Wild Things Are,'' is receiving its New York stage premiere (it has previously been heard in concert at the New York Philharmonic, conducted by Zubin Mehta), the Philharmonic will be introducing ''Ringed by the Flat Horizon,'' the first orchestral work by George


SINGLES HAVE 2 ROLES
LEAD: I KNEW that becoming single midway through my life would change my economic and social status, but I was not prepared for the root-deep shake-up it would be to my gender identification.


MEDICINE IS SUFFERING FROM CHANGES
LEAD: I am writing to comment on the article ''Decline in Students at Medical Schools'' that appeared Oct. 4.
As a board-certified family practice physician of 25 years, I have seen the changes occurring in medicine that are deterring the best students of the best colleges from choosing medicine as a lifelong profession.


Protecting Plants from the Inside Out
LEAD: THE appearance of such desirable crop traits as disease resistance was once a very gradual process, governed by the laws of natural selection and aided, perhaps, by tedious selective breeding by farmers.
Now agricultural scientists are doing in the laboratory in a matter of days or weeks, what once took years.

Giant Lobster Is Liberated
LEAD: A 22-pound lobster escaped the fate of many lobsters when an Alaskan doctor paid to have it taken from Anchorage to Maine and set free in the Atlantic.

LEAD: The Brooklyn Army Terminal, completed as World War I drew to an end, served the Army in World War II and the Korean War.

RAIDING THE TITANIC
LEAD: Senator William Alden Smith may not have known that a ship's ''bow'' is different from a ship's ''head,'' but William F. Buckley Jr. apparently does not know that a ship's bulkheads are different from a ship's watertight doors.

Next Week; Will Free Agents Be Signed in Baseball?
LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036.
Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number.
We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

Breen, a community-education specialist with the Westchester chapter of the National Council on Alcoholism and Other Drug Addictions. ''They believe that they are good kids, and then cross their fingers when they go out to a party.

MOVIES
LEAD:  Tai-Pan  Starring Bryan Brown, Joan Chen, John Stanton. 1986.
Vestron Video. 127 minutes. $79.98. ''Tai-Pan,'' a misguided film epic set in the early 19th century, attempts to recount British maneuverings in the China trade and the seizure of Hong Kong.
Based on James Clavell's best-selling novel, the movie offers a somnolent story notable only for its lethal concentration of swaggering merchants and sniveling ingenues.


The Litigious Groves of Academe
LEAD: AT THE TRIAL, Shyamala Rajender had to endure what she calls ''a pack of lies'' hurled at her by the University of Minnesota, where she used to teach chemistry. ''They said I was not a good teacher, that I was not a good researcher, that I didn't compare with any of the bright stars in the department,'' she recalled, the anger barely veiled in her voice after more than a decade of grievance procedures and litigation that finally forced the university to grant her tenure.


Postings: East Bronx Colony; 11 Single-Family Homes
LEAD: A new development of 11 single-family homes, called the Estates at Country Club, has just been opened near Eastchester Bay in the East Bronx by Ruffalo Associates.
The homes are along Country Club Road north of the Throgs Neck Bridge.


Signs of Child Abuse, and How to Get Aid
LEAD: State and city officials urge anyone who suspects that a child has been abused or neglected, or is in risk of such mistreatment, to report the suspicions immediately to one of three special telephone hot lines that have been set up specifically to respond to child-abuse reports.


WHAT HAS HAPPENED TO BEST FRIENDS?
LEAD: RECENTLY I was invited to lunch by a new friend, Fran.
The invitation was for the same day I planned to visit my best friend, Judy.
Judy lives in a fourth-floor walk-up in the Bronx.
She had had surgery a few weeks ago, and needed help with shopping.
When I declined the invitation, and told Fran why, she stared at me, surprised.


THE DARK PLAYGROUND
LEAD: By surrendering - even for one dark hour - to the powerlessness from which his maleness is likely to protect him, Daniel Voll has shown unusual sensitivity.
Willingly descending into his friend's pain, humiliation and vulnerability to understand it from within is an act of profound caring that indeed surpasses 1980's rhetoric.

A Widening Pattern of Abuse Exemplified in Steinberg Case
LEAD: For more than a decade, friends and police investigators say, Joel B. Steinberg physically and emotionally abused his lover, Hedda Nussbaum.
And in that time, they say, a woman who once was an intelligent and effective editor and author seemed to lose all self-respect and become unable to extricate or defend herself.

LEAD:  The Left-Handed Gun  With Paul Newman, directed by Arthur Penn. 1958.
Warner Home Video. 102 minutes. $19.98.
If you think a movie starring Paul Newman and directed by Arthur Penn can't be all bad, you don't remember ''The Left-Handed Gun,'' which came and went in 1958 and, like the bad guys in westerns, now returns to put a new generation to sleep.

MODERNIZING ELECTRICAL WALL OUTLETS
LEAD: IN many older homes, electrical wall receptacles possess only two slots per outlet.
Modern three-slot receptacles, which have a semicircular hole centered beneath each pair of slots, are more convenient.
And because they provide better grounding for plug-in appliances, they are safer.


Nervous Allies Fear a Leadership Gap in America
LEAD: IT often falls to the British to say most forthrightly what is on the minds of Europeans when they worry about the United States.
Last week in London, Nigel Lawson, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, said it was imperative for the health of the world economy that America slash its huge budget deficit and raise taxes.

Returned From the Brink of Extinction
LEAD: By the time large-scale commercial whaling ended in the early part of this century, gray whales had been hunted almost out of existence. ''Twice, the population was thought to be extinct,'' said Don Wilkie, director of the aquarium-museum at the Scripps Institution of Oceanography at La Jolla, Calif.


Jazz/Pop
LEAD: Henry Butler, a pianist from New Orleans, will be reunited with one of his teachers and inspirations this week at Sweet Basil.
The teacher is Alvin Batiste, one of the most distinctive and virtuosic modern jazz clarinetists.
Mr.
Batiste, an early associate of Ornette Coleman, is a player who has been heard too infrequently in New York.

Some, like Matt Sodl, the senior defensive end, were crying.

William B. Beam
LEAD: William B. Beam, a retired executive vice president of the American Express International Banking Corporation, died of kidney failure Tuesday at Baylor Hospital in Dallas.
He was 62 years old and lived in Dallas and Swiftwater, Pa.
Until 1985, he also lived in Manhattan.


DEMOCRATS SCORE UPSETS
LEAD: SOMETIMES it is the winners who proclaim, ''Wait till next year.'' Certainly that was the underlying gleeful tone of New York State Democratic leaders last week as they savored upset victories in important city and county elections and declared that the results boded well for Democrats nationally in the 1988 elections.

Others stick to the fingers, and sometimes in the throat.

Spot Checks For Components
LEAD: ALARMED BY THE present perturbation of the economy, many circumspect audiophiles have postponed planned purchases.
To be sure, the more passionate music lovers usually manage to persuade themselves that buying stereo equipment falls into the same budgetary bracket as rent and groceries.
But some who have toyed with the notion of revamping their entire sound system are now more likely to think in terms of selective updating -changing only those components that have clearly outlived their allotted span.

LEAD: Saying that he would ''much rather be here talking about arms control or the stock market crash,'' Senator Albert Gore Jr. volunteered at a state convention in Miami yesterday that he had occasionally smoked marijuana as a student and as a soldier in Vietnam.

Last week, West Germany buckled to American pressure and cut interest rates, helping American banks to cut theirs.


France's Past Cast in Wax
LEAD: AMID the impatient traffic, waves of pedestrians, overflowing cafes, multi-screen cinemas and pasta and pizza parlors of the Boulevard Montmartre in Paris lies a tiny building of rococo splendor that is one of the oldest wax museums in Europe.
Since its founding in 1882, the museum has closed its doors just once - on the day the Germans occupied Paris.

FICTION
LEAD:  BLACK SWAN.
By Christopher Hope.
Illustrated by Gillian Barlow. (Harper &amp; Row, $10.95.) This moving, lyrical novel, the author's fourth, is set in South Africa in 1965.
Its hero, 17-year-old Lucky, is an idiot savant who lives with his adoptive grandmother in a black township.
The boy is able to mimic perfectly the voices and manners of movie and radio personalities, but defies all outside attempts to pull him out of his dream world.

LEAD: The lawyer for a union leader charged with 12 others in a bribery case faced the problem of countering secretly recorded tapes portraying the defendants as thugs.

ISRAELIS SEEM AMBIVALENT ON VILENCE IN DOMESTIC WAR
LEAD: THERE is a war going on here.
It is an intercommunal war between Israelis and Palestinians.
In Lebanon a similar war between ethnic communities has resulted in the destruction of buildings and whole cities, which makes it easy to detect.
But in Israel the Government and its security force are strong, the lid is more tightly sealed, and so, day to day, the war is harder to see.

LEAD: A DECISION by a Federal District Court judge that the North Babylon School District must reschedule its annual date of graduation is being appealed by the district, which wants to maintain the tradition of holding graduation exercises on Saturday morning.

A Newsman In Divinity School
LEAD: IN THE first days of the 1985-86 school year at Harvard, the course called ''World Religions, Diversity and Dialogue'' was so popular that all the seats were taken and some students were sitting cross-legged on the floor of a great lecture hall.
With two hands, the professor pushed her blonde hair behind her ears and made a statement that was to reverberate in my mind for the rest of the school year.


BEYOND THE MALL: SUBURBS EVOLVING INTO 'OUTER CITIES'
LEAD: IT happened incrementally, and for a long time few realized the magnitude and import of what was going on.
But over the last quarter-century and especially in the last decade, the American metropolis has been transformed into something new and different.
Suburbs, once dependent on the central city, have metamorphosed into vast, glittering, independent ''outer cities'' that rival and often surpass the traditional big-city downtowns as centers of economic power and vitality.

A CIVILIAN RECALLS HIS 'GOOD WAR'
LEAD: IT was my examination for the draft in 1940 that saved my life - just as that ceremony led to the opposite outcome for so many of my generation.
My chest X-ray revealed advanced tuberculosis, and the news that there were to be more germs than Germans in my future.
Being infected in both lungs I was considered unlikely to recover -a bit of trivia not revealed to me at the time.


Savoring the Distinctiveness of Korean Art
LEAD: THE WEST HAS LONG been familiar with the art of China and Japan, but Korean art remained relatively unknown until the mid-1970's.
Viewed as a mere imitation of its two neighbors, the culture was generally overlooked.
One effort to correct this situation is an exhibition of 100 works - ''From the Land of Morning Calm: Korean Art at the Brooklyn Museum.


WHAT'S NEW IN AGRICULTURAL BIOTECHNOLOGY
LEAD: THE first wave of products stemming from the biotechnology revolution focused mainly on human health care.
But now agricultural biotechnology - the genetic manipulation of crop plants and farm animals - is blossoming as never before.
True, only a few products of genetic engineering are on the market, including vaccines to prevent diseases in calves and piglets.

Goetz, Mr.

LEAD: Verification of the absence of mobile missiles such as the SS-20 is impossible (''Verification: Will It Work?'' by David Aaron, Oct. 11).
Not just difficult - impossible.
The reason is simple.
No one in the West knows how many were produced or are being produced or how many assembly points and subcontractors are involved.

LEAD: Advocates of change in China won a solid victory at its 13th Congress of the Communist Party, but the balance between them and more cautious leaders has been carefully preserved, according to a number of academic specialists on China.


Spain
LEAD: To the Editor: I go to Spain - and only to Spain - three times a year.
And I do so because I love the Spanish people and their culture.


About Cars; Mazda Adds Zip With GTX
LEAD: THE letters about what is right and wrong with today's automobile continue to flow in.
It has been a month since that column ran, and the torrent has slowed to a trickle, two to three letters a day now.
But it is obvious that people across the country have some definite ideas about what they are not getting in the way of dandy transportation.


Koreans View Their Election With Hope - and Cynicism
LEAD: SOUTH KOREANS are enjoying a novel sensation: being courted by politicians eager for their votes.
As campaigning accelerates for next month's election, their first chance in 16 years to vote directly for a president, hundreds of thousands of Koreans are turning out at the candidates' rallies.

BRODSKY'S NOBEL: WHAT THE APPLAUSE WAS ABOUT
LEAD: THERE was applause in Stockholm when Joseph Brodsky was named the winner of this year's Nobel Prize in Literature.
There probably always is at these occasions, since applause is what they are all about, but this particular outbreak of handclaps was reported to have been more animated and partisan than usual.


Stay Out of My Head
LEAD: Two million times a year, American citizens are subjected to ''lie-detector'' tests.
This explosion of the use of machines that measure nervousness (and that fail to catch the cool, practiced liar) is the most blatant intrusion into personal freedom in this country today.

LEAD: Dwayne Downing returned an interception 38 yards for a touchdown and Blair Thomas ran 58 yards for another score today as Penn State defeated Maryland for the 23d consecutive season, 21-16.


Shoppers Shrug Off Market Turmoil
LEAD: Consumers don't seem too worried about the general state of the economy, to judge from the first indicators of their sentiments since the stock market collapse.
Polls produced mixed, somewhat puzzling responses, but none of them seemed to portend a widespread movement to swear off spending.
A similar reading emerged from the sales indicators.

WHERE TO BUY BOOKS
LEAD: IT'S the time of year when I start feeling sorry for the man from United Parcel Service.
Almost daily he has to lug an armload of coffee-table sized photography books, still warm from the presses, into my apartment.
It's getting close to Christmas, which means (to book publishers, at least) that it is a grand time for luxurious, eye-catching books.


WHO SHOULD BE THE M.V.P.'S IN BASEBALL?
LEAD: Year after year the selection of baseball's most valuable players is an almost arbitrary choice between two players equally worthy of the award - one seemingly deserving on the basis of statistical achievement, the other for leadership of a pennant winning ball club.
Why not establish a new annual award to honor the ''Slugger of the Year'' in each league?

LEAD: OPERA IS DRAMA, AND, AS JOSEPH KER-man argued more than 30 years ago in his provocative ''Opera as Drama,'' the composer is the dramatist.
That is still one of the trickiest truths of opera to understand.

What does it mean that the composer is the dramatist?

TAKE POWER LINES OUT OF NATURE'S WAY
LEAD: On Oct. 11 you printed an article entitled ''Criticism for Utility Follows Snowfall.'' Year after year, the lives of thousands of Connecticut residents are disrupted when storms result in the loss of electric power.
These incidents are not ''acts of God.'' They are exacerbated by the failure of the utility companies to bury power and telephone lines.

WHAT'S DOING IN AUSTIN
LEAD: Like an oasis in Texas, Austin rises green and lush between the swamps of Houston and dusty plains of West Texas.
Its hills and mesas buck and ripple along the Balcones geologic fault, which rises from the south near San Antonio and reaches heights of 300 feet or more just north of Austin.
From the cliffs and upper slopes of the hills, with hawks wheeling high overhead, one can look down on two major lakes created from the Colorado River as it snakes its way through the city and countryside.

Rock Grows Up, Gracefully And Otherwise
LEAD: SEVEN YEARS AGO I ATTENDED a concert by the late blues giant Muddy Waters that forever changed my assumption that rock music made by musicians over 50 could only look foolish.
Mr.
Waters, then 66, looked every day of his age.
But when he barked out such bump-and-grind blues classics as ''I'm Your Hoochie Coochie Man'' and ''Got My Mojo Working,'' the singer-guitarist exuded a gruff charisma that was commandingly ferocious.

The Teen Years: Time of Mixed Messages
LEAD: THEY ARE the children of the children of the 60's, growing up in an age when much of what seemed outrageous then is commonplace.
Yet in many ways, today's teen-agers are having to sort through an ambiguous and contested legacy.
The sexual revolution in America bequeathed them a social code that is explicit yet no longer liberated, and an atmosphere in which adolescents are scrutinized more publicly than ever before, yet given little guidance by the adults they must answer to.

Bear Seized at Private Club
LEAD: The police seized a 400-pound bear after learning that customers at a private club were being encouraged to pay $5 to wrestle with the bear.
The police intervened Thursday night at Ms.
Kitty's after Toby, a defanged brown bear, had wrestled his first match, officials said.
No one was hurt.
The bear's owner, Burlie Webb of Hot Springs, Ark., was charged with one count of illegal exhibition of a wild or exotic animal.

FICTION
LEAD:  OCCUPATION.
By John Toland. (Doubleday, $19.95.) ''In war,'' Omar Bradley wrote, ''there is no second prize for the runner-up.'' But what about Japan?
Maybe the American occupation at the end of World War II wasn't a prize.
But it began a political and social revolution that made Japan the economic power it is today.


What Do People Want, Anyway?
LEAD: THE Campbell Soup Company, like most consumer products companies, has always asked its customers lots of questions.
Last year alone, its field researchers contacted close to 110,000 people to talk about food - taste, preparation, nutritional value, the works.
On the basis of what they said, Campbell changed the seasonings in five Le Menu dinners and introduced a line of low-salt soups called, appropriately enough, Special Request.

Careers and lives are at stake.
As one suspects, the drug itself has damaging side effects - the ''downside'' of the title.

Dollars for Housing
LEAD: A total of $1.4 million for housing for the homeless has been awarded to three nonprofit organizations in Westchester and will be used to help create apartments for 26 families and a communal house for five individuals.
The money came from the New York State Homeless Housing Assistance Program, which gave $20 million for 24 projects across the state.

Headliners; On Stage
LEAD: What theater lovers these New Yorkers be!
The New York Shakespeare Festival will present all 36 plays of William Shakespeare in a six-year-long, $33 million series, Joseph Papp, the festival producer, announced last week.
They will be performed by an all-American company, including such stars as Meryl Streep, James Earl Jones, Robert De Niro, Raul Julia and Kevin Kline, who honed their craft in the Shakespeare festival at one time or another during its 34-year history.


A Lost World Interred in Berlin
LEAD: BEFORE World War II, Berlin ranked among the great cities of the world, and many images from that time are familiar to us: the grandeur of Unter den Linden, the cosmopolitan elegance of the Hotel Adlon, the brimming activity of Potsdamer Platz and Alexanderplatz.
But these places were destroyed, surviving today only in photographs that scarcely represent their grand subjects.

How O'Keeffe Painted Hymns to Body and Spirit
LEAD: THE GEORGIA O'KEEFFE CENTENNIAL exhibition at the National Gallery of Art is an attempt to allow the work of one of America's best- known artists to speak for itself.
The 10 galleries devoted to 120 of her works offer no meditations on the artist's glamour and theatricality, on her love affairs with Alfred Stieglitz and the Southwest, or on her particular blend of sensuality and abruptness, exhibitionism and reclusiveness.

The Big Dig
LEAD: THE LEGENDARY PROJECT, TO construct a tunnel beneath the English Channel, dates to 1881, the most recent effort having been aborted in 1974.
This year, however, a most auspicious beginning has been made.
Photographed above, the access shaft at Sangatte - 55 meters across, 62 meters deep (about 180 by 200 feet) - on the French side of the channel, has solved a problem that dogged engineers in the past.

LEAD: ALONG with its many other treasures, Hong Kong is the home of the Tai Ping carpet, already as famous in only 30 years as some of those precious floor coverings that came out of pre-revolutionary China.
The hand-woven carpets of Tai Ping, made by Hong Kong Manufacturers Ltd., in the New Territories ''new town'' of Tai Po, about 25 miles north of Kowloon, are to be found in Buckingham Palace, Windsor Castle, the headquarters of the United Nations in Geneva, the Ritz Hotel in London, the Four Seasons Hotel in Philadelphia and the Loews Regency Hotel in Manhattan, the Los Angeles Music

LEAD: Just imagine what Mikhail Gorbachev's predecessors would have made of the stock market fall.
Capitalism's rottenness is now painfully obvious, they would have proclaimed.
Yet, as the world's Marxist-Leninists gathered in Moscow to commemorate the revolution that brought them to power 70 years ago, no such ideas were put forward.

Moore P. Huffman
LEAD: Moore P. Huffman, a retired partner of Morgan Stanley &amp; Company, investment bankers, died of a heart attack Oct. 31 at his home in Woody Creek, Colo.
A former resident of Bedford Hills, N.Y., and of Aspen, Colo., he was 77 years old.


Dance: Joffrey Recasts 'Three Preludes'
LEAD: EVERY ballet company repertory needs a slight romantic pas de deux, and the Joffrey Ballet has one in Ben Stevenson's ''Three Preludes,'' a crowd-pleaser created in 1969 and acquired this year by the company, which presented it with a new cast on Thursday at City Center.
Set to piano music by Rachmaninoff that was performed here by Stanley Babin, ''Three Preludes'' offers a pastel vision of a studio flirtation between two young dancers and its extension into ballet partnering.

Jail Riot Quelled in Brussels
LEAD: The police restored order at a prison in Brussels today after 50 people were injured in rioting by inmates, officials said.
A police spokesman said about 100 inmates at the Forest Prison smashed furniture and lit fires Friday night.
He said order was restored after a few hours when police entered the jail and freed four guards who had been taken hostage.


Mozambique Downs Plane
LEAD: Armed forces shot down an unidentified plane near Mozambique's border with Malawi on Friday, Maputo radio said today.
The radio quoted military sources as saying the plane was violating the country's airspace about 10 miles from Malawi's western border.
The radio said the authorities were still trying to identify the plane.

LEAD: ALAIN PROST MUSCLED THE TITANIUM SHIFT into sixth gear, dialed up the 1,200-horsepower turbo booster and flung his iridescent red-and-white Formula One race car past the Estoril grandstands at 180 miles per hour, faster than an F-15 jet fighter on takeoff.
Prost, twice the world champion, was waging a record-breaking duel with Gerhard Berger in the dramatic closing minutes of the 70-lap 1987 Portuguese Grand Prix, one of 16 races in the Formula One Grand Prix championship, the World


A LEFTIST LEADER SURGING IN CANADA
LEAD: When President Reagan visited Canada's capital in April, White House officials declined a request for a meeting with Edward Broadbent, leader of the New Democratic Party.
Protocol required the President to meet with the country's official opposition Leader, John Turner, but not with Mr.
Broadbent, whose party has been a left-wing minority in Parliament for 52 years.

LEAD: A wiretap has been discovered on a Harvard University law professor's telephone, and the professor said today that the surveillance might have led to public disclosure of his misgivings about Judge Douglas H. Ginsburg, who ended his bid for Supreme Court today.

Out of Prison
LEAD: Govan A. Mbeki, who was confined in a South African prison 23 years ago for talk of taking arms against the system that ordered his imprisonment, was released last week.
Mr.
Mbeki, a longtime leader of the outlawed African National Congress and a close associate of Nelson R. Mandela, is now 77 years old and in ill health.


Quick Transition
LEAD: THOSE who can, do, and as for those who no longer can, well, if they're lucky they do what Dave Lewis did after the 34-year-old defenseman realized that he no longer had the skills that sustained him for most of his 15 seasons with four teams.
Lewis, a former Islander who joined the Detroit Red Wings before the 1986-87 season, retired after Friday's loss to the Minnesota North Stars and promptly began a new career as a Red Wing assistant coach.

Standing on his sooty granite pedestal by the side of Leipzig's old St.
Thomas Church, where he used to direct the choir, he glowers at a wooden door across the way from which, in the evening, come muffled bursts of laughter.

Facts Don't Always Give the True Story
LEAD: AS ITS TITLE MAKES CLEAR, and the film itself makes even clearer, ''Gaby - A True Story'' is about a real woman and her real travails.
Gabriela Brimmer was born with cerebral palsy, and without command of any muscles except those in her left foot.
That foot became her only means of communication: she could spell out words by pointing her big toe at an alphabet board.


Slain Girl Was Abused for Weeks, Evidence Shows
LEAD: Forensic evidence indicates that 6-year-old Elizabeth Steinberg was subjected to several weeks of physical abuse before the battering last weekend in which her fatal injuries were inflicted, a top official in the investigation said yesterday.

The car, on display at the Henry Ford Museum in Dearborn, Mich., is a 1956 model, not a 1955.

That is because Geers Gross is the ad agency for Kraft's Frusen Gladje premium ice cream.
That is a conflict without a doubt.

Blast Jolts Earthquake Area
LEAD: Residents were awakened early today by what some thought was an earthquake when scientists blew up 1,200 pounds of dynamite underground to study the fault that caused the powerful temblor in the Los Angeles area last month.
The explosion occurred at 4:10 A.M. near the epicenter of the Oct. 1 earthquake that killed seven people.

A Dim View of Justice
LEAD: First Bork, then Ginsburg.
Not since Richard Nixon responded to the Senate's rejection of Supreme Court nominee Clement Haynsworth in 1969 by nominating the unqualified G. Harrold Carswell, has a President acted as if he held the American people in such utter contempt.
Surely in the wake of the bruising Bork battle, it was incumbent upon President Reagan to offer a confirmable nominee of demonstrated judicial vision and high moral character.


4-Year-Old Boy Kills Mother After Finding Loaded Pistol
LEAD: A 4-year-old boy shot and killed his mother after he found a loaded .22-caliber pistol hidden in a closet, the police said Saturday.

British Faster Again
LEAD: The Marines found a few good runners for yesterday's 12th annual Marine Corps Marathon, but as it turned out, they weren't quite good enough.
For the fourth year in a row, the British Royal Marines defeated the United States Marines.

Donald Trump's Circus, and Bread
LEAD: After an ardent 18-month courtship, Donald Trump has failed to win the hand of NBC as owner-tenant for 10 acres of his dramatic 76-acre development proposed for Manhattan's West Side.
That adds urgency to efforts by Mayor Koch and Governor Cuomo to keep NBC in New York, the way they have now succeeded in keeping the Dreyfus Corporation.

TV Review; 'The World's a Stage,' Theater History on 31
LEAD: BEGINNING tonight at 9, WNYC, Channel 31, begins ''All the World's a Stage,'' a 13-part BBC series that is an attractively packaged history of the theater, a sort of electronic Theater 101 course.
Actually, it is, as a subtitle indicates, ''one man's journey'' through that history.
The man is Ronald Harwood, the writer whose credits include ''The Dresser,'' both play and film, and, more recently, the HBO movie ''Mandela.

LEAD: Four decades after their parents and grandparents swarmed from revolutionary upheaval in China to the safety of Hong Kong, a wave of young Chinese professionals is again fleeing Communism, packing their bags for Canada, the United States and Australia.

City Opera: 'Student Prince'
LEAD: GRANTED that there is an apparently limitless audience for kitsch and that it supplies the New York City Opera with full houses and increased revenues.
But if the company steadfastly avows that operettas and musical comedies have enough artistic merit to be presented alongside the standard operatic repertory, it might at least offer consistently polished performances of such works.

Poland's Foreign Debt
LEAD: Poland said that its foreign debt had reached $36 billion and that it did not expect to come to grips with its repayment problems until the mid-1990s.
The official Polish news agency quoted the deputy finance minister, Andrzej Dorosz, as saying over the weekend that Poland's continuing inability to pay the full interest due on its loans was contributing to the growth of the debt.

Ulster Ordeal: The Bad Years
LEAD:  Dec. 4, 1971 - A bomb planted by Protestants kills 15 Roman Catholics in a Londonderry bar.  an. 30, 1972 - In what is remembered as ''Bloody Sunday,'' 13 Catholic demonstrators are killed in Londonderry by British soldiers fearing an I.R.A. ambush.
Feb. 22, 1972 - Bombs kill 7 British soldiers and civilians in Aldershot, southwest of London, in what is believed to be revenge for ''Bloody Sunday.


Rate Drop Is Viewed As Cushion
LEAD: The sudden decline in interest rates that began when stock prices plunged on Oct. 19 has been large enough to help assure many economists that turmoil in the stock market will not lead to a recession.


Debt Pact Attacked in Brazil
LEAD: A provisional debt agreement reached by Brazil and foreign commercial banks in New York late Thursday has come under immediate attack from influential members of this country's two main political parties.


Enron Lags In Debt Plan
LEAD: The Enron Corporation, hit by the downturn in the stock market and a loss of $85 million from unauthorized trading, said Friday that it might not meet a debt-reduction target for the end of the year as proposed in a restructuring plan.
The Houston-based company had planned a major stock offering the week of Oct.


Federal Judge Orders Professor Reinstated At Boston University
LEAD: A Federal district judge has ordered Boston University to reinstate with tenure a professor of English who was found to have been the victim of sex discrimination.


De Laurentiis Plans to Quit
LEAD: Dino De Laurentiis, chairman and chief executive of the financially troubled De Laurentiis Entertainment Group, plans to resign from the company and is currently negotiating his release from a contract that pays an annual base salary of $850,000.


Treasury Sales Limited This Week
LEAD: Treasury auctions are limited this week to the three- and six-month bill issues sold every Monday.
Except for a two-year note issue and one-year bills expected next week, government securities dealers do not expect any Treasury offerings other than short-term bills until the last half of December.


Stage: 'Old Business,' On Father-Son Conflict
LEAD: THE eternal battle between fathers and sons is examined in Joe Cacaci's ''Old Business,'' as Abe Fleischer, a septuagenarian real estate tycoon, reluctantly makes way for his son to become head of the family empire.
In retirement in Florida, Abe keeps close watch on the son's activities and, predictably, returns to action.


Two Plead Not Guilty In Murder-Arson Case
LEAD: Two 13-year-old boys who are accused of setting fire to an abandoned car in a Brooklyn lot on Thursday, fatally burning a man inside, pleaded not guilty to second-degree murder and arson charges early yesterday.

CHARLOTTE MAYOR'S DEFEAT ECHOES FAR
LEAD: Harvey Gantt is a compelling symbol of the New South.
In 1963, he became the first black to enroll at Clemson University.
Twenty years later, he became the first black Mayor of Charlotte, elected by a city that was 70 percent white.

Stage: Bel Canto Troupe In Pizzetti's 'Cathedral'

So it appears to be with Ildebrando Pizzetti's ''Assassinio Nella Cattedrale,'' an opera that was not much admired when it received its American premiere in 1958 but that provided reasonable pleasure at its revival Saturday evening by the Bel Canto Opera, at St.


Mexican Ambivalence
LEAD: Repeatedly over the last seven years, the Reagan Administration has expressed hopes of creating a North American common market that would link the United States and its neighbors.
But in concluding a bilateral commercial accord here on Friday, Mexico and the United States showed that an enormous gap remains between that dream and current reality.


Tax Proposal Affects Bonds
LEAD: Investors in old bonds valued at less than their face value would be hit with a new tax under provisions of the tax bill passed last month by the House of Representatives For investors buying those bonds, known as ''market discount'' issues, the House bill proposes to tax the difference between the purchase price and the bonds' value at maturity.

LEAD: The latest plunge in the value of the dollar against other major currencies means that the prices of imported goods - ranging from German wines to Italian shoes to Japanese cars - will rise in coming weeks and months, according to importers, industry officials and economists.

Dawn Upshaw, the society's visiting soprano, decided not to chance the Liszt songs she had planned, but there were the Seven Romances of Shostakovich - settings for voice, two strings and piano to poetry by Alexander Blok.

LEAD: Toni Morrison has been appointed to the Robert F. Goheen Professorship in the Humanities Council at Princeton University, effective in the spring of 1989, according to the university.

Report Assails U.S. Helicopter
LEAD: Crashes of the Army's most modern troop-carrying helicopters have been caused by ordinary radio waves from microwave towers, radio attennas and radar, a published report says.

Dance: All-Ashton Program by the Joffrey Ballet
LEAD: THE tenderness and wit for which Sir Frederick Ashton is justifiably famous as a choreographer were much in evidence in the all-Ashton program that the Joffrey Ballet presented Saturday night at the City Center Theater.
The program also featured several dancers in roles for which they had not been previously reviewed this season.


U.S.-Yugoslavia Talks
LEAD: The United States Deputy Secretary of State, John C. Whitehead, arrived here on Saturday for talks on Yugoslavia's economy and measures to restructure the country's $19.5 billion foreign debt, the Tanjug News Agency reported.
The agency said Mr.
Whitehead was received by the Croatian leader, Ante Markovic.


Pitino System to Take Time
LEAD: Nearly a month ago, Rick Pitino began trying to alter five years of bad Knick habits.
He introduced a system of basketball that asked the players to move, react and interplay with one another.
It was completely contrary to much of what had been drilled into the Knicks under Hubie Brown, who preached constraint and control during his five seasons as the team's head coach.

Bruce David Gelb, the son of Mr. and Mrs.
Allen G. Gelb of Westfield, N.J., and New York.

INSIDE
LEAD:  Arab Leaders Condemn Iran


Al Richmond, Leftist Ex-Editor
LEAD: Al Richmond, a former editor who was convicted of subversion and imprisoned during the McCarthy anti-Communist era, died of pneumonia Friday.
He was 73 years old and lived in San Francisco.


Puzzling Out Foreign Profits
LEAD: The dollar's accelerated decline against the yen last week foreshadows bigger profits for Avon Products Inc.
Japan is Avon's largest foreign market, and the stronger yen will translate into more dollars when the money is accounted for at the company's New York headquarters.


Nicaraguan Cardinal Seeks Pledges Before Mediation Starts
LEAD: Just two days after the Sandinista Government agreed to name Miguel Cardinal Obando y Bravo as intermediary in talks with guerrilla leaders, the Cardinal said he was not sure he would accept the job.


REAGAN WEIGHING CONFLICTING ADVICE ON COURT NOMINEE
LEAD: Administration officials today weighed conflicting advice from senators and conservative strategists on how quickly to proceed in naming a new nominee for the Supreme Court.

Robins Company should be required to set aside up to $2.3 billion to compensate 163,000 women who contend that they were injured by Robins's Dalkon Shield birth-control device, an expert witness testified today as a bankruptcy hearing continued in Federal court here.

Pop Music: Simply Red
LEAD: MICK HUCKNALL, the redheaded lead singer and chief songwriter of the pop group Simply Red, is one of the most emotionally intense vocalists to emerge out of the British blue-eyed soul movement.
The waifish young singer from Manchester, whose hair color inspired the group's name, has a raw piercing countertenor that he pushes with a punishing urgency.

Few Program Traders Return
LEAD: Many money managers and individuals stayed away from the stock market yesterday out of fear of the return of computerized program trading.
But, ironically, program traders did not return in full force after the New York Stock Exchange lifted its restriction on the use of its trading floor computer system for the execution of such trades.

Powell Jr., the pragmatic centrist who retired from the Supreme Court in June, than that of Judge Robert H. Bork, the thundering critic of liberal judicial activism whose nomination for the vacancy was defeated last month.

Two Bears Injured
LEAD: Two members of the Chicago Bears' defensive unit will be lost for at least four weeks with injuries suffered in the team's victory at Green Bay on Sunday.
Dan Hampton, a defensive end, injured his left knee in a pileup in the first quarter.
Otis Wilson, a linebacker, injured his right knee in the fourth quarter.

LEAD: The thick, acrid smoke that drifted into the New York metropolitan area on Sunday remained there yesterday.

PIPELINE COMPANY TO CLEAN PCB SITES
LEAD: The Texas Eastern Corporation tentatively agreed today to clean up PCB's and other toxic wastes disposed of at 89 sites in 14 states along its 10,000-mile natural gas pipeline.
The cleanup will cost an estimated $400 million.
Under an ''agreement in principle'' with the Environmental Protection Agency, Texas Eastern will also pay penalties and costs of $15 million for violating regulations on the disposal of PCB's, or polychlorinated biphenyls, along the pipeline.The pipeline, operated by the company's Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation subsidiary, stretches from Texas and

LEAD: THE worst defense against a menacing yellow jacket wasp may be the squashing body blow.

Bank of Boston
LEAD: The Bank of Boston Corporation, the nation's 15th-largest bank holding company, said it had agreed to buy the BankVermont Corporation in a one-for-one stock swap valued at around $60 million.
The acquisition is the first under Vermont's new interstate banking law.
BankVermont, based in Burlington, has assets of $667 million.

LEAD: The decline in oil prices last year has been felt even more strongly this year in oil-producing states, as measured by bankruptcies, tax revenues and other indicators, a survey by the American Petroleum Institute has found.

Concert: London Ensemble
LEAD: THE arrival of the touring London Phiharmonic at Avery Fisher Hall on Monday evening provided an opportunity to check on the progress of Semyon Bychkov, one of the most generously praised of the world's under-40 conductors.
Mr.
Bychkov, who was born in Leningrad in 1952 and emigrated to the United States in 1975, is music director of the Buffalo Philharmonic and beginning in 1989 will hold the same post with the Orchestre de Paris.

LEAD: A 26-year-old pregnant woman was pushed by a stranger into the path of a subway train yesterday in Manhattan and survived by squeezing into a crawl space underneath the platform as the train pulled into the station.


Work on Solar Car Enriches Engineering On Many Fronts
LEAD: SUN-POWERED passenger automobiles are so far down the road that they may never amount to more than a dream.
But last week, an American automobile maker proved that an experimental solar-powered car could cross a continent nearly as fast as a conventional gasoline-powered vehicle.

LEAD: The University of Iowa said yesterday that the National Collegiate Athletic Association and the Big Ten Conference have cleared Kevin Harmon, the Hawkeye running back, of any wrongdoing in connection with reports that he received money from sports agents.

LEAD: A $100 million issue of New Hampshire Turnpike System tax-exempt revenue bonds was tentatively offered yesterday with a maximum yield of 8 3/8 percent for an issue due in 2017.

LEAD: After months of arguing over alternative plans to keep the Museum of the American Indian in New York City, the highest New York State, local and Congressional leaders have united behind a proposal to house the collection in the Custom House in lower Manhattan.

U.S. Fights a New Battle of Antietam
LEAD: On Sept. 17, 1862, the cornfields and wooded ridges surrounding Antietam Creek ran with blood as the Union and Confederate armies clashed in the most savage single day of fighting in this country's history.
As darkness fell, 23,000 Americans lay dead or wounded in the fields and woods.

LEAD: The Allis-Chalmers Corporation said it intended to propose a Chapter 11 reorganization in which its major businesses would be sold together or individually.
The diversified industrial company, which filed for protection from creditors last June, said it had retained the investment banker Lazard Freres &amp; Company to assist it in the effort to sell the company.

In an Ulster City, Grief for 11 and Rage
LEAD: With 11 of its citizens dead from a bomb blast Sunday, this town turned today to the rituals of mourning and sectarian rage that are a commonplace part of life in this tortured province For James Mullan, a tall pharmacist with a faced reddened by grief, that meant contemplating a dreadful irony.
Moments after a bomb estimated at 30 pounds ripped open the community center here, he located his 10-year-old son in a thick fog of dust.


Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Q.What would happen if a thermonuclear bomb exploded on the surface of the Moon?
Could a large number of explosions alter the orbit of the Moon and affect our tides?
A.In order to disturb the Moon's orbit of the Earth, you would have to produce and focus enough energy to overcome the force of the gravitational attraction between the two bodies.

One Killed as Trains Collide
LEAD: Two Union Pacific freight trains have collided head-on, destroying the lead engines on both trains and killing a conductor, officials said.
Six crew members were injured, some when they jumped before the crash.
The collision occurred around 6:15 A.M.
Sunday, about 10 miles west of Kemmerer, when a westbound train heading from Chicago to Seattle collided with an eastbound train going from Seattle to Chicago.

Avery Reorganizes
LEAD: Avery International Inc. said it planned a restructuring in 1988 that would affect about 1,000 workers, cut the revenue base by 9 percent and result in a $25 million write-off and an unspecified loss in the fourth quarter.
Avery, a manufacturer of self-adhesive labels and office products based in Pasadena, Calif., said the overhaul would mean the first earnings decline in 12 years.


Cannon Settles S.E.C. Case
LEAD: The financially troubled Cannon Group Inc. said today that it had settled a yearlong Securities and Exchange Commission inquiry into the company's accounting practices without the need for further financial adjustments.

LEAD: Officials overseeing New York City jails say the troop barge the city has leased from a British company to cope with inmate overcrowding is dangerous to both prisoners and correction officers.

IC-Pepsi Venture
LEAD: IC Industries and Pepsico Inc. said they were forming a venture to bottle Pepsi-Cola products in the Midwest.
IC Industries, a diversified company based in Chicago, will own 80 percent of the venture, with Pepsico, based in Purchase, N.Y., owning 20 percent.
The venture will handle 12 percent of Pepsico's domestic soft drink volume, making it second only to the Pepsi-Cola Bottling group, which is owned by Pepsico and handles 33 percent.


V.A. Reduces Its Loan Rate
LEAD: The Veterans Administration said today that it was lowering its maximum interest rate for federally backed home mortgages by half a percentage point, to 10.5 percent, the first rate reduction in 10 months.

Gore's Fears Are Eased On Issue of Marijuana
LEAD: On his way to meet Senator Albert Gore Jr. this morning, DuBose Porter stopped by Ma Hawkins's Coffee Shop to hear what the folks were saying about the Presidential candidate, who has admitted that he smoked marijuana years ago.


Foreign Cars Up in Japan
LEAD: Foreign car sales in Japan rose to 6,627 in October, a 34.8 percent increase from a year earlier and the 46th straight year-on-year increase, the Japan Automobile Importers Association said today.
But October sales fell from a record 10,089 automobiles in September.
West German-made cars, accounting for 70 percent of the October total, rose 27.3 percent from a year earlier, to 4,637.


Italians Approve Restrictions On Atom Power and Judges
LEAD: Italian voters have overwhelmingly approved five referendums to limit the development of nuclear energy and to make judges more liable for courtroom errors.

GAY CULTURE SEMINAR
LEAD: A symposium on New York City gay and lesbian history and culture will be held next Tuesday at the City University Graduate Center audi-torium (lower level) at 33 West 42d Street.
The symposium is sponsored by the faculty Committee for Lesbian and Gay Studies at the school and will include a lecture on ''Creating Cul-tural Legacies'' and talks on the his-tory of lesbians in Cherry Grove, Fire Island, and of relations between the state and New York City gay bars.

LEAD: John Logan, a prize-winning poet, editor and English professor who taught at the State University at Buffalo and other colleges, died of a heart ailment and complications from gall bladder surgery Friday in San Francisco, where he lived.

Corrections
LEAD: The headline on an article Oct. 11 by Joseph S. Nye Jr., ''For a Triple Zero Pact,'' was misleading.
Professor Nye argued that many Europeans are reluctant to rely on conventional deterrence and would therefore resist a ''triple zero'' agreement removing all nuclear weapons from Europe.

8% Gain for Newspapers
LEAD: Newspaper advertising increased 8 percent in August over August 1986, according to estimates by the Newspaper Advertising Bureau.
The figure was $2.5 billion.
Retail was up 3.2 percent; classified, up 15.5 percent, and national, up 5.4 percent.

ISRAEL PHILHARMONIC PLAYS WARSAW
LEAD: Zwi Litwak's father moved his family from Poland to Palestine in 1934, the year after Hitler became Chancellor of Germany.
This week, Mr.
Litwak, now a violinist with the Israel Philharmonic, and his 77-year-old mother, Miriam, returned to Poland for the first time.


Nations Letting Dollar Slide
LEAD: The value of the dollar slipped to new lows against several major currencies today amid renewed signs that foreign governments are unwilling to defend it if the Reagan Administration will not.


Amid Greek Threats, U.S. Opens Talks on Bases
LEAD: The United States and Greece opened formal negotiations today on the future of the American bases here amid threats by Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou that base rights would be ended unless major Greek demands are satisfied.


In a Polish Forest, Neglect and Study
LEAD: THE thin yellow stripes on the four towering, vaguely spiral oaks barely pierced the forest's thinning autumn foliage.


Horses Get Substitute Trainer
LEAD: Peter Ferriola's stable, which had won 16 races at Aqueduct this fall before being put out of action when three of its horses failed post-race drug tests last week, will be racing again tomorrow, but with a new trainer at the helm.

2 More Top Aides Quit Arizona Chief's Staff
LEAD: Two more top aides left Gov.
Evan Mecham's staff today.
One, facing extortion charges, resigned shortly after his trial date was set, and the other took a leave of absence to head the Mr.
Mecham's fight against a recall campaign.


The Dance: Rachel List Company
LEAD: WHEN Rachel List and Company performed Sunday night, dancers made music and musicians danced in a jolly get-together that sometimes resembled a barn dance.
But instead of occurring in a barn, it took place at the Emanu-El Midtown Y. A former member of Les Grands Ballets Canadiens, Ms.
List is also an expert in Appalachian clogging dances, and she based ''Crazy Quilt'' upon them.

Japan Seeking Foreign Chips
LEAD: Japan is urging domestic companies to buy more chips abroad to quell complaints that its market is closed, a spokesman for the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said today.


CONCERT SITE CHANGED
LEAD: The site of the first in the Neighbor-hood Concert Series has been changed.
The New York Strings, a jazz ensemble, will appear at 1 P.M. tomorrow at the Children's Museum of Manhattan, 14 West 54th Street.
Thirty free concerts are being sponsored by Carnegie Hall and the De-partment of Cultural Affairs of the City of New York.

The Editorial Notebook; AIDS, in Harsh Review
LEAD: The AIDS epidemic spread so far because initially no one took it seriously enough: Government, the media, researchers, blood banks and the gay community each found their own reasons to ignore or deny the threat.
That's the compelling theme of ''And the Band Played On,'' by Randy Shilts.
It's a highly readable account, full of valuable reporting and insight.

Commodore's Odd 128
LEAD: THE Commodore 128, introduced a few years ago, is an odd bird.
It is, in effect, three different computers in one box.
In its first mode, it is completely compatible with the enormously popular Commodore 64 (now 64c), and you can plug all of the 64 peripherals into the 128 or run any of the thousands of programs written for the older machine.

Who's in Charge Here?
LEAD: It was a funny fad that started in 1962: picture books called ''Who's In Charge Here,'' mocking political figures like Ronald Reagan with fake speech balloons on real photographs.
In 1987, the title has stopped being funny.
People are asking, on one issue after another, Is President Reagan truly in charge?

LEAD: A state senator from Rochester and a former state senator from Brooklyn pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges that they had conspired to steal thousands of dollars of public money to finance election campaigns.

LEAD: A proposal that would reduce allowable density for buildings along Broadway, Seventh Avenue and more than a dozen side streets around the theater district was submitted yesterday to the New York City Planning Commission.

Mr.

LEAD: Secretary of Education William J. Bennett said tonight it would be ''crazy'' to bar people from the Supreme Court or other high public office because they had smoked marijuana or committed other indiscretions in their youth.

More than 100,000 people, including computer makers, dealers and buyers, wandered through the Las Vegas Convention Center looking for the next major advances in computer hardware and software.

LEAD: One after another, the persona is punctured and collapses.

Visa Teller Link
LEAD: Visa International, the international organization of Visa card-issuing banks, said it had exercised its option to link up with Plus, the network of automatic tellers.
The move means that holders of Visa cards from outside the United States will be able to use Plus machines, many of which are in this country.

LEAD: In a stunning literary upset, Larry Heinemann, a 43-year-old Army veteran who said he was still embittered by his experience as an infantryman in Vietnam, won the 1987 National Book Award for fiction with his second novel, ''Paco's Story,'' the story of a wounded Vietnam veteran's efforts to readjust to civilian life.


Corrections
LEAD: The headline of a dispatch from Oakdale, La., yesterday about the Federal Detention Center there misstated the reason for the center's expansion.
The additional space will be used for aliens from countries other than Cuba who have criminal records.

LEAD: When it comes to inventiveness, New York designers stacked up quite well against their European counterparts this season.
In the spring and summer fashion openings that began in Milan, Italy, at the beginning of October and ended here Friday, they all embraced short skirts with the same sort of gleeful abandon.

LEAD: Alphonse (Ollie Boy) Persico, a former head of the Colombo organized crime family who has been a fugitive since 1980, was arrested yesterday by Federal officers in West Hartford, Conn., the authorities announced.

LEAD: An unexpected bid by Manila to forge a common Southeast Asian policy in support of American military bases in the Philippines has brought consternation to neighboring capitals, according to regional officials and private analysts meeting here to discuss Pacific security.


Rates Steady in Quiet Trading
LEAD: Interest rates were little changed in very quiet trading yesterday as traders and investors waited for a budget agreement in Washington and for more data showing the effects of the stock market's decline on the economy.


Unchecked by Meeting
LEAD: The dollar continued to slide yesterday, unswayed by a meeting of central bankers that ended without any initiatives to calm the financial markets.

LEAD: The Federal Government would like to turn the campus of defunct Yankton College into a minimum-security prison, but some residents think the middle of a residential neighborhood is the wrong place.

LEAD: The City Council majority leader, Peter F. Vallone, who said Sunday that homeless people refusing to go to shelters should be arrested and ''accommodated in a cell overnight'' for their own protection, yesterday denied that he meant to suggest jailing them.

Yugoslav Economic Ills
LEAD: Yugoslavia today reported slackening industrial output, a declining currency and rising inflation as its economic crisis continues to escalate.
The state press agency, Tanyug, said industrial output would fall short of a 3.6 percent target for the year, having risen 2 percent in the January to September period.

Beneath a Street, Art Soothes
LEAD: Times Square is many things to too many people, but one thing it is to everybody is noise.
The noise comes from every direction, and it is of every kind -squealing, honking, rumbling traffic, above all, but also the murmur and babble of thousands of people, the rush of wind, the blaring of street musicians, the roar of the subway from beneath the sidewalk.

Steel Output Drops
LEAD: Steel production fell five-tenths of 1 percent, to 1.866 million tons, in the week ended last Saturday, from 1.875 million tons in the previous week, the American Iron and Steel Institute said yesterday.
Output amounted to 86.4 percent of capacity during the week, compared with 86.8 percent in the previous week.

LEAD: Conrail will buy 30 new high-horsepower locomotives from the General Electric Company for more than $36 million, the freight railroad said.

Hero of the Metropolis
LEAD: To the Editor:


Air Force Missile Destroyed
LEAD: An unarmed Minuteman 2 missile was destroyed because of technical problems seconds after liftoff tonight, the Air Force said.
Base firefighters battled a blaze caused by the explosion, but no injuries were reported.
Officials said they did not know what caused the problems.


Cuomo Says Sympathy Can Aid Minority Youth
LEAD: Governor Cuomo called today for compassion coupled with accountability to help black and Hispanic children.


Robert C. Allen; Disney Executive, 55
LEAD: Robert C. Allen, vice president of Walt Disney World, died Sunday, apparently after a heart attack.
He was 55 years old.

LEAD: Tomorrow is Veterans Day, and closings vary.
Following are holiday schedules.
NEW YORK  Parade: Begins at 9 A.M. at 39th Street and Fifth Avenue, heads south to 24th Street and ends about noon.
Parking: Alternate-side parking suspended.
Sanitation: No collection or street cleaning.

Rare White Rhino Dies
LEAD: A rare white rhinoceros intended for a breeding program has died after a 38-hour trip from the San Diego Zoo and nearly two more days in a tight enclosure, officials of Wildlife Safari say.

Mesa Gets 9.9% Stake In Singer
LEAD: T. Boone Pickens, through his Mesa Limited Partnership, announced today that he had increased his stake in the Singer Company to 2.1 million shares, giving him a 9.9 percent interest in the aerospace and electronics manufacturer.


Pristina Journal; Blood Will Have Blood; It's the Code of the Clans
LEAD: Despite 40 years of strict Yugoslav laws against blood feuds, including capital punishment, a feud in which one murder must be answered by another is under way in Kosovo Province.


Zenaida Drabkin Siskind; Lawyer, 86
LEAD: Zenaida Drabkin Siskind, a former president of the Bronx Bar Association and member of the Mayor's Judiciary Committee under two administrations, died of pneumonia, following a series of strokes, Sunday at Goldwater Hospital.
She was 86 years old and lived in Manhattan.


Worlds Seeks New Capital
LEAD: Battered by declining sales of key products, Worlds of Wonder Inc. said today that it would explore various refinancing alternatives, including a merger.
