LEAD: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua said today that if President Reagan agreed to receive him he would consent to the presence of rebel leaders at the meeting.


Woman Ordered Held In Special Mental Unit
LEAD: While a state judge pondered the future of Joyce Brown, the first person hospitalized under Mayor Koch's new program, another judge yesterday denied a second homeless woman's request to be released from a psychiatric ward at Bellevue Hospital Center.

LEAD: To the Editor:


BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 11, 1987
LEAD:  Markets


Reagan Wants Dollar to Halt Fall, But U.S. Doesn't Take Any Action
LEAD: President Reagan said today that he did not ''want a further decline'' of the dollar, but beyond the President's remarks the Administration did nothing in the markets to stabilize it.


Brooklyn College Joins Conference
LEAD: Brooklyn College will be among five charter members of a Division III league to be known as the Atlantic Collegiate Football Conference that will begin play in 1988.


Baptist Fundamentalists in the South Suffer 2 Defeats in Battles for Church
LEAD: Fundamentalists here and in North Carolina suffered defeats today at the hands of moderate Southern Baptists in a struggle for power over the nation's largest Protestant denomination.


Economic Scene; Europe Wants Leadership
LEAD: AFTER the Wall Street plunge, which is still reverberating in markets around the world, Europeans are again looking to the United States for leadership to prevent the financial crisis from becoming a worldwide slump.
But they are fearful that sufficiently strong leadership will not be forthcoming either in Washington or Bonn or Tokyo or in the West collectively.

Proposed Prison Barge Undergoes an Inspection
LEAD: The Bibby Venture docked at Pier 36 on the East River as members of City Council Public Safety Committee took an inspection tour.
Officials overseeing the city's jails have criticized the barge, which can hold 381 prisoners, as ''a labyrinth of spaces that is largely unsupervisable by either sight or sound.


Kasparov Wins After Karpov Error
LEAD: Gary Kasparov capitalized on a blunder by Anatoly Karpov to win the 11th game yesterday and take the lead for the first time in their world championship chess match in Seville, Spain.
The 24-year-old champion now has six points to his 36-year-old challenger's five.


Arbitrage Role Appears Small
LEAD: Few shares of stock were sold on Oct. 19 by firms using computers to shift investments between stocks and stock index futures, a regulatory agency said today.

Advertising; S.&amp;S. Gets Toyota's Lexus Car

John Vanbiesbrouck termed it a constant struggle, and from Alain Chevrier's vantage point, the depths of the Ranger problem over their winless streak, which last night ballooned to eight games, made for a desperate team.

LEAD: ''When Mr.

Finley, Kumble, Major Law Firm, Facing Revamping or Dissolution
LEAD: The nation's fourth-largest law firm, Finley, Kumble, Wagner, Underberg, Manley, Myerson &amp; Casey, long rocked by internal rivalries and increasingly concerned about mounting debts, is about to undergo a dramatic reorganization, if not a total dissolution, according to lawyers in the firm.


RAYTHEON CONTRACT
LEAD: The Raytheon Company has re-ceived a $790.4 million military con-tract for 884 Patriot air defense guided missiles and 15 sets of ground equipment, the Army said.
It said the work on the antiaircraft missiles, which will be performed at Andover, Mass., is expected to be completed by the end of 1990.

METROPOLITAN DIARY
LEAD: THE super-stretch limousine, when Jennifer Dierckx de Casterle spotted it, had stopped for a light on Madison Avenue in the upper 60's.
Dimly discernible through the rear smoked-glass windows was a chic-looking woman.
At the wheel was a liveried chauffeur.
He was impeccably clad, from cap on down.


ADVERTISING;
LEAD: American consumers last year saved $2.75 billion on their shopping bills through the use of cents-off coupons, according to the A.C.
Nielsen Company, which monitors such activity.


Westies' Informer Links Gotti to Labor Shooting
LEAD: An informer testified yesterday that members of the Westies gang shot a union official as a favor for John Gotti, whom the authorities have called the boss of the Gambino crime family.


Saudi Says Goal for Oil Is to Keep Price at $18
LEAD: Saudi Arabia's oil minister said today that his country would try to keep the price of oil at $18 a barrel, the level set by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries a year ago, ''for some time to come.''


Abrams Asked to Study Ex-State Official's Case
LEAD: The Inspector General of New York State said today that he had asked Attorney General Robert Abrams to consider whether legal action was warranted against a former state insurance official who is accused of giving business to private companies controlled by his son.


U.S. Poll Puts the Economy Over Military in Importance
LEAD: Americans see economic strength as far more important than military strength in assuring United States influence in the world, a poll by a liberal research organization has concluded.

Stage: Pound's 'Elektra'
LEAD: IN the early 1950's, while confined in St.
Elizabeth's Hospital for the criminally insane in Washington, Ezra Pound worked on a contemporary version of Sophocles' ''Elektra.'' Until now, Pound's adaptation (written in collaboration with Rudd Fleming, a classics scholar) has been unproduced and unpublished.


Two Foremen Accused Of Illegal Renovation
LEAD: Two construction foremen were arrested yesterday and accused of illegally renovating a landmark building on East 79th Street, city officials said last night.


Prince Weighs Cambodia Talks
LEAD: Prince Norodom Sihanouk is planning to travel to France this week amid reports that he may meet there before the end of the year with Cambodia's Prime Minister, a spokesman for the Prince said here today.


War Heroes, War Powers
LEAD: The essence of battle, says the historian John Keegan, is ''the behavior of men struggling to reconcile their instinct for self-preservation, their sense of honor and the achievement of some aim over which other men are ready to kill them.'' Most Americans are never called to endure this fearful struggle.


Ford Is Penalized $325,000
LEAD: The Ford Motor Company has paid $325,000 in penalties assessed by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration for alleged record-keeping violations at two plants.
Ford paid $305,000 for ''willful violations of OSHA's record-keeping standards'' at its Hapeville, Ga., plant, and $20,000 for similar violations at its St.

LEAD: Lou Carnesecca sat in the den of his Jamaica Estates home Monday night and watched Mark Jackson, the Knicks' top draft choice, make his first start as a point guard in the National Basketball Association.

LEAD: Mark Breland and Michael Olajide share the dubious distinction of being hot young fighters from New York who have recently lost for the first time as professionals.

LEAD: Mayor Xavier Suarez of Miami was re-elected today to a second two-year term, repulsing the comeback try of former Mayor Maurice Ferre in a runoff election.

Hamilton S. Gregg, 63; Investment Firm Owner
LEAD: Hamilton S. Gregg, an investment executive, died of a heart attack Thursday at his apartment in Manhattan.
He was 63 years old and lived in Manhattan and Falls Village, Conn.

LEAD: The French and West German stock markets suffered some of their heaviest losses ever today as investors worried about the falling dollar and Washington's difficulties in cutting its budget deficit.  [ Tokyo stock prices fell 649.70 points, or 3 percent, on Wednesday following the declines in Europe and in New York.

RADIOACTIVE LEAK IDLES 400
LEAD: Leaks of low-level radioactive water contami-nated the clothing and skin of several workers at the closed Pilgrim nuclear plant over the weekend, and the Boston Edison Company ordered a work stop-page Monday and sent about 400 em-ployees home.

Acting Webb Chief May Be Permanent
LEAD: Philip J. Dion, a financial executive, will probably succeed Robert K. Swanson as chairman and chief executive of the Del E. Webb Corporation when its directors convene next week, industry analysts said yesterday.
The 42-year-old Mr.
Dion is already serving as acting chief executive.


Japan's Unusual Recovery
LEAD: Despite the turmoil in its stock and currency markets, Japan's economy is continuing to rebound from nearly two years of sluggish growth caused by the soaring yen.
But economists have begun to worry that the dollar's rapid fall against the yen in recent days could slow the robust recovery.


Bond Prices Decline Modestly
LEAD: Bond prices declined modestly yesterday, as investor demand remained slack before Veterans Day.


William C. Pahlmann, Decorator Known for Eclectic Designs, Dies
LEAD: William C. Pahlmann, a leading interior decorator and the first to design model rooms for department stores, died last Friday in a hospital in Guadalajara, Mexico, where he had a home.
Mr.
Pahlmann, who suffered for many years from arteriosclerosis, was 86 years old.


Oriole Officials Named
LEAD: Edward Bennett Williams, the owner of the Baltimore Orioles, completed his restructuring of the team's front office yesterday.
Roland Hemond was named vice president of baseball operations; Frank Robinson was named a special assistant to the owner; Doug Melvin was named director of the farm system, and Calvin


Roberta Peters to Head Music-Theater Institute
LEAD: The soprano Roberta Peters has been named chairman of the National Institute for Music Theater, an organization dedicated to raising money to help creators and artists in the fields of opera and musical theater in the United States.
The institute, which was founded in 1969 by Roger L. Stevens, established the George London Grant for opera singers and the Mary Martin Prize for artists in the musical theater.


Wal-Mart Up; Limited Is Flat
LEAD: Wal-Mart Stores Inc., a major discounter, said yesterday that its third-quarter profit rose 41 percent.
Earnings were flat at The Limited Inc., which owns women's apparel stores.


ORBITING OBJECT HINTS AT OTHER PLANET SYSTEMS
LEAD: The first strong evidence of a large object orbiting a star other than the Sun was reported yesterday by American astronomers.
They said the object, hotter, brighter and more massive than Jupiter, was most likely the first discovery of a brown dwarf, one of a type of hypothesized celestial objects that are intermediate between a planet and a star.


Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, a dispatch yesterday from Russell, Kan., about the formal Presidential declaration of Senator Bob Dole misstated his relationship to Robin Dole.
She is his daughter by his first marriage.

The Dance: Desrosiers Theater
LEAD: The image's the thing for Robert Desrosiers, a Toronto-based choreographer and dancer who happily turns every stage into a hallucinatory playpen.


Lincoln Center Seeking Funds for New Tower
LEAD: With a ceremonial shovel and a luncheon, Lincoln Center opened a campaign yesterday to raise money for its first new building in 20 years.
Officials said $45.6 million of the estimated $85 million needed had already been promised.


Jury Seated in Cocaine Trial
LEAD: A jury was seated today after five and a half weeks of selection for the cocaine-smuggling trial of Carlos Lehder Rivas, the reputed head of a Colombian drug ring.
Federal District Judge Howell W. Melton set opening arguments for Monday, and testimony is expected to last three months.
Mr.
Lehder, who is 38 years old, is charged in a 1981 indictment with smuggling 3.3 tons of cocaine from Colombia to Normans Cay in the Bahamas and then to Georgia and northern Florida in 1979 and 1980.


The Pop Life
LEAD: Squeeze Has a Hit The saga of Squeeze, the embattled English pop group that is appearing Friday evening at Madison Square Garden, is one rock-and-roll story in which artistic self-examination and the faith of a record company (A&amp;M) have worked together to create an unexpectedly happy ending.

LEAD: ''If Reagan invites me to talk, I would be willing.
If he wants to be joined by Secretary Shultz, by Calero or by the contra leadership, that is up to him.''  - President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua. [ A1:2. ]

LEAD: A national newspaper said today that 60,000 Moscow residents would be dismissed by 1990 under Mikhail S. Gorbachev's campaign to streamline government by cutting 50 percent of all ministry jobs.

CORRECTIONS
LEAD: An article and a picture caption on the Washington Talk page on Tuesday, about American efforts for an easing of Soviet emigration policies, misidentified a Soviet official from the Institute of U.S.A. and Canada Studies.
He was Vasily A. Vlasikhin.


Citicorp Paper Rates Down
LEAD: Interest rates declined at Citicorp's regular weekly commercial paper auctions yesterday.
It marked the fourth straight week that rates have fallen, bringing the total decline during that period to about 1 1/4 percentage points.


U.S. SEES RUSSIANS LAGGING ON PACT
LEAD: Reagan Administration officials said today that they were concerned that Soviet negotiators were not forthcoming enough in talks aimed at wrapping up the treaty banning medium- and shorter-range arms.

LEAD: Japanese dealers and collectors dominated bidding last night at Christie's auction of Impressionist and modern art - purchasing paintings by Renoir, Kandinsky and Chagall at record prices for these artists and buying other major works by Monet, Miro, Rouault and Laurencin.

LEAD: President Reagan, who criticized his predecessor's creation of the Departments of Education and Energy, said today that he wanted to make the Veterans Administration a Cabinet-level department to give veterans ''the recognition they so rightly deserve.''

LIFE IN THE 30'S
LEAD: IT was a summer night when I heard the running footsteps behind me.
I ran, too, and slipped into the hallway of my building, a locked door and a pane of glass insulating me from the outside.
The woman was only a few steps behind me.
Her face on the other side of the glass was black with mascara mixed with tears.


A CHEERY GIFT FOR THE PUBS
LEAD: Breweries, bartenders and imbibers toasted a vote by the House of Commons today to scrap a provision requiring pubs in England and Wales to close for two and a half hours in the afternoon.


3 Die as Police Clash With Protesters in Bangladesh
LEAD: At least three people were shot and killed by the police here today as thousands of rioters set fire to cars and buildings, and threw bricks and homemade bombs in an attempt to force President H. M. Ershad from office.

2,000 Hippopotamuses Die In Zambia Anthrax Outbreak
LEAD: An outbreak of anthrax has killed more than 2,000 hippopotamuses in the Luangwa Valley wildlife sanctuary in the last two weeks, the Government said today.


Scenes at the Vietnam Memorial
LEAD: Rain-soaked combat boots lined up yesterday at the Vietnam Veterans Memorial.
The boots symbolize missing servicemen and were left from a rally over the weekend.
At right, Interior Secretary Donald P. Hodel helping a visitor to the memorial find a name on the monument.
Mr.
Hodel, a computer enthusiast, wanted to try out the computerized catalogue, installed last spring, that directs a visitor to the location on the monument where a specified name may be located.


A Sweepstakes for Brighter, Lighter and Cheaper Subway Cars
LEAD: The New York City Transit Authority is readying plans for a new generation of subway cars that officials say would have wider seats and smoother rides and be brighter, lighter and substantially cheaper to run.


Music: 'Salsa Meets Jazz'
LEAD: WHEN salsa meets jazz at the Village Gate, it's usually a coming-together of disparate points of view, however sympathetic and compatible.
Jazz-trained improvisers and musicians whose roots are in Latin music tend to approach phrasing, rhythm, and the organization of solos quite differently.
The jazz musician plays on the chords,the structure, the thematic material.


Car Doors Spring Open In Sudden Subway Stop
LEAD: All the doors on one side of a 10-car subway train unaccountably sprang open yesterday when the operator slammed on the brakes to avoid striking a man on the tracks in a Manhattan station, the Transit Authority said.

Even Rivals Agree, Kings Sets Pace In Food Marketing
LEAD: NEW JERSEY has spawned a number of supermarket chains but when it comes to innovation in marketing and a reputation for quality and service, Kings Super Markets, a 16-store chain, is often ahead of the pack.


Blues Top Slumping Flyers
LEAD: Tony McKegney scored two goals and added an assist, leading the Blues to a 5-2 victory tonight over the Philadelphia Flyers.

LEAD: Judge John P. Griffin, who placed Dwight Gooden on two years' probation last January after the pitcher pleaded no contest in an altercation with the police in Tampa, Fla., said Monday that he is concerned the results of drug tests the Mets' pitcher is taking under the supervision of major league baseball are not being sent to probation officials in Florida or New


Comings and Goings
LEAD: Three days after Ron Harper severely sprained his left ankle and chipped a small bone in his foot, the Cleveland Cavaliers learned their star guard would be out eight to 10 weeks, not the four weeks physicians originally predicted.
So the Cavaliers signed 6-foot-11-inch Johnny Rogers, who was the second-round draft choice of the Sacramento Kings in 1986 and averaged 10.4 minutes and 4.2 points a game last season.


Ere Virtue Ruled
LEAD: Of the many amazing things about the latest Supreme Court fiasco, the most amazing is the revelation that there are grown-up people in the United States who have never smoked marijuana.
A number of mildly notorious persons, including some of the Presidential yearners, have, in fact, seized this occasion to announce that they have never smoked marijuana.


Pot, and Public Pieties
LEAD: The Age of Aquarius dawned in the late 60's; now it's noon.
As the stir over Douglas Ginsburg's marijuana smoking demonstrates, the anti-authoritarian generation born after World War II has begun to assume authority in a conservative, non-permissive era.
As long as the resulting conflicts and contradictions concerned purely private foibles, society could avoid coming to grips with them.


Air Force Missile Blows Up
LEAD: Air Force officials aborted the launching of an unarmed Minuteman 2 missile, blowing it up seconds after it left its pad Monday evening.
The aborted launching, which also set a brief brush fire, did not represent a major setback to the test program, but no immediate details were available on the reason for the failure.


Lest We Forget
LEAD: They walk as if on hallowed ground.
They touch the stone and speak with the dead.
They come to mourn and to remember - an old ritual made new, creating in this time another timeless moment.


Soldier Killed by Jersey Trooper
LEAD: One soldier was fatally shot and a second soldier was wounded in a fight with a state trooper who tried to arrest them for marijuana possession on the New Jersey Turnpike, the authorities said today.


DIRTY LYRICS: WORSE THAN DIRTY
LEAD: Now that Albert Gore Jr. is running for President, he'd like to cultivate the entertainment business - Los Angeles being a deep well for Democratic fund raising.
But the business has come to know his wife, Tipper, as a leading critic of raunchy rock music lyrics.
Such criticism is not the sort of thing that gets entertainment dollars flowing.


State Guidelines Try to Bring Equity To Child Support
LEAD: IN coming months, there will be a new and potentially influential factor to deal with on the issue of child-support payments: a set of numerical formulas to spell out for courts around the nation how much money is to be allocated to children.


Impact of the Prince of Prints
LEAD: Kenneth Tyler, the fine-art printer, remembers that a mere 30 years ago prints in this country were small, timidly black and white and mainly collected by book lovers.
Now they are large, bold and done by first-rank artists, thanks in part to Mr.
Tyler himself.
Thinking big and in glorious color, he has worked with such talents as Robert Motherwell, Frank Stella, Roy Lichtenstein and David Hockney to extend their vivid imagery into the graphic arts.


60-MINUTE GOURMET
LEAD: IT always amuses me that the foods I prepare with the least effort are often the most appealing to my guests.
I am speaking, in particular, of fish and seafood stews.
Once the ingredients are assembled, I can prepare a fish stew in 20 minutes.


Industrial Advertising Study by McGraw-Hill
LEAD: McGraw-Hill has released the findings of a study on industrial advertising that should make some converts to the cause.


Jackie Vernon, 62; Comic in Television, Film and Nightclubs
LEAD: Jackie Vernon, a television and nightclub comedian, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Hollywood.
He was 62 years old.


Wshington Talk: Briefing; Don't Invite 'Em
LEAD: It was unusual enough that top officials of the Sandinista Government of Nicaragua should be attending a diplomatic reception at the State Department.
But the event, in honor of the Organization of American States, quickly turned undiplomatic as Adolfo Calero, a leader of the American-backed rebels who are trying to topple the Sandinistas, sought to shake hands with Victor Tinoco, the Nicaraguan Deputy Foreign


Stark Hesseltine Dies; Was Theatrical Agent
LEAD: Stark Hesseltine, a theatrical agent who represented some well-known actors and actresses in his career, died of an AIDS-related illness last Wednesday at New York University Medical Center.
He was 58 years old and a resident of Manhattan and East Hampton, L.I.


Three Manhattan Theaters Are Given Landmark Status
LEAD: The inside of the Biltmore Theater and the outside of the Broadhurst Theater became New York City landmarks yesterday, bringing to 13 the number of houses in the theater district to be designated by the Landmarks Preservation Commission.


Coliseum Urged To Keep Raiders
LEAD: By a 10-1 vote, the City Council today urged the Los Angeles Coliseum Commission to use the $19.6 million it received from an antitrust lawsuit settlement with the National Football League to improve the stadium and persuade the Los Angeles Raiders to remain there.


BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY: Advances; A Reactor That Can't Melt Down?
LEAD: MORE than a decade after the last order was placed in this country for a commercial nuclear plant, some engineers and utility analysts think it is time to start developing a second generation of reactors that would be meltdown-proof.
Their hope is that these reactors would be available when the demand for power picks up and when cost or environmental impact makes fossil fuels unattractive.

Washington Talk: Briefing; High-Flying Snow Goose
LEAD: More than 800 paintings of North American ducks and geese were in competition yesterday in the United States Fish and Wildlife Service's annual Duck Stamp contest.
The winning entry, of a lesser snow goose flying over an early morning marsh, was painted by Daniel Smith of Eden Prairie, Minn.

LEAD: Under heavy pressure from Congress to do something about flight delays, the Department of Transportation today issued its first comprehensive monthly ranking of major airlines' on-time performance.

LEAD: Kenneth M. Leffelman, the 59-year-old head of a beleaguered family, is in the county jail, the third farmer to be jailed in this area in disputes pitting them against lenders, officials and the courts.

Arty?

Albert Kreindler, Real Estate Lawyer, 59
LEAD: Albert Kreindler, a real estate lawyer and former member of the New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission, died Thursday at Mount Sinai Hospital after a long illness.
He was 59 years old and lived in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.


Ex-Goveror of Virginia To Seek Seat in Senate
LEAD: Former Gov.
Charles S. Robb, a Democrat, said today he would seek the United States Senate seat of Paul S. Trible Jr., a Republican who has said he would not run for re-election next year.


Graham D. Mattison, Investment Banker, 81
LEAD: Graham D. Mattison, a retired investment banker, died Nov. 3 at his home in Rio de Janeiro after a long illness.
He was 81 years old.


Niger Head's Death Costs West Ally Against Libya
LEAD: President Seyni Kountche of the West African country of Niger died of a brain tumor in a Paris hospital today after 13 years in office.


Abdel Sharkawi, 67, Egyptian Leftist Writer
LEAD: Abdel Rahman Sharkawi, an Egyptian writer and left-wing political figure, died of a heart attack today, his 67th birthday, the Middle East News Agency said.

LEAD: The Federal Bureau of Investigation completed an exhaustive background check today on Judge Anthony M. Kennedy, the probable nominee for the Supreme Court, and reported to the White House that no significant problems had been found, a senior Administration official said today.

TV Reviews; 20 Years After 'Sgt. Pepper'
LEAD: IT really was 20 years ago -June 1, 1967, to be exact, when the Beatles released ''Sgt.
Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band'' in Britain.
Was it the greatest and most influential rock album ever made? ''Sgt.
Pepper: It Was 20 Years Ago Today'' declares it was all that and more.
The two-hour documentary, on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock tonight, revisits a time and place.


Votes Against U.N. Slander
LEAD: Just 12 years ago, the United Nations adopted an ugly resolution equating Zionism with racism.
Voting on the anniversary, the House joined the Senate in unanimously approving a resolution calling on the General Assembly to repudiate that resolution.
Congress rightly condemned it for offending the U.N.


Trump and Saudis
LEAD: To the Editor:


An Arab Consensus Is Seen on Opposition to Iran
LEAD: A meeting of Arab leaders here appears to have realigned the balance of power in the Middle East in favor of the pragmatic policies and moderate forces opposed to Iran and led by Jordan, Saudi Arabia and Arab oil producers in the Persian Gulf.


Manila Forms Band to Fight Rebel Groups
LEAD: As 200 residents of the city's Tondo slum area looked on, police Maj.
Romeo Maganto, with a quick twist of his forearm, flipped one of his lieutenants onto the grass outside his station house.


The 2 1/2 No's
LEAD: The Chinese have taught us that not every problem in diplomacy has to be solved in a hurry.


From One Cookbook, an Expert Chef Was Made
LEAD: WHEN Faye Levy went to France in 1976, she figured she would stay for six weeks - just long enough to take a course at La Varenne, the newly opened cooking school that had been recommended to her by Julia Child.


First Executive Won't Issue Shares
LEAD: The First Executive Corporation said it was dropping a plan made last month to issue 10.5 million shares at $17.15 each, or $180.1 million, to the ICH Corporation.
First Executive's stock has declined sharply since the market's collapse, and closed today at $9.75, down 12.5 cents, in over-the-counter trading.


PARTY IN QUEBEC LOSES ITS LEADER
LEAD: Barely a week after the death of Rene Levesque, the party's founder, the leader of the Parti Quebecois has been forced to resign by militants who want to revive the campaign for Quebec's independence.


Veterans Day
LEAD:  NEW YORK  Parade: Begins at 9 A.M. at 39th Street and Fifth Avenue, heads south to 24th Street and ends about noon.
Parking: Alternate-side parking suspended.
Sanitation: No collection or street cleaning.
Government offices: Federal, state and municipal offices closed.
Post offices: Open at 90 Church Street, 909 Third Avenue, Grand Central Terminal, 610 Fifth Avenue, and 33d Street and 8th Avenue.


Mother Sued Over Payment For Son's Liver Transplant
LEAD: The Pittsburgh hospital where 7-year-old Ronnie DeSillers died last spring while awaiting his fourth liver transplant is now suing the boy's mother for $261,189 in unpaid bills.


Small Bank's President Looks to Foreign Cash
LEAD: Leeds Hackett said yesterday that he realized that a collapse in the stock market and a falling dollar did not herald the best time to open a small bank aimed at helping foreigners invest in the United States.


Layoffs Are Seen At Chrysler Plant
LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation plans to lay off more than 1,700 workers at the automaker's plant in Newark, Del., a union official said.
A Chrysler spokesman in Detroit said, ''We informed the union there is a possibility.
The assembly plant schedules are always in review.
Nothing is etched in stone.''

EXCHANGES OPEN TODAY
LEAD: Stock and commodity exchanges in New York and Chicago will be open today, Veterans Day.
In New York most leading banks will be closed, so foreign-exchange markets will be vir-tually inactie in the United States.
In the credit markets, Treasury issues will not be traded, but corporate, mu-nicipal and futures issues will be.

LEAD: For 59 of her 60 years Helen Myers has loved books.


Madeline Levine, Professor, 85
LEAD: Madeline Levine, a retired professor of early childhood education at New York University, died of Parkinson's disease Thursday at St.
Vincent's Hospital.
She was 85 years old and lived in Manhattan.


G.E. Credit Notes
LEAD: The General Electric Credit Corporation is offering $300 million of 8 3/4 percent notes due in 1992 for 99.562 to yield 8.86 percent through underwriters led by its affiliate, Kidder, Peabody &amp; Company.
The triple-A-rated notes are not callable and yield about six-tenths of a percentage point more than five-year Treasury notes.

LEAD: Two more top aides left Gov.
Evan Mecham's staff Monday.
One, facing extortion charges, resigned shortly after his trial date was set, and the other took a leave of absence to head the Mr.
Mecham's fight against a special election to oust him from office.


Bridge: Some Jump Shift Responses Have Fallen From Fashion
LEAD: An obvious bid that has become unfashionable is the direct jump shift in response to a suit opening, hinting at a slam.


Islanders Capitalize on 3 by LaFontaine
LEAD: There are drawbacks to making history, among them having to explain it, being required to assess it and forever being asked to relive it.
For the last three days, Pat LaFontaine, microphones stuck in his face and television cameras blinding his eyes, has wanted to do nothing so much with history as make it a thing of the past.


Italian Chefs Come to U.S. Bearing Regions' Bounty
LEAD: FROM neighborhood pizza parlors to big brassy dinner clubs, Italian restaurants have been among America's favorite dining-out choices throughout much of this century.
But the very words ''Italian restaurant'' have meant different things at different times to different people.
The most recent change is producing some of the most interesting and exciting eating places in years.

LEAD: A former smoker, a writer who has gone two and a half years without a cigarette, offered this description of her efforts to quit, in hopes that others can better appreciate what it takes.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  Tennis  Bunge Advances: Seventh-seeded Bettina Bunge of Switzerland overcame Larisa Savchenko of the Soviet Union, 6-2, 6-1, yesterday in the first round of the $150,000 Virginia Slims of Chicago.
Savchenko's doubles partner, Natalya Zvereva, survived her first-round test by eliminating Betsy Nagelsen, 6-3, 6-2.


Some of the Best To Miss Cup Races
LEAD: The seven Breeders' Cup races at Hollywood Park Nov. 21 drew 106 preliminary entries yesterday, but several of the nation's very best runners were not among them.


Insider Purchases Soaring
LEAD: Executives are putting their money where their mouths are.
Ever since Oct. 19, the day the stock market plunged 508 points, they have been insisting that their companies are fundamentally sound.
Now a survey shows that executives have been putting their own money into their companies' stock at an unprecedented rate.

LEAD: The National Collegiate Athletic Association's one-week period for the early signing of basketball players begins today, offering high-school stars an opportunity to make early commitments to colleges deeply interested in tapping and refining their abilities to dribble, pass, rebound and shoot.

LEAD: Brokerage houses, the central bank and the Government's development bank are working on a rescue plan to stabilize the Mexican stock market, one of the world's fastest-rising trading arenas until last month's plunge, analysts said today.


The Short Life of a Former Foster Child
LEAD: For a brief time two years ago, Reggie Brown, known as Gizmo to his friends, emerged from the ranks of the anonymous young homeless to enjoy an unlikely celebrity.
His tragic odyssey through the foster-care system had cast him as a plaintiff in a lawsuit that held out the promise for sweeping changes in what happens to children after they become too old for foster care.


Allied Names President
LEAD: As expected, the Allied Stores Corporation has appointed Robert H. Morosky, who resigned as a top official of The Limited Inc. in June, as its president and chief operating officer.
Mr.
Morosky, 46 years old, will join Allied on Nov. 30.
The Campeau Corporation of Toronto purchased Allied Stores in December in a $3.5 billion leveraged buyout and sold most of its division.

EUROPE-PRETORIA TRADE
LEAD: European Community imports from South Africa were one-third lower in the first quarter of 1987 than in the 1986 period last year, according to community figures released today.
The fall reflects trade in general, an European Community commission report said, and not just restrictions on imports of iron, steel and gold coins from South Africa, which com-munity foreign ministers agreed to September 1986.

The U.N. Today: Nov. 11, 1987
LEAD:  GENERAL ASSEMBLY


Case Raises Questions In Homless Roundup
LEAD: When Mayor Koch began an effort to hospitalize mentally ill homeless people against their will last month, he called it the ''single most important program'' of his administration.
Instead of clarifying the issue, the case of Joyce Brown - the first person picked up under the program aimed at treating homeless people who cannot care for themselves - has sharpened the debate over how government should care for the homeless.


Jordan Leads Bulls Past Hawks, 105-95
LEAD: Michael Jordan scored 29 points for Chicago, and the Bills took advantage of 38 percent shooting by the Atlanta Hawks for a 105-95 victory tonight.


LAWSUIT SETTLED IN TEAMSTER CASE
LEAD: The Labor Department today announced the settlement of a lawsuit filed nearly 10 years ago against the former trustees of the principal pension fund of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.


NBC Leads TV Ratings For 2d Week in Row
LEAD: NBC handily won the ratings race for the second consecutive week, with help Sunday from the first installment of the mini-series ''Billionaire Boys Club,'' according to figures released yesterday by the A. C. Nielsen Company.


Art Center For Tower In Midtown
LEAD: AFTER more than six years of planning and construction, a 32-story office tower at the northwest corner of Lexington Avenue and 57th Street, which will have an opulent marketplace for art and antiques as its centerpiece, is nearly finished.
The antique center opens next week and the office space early next year.


LET THEM EAT GLASTNOST, FRENCH COMMUNISTS SAY
LEAD: In this crumbling bastion of the French Communist Party, where Marx's prophecies are being confounded, the only real hope for Communist comrades is a movement of renewal begun by Mikhail S. Gorbachev in distant Moscow.


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: An article in Business Day last Wednesday, about the legal hopes of Texaco Inc. in the Supreme Court, erroneously described shareholder suits related to the litigation with the Pennzoil Company.
While Texaco shareholders have sued company directors for their handling of the dispute, Pennzoil shareholders have not.


Shift in Public Assistance Urged At a Meeting on Minority Children
LEAD: Government officials and scholars, discussing the plight of the state's black and Hispanic children, called today for changing the emphasis of public assistance to focus more on neighborhoods than individuals.


McDonald's Is Urged to Alter Packaging
LEAD: New York State asked the McDonald's Corporation today to take its Big Macs, Chicken McNuggets and other foods out of Styrofoam and serve them in biodegradable materials.


Poles Seize Underground Leader
LEAD: The police have arrested a fugitive leader of the opposition underground, Kornel Morawiecki, the founder of a clandestine group called Fighting Solidarity, for ''using false identity cards,'' the Government's spokesman said today.

A Time to Recognize Women Are Veterans Too
LEAD: To the Editor:


Standard Brands Recapitalization
LEAD: The Standard Brands Paint Company, which rejected a takeover bid last month, said it had begun a $193 million recapitalization plan that would increase the company's debt and adopted a poison-pill style shareholder rights plan to deter an unfriendly takeover.


TV Reviews; 'Divided Union,' Series On Civil War, on A&amp;E
LEAD: IN the midst of a ''Celebration of America'' campaign, cable's Arts &amp; Entertainment Network is presenting, beginning tonight at 9 o'clock, a five-part series entitled ''The Divided Union.'' As a co-production of A&amp;E and Peter Batty Productions, this account of the Civil War is one of those sometimes confusing television exercises that mixes comments by historians and genuine archival photographs with ''actual re-enactments'' of battles, filmed on locations from Fort Sumter to Appomattox.


Gore Everybody's Ox
LEAD: After two weeks of push and shove, the pieces of a credible budget deficit-reduction deal lie scattered on the negotiating table in Washington.
What White House and Congressional negotiators need to put it together is the courage not to compromise too readily and settle for too little.


Judge Weighs Texaco Plea
LEAD: A Federal judge reserved decision today on whether to grant Texaco Inc.'s request to disband one of the two creditors committees in its Chapter 11 bankruptcy case.


Washington Talk: Briefing; Deficit of Another Sort
LEAD: Representative Guy Vander Jagt of Michigan, chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee, mailed a solicitation letter to potential donors last week in which he admitted that the committee was ''seriously behind in our fund-raising.''


RESTRAINT DEVICES CHOSEN BY POLICE
LEAD: New York City police officials, seeking to equip the department with something more powerful than a nightstick but less deadly than a gun, have chosen five devices to be used in dangerous situations.

BORDEN ACQUIRES 8 SMALL CNCERNS
LEAD: Borden Inc. said that it had ac-quired eight small companies at a total cost of $55 million.
Since March 1986, Borden has invested more than $1 billion in 39 acquisitions, which ac-count for $2 billion of its $6.5 billion in 1987 projected annual sales.


First Interstate
LEAD: First Interstate Bancorp is offering $150 million of 9 3/8 percent notes due in 1992 for 100 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.
The notes, rated Aa-3 by Moody's Investors Service and AA- by the Standard &amp; Poor's Corporation, are not callable and yield about 1 1/8 percentage points more than Treasury issues of similar maturity.


Elusive Rebels Are Spreading Fear Across Peru
LEAD: Decorating the walls of the University of San Marcos here, revolutionary graffiti, informational bulletin boards and huge mural paintings of Mao and Marx testify to the presence of Shining Path guerrillas in Peru's oldest center of learning.

ELIE WIESEL IN PLEA TO GERMANS
LEAD: Speaking, he said, from the ''very rostrum'' from which his death and that of his people were ''decreed and predicted,'' Elie Wiesel, chronicler of the Nazi crimes, appealed to German youths today to ''fight forgetfulness'' about their past.

Market Place; G.M.'s Allure: Hefty Dividend
LEAD: YEARS ago, the mighty General Motors Corporation was regarded as the quality leader and low-cost producer in the automobile industry.
But times have changed.
Nowadays, many analysts see as G.M.'s chief attraction its hefty dividend yield of slightly more than 8.5 percent.


Southland Buyout Hits Snag
LEAD: The owner of the 7-Eleven chain, the Southland Corporation, said today that it could not proceed with its plan to become a private company because of the unreceptive climate for high-risk bonds.


Waves of Panic Buying Push Copper Prices Up
LEAD: Waves of panic buying sent copper futures soaring yesterday on New York's Commodity Exchange amid fears that supplies were drying up.


Dollar Drop For Months Is Predicted
LEAD: The dollar's value is likely to continue to decline for at least the next few months, many economists and participants in the foreign-exchange markets say.


A Salt Substitute for America's Roads
LEAD: First comes the snow; then, instantly comes the salt.
In a typical winter, highway departments spread about 10 million tons of it to keep roads safe and dry.
Homeowners spread more on driveways and sidewalks.
The corrosive effects are well known but for years they've been dismissed with the argument that at $25 per ton, salt is far cheaper than any alternative.


Transplant Patient Alert

Sikh Leader Slain in London
LEAD: Two gunmen burst into a London school today and opened fire on a mixed Hindu and Sikh congregation, killing a moderate Sikh leader and wounding three others, the police said.
The police were questioning two men held by members of the congregation after the incident, which occurred during a religious service in the Southall district.

Man in the News; Restrained Pragmatist Anthony M. Kennedy
LEAD: In the modern world of family turmoil, the life of Judge Anthony McLeod Kennedy seems almost like a living Norman Rockwell portrait of provincial constancy and familial loyalty.
He has been married to the same woman for 24 years, has sent all three of his children to his alma mater, Stanford University, and lives in the same white colonial-style house in Sacramento, behind a camelia bush and a neat row of gardenias, where he was born 51 years ago.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Q.The shingles on our house are dark and weather-beaten.
We are uncertain as to how to paint them and how often to do it.
Can you help?
A.Assuming they are wood shingles or shakes, they should be stained or treated with a clear wood preservative.
Using a paint on shingles almost always results in peeling and flaking.

Whither Ginsburg?
LEAD: President Reagan never formally submitted Judge Ginsburg's nomination to the Senate.
Thus it does not fit into any of the categories in which Supreme Court nominations are recorded in the annals of Congress: ''confirmed,'' ''rejected,'' ''withdrawn,'' ''postponed'' and ''not acted upon.''

C.P.A. Fights Florida Soliciting Ban
LEAD: A certified public accountant in Florida has sued the state's Board of Accountancy, seeking to overturn two laws that prohibit him from soliciting clients or quoting prices for audits.


Sixers Sign Robinson
LEAD: The Philadelphia 76ers came to terms with Cliff Robinson yesterday, signing the forward to a two-year contract, said General Manager John Nash.
Other terms of the contract were not disclosed.
The agreement settled a dispute that kept Robinson from playing in eight exhibition games and the season opener.


Smaller Trade Gap Seen for September
LEAD: The trade deficit for September will be announced today, and the amount is likely to be lower, but not by much, than the $15.7 billion deficit for August that helped to set off the stock market collapse last month.

LEAD: IF you'd enjoy good food and a chance to chat with some of this country's most dedicated Atlantic salmon anglers and conservationists, you should plan to attend the Atlantic Salmon Federation's annual dinner at the Plaza Hotel, 59th Street and Fifth Avenue, Nov. 19.

Two M.T.A. Rail Lines Plan Smoking Limits
LEAD: The Long Island Rail Road is to announce a plan today to eliminate smoking on trains that operate on its five shortest branches.
These trains constitute more than 300 of the 700 daily trips on the L.I.R.R.

Good news, even.

CABARET: ANDREA MARCOVICCI
LEAD: ANDREA MARCOVICCI, the singer and actress who made her first New York nightclub appearance in 10 years on Tuesday at the Algonquin Hotel, calls herself a torch singer.
To Miss Marcovicci, the term does not imply the masochism epitomized by Helen Morgan, Libby Holman or even Billie Holiday.
Instead it is synonymous with a longstanding tradition of movie love song evocative of a genteel, high-styled romantic sensibility.


3 Banks in West Fail
LEAD: Three banks in the Western United States have failed, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation announced today, bringing the year's total to 159.
The F.D.I.C. said it was seeking to arrange a takeover for the Middle Park Bank of Granby, Colo., and its affiliate, the Bank of Winter Park in Winter Park, Colo., which had assets of $35.4 million and $25.9 million, respectively.


Designers Work On Bellevue Rooms
LEAD: DEBORAH QUINTAL designs interiors for country clubs and grand Manhattan apartments.
Bonnie Roche, an architect, rebuilds rooms for clients like Paloma Picasso.
And Richard Knapple coordinates lavish settings for Bloomingdale's.


Smurfs Join Kean at Opening Of Jersey City Shopping Mall
LEAD: New York got more competition from New Jersey today as a new shopping mall, Hudson County's first, opened on the Hudson waterfront here, a 10-minute PATH ride from lower Manhattan.

Catering to a Couch Potato's Every Need
LEAD: The tom-toms are beating a new trend-watching message: the hot place to be this year is at home.
The young and the stylish, now the professional and the tired, are spending supine evenings in front of the television. ''Couch Potatoes'' like these are rapidly gaining attention as the new ''in'' crowd, and they are inspiring a raft of novelty items.

Fine Weaving That's Functional
LEAD: TODAY Lisa Wagner, right, opens Treadles, a shop that features handwoven goods - rugs, blankets, placemats, napkins and pillows -made by 70 artisans.
The idea came to her two years ago, when she took up weaving as a hobby and noted that except in museums, fine weaving was not easily available. ''Weavers tend to work in isolation,'' said Ms.


ITT and Units Settle Fraud Suit
LEAD: The ITT Corporation and its loan subsidiaries have agreed to settle a fraud and racketeering suit by refunding up to $2.6 million to about 50,000 Arizona borrowers and to pay additional penalties to end a potential Government case against them, officials said.
The companies, accused of raising profits by packing unneeded and largely useless insurance into consumer loans, did not admit or deny guilt.


Europeans Disagree On U.S. Budget Cut
LEAD: European officials and economists welcomed the news from Washington today that an announcement on reducing the budget deficit might be imminent, but they differed over whether a cut of about $25 billion would calm the turbulent financial markets.


Heroes, and Stale Heroics
LEAD: Last weekend's bloodless ouster of Tunisia's President-for-Life Habib Bourguiba was the final stanza of a sadly commonplace saga.
When Tunisia wrested independence from France in 1956, Mr.
Bourguiba was rightly acclaimed as liberator.
But like the sampling of leaders shown above, he came to regard himself as permanently indispensable.


South Africa Acknowledges Its Troops Aided Angolan Rebels
LEAD: South Africa acknowledged for the first time today that its troops have fought in southern Angola on the side of anti-Government rebels.


Battered Enough
LEAD: New York City's Department of Correction has stationed two officers outside Hedda Nussbaum's private room to guard her 24 hours a day.
Has it really been necessary also to shackle and chain her by one leg to her hospital bed?


Hayes Theater for Sale
LEAD: The Helen Hayes Theater, one of the smallest on Broadway and one of the few still wholly independently owned, will be sold at an international real estate auction on March 24, according to a statement released jointly by Christie's and Cushman &amp; Wakefield, which are holding the sale.

Stage: By Durang, 'Laughing Wild'

Although Christopher Durang's new comedy at Playwrights Horizons is mostly in the form of stand-up monologues and might also be titled ''The World According to Me!,'' the laughter does not come nearly so easily.

HOME IMPROVEMENT
LEAD: SQUEAKY, wobbly stairs aren't just a nuisance.
They can be hazardous if trouble spots are allowed to worsen.
Squeaks are caused by stair parts rubbing against each other.
You can silence many staircase noises merely by applying powdered graphite or some other dry lubricant to reduce the friction.
But stair parts shouldn't move at all, and while lubricating them may mask the symptoms, it is not a cure for the disease.


Islanders Managing to Thrive
LEAD: Of late, it's getting increasingly hard to tell which is more difficult for the Islanders: to maintain a lead in the third period or a straight face in the locker room after losing one.


Portrait of Home, in Paint, Clay or Fabric
LEAD: ''THE ornament of a house is the friends who frequent it,'' said Ralph Waldo Emerson.
But for a growing number of homeowners, the ornament is the house itself - depicted in a watercolor, on a needlepoint pillow, on cocktail napkins or sculptured in clay.

Paper Capacity to Rise
LEAD: American paper manufacturers are expected to increase their production capacity by 3 percent in 1987 and 2.5 percent over the next three years, according to a paper industry trade group.
The American Paper Institute said yesterday that a survey of manufacturers indicated primary paper and paperboard production capacity should reach 78 million tons this year, an increase of 2.24 million tons from 1986.

LEAD: The General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade narrowly averted a cash crisis when Italy announced it had paid its 1987 contribution of about $2 million to the trade body, a GATT spokesman, David Woods, said today.

The hourlong program is called ''A Blues Session: B. B. King and Friends'' and it can be seen tonight at 11:30.

LEAD: The Rev.
Channing E. Phillips, a civil rights leader and the first black to be placed in nomination for the Presidency of the United States by a major political party, died of cancer yesterday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center.
He was 59 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: Though the Payson van Gogh does not rank among the greatest paintings of its period in France, it is a very beautiful picture.

A Report Sees No Major Troop Cuts
LEAD: A study under review by the Reagan Administration concludes that it may not be possible to reach an important new agreement on conventional arms with the Soviet Union that will yield major military benefits for the West The study, which was prepared for the Air Force by the Rand Corporation, an independent research center that receives Federal funds, comes as Western nations and Soviet-bloc nations are preparing for new talks on reducing conventional arms in Europe from the Atlantic to the Urals.

Mets Trade Blocker
LEAD: The Mets traded Terry Blocker, a minor-league outfielder, to the Atlanta Braves yesterday for a player to be named.
Blocker, 27 years old, was the Mets' No. 1 selection in the June 1981 draft.
Last season, playing at Tidewater of the International League, he he was among the league leaders in average (.312, tied for third), hits (164, tied for second), steals (33, tied for fifth), and runs (89, third).

Concert: Soloists With the Jupiter
LEAD: ORCHESTRAS have increasingly turned to programs in which some or all of the pieces feature orchestra members as soloists.
This is presumably good for morale, good for the budget (since members usually cost less than high-profile virtuosos) and maybe even good for the audience, since the musicians are often excellent and the orchestra's esprit de corps is theoretically reinforced.


Bridge: Tournament Sex Bias Case Is Set for Courtroom Today
LEAD: A bridge paradox is to come before a judge in Los Angeles today.
It is the climax of a three-year effort by a Manhattan couple, Robert and Gillian Blanchard, to prevent the American Contract Bridge League from conducting gender-based events, which they claim breach California's Unruh Act, which bars discrimination based on race, sex, religion or national origin.

Svetlana Alliluyeva Allowed To Settle Once More in Britain
LEAD: Svetlana Alliluyeva, Stalin's daughter, has been given permission to resettle in Britain from the United States, the Home Office said today.


Van Gogh's 'Irises' Sells for $53.9 Million
LEAD: Van Gogh's glowing ''Irises'' -painted in 1889 during the artist's first week at the asylum at St.-Remy - was sold at Sotheby's in New York last night for $53.9 million, the highest price ever paid for an artwork at auction.
The sale of 100 artworks, in which 75 were sold, totaled $110 million, a record total for an art auction.


Youmans Checks Out
LEAD: Floyd Youmans, the Montreal Expo pitcher, has left an alcohol rehabilitation center he checked into last month and has made ''great progress,'' the club's general manager, Bill Stoneman, said yesterday. ''I've spoken with him and I'm very encouraged,'' Stoneman said. ''He sounded like a totally different man.


With Eagles Winning, Ryan Changes His Tune
LEAD: Buddy Ryan's meaning is often obscured by his folksy Oklahoma drawl.
But he is coming across loud and clear these days as the hard-driving coach of the Eagles, whose regulars have won four straight games and who face the Giants Sunday in Philadelphia.


Handling All The Details
LEAD: THE cost of moving a house depends upon its size and the distance it must travel.
If public thoroughfares are involved, a major expense is the cost of moving electrical, telephone and other wires.

Dr. Abner H. Rosenthal; Phoenix House Staff Physician, 81
LEAD: Dr.
Abner H. Rosenthal, a physician who practiced family medicine in Queens for nearly 50 years before joining Phoenix House, a drug-abuse services agency, as a staff physician, died of complications Tuesday following a stroke at his home in Flushing, Queens.
He was 81 years old.
Dr.
Rosenthal, a graduate of City College, received his medical degree from the University of Maryland in 1930.


Options' Risks Shown By Stock Market Slide
LEAD: The stock market's collapse on Oct. 19 showed once again the potential volatility of the securities markets.
And it demonstrated to thousands of investors around the country that options can be among the most volatile of all instruments in these markets, even for those who use them in conjunction with other strategies.

Percentage of Jobless Lacking Benefits Is Highest in 30 Years
LEAD: Almost three-quarters of the nation's jobless workers received no unemployment insurance benefits last month, the greatest percentage recorded in more than 30 years, a private research group said today.


Santa Fe Delays Public Sale
LEAD: The Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation, which has received two takeover offers, said today that it was postponing a plan to sell part of its oil and gas operations to the public.
It cited market turmoil.


Building Collapse Kills Baby and Traps 4 in Greenwich Village
LEAD: A five-story building in Greenwich Village collapsed yesterday morning, trapping five residents and causing the death of one of them, a 13-month-old boy.
Officials said the building had been undergoing renovation without proper construction permits and supervision.

Tempo Enterprises
LEAD: The board of Tempo Enterprises Inc. tenatively approved a takeover offer from Tele-Communications Inc., the nation's largest cable television system operator.
The offer provides for an exchange of TCI common stock for Tempo common stock valued at $8 a share.
Tempo shareholders will be given the option of receiving $8 in cash a share for each of their shares or converting to TCI stock.

Air Cleanup: Clash of Aims; Help for One Region May Harm Another
LEAD: For environmental and public health groups seeking to strengthen the Clean Air Act, this seemed to be the year to do it.
It has been 10 years since the last major revisions were made in the antigress seemed to have several compelling reasons for making changes this year.
The first is a Dec. 31 deadline by which cities must lower smog and carbon monoxide to levels deemed necessary to protect human health, as prescribed in the current law.

Ivan Lendl downed Ronald Agenor of Haiti, 6-2, 6-1, in a match interrupted for 20 minutes because of rain seeping through a hole in the roof at the arena.

The room is black.
The corners are black.
Black houses.
And black - I myself.''

Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, a dispatch on Aug. 24 from Vilnius, U.S.S.R., about protest rallies in the former Baltic nations misidentified a monument in Riga, Latvia, where 5,000 people were reported to have gathered.
The site was the Monument of Liberty, which dates from the period of Latvian independence; it is not a memorial to war victims.

So it wouldn't be correct to blame him for lowering his head and ignoring his teammates when the Knicks were desperate.

Cadbury Objection
LEAD: Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C. said it would reject any request for management involvement from the General Cinema Corporation, a United States company that has more than doubled its stake in the British candy and beverage maker.
As yet, it has received no approach from General Cinema, Cadbury said, but it described the share purchase as a highly opportunistic move by an American corporation with a market capitalization little more than half of Cadbury's.

LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said it plans to spend about $3 billion next year and a similar amount in 1989 to expand its long-distance telephone network.

Hogeboom to Start
LEAD: Coach Ron Meyer of the Indianapolis Colts said yesterday that Gary Hogeboom would start at quarterback for the first time in four weeks when the Colts play the Dolphins in Miami on Sunday.
Hogeboom suffered a broken rib and a punctured lung in a game against the Jets during the National Football League strike and has since been replaced by Jack Trudeau.


COMPANY BRIEFS
LEAD: *
AVX Corp., Great Neck, L.I., a maker of multilayer ceramic capacitors, said it had completed the purchase of the multilayer ceramic, glass and tantalum capacitor operations of Corning Glass Works for $66 million.
Separately, Corning sold its resistor operations to Vishay Intertechnology Inc. for $37 million.


REAGAN NOMINATES ANTHONY KENNEDY TO SUPREME COURT
LEAD: President Reagan, stung by the failure of two nominations to the Supreme Court in the last three weeks, today nominated Judge Anthony M. Kennedy and expressed the hope that he could be confirmed quickly in a spirit of bipartisan cooperation.


G.M. Seen Closing Plant Temporarily
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation will temporarily close its assembly plant in Hamtramck, Mich. in January, idling 2,500 workers, while it redesigns models produced there, according to a report published today.
The Detroit Free Press said the nation's largest auto maker would close the $600 million plant for three weeks as workers begin converting it for production of 1989 Buick Riviera and Oldsmobile Toronado models.

Power Rationed in Rumania
LEAD: Rumania announced strict rationing of power and natural gas today as the Communist country prepared for a fourth straight winter of restrictions and hardships for its 23 million people.
The Government declared a 30 percent reduction in natural gas and electricity quotas for private households until March 1.


U.S. TO BACK GENE-ENGINEERED DRUG FOR CLOTTING
LEAD: The Food and Drug Administration plans to announce approval of a new drug Friday that can reduce the damage of heart attacks by dissolving harmful blood clots, Government officials said today.

For Ex-Police Officer, New Life After Drugs
LEAD: His hands are steady now.
His voice is firm.
The police officer who became a cocaine addict and entered a drug treatment center 15 months ago is beginning to talk about returning to the world outside again, this time without a uniform, without a gun and without a secret life.

LEAD: HARDLY since the Diamond Jubilee of Queen Victoria in 1897 has an anniversary been as thoroughly celebrated as the 50th birthday of the Guggenheim Museum.
People by the hundreds danced, dined, drank, talked, reminisced.
The staff got to forget what day it was, and virtually every foreign artist who has ever shown at the Guggenheim flew in to pay tribute to Thomas M.

LEAD: An article yesterday on an anti-cholesterol drug misstated the cost of another drug, lovastatin.

Koch Rules Against Wider Role for Firefighters
LEAD: In an effort to resolve tensions between New York City's Police and Fire Departments, Mayor Koch last night announced that the Fire Department would be notified about more emergencies than it is now.
But he overruled a proposal to expand the firefighters' authority further.


Diner's Journal
LEAD: THE Lincoln Center area is always a challenge for those seeking interesting dining before or after performances.
A spiffy new Italian trattoria just across the street, called Poccino, is a welcome addition.
The sleek, glass-enclosed dining room and its futuristic bar look out on the Lincoln Center complex and the nonstop urban opera along Broadway.

Senate Backs A-Waste Site Plan
LEAD: The Senate today approved an overhaul of the nation's program for dealing with high-level nuclear waste that virtually chooses Nevada as the most likely state for a permanent repository for such waste.
The vote was 63 to 30.

CELLO CONCERTO
LEAD: The New York Chamber Sympho-ny, conducted by Gerard Schwarz, is to perform works by Mozart and the premierof a cello concerto by and Sunday at 3 P.M. at the 92d Street Y. Soloists for the concert are to be the pianist Alicia de Larrocha and Andre Emelianoff, cellist.
Tickets are $15 to $22.50.
Information: 966-1100.

Comings and Goings
LEAD: The World Boxing Association junior-featherweight champion, Louie Espinoza, has signed contracts for two fights - in Puerto Rico Nov. 28 against the eighth-ranked contender, Julio Gervacio, and Jan. 15 against Bernardo Pinango, the No. 1-ranked contender. . . .
Pernell Whitaker, a 1984 Olympic gold medalist, will fight Jose Luis Ramirez in Paris in March for the World Boxing Council's lightweight crown, according to Dan Duva, Whitaker's promoter.

Rangers Decide To Suffer Quietly
LEAD: The Rangers - victims of circumstances, injuries and too many changes - haven't won in their last eight games and have lost seven straight for the first time since 1963, but they have opted to cope quietly with their nonsuccess.


DUKAKIS SAYS GOVERNMENT CAUSED STOCK PLUNGE
LEAD: Gov.
Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts charged yesterday that last month's stock market plunge was ''a government-made disaster.''


South Boston Journal; Close-Knit Neighborhood Disowns a Favorite Son
LEAD: It took the residents of South Boston 161 years to elect one of their own as Mayor of Boston.

253 Pounds of Trouble for Jets
LEAD: On Sunday in Kansas City, the Jets will meet one of the more interesting new players in the National Football League, Christian Okoye of Enugu, Nigeria.


The Monthly Trade Figures: A Closely Watched Barometer
LEAD: The monthly trade figures have become a litmus test of sorts for the health of the overall United States economy.
This is why investors and traders in all the financial markets pay so much attention to the report - and, correspondingly, why the prices of stocks and bonds and the value of the dollar in relation to other major currencies can rise or fall, depending on how the actual figures stack up against expectations.


Call Is Issued for New Policy
LEAD: A group of American and European business leaders today called on governments to reduce the trade imbalances that have fueled turmoil in the financial markets.

Brunch Spots Where Music Is on the Menu
LEAD: GOING out to eat long ago ceased having much to do with simply eating.
From the power breakfast to the hot date, the number of variations on the general theme of dining out have mushroomed into a veritable smorgasbord of possibilities.


Met Opera: Pavarotti and Sutherland in 'Trovatore'
LEAD: NORMALLY it takes a new opera production years to decline to the point of terminal weariness and ineptitude, but the Metropolitan Opera's ''Trovatore'' reached that sad state in one evening, at last night's premiere.
Placing the blame precisely is not easy, simply because there is so much blame to go around.


John Lydenberg; Scholar, 74
LEAD: John Lydenberg, a retired professor of American literature at Hobart and William Smith Colleges in Geneva, N.Y., died of cancer Wednesday at his home in Princeton, N.J.
He was 74 years old.


Jailed for Paddling the Paddler
LEAD: A judge has held that it is all right for a school principal to paddle a pupil but wrong for the pupil's mother to hit a principal.


4 South Africa Soldiers Said to Die in Angola
LEAD: South Africa said today that four of its soldiers had been killed in combat with Cuban-backed Angolan troops in southeast Angola, in what appeared to be an intensification of the 12-year-old civil war in that country.

5,000 at NBC to Receive Stock as Gift After Strike
LEAD: Some 5,000 NBC employees who kept the network on the air during a 17-week strike by filling in as news writers, camera operators and engineers will be given a bonus of 10 shares each of General Electric stock.

No Winners at Tourney
LEAD: The yearly records of the Volvo International tennis tournament in Stratton Mountain, Vt., will show no singles or doubles champions for 1987.
Final matches in both events were rained out last Aug. 9 and, despite efforts by tournament officials to arrange for the finalists to return and complete the matches, the organizers announced yesterday they had given up.


Ford Plans New Stock Repurchase
LEAD: The Ford Motor Company, which has been reluctant to spend much of its cash hoard on acquisitions, said today that it would repurchase up to $2 billion of its own shares after a current buyback program ends.

British Jobless Rate Dips
LEAD: Britain's unemployment rate fell to a seasonally adjusted 9.8 percent in October, dropping below 10 percent for the first time in six years, the Department of Employment said today.
Total seasonally adjusted unemployment was estimated at 2.71 million people in October, down from a revised 2.77 million in September and 3.16 million in the comparable period a year ago.


Cleveland-Cliffs
LEAD: David F. Bolger, the New Jersey investment banker seeking control of Cleveland-Cliffs Inc., has hired Donaldson, Lufkin, &amp; Jenrette Inc. as his financial adviser.
Mr.
Bolger, who holds 1.05 million, or 8.5 percent, of Cleveland-Cliffs's shares, is soliciting proxies to replace the board of the Cleveland-based iron ore and gas drilling concern.


Dollar Perplexes Candidates
LEAD: What the Republican and Democratic candidates for the Presidency are saying about the dollar is, mostly, the obvious: it will remain weak until a workable long-term agreement is reached to reduce the nation's budget deficit.


San Francisco Fire Dept. Job Pact Faces Challenge
LEAD: A Federal district judge tentatively approved a settlement today establishing goals for hiring and promoting women and blacks in the San Francisco Fire Department.

Stocks, Dollar Advance In Asia on U.S. Report
LEAD: Share prices climbed this morning, as traders, buoyed by news of a shrinking American trade deficit and a stronger dollar, flooded the market with buy orders.

LEAD: Workers guiding 75-foot Norway spruce onto flatbed truck in Suffern, N.Y., for trip to Rockefeller Center.


THEATER: A MUSICAL, 'TEDDY AND ALICE'
LEAD: FOR those who worried that Broadway might be nothing more than a carnival fairway offering mindless fun, along comes ''Teddy and Alice,'' a show that fearlessly puts pedagogy back into the American musical.
An extravagant treatment of the life of our 26th President and his terminally spunky daughter, the production at the Minskoff is full of fascinating footnotes to our nation's proud history.

8 Charged With Mafia Drug Plot, Including Murders and Extortion
LEAD: Eight men with ties to organized crime were charged yesterday with conspiring to control drug sales at locations in Brooklyn and Staten Island in a pattern of racketeering that included murder, extortion and bribery.

Canadians Cool To Tunnel Plan
LEAD: The international underwriters of the $:750 million ($1.34 billion) Eurotunnel share issue said today that they had withdrawn plans to seek financing in Canada because of low interest among investors.


BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 13, 1987
LEAD:  The Economy


ARSON AT THE FRANKFURT OPERA
LEAD: The Frankfurt Opera House was badly damaged today by a fire started by an unemployed and homeless East German refugee, officials said.


Advertising; PEOPLE
LEAD: John M. Greening has been elected senior vice president of DDB Needham Woldwide, Chicago.


Whiteheads Divorce and Cite Battle For Baby M, Not Pregnancy, as Cause
LEAD: Richard and Mary Beth Whitehead were divorced here today, eight days after she formally revealed she was two months' pregnant by another man.


Economic Scene; World System Seeks Stability
LEAD: AFTER a week of intense discussions here among leading European and American economists and politicians, an agenda can be constructed of the critical problems to be solved if the stock market collapse is to be prevented from becoming a greater catastrophe.

From New Talent, Bold New Images
LEAD: IT sometimes seems that the exhibition scene in photography is characterized by an endless repetition of familiar names and images.
The names bring in the crowds, and the images help pay the rent.
But at the moment, as if by an unspoken, collective urge, the focus has shifted to the young and the undersung, giving them a showcase they sorely need if they are to follow in the footsteps of giants like Henri Cartier-Bresson and Edward


Kasparov Maintains His One-Point Lead
LEAD: Neither Gary Kasparov nor Anatoly Karpov was able to upset the balance of the 12th game of their world championship chess match in Seville, Spain, on Wednesday, and they agreed to an early draw.

LEAD: ''Who among us is not familiar with the tattered, filthy, malodorous presence of the wretched homeless?
The blame and shame must attach to us, not to them.''  - Acting JusticeRobert D. Lippmannof New York StateSupreme Court.  [ B2:2. ]

Corrections
LEAD: A picture caption on Tuesday with an article about Governor Cuomo's attendance at a conference in Tarrytown, N.Y., on the plight of minority-group children, reversed the identities of two of the women shown with Mr.
Cuomo.
Yveline Sylvain of the Youth Leadership Conference, was at the right, and next to her was Meredith Carey of the Manhattan Borough President's Youth Advisory Committee.


Carlucci Hints Budget Plan Portends Shrinking Military
LEAD: Frank C. Carlucci, President Reagan's choice to be the new Defense Secretary, said at his confirmation hearings today that continuing reductions in military spending are likely to lead to a smaller American military force.


Film: 'Cross My Heart,' a Date in Detail
LEAD: IF a date were a thing that could be examined under a microscope, then ''Cross My Heart'' offers some idea of what it might look like, warts and all.
The entire film concentrates on the all-important third encounter between David (Martin Short) and Kathy (Annette O'Toole), an event that the film deems critical for several reasons.

MARKETS REBOUND
LEAD: The nation's deficit in international trade shrank by a hefty $1.6 billion in September, improving against all major trading partners except Canada, the Commerce Department said today.


PAMELA B. RUBIN AND JON R. CARTER WED
LEAD: At Temple Emanu-El in New York, Pamela Beth Rubin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs.
Frederic P. Rubin of Old Westbury, L.I., was married yes-terday to Jon Robert Carter, the son of Arthur L. Carter of New York and Linda Gordon of Newfane, Vt.
Rabbis Ronald B. Sobel and Eugene Lipsey officiated.


3 Are Killed in Bangladesh Riots
LEAD: At least three people were reported killed today in a clash between rioters and the police as anti-Government protests continued sporadically and shops in central Dhaka were shut for half the day.


Lab Wars, Star Wars
LEAD: There is trouble in one of the key atomic weapons labs working on ''Star Wars,'' over an issue of greater importance than seeking a defense against missiles.
It is about whether defense of scientific integrity can be maintained against a push to make even the most technical questions political, if they can be exploited.


3-Year-Olds in Stretch
LEAD: Mack Lobell and Jate Lobell, 1986's top trotter and top pacer, will end their campaigns as 3-year-olds in Breeders Crown races Friday night at Pompano Park.


Australian 'Howling'
IF you see only one werewolf movie this year, you might as well make it ''Howling III,'' Philippe Mora's not-altogether straight-faced howler on behalf of lycanthropes' liberation.
Among other things, the Australian-made movie suggests there's nothing inherently evil about being a werewolf that a little human understanding wouldn't cure.
Mr.
Mora and his associates are blunt about it: this anti-werewolf hysteria must stop.
In the meantime, they're free to exploit it with a good deal of earnest levity. ''Howling III'' involves a tribe of indigenously Australian (marsupial) lycanthropes, a defecting Russian ballerina named Olga, who is herself a werewolf, and Beckmeyer, a hardworking, civil libertarian Australian professor, who has espoused the werewolf cause.


Shell Resists Bid
LEAD: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group has threatened to leave Brazil if a proposal to put the distribution of petroleum products solely in the hands of Government companies becomes law.
It is the second economic issue this month pitting Government interests against those of multinational companies.
Autolatina, a venture of the Ford Motor Company and West Germany's Volkswagenwerk A.G., has challenged the Brazilian Government's system of price controls in court.


PAINFUL VIEW OF HOWARD BEACH CASE
LEAD: For five weeks, a 42-year-old black woman, Jean Griffith, has sat in a Queens courtroom listening to graphic testimony describing how her son was killed and her fiance severely beaten last December in Howard Beach.


Tales of the Pioneers
LEAD: Even before they could vote in national elections, women sometimes attained positions of responsibility and authority in the Federal Government.
But they rarely received public recognition for their work.

LEAD: The new executive vice president of the University of Notre Dame, the man who controls the overall philosophy of the athletic department, is a priest with no experience in the administration of college sports.

Disney Profits Climb by 66.8%
LEAD: The Walt Disney Company, benefiting from an upswing in attendance at its theme parks and the popularity of its new and old film releases, said today that its earnings rose 66.8 percent in the fourth quarter.


Suez Canal Revenues Up
LEAD: The Suez Canal earned Egypt $1 billion in the first 10 months of 1987, up $50 million from a year earlier, Ezzat Adel, chairman of the Canal Authority, reported today.
An increase in ship tolls, scheduled for next year, has been canceled because of the world financial turmoil, he said.


Houston Post Sale Nearly Completed
LEAD: Media News Group Inc., the owner of The Dallas Times Herald and 27 other daily newspapers, is expected to complete next week its $150 million purchase of The Houston Post, the company said.
Originally announced Sept. 10, the all-cash purchase of the newspaper from the Toronto Sun Publishing Corporation was expected to close by Nov.


Patrick J. Growney; Lawyer, 81
LEAD: Patrick J. Growney, a retired partner of the New York law firm of Shearman &amp; Sterling, died Monday at a convalescent home in Bryn Mawr, Pa.
He was 81 years old and lived in Gladwyne, Pa.


John H. Rizzuto; Fashion Executive, 52
LEAD: John H. Rizzuto, former president of Givenchy Inc., the United States corporate office of the Paris fashion house, died Tuesday at his home in Manhattan after a long illness.
He was 52 years old.

Moscow Talk: Leader's Fall From Heights
LEAD: Maksim, a computer worker, spotted the real news tucked five minutes beyond the headlined stories, offered by the state-controlled television announcer in the minimalist form that Muscovites are alert for: Boris N. Yeltsin, the city's leading politician, had been suddenly ousted.


Berlin Journal; In Search of a Work of Art to Overcome the Wall
LEAD: The Berlin wall, Peter Unsicker says, is the only really German art since the war. ''It's built by Germans in the East, painted by Germans in the West,'' he explained, not without a tinge of Berliner Schnauze, the cheek on which Berliners used to pride themselves.


Senator Lugar Hurt in Fall
LEAD: Senator Richard G. Lugar, Republican of Indiana, broke a bone in his face and suffered a cut over his eye when he slipped today on his icy driveway in McLean, Va., a spokesman said.
Mr.
Lugar was treated at Bethesda Naval Hospital and released but will have to return Wednesday to have the facial bone set, the spokesman, Andy Fisher, said.

Texaco Committees Ordered to Merge
LEAD: The Federal judge overseeing the bankruptcy proceedings of Texaco Inc. yesterday ordered the two separate committees of creditors to merge.


COMPANY BRIEFS
LEAD:  Apple Computer Inc., Cupertino, Calif., said it would raise its dividend to 8 cents a share, from 6 cents.
It is payable Dec. 15, to shareholders of record Nov. 23.

LEAD: Dr.
Lowell T. Coggeshall, an authority on tropical diseases and a former vice president and trustee of the University of Chicago, died Wednesday at the South Baldwin Hospital in Foley, Ala.
He was 86 years old and lived in Foley.
