RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  N.B.A.
Lakers 111, Clippers 82: James Worthy scored 20 points and A.C.
Green added 17 last night in Inglewood, Calif., as the Lakers remained the only unbeaten team in the Western Conference.
The defending league champions need a victory Saturday at Golden State to equal the best start in their history.


Stalin's Daughter Isn't Moving
LEAD: Svetlana Alliluyeva, Stalin's daughter, said today that she had no plans to move to Britain, although she inquired informally about a work permit.


Holmes a Court Is Under the Gun
LEAD: After being badly hurt by last month's stock collapse, the investor Robert Holmes a Court is searching the world for buyers for his 9.6 percent stake in Texaco Inc. and his other holdings as well.


A.M.A. Rules That Doctors Are Obligated to Treat AIDS
LEAD: The American Medical Association declared today that doctors had an ethical obligation to care for people with AIDS as well as for those who had been infected with the virus but showed no symptoms.


WOMEN'S DANCE SERIES
LEAD: Melanie Slater and Pamela Hoff-man are to open the Working Women dance festival tonight at 8 at Middle Collegiate Church, 50 East Seventh Street.
The choreographers will present ''Lore,'' which they describe as a concert of human tales.
Others scheduled to present dances in the festival are Amy Sue Rosen, tomor-row and Sunday at 8; Sally Silvers, from Dec.


Giamatti's Report
LEAD: Speaking to students at Yale, the university he formerly was president of, A. Bartlett Giamatti, now the National League president, said last night that the most serious problem that baseball has before it is the unruliness of spectators that threatens to ''take the game away from the American family.

After Summit, a New Look for Egypt
LEAD: Egypt nudged a small way farther from isolation today after an Arab League summit meeting lifted a prohibition on diplomatic ties with Cairo because of its 1979 peace with Israel.

LEAD: A study said today that anticipated new accounting regulations could have a major impact on big business -reducing stock market prices, affecting corporate takeover decisions and altering benefits to retired Americans.

U.N. Repeats Debt Warning
LEAD: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar has told the United States representative here that the United Nations will run out of funds unless Washington pays $87 million of its annual contribution by early December, United Nations officials said today.


3 on Election Panel to Oppose Bypassing Contribution Limit
LEAD: Three of the six members of the Federal Election Commission indicated today that they would oppose a request to allow political action committees to bypass Federal restrictions on political contributions.


Coors Biotech
LEAD: The Coors Biotech Products Company, a division of the Adolph Coors Company of Golden, Colo., said it would form a venture with Meiji Seika Kaisha Ltd., a Tokyo confectionery company.
The venture would market a food additive that the Japanese company had developed and sold in its country for more than three years.

Deaver's Illness Delays Trial
LEAD: Michael K. Deaver's second painful kidney stone attack in two weeks forced the adjournment today of his perjury trial until at least Wednesday while he undergoes surgery and recuperation.


Bridge: Event This Weekend Gives Rare Chance at Par Contest
LEAD: Perhaps the most difficult task that any bridge expert ever undertakes is the construction of par hands, prepared deals designed to test the bidding, play and defense skills of a group of contestants.
The difficulty lies largely in guaranteeing that alternative plays will not succeed.

Reagan's New Reality: Compromise
LEAD: By naming Judge Anthony M. Kennedy to the Supreme Court and making significant concessions in talks on reducing the deficit, President Reagan has agreed to compromise some of the basic goals and precepts he set for the final two years of his Administration.


4 Airlines Order 7 Boeing Jets
LEAD: Four airlines have ordered seven jets for a total of about $240 million from the Boeing Commercial Airplane Company, the company said.
Germania, a charter airline based in Cologne, West Germany, ordered three 737-300's for delivery in November and December 1988, doubling its fleet.
KLM Royal Dutch Airlines ordered two 737-300's for delivery in December 1988.

Trainer Banned Over Drugs
LEAD: Peter Ferriola's training license was suspended for 120 days yesterday by the New York State Racing and Wagering Board because three of his horses tested positive for Lasix after racing at Aqueduct last week.


Mortgage Buying Set by Fannie Mae
LEAD: The Federal National Mortgage Association announced yesterday that it would buy adjustable-rate mortgages whose interest rates are tied to an index measuring the cost of funds for savings and loans in the district of the Federal Home Loan Bank of San Francisco.


Podiatrist Is Indicted in a Medicaid Fraud Case
LEAD: A podiatrist has been indicted by a Westchester County grand jury on a charge of stealing $1.8 million in fraudulent Medicaid billings for special footwear, it was announced today.


Arizona Bid to Cards
LEAD: Arizona State University in Tempe, and the cities of Tempe and Phoenix, have joined to offer the St.
Louis Cardinals football team a $10 million package in an effort to lure Bill Bidwill, the owner, and his National Football League team to Arizona.
Bidwill, who has said the Cardinals would move after completing this season, has also investigated Jacksonville, Fla., Baltimore and Memphis.


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: A report in Science Times Tuesday about a tribute to Dr.
Arnold O. Beckman, the prominent designer of scientific instruments, misstated the site of the event.
It was the University of Pennsylvania.


Chrysler Unit Offering 1 Billion of Securities
LEAD: The Chrysler Financial Corporation is using underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation to offer about $1 billion of securities backed by automobile loan receivables.
The financing is the largest public offering of loan receivables by the Chrysler unit, about twice the size of a similar financing arranged in


U.S. Bars Visit by Jackson to Servicemen in Gulf
LEAD: The Rev.
Jesse Jackson will not be allowed to make a planned Thanksgiving visit to United States forces in the Persian Gulf, the Defense Department said today.

Yankees Fill Roster
LEAD: The Yankees filled their 40-player winter roster yesterday by buying the contracts of six players from their Columbus minor-league team.
The players are Darren Reed, an outfielder; Mitch Lyden, a catcher; Chris Alvarez, a third baseman, and three pitchers, Amalio Carreno, Troy Evers and Steve Frey.


Cotton Contracts Soar On Soviet Crop Report
LEAD: Cotton futures surged the limit for daily trading yesterday on indications that wintry weather has severely damaged the Soviet Union's crop.


Graf Draws Garrison in Slims
LEAD: Her serve is in need of improvement and her net game is still in its infancy, but Steffi Graf said she was generally satisfied with the progress she has made this year.
Imagine, then, how formidable she will be when she reaches her full potential.


Wilbur Dale Talley, An American Dancer
LEAD: Wilbur Dale Talley, a ballet dancer who performed with the Harkness Ballet and Ballet Internacionale de Caracas, died on Wednesday at the General Hospital South in Maracaibo, Venzuela, from injuries sustained when he was thrown from a horse on Sunday.
Mr.
Talley, whose stage name was Dale Talley, was 39 years old.


Indian Museum Presses for a Move to Washington
LEAD: Lawyers for the Museum of the American Indian left, and Smithsonian Institution officials, right, at hearing in Washington.
Both groups formally urged Congress to approve a bill that would allow the museum to move from its home at 155th Street and Broadway to a new one on the Mall in Washington.


Name That Bill
LEAD: On the theory that a rose by some other name might smell sweeter, Representative Richard A. Gephardt has renamed the amendment that he succeeded in attaching to the trade bill now being studied in a House-Senate conference committee.
The Gephardt amendment would require the President to negotiate with a country that has erected trade barriers against United States products and, if that country refuses to modify those barriers, authorize the


Police Begin Stopping Drivers Of Cabs to Insure Their Safety
LEAD: In an effort to reduce crimes against taxicab drivers, the New York City police will stop hundreds of cabs each night for random ''safety checks,'' Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward said yesterday.


Ex-Judge Gets 8-Year Term On a Racketeering Charge
LEAD: A former New York City Civil Court judge who pleaded guilty last spring to committing crimes before he was elected to the bench was sentenced yesterday to eight years in Federal prison, despite his emotional appeal for mercy.

Iran Unites the Arabs
LEAD: The communique adopted at the Arab summit meeting in Jordan is astonishing: it thunders at Iran in tones once reserved for Israel.
It calls for an international peace conference, in which Arab participants would have to deal with Israel, and leaves the door open for its members to renew ties with Egypt.

The Inspired, the Silly and the Useless

MGM/UA Loss Grows
LEAD: MGM/ UA Communications Inc. reported losses today of $46.2 million for its fiscal fourth quarter ended Aug. 31, bringing the cumulative losses for the year to $88.1 million.
No comparison figures are available since the reconstituted MGM/UA is in its first year of operations.
Based in Culver City, Calif., the movie and television producer had revenues of $118 million for the quarter and $427.6 million for the year.


Reagan Meets With Afghan Guerrilla Leaders
LEAD: President Reagan talking with Yunis Khalis, the chairman of the Islamic Union of the Mujahedeen, during meeting with guerrilla leaders yesterday in the Oval Office.
Mr.
Reagan, who pledged continued U.S. support for the insurgents, said the presence of Soviet troops in Afghanistan remains a ''major impediment'' to improved relations and that ''the withdrawal of Soviet forces is the key to resolving the Afghan crisis.

Keillor spent this particular evening engaged in a far more active pursuit: reading the crowd.

Art: 67 Years of Works By Latin Americans
LEAD: ''ART of the Fantastic: Latin America, 1920-1987,'' at the Queens Museum, is an effective and, at times, impressive exhibition, even though it is not a consistently good one.
The chopped-up galleries of the museum and the chaotic, often cheek-by-jowl installation are a detriment; the fact that the exhibition, organized by the Indianapolis Museum of Art to celebrate the 10th Pan American Games, has been cut is a disappointment.

City Opera: Mozart and Knussen Duo
LEAD: ''WHERE THE WILD THINGS ARE,'' a children's opera for adults (and an adult opera for children, too) by Oliver Knussen and Maurice Sendak, lumbered happily into the New York State Theater last night.
Playing on a double bill with a version of Mozart's incomplete opera ''L'Oca del Cairo,'' it will close out the New York City Opera season with five more performances through Sunday evening.


Devils' Streak: End Is No Loss
LEAD: The winning streak at home came to end for the Devils tonight after eight victories.
But the ninth game was not a total loss and the Devils are still the only National Hockey League team that is undefeated at home.


Our Towns; Smokers Fume At the Interlopers Of the L.I.R.R.
LEAD: How many times will Blanche Celestine have to die a thousand deaths? ''I'm dying now,'' she said.
It's the maniac nonsmokers who are destroying her health.


Money Fund Assets Up
LEAD: Assets of the nation's 411 money market mutual funds increased $558 million, to $261.11 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
Assets of the 111 institutional funds increased $598.2 million, to $73.58 billion.
Assets of the 207 general-purpose funds were down $641.5 million, to $78.77 billion.

G.M. to Export Cars to Japan
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation said it would export three car models to Japan through the Suzuki Motor Company, in which it has held a 5.3 percent interest since 1981.


A Big Fund Ready to Capitalize on Hard Times
LEAD: In major articles in The Atlantic and Newsweek, Peter G. Peterson, a former Commerce Secretary and a former head of Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb, has warned of troubled economic times ahead.


Gorbachev Accuses Former Ally Of Putting Ambition Above Party
LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, backing the removal of a former ally as Moscow party chief, accused him of mismanagement and undisciplined behavior, Tass, the official press agency, reported today.


AIDS Tests Suggested For Infants of 1980-85
LEAD: Parents whose infants had transfusions before the nation's blood supply was routinely screened for the AIDS virus should consider blood tests for their children, a California researcher said today.


Debentures Placed For Holiday Inns
LEAD: The Holiday Corporation yesterday announced the private placement of $100 million of the 7 1/2 percent, 10-year subordinated debentures of Holiday Inns Inc. to Bass P.L.C., a British brewer.


3M Realigns Its Divisions
LEAD: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company announced a realignment that would separate its consumer and commercial businesses from its industrial products lines.
The shuffling will not result in any shrinkage of the businesses, the company said.


Brokers' New Ads Offer Reassurance
LEAD: The stock market's collapse in mid-October shook the confidence of seasoned Wall Street veterans and small investors alike.
It also presented financial institutions with a daunting challenge: How to restore investors' faith in the market.

'MAYFLOWER MADAM,' FROM THE BOOK, ON CBS
LEAD: ON CBS this Sunday at 9 P.M., ''Mayflower Madam'' provides perhaps the ultimate, certainly the most unintentionally hilarious, example of commercial television caught in a vise between cupidity and hypocrisy.
The network and the producer, Robert Halmi, were quick to snap up the rights to ''Mayflower Madam,'' the best-selling book by Sydney Biddle Barrows, former debutante, about the swank call-girl service she ran in Manhattan for about five years.


William Clay Ford Named to Key Post
LEAD: William Clay Ford, who has spent most of his business life in the long shadow cast by his older brother, Henry Ford 2d, was named yesterday as chairman of the finance committee of the Ford Motor Company's board.
He succeeds his brother, who was chairman of the powerful committee until his death at 70 on Sept.


Erratic Session Ends With Gains for Dollar
LEAD: The dollar moved higher in active, choppy trading yesterday.
Traders said the currency was bolstered by an improvement in the United States trade deficit and by rumors that the Administration and Congress were near agreement on a package to cut the Federal budget deficit.


NANCY S. PFEFFER WED TO DAVID H. KAUFMAN
LEAD: Nancy S. Pfeffer, a daughter of Beatrice Pfeffer of New York and the late Dr.
Burton B. Pfeffer, and David H. Kaufman, a son of Sally Kaufman of Brooklyn and the late Norman Kaufman, were married yesterday.
Rabbi David Posner performed the ceremony at Temple Emanu-El in New York.


Interest Rates Finish Mixed
LEAD: Interest rates were mixed yesterday, rising for some short-term securities due in less than two years but falling or holding steady for longer-term issues.

Restaurants
LEAD: NINE-MONTH-OLD Remi is one of those rare places that combine a striking setting, attentive service and distinctive food.
Remi in Italian means oars, and both the menu and the design theme reflect maritime Venice.


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: An article yesterday about Mel Miller, the Speaker of the New York State Assembly, misstated the circumstances that led an Assemblywoman, Gerdi E. Lipshutz, to resign from the Assembly last March.
Ms.
Lipshutz, a Queens Democrat, quit after testifying at the trial of an Assembly staff member that she had carried two ''no show'' jobs on her payroll.

LEAD: The nation began celebrating its bicentennial in 1976, and activities continued off and on through this Sept. 17, the 200th anniversary of the signing of the Constitution.

Drug Report Assailed
LEAD: Jeannie Longo of France, who holds more than 10 world records in cycling, had never tested positive in drug tests in nine years of competition until traces of ephedrine were found in her system after she won a 3-kilometer race in September at Colorado Springs. ''I'm the most sane athlete about drugs, amphetamines,'' she said yesterday in Grenoble, France, after the drug report from the American Cycling Federation was received by the French Cycling Federation and made public.

Film: Schwarzenegger In 'The Running Man'
LEAD: THE year is 2019.
In the fascist state that America has become, Ben Richards (Arnold Schwarzenegger) is a helicopter pilot with the Federal police.
One night, while on a routine patrol, he's ordered to terminate a food riot in Bakersfield, Calif.
Some 1,500 unarmed women and children are running amok in search of nourishment.


Show-Biz Animals All Around Town
LEAD: Elephants have been practicing their pas de deux at Lincoln Center and bears have been pirouetting at Radio City Music Hall, helping to open the winter season weeks ahead of the calendar.


Irving Bank Bid
LEAD: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York will delay until Nov. 17 its decision on the Bank of New York Company's application to acquire the Irving Bank Corporation, a Fed spokesman said.
The decision was due yesterday, but the Fed decided, with the concurrence of the banks, that the ''five-day period the Fed has to accept or reject the application would run out next week,'' the spokesman said.


Salvador to Amnesty 3 Held as Americans' Killers
LEAD: Three suspects charged in a 1985 attack that killed 13 people, including six Americans, were ordered freed today under a new amnesty program.


Knicks Trade Sparrow
LEAD: Little by little, the Knicks are discarding the few remnants of their embarrassing past.
Yesterday, the day after suffering their fourth defeat in four games, they sent Rory Sparrow to the Chicago Bulls for a second-round draft choice in 1988.


Iowa Union Backs Dukakis
LEAD: A union that represents state workers said Tuesday that it had endorsed Gov.
Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts, becoming the first major labor group in Iowa to back a Presidential candidate.


Islander Thrill Show Goes On
LEAD: The script was being followed: a 4-1 cushion for the Islanders had become a 4-3 tightrope in the third period at St.
Louis Arena.
In their three previous games, the Islanders had been outscored by a total of 9-1 in the third period, yet had won twice in overtime.


Hite's New Book Is Under Rising Attack
LEAD: Shere Hite's new book, ''Women and Love,'' is coming under increasing attack by academic specialists who contend that its statistical conclusions that a great majority of women are unhappy with their male partners are based on badly flawed methodology.


Giants Brace for a Tough One
LEAD: For the first time in years, a Giants-Eagles game is taking on the dimension of a true division rivalry.


Stock Price of Drug's Maker Jumps on Word of Clearance
LEAD: The price of Genentech Inc. shares rose $3.25 today, to $42.75, on anticipation that the company would receive Government approval on Friday to market its drug for dissolving blood clots, called tissue plasminogen activator, or T.P.A.


Polling, Communist-Style
LEAD: The Chinese long ago dismissed public opinion polling as a trapping of bourgeois liberalism: Why would a party that embodies public opinion need polls?
But on the eve of their recent congress, party leaders decided that Deng Xiaoping's creed, ''Seek Truth from Facts,'' would be well served by the bourgeois device.


DANGER: QUOTATIONS
LEAD: For 50 years, illustrations in newspapers, magazines and books have carried the credit line of the Bettmann Archive.
The person behind the New York-based archive, it turns out, is a man not only of pictures but also of words.


Homeless Woman Sent to Hospital Under Koch Plan Is Ordered Freed
LEAD: A New York State judge yesterday ordered the release of the first person involuntarily hospitalized under a new Koch administration plan to remove seriously disturbed homeless people from the streets.
The judge ruled that the city had failed to prove that the homeless woman was mentally ill or unable to care for herself.

Art People
LEAD:  Just an Artist's Dream?


MUMMENSCHANZ
LEAD: The Swiss mime group Mummen-schanz is to appear on Sunday at 2 P.M. at the Lehman Center for the Performing Arts, Lehman College, Bedford Park Boulevard, the Bronx.
Members of the troupe use masks, costumes and lighting to form living sculptures.
Tickets are $13, $15 and $17.50.
Information: 960-8833.

110 Boston Commuters Injured in Train Crash
LEAD: A commuter train crashed into another that was stopped at an underground station this morning, injuring at least 110 people, 6 of them seriously, officials said.


Stroh to Buy Back Tampa Brewery
LEAD: The Stroh Brewery Company of Detroit said today that it would buy back a Tampa, Fla., brewery it traded to the Pabst Brewing Company of San Antonio five years ago.


The Working Woman's Dream
LEAD: What do women really want?
Many of them want to go to work, and therefore also want houses that are easier to keep clean.
A New Jersey housing developer asked women what conveniences they'd install in a house of their own design.


ARMS TALKS DELAY WORRIES OFFICIALS
LEAD: American and Soviet negotiators have not yet agreed on some important verification procedures for the treaty banning medium- and shorter-range missiles that is to be signed next month, Administration officials say.

A Walk on the Wild Side of the Stock Market
LEAD: To the Editor:


Dance: Nina Wiener Troupe
LEAD: ENVELOPED by the sound of sensuous sighs, a woman is dwarfed by a Futurist landscape and recalls a relationship with a man that went sour.
This, in a sketch, is ''Fierce Attachments,'' Nina Wiener's new dance work, and its look and sensibility are uncomfortably close to Calvin Klein's perfume commercials.

Art: Works by Julian Schnabel at the Whitney
LEAD: NO matter how sick many people may be of the swagger and theatrics of Julian Schnabel, and of the publicity machine fed by him and his work, his show at the Whitney Museum of American Art is welcome.
It has enough information and flair to encourage a fresh look at a 36-year-old artist who seems to have been so much with us for so long that we never had a chance to decide if we wanted him or not.


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: An article in the Business People column in Business Day last Friday, about the appointment of Frank Harrison 3d as a vice chairman of the Coca-Cola Bottling Company Consolidated, listed his college history incorrectly.
He received his bachelor's degree from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and his M.B.A.

WHOSE SURNAME(S) FOR BABY?
LEAD: In the months preceding a child's birth, first names were always the ones that kept parents awake at night, mulling over their mellifluous qualities, debating whose relative deserved a namesake.
Last names were a given: like father, like child.


Top Skier Sidelined
LEAD: Tamara McKinney, who would give the United States its best hope for a medal in Alpine skiing at the Winter Olympics in Calgary, Alberta, in February, will be sidelined at least six weeks with a hairline fracture of her lower left leg that she suffered while training Monday at Copper Mountain, Colo.


Shell and B.P Report Gains
LEAD: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group of Companies, the world's largest oil enterprise, reported a 27 percent increase in its third-quarter profit yesterday, while the British Petroleum Company reported an 8 percent gain.


Unrecognized Risks of X-Ray Radiation
LEAD: To the Editor:


SUPER-8 FILMS
LEAD: A program of super-8 films from Berlin is to be shown tomorrow night at 8 o'clock at the Collective for Liv-ing Cinema, 41 White Street.
The films were part of this year's ''Docu-menta 8'' exhibition in Kassel, West Germany.
The screening is a joint venture of the Collective for Living Cinema and Goethe House.


2 American Mountaineers Tell Of Witnessing Tibet Protests
LEAD: Two American mountaineers, who had gone to climb the remote peaks of Tibet, found themselves witness to violent demonstrations six weeks ago calling for independence.


Informer at Westies Trial Admits Frequent Lies Under Oath
LEAD: A convicted killer who turned informer at the racketeering trial of several members of a West Side gang testified under cross-examination yesterday that he had frequently lied to authorities, even under oath.

LEAD: The marijuana smoking that led to Judge Douglas Ginsburg's withdrawal from consideration for the Supreme Court also revives questions about President Reagan's war on drugs.
What war on drugs?

Kate Smith Is Buried
LEAD: Frankl Zinter, designer of Kate Smith's mausoleum, removing tape as structure was assembled at St.
Agnes Cemetery in Lake Placid, N.Y.
A private ceremony was held yesterday; a public service will be held there today.
Miss Smith, best known for her rendition of ''God Bless America,'' died in June 1986.

Drug Approval For Genentech
LEAD: Genentech Inc. received approval today from the Food and Drug Administration for its blood clot-dissolving drug, tissue plasminogen activator, or T.P.A.
The approval comes just five months after an F.D.A. advisory committee recommended against licensing Activase, as Genentech calls the drug, and asked for additional information about the its ability to save lives.


9 Killed in India Hurricane
LEAD: A hurricane lashed coastal areas of India's southern Andhra Pradesh state today, killing at least 9 people and forcing the removal of about 29,000, the United News of India reported.

A SELECTION OF STYLISH SAMPLES
LEAD: For the last two years, Honora Horan has run a small evening-dress rental business in New York called Pret-a-Party.
She works by appointment, made by calling 212-696-9260, and charges from $75 to $150 for a rental, with a refundable deposit of $100 to $250, depending on the value of the dress and its fragility.


Mildred Smith Huser  Lawyer, 94
LEAD: Mildred Smith Huser, a Brooklyn lawyer who was a delegate to the 1920 Republican state convention, died Monday at the New Rochelle Medical Center.
She was 94 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.


Bad Turn for a Slalom Star
LEAD: Cheery pink and yellow hair bands, a navy sweater, aquamarine sweat pants, a lavender sock, a pink sneaker: these were the colors of Tamara McKinney today as she sat in the cafeteria of a resort where other members of the United States ski team were finishing a week of practice.

LEAD: Phil Simms looked fit, didn't limp and didn't throw today.

Cuomo Rules Out a Late Race In Primaries, but Still Hedges
LEAD: Governor Cuomo, faced by persistent rumors that he is considering a last-minute Presidential bid in 1988, said yesterday that he would not participate in the late primaries in California and New Jersey.


Korean War Memorial Site
LEAD: The Reagan Administration has approved plans to erect a memorial honoring veterans of the Korean War on the mall between the Capitol and the Lincoln Memorial.
Representative James J. Florio, a New Jersey Democrat who backs the memorial, said Tuesday that Interior Secretary Donald P. Hodel had approved the site.

LEAD: Mike Power, the Boston College quarterback, has revived memories of Doug Flutie, a former star for the Eagles.
Against undefeated Syracuse on Saturday, Power may well be spending most of the day doing a Flutie-like impression of a scrambling quarterback.

LEAD: The leaders of West Germany and France concluded a two-day meeting today with agreements to jointly develop a combat helicopter and to set up joint councils on military and economic policy.

John H.F. Haskell, 83, Ex-Finance Executive
LEAD: John H. F. Haskell, a retired banker and a former diplomat and officer of the New York Stock Exchange, died of heart failure Tuesday aboard the Queen Elizabeth 2 en route to New York on a visit.
He was 83 years old and lived in Grasse, France.


U.S. Closes Savings and Loan And Shifts Insured Deposits
LEAD: Federal regulators today closed the Tri-County Savings and Loan Association because it was insolvent and transferred its insured deposits to a Pennsylvania-based savings institution.

LEAD: ACCORDING to conventional wisdom in the computer age, the typewriter is obsolete.
Indeed, many would call it a veritable dinosaur when it comes to producing the printed word.

LEAD: On a night when they expected Bernard King to make an emphatic statement concerning his feelings about being discarded, the Knicks were instead victimized by the dramatic performance of another familiar player.


ORTEGA PROPOSES TRUCE BUT REBELS OBJECT TO TERMS
LEAD: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua presented a detailed proposal today for a cease-fire with the contras that would oblige the rebels to surrender their weapons after one month and accept a political amnesty.


U.N. Body Calls for Widening of Test Ban Treaty
LEAD: The United Nations moved today to expand a 1963 treaty into a complete ban on nuclear testing.


Your Money; Yields Stressed By Investors
LEAD: DAVID PEARL, a New York apparel manufacturer, has been selling some of his stocks since the steep October market decline. ''I decided to redirect my allocation of assets that were geared toward growth into income-oriented securities,'' he said. ''You look for some security.''

LEAD: The public humiliation of a Communist Party official once regarded as one of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's closest political supporters has raised critical questions about the Soviet leader as he prepares for his first visit to the United States next month.

LEAD: Two months ago, Les Miller was working the graveyard shift in Arkansas City, Kan., affixing handles to picnic coolers for $5 an hour.
Tomorrow, he'll line up as a starting defensive end against the Los Angeles Raiders, epitomizing all that has become wonderful and unbelievable for the San Diego Chargers.

Miller played the flauto traverso, the valveless, largely wooden predecessor of the ''modern'' flute

Old Brook Bed Is Discovered Under Rubble
LEAD: Somewhere beneath Washington Square Park, under asphalt, sand, gravel, shards of brick and old water pipes, lies the bed of a brook.
Yesterday two geology professors and a graduate student from New York University set out to find it without moving so much as a pebble.
They used radar.
Their equipment, called ground penetrating radar, has penetrated sand, gravel, clay and solid rock, but it nearly met its match yesterday with the urban debris under New York City.

CORRECTION
LEAD: A chart in Business Day yesterday with an article on a new American export drive in Europe mislabeled the two main components.
The labels for imports and exports, in the chart showing trade in capital goods, should have been reversed.

LEAD: Atlanta officials are hoping that a scarred, five-block area in the heart of the downtown area can mimic the city that surrounds it by rising from the ashes of its own destruction.


Mike Nichols to Receive Abbott Theater Award
LEAD: Mike Nichols, who has won six Tony awards for directing and two more as a producer, will receive the third Mr.
Abbott Award for lifetime achievement in the theater.
The award will be presented Monday during a ceremony at the Astor Ballroom of the Marriott Marquis Hotel.


Air Wisconsin Is Being Sought
LEAD: Air Wis Services Inc., the parent of the commuter carrier Air Wisconsin, said that it had received an unsolicited takeover offer from an unidentified party for $11.50 a share in cash, or $85.1 million.
An Air Wis spokesman said the buyers are a venture capital group and two individuals but refused further identification.

LEAD: The Justice Department is investigating whether a special prosecutor should be appointed to look into possible conflicts of interest by Judge Douglas H. Ginsburg while he was a Justice Department official, a Federal law enforcement official said today.

10 Arrested in South Africa
LEAD: The South African police arrested 10 youths at the Soweto township houses of anti-apartheid activist Winnie Mandela today.
Mrs.
Mandela, wife of the imprisoned black leader Nelson Mandela, said the police had surrounded one of her two houses, searched it and taken away five youths who had been staying there.


Young 49ers' Starter
LEAD: Steve Young will start at quarterback for the San Francisco 49ers on Sunday, Coach Bill Walsh announced after yesterday's practice, and Joe Montana's status remains in doubt for the important game against the New Orleans Saints.


Big Hong Kong Bank To Buy 14.9% of Midland
LEAD: The Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation has agreed to buy 14.9 percent of Midland Bank P.L.C., Britain's fourth-largest bank, for nearly $680 million, the two banks announced today.

LEAD: Laurence H. Tribe may have his office in the bookish confines of the Harvard Law School.

British Inflation at 4.5%
LEAD: Retail prices in Britain rose five-tenths of 1 percent in October from the previous month, bringing the inflation rate to 4.5 percent, the Department of Employment announced today.

LEAD: Peter Ferriola, whose training license was ordered suspended for 120 days Thursday after charges he violated state medication rules, has obtained a stay of the ruling that will allow him to continue training pending a hearing Nov. 23.


AM International Stake Purchased
LEAD: AM International Inc. said that the Komori Printing Machinery Company, a Japanese printing concern, had purchased 6.4 percent of the company's common stock on the open market.
In a filing today with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Komori said it had acquired the shares for ''investment purposes.


Vehicle Sales Rise In Period
LEAD: Sales of new American-made cars and light trucks totaled 228,665 units in the first 10 days of November, up 2.2 percent from the comparable period a year ago, the eight domestic manufacturers reported today.
There were eight selling days in the period both this year and last year.

Pasqua Traded; Dotson a Yankee
LEAD: The Yankees, who hadn't made a deal with the Chicago White Sox in 11 weeks, bolstered their starting pitching corps yesterday by acquiring Richard Dotson in a five-player trade with the White Sox.
Dan Pasqua, the enigmatic young power hitter, was the most significant of the three players the Yankees shipped out.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  N.H.L.
North Stars Win: Brian Bellows's power-play goal with 6 minutes 28 seconds to play last night gave Minnesota a 5-4 victory at Buffalo.
The Sabres, trailing by 4-2 after two periods, tied the score on early third-period goals by Phil Housley and Scott Arneil.
But with Calle Johansson of Buffalo in the penalty box for tripping, Steve Payne trapped the puck along the boards and relayed it to Brian Lawton, who immediately found Bellows.

Bring the Others in From the Cold
LEAD: Joyce Brown's claim that she has a right to live on the street, supported this week by a judge, may stimulate dinner parties and Philosophy I discussions.
But in practical terms, her case is beside the point.
Sweeping the mentally ill off the streets makes no sense unless the authorities are in a position to care for them properly.


U.S. Sees Progress With Allies
LEAD: The Reagan Administration is confident that it will soon be able to promise its biggest allies lower Federal budget deficits and to assure them that it will avert a restrictive trade law, senior Administration officials said today.


Bronx Man Slain in Holdup
LEAD: A 49-year-old grocery worker was fatally shot in a Bronx holdup yesterday evening, the police said.
A spokesman, Officer Peter O'Donnell, said the robbery took place at 7:15 P.M. in a bodega at 1792 Westchester Avenue, in the borough's Clasons Point section.
He said one of two intruders shot the worker, Jose Hernandez, of 1310 Rosedale Avenue in the Soundview section, in the right eye, and the victim died shortly thereafter at Bronx Municipal Hospital.

CORRECTION
LEAD: Because of a production error, a Washington dispatch on Wednesday, about the Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association and its attitude on air safety, omitted the association's position on collision-avoidance equipment.
Edmund Pinto, an association vice president, said his organization supported the use of ''supplementary equipment'' that would alert air traffic controllers to the position and altitude of a private plane in congested areas.

Richard Rhodes and the Bomb
LEAD: It took Richard Rhodes five years to research and write ''The Making of the Atomic Bomb'' - or two years longer than it took the nuclear scientists in New Mexico to make the bomb that was dropped on Hiroshima.


Grant for Mentally Disabled
LEAD: A Chicago foundation has awarded $2 million to a nonprofit group that works to assure the rights of mentally disabled people, the foundation said Thursday.
The John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation made the award to the Mental Health Law Project, a Washington-based public interest organization that recently helped restore Social Security benefits to thousands of mentally disabled people, a statement said.

He was 69 years old.

LEAD: Steve Nelson, a mainstay at linebacker for the New England Patriots since coming out of North Dakota State as a second-round draft pick in 1974 and three times a Pro Bowl selection, said yesterday that he would retire after this season, his 14th in the National Football League.


TWINKIES FANS COPE
LEAD: While some of us may be fretting about the stock market and others about the Persian Gulf, there is one segment of the population that has been undergoing a far more serious personal crisis this last week.


Reagan Imposes Punitive Tariffs Against Brazil
LEAD: President Reagan announced today that he would impose punitive tariffs covering more than $100 million worth of imports from Brazil in retaliation for Brazilian curbs on American computer and software products.


CORRECTION
LEAD: An article in Business Day on Thursday about the risks of options trading misidentified in the first mention the type of investor who would suffer big losses if the underlying security turned down.
As the article correctly explained thereafter, it is the seller, not the buyer, of an options put contract who risks the heavy losses.


Exclusionary Club May Pose Problems for Judge Kennedy
LEAD: Judge Anthony M. Kennedy's resignation from an all-male club here came after its members refused to admit women despite a threat of a lawsuit by the city.

The section quoting Mr.
Yeltsin was translated by The New York Times; the section quoting others was translated by Reuters.

The Times and Its Pressmen Tentatively Agree on a Pact
LEAD: The New York Times Company and leaders of the newspaper's pressmen's union have tentatively agreed on terms of a labor contract considered crucial to proceeding with the newspaper's plans to invest $400 million in a new plant in New Jersey that will include color presses.


Psychiatrists Debate Role in Legal System
LEAD: As they did in the case of Joyce Brown, as they do in hundreds of civil and criminal cases every day, consulting psychiatrists pondered the vicissitudes of their inexact science yesterday and disagreed over the role of their profession in court.
How accurate are psychiatric diagnoses?
Should psychiatrists, with the power to deprive people of liberty, continue to work for one side or another in court, or should they work exclusively for the court itself?


7 Democrats Say White House Resisted Iran Panel
LEAD: Seven of the nine House Democrats on the Congressional Iran-contra committees will attach a separate statement to the panels' report next week taking issue with the report's conclusion that the White House was fully cooperative with the Congressional inquiry.

LEAD: Riccardo Ingram's football and baseball career at Georgia Tech ended yesterday after the star senior admitted taking money from sports agents and signing a representation contract in violation of National Collegiate Athletic Association rules.
Athletic Director Homer Rice said the violations were reported to the N.C.A.A.

Hong Kong Inquiry
LEAD: The Hong Kong Stock Exchange said today that in the wake of the global stock collapse it had appointed an accounting firm to help with market surveillance and that the financial position of seven small brokerages was being investigated.
The exchange's senior chief executive, Robert Fell, said the trading activities of all seven had been suspended pending the findings of the accountants, Coopers &amp; Lybrand.

The Meeseful Wonder
LEAD: Senator Orrin Hatch says there are gutless wonders at the White House.
President Reagan says there isn't a single gutless wonder on the premises.
Since these two usually see eye-to-eye on everything, the gutless-wonder dispute is a big, big story.

LEAD: The 13th game of the world chess championship between Gary Kasparov, and the challenger, Anatoly Karpov, ended in a draw today after 36 moves.


Fire Destroys Warehouse on Long Island
LEAD: Firefighters in Bethpage recovering hoses on ground littered with cans of propane fuel after an early morning fire at a barbecue-supply warehouse at 50 Lexington Avenue.
It took 150 firefighters six hours to contol the blaze.
They were hampered because of exploding fuel cannisters.
Residents of 15 nearby homes were removed as a precaution.

The Editorial Notebook; By How to Invest Without Anxiety
LEAD: Several years ago, while visiting Australia, I bought the remnants of what must have been an enormous 1930's dinner service: 41 pieces in all, some of it oddly and wonderfully shaped.
I knew its age and its maker, and that I loved it.
What I didn't know was the kind of money such stuff pulled in New


Dutton Released
LEAD: Another 36-year-old N.F.L. defensive standout with 14 years' experience might have seen his season end yesterday.
The Dallas Cowboys released John Dutton, a defensive tackle who spent the last eight seasons with Dallas.
Dutton has been replaced as a starter by Kevin Brooks.


Senator Lugar Hurt in Fall
LEAD: Senator Richard G. Lugar, Republican of Indiana, broke a bone in his face and suffered a cut over his eye when he slipped Thursday on his icy driveway in McLean, Va., a spokesman said.
Mr.
Lugar was treated at the Bethesda Naval Hospital and was released but will have to return next Wednesday to have the facial bone set, the spokesman, Andy Fisher, said.

Ungermann-Bass Bars Digital Offer
LEAD: Ungermann-Bass Inc., a computer network manufacturer based in Santa Clara, Calif., said its board had unanimously rejected an acquisition proposal from Digital Communications Associates Inc.
Digital, a computer parts maker based in Alpharetta, Ga., had said on Thursday that it might begin a hostile tender offer if Ungermann did not accept its offer of $9.75 a share, or about $172.6 million, but the company told Reuters today that it had no immediate plans to take further action.


Homicide Experts Meet: Gruesome Cases and a Bit of Fun
LEAD: Call them what you will - the mavens of murder, the doyens of death.
They are 125 of the country's leading experts on homicide, and for three days they have met here to compare cases and swap stories, talking of knives and cyanide and killings in the night.


Payment by Venezuela
LEAD: The Venezuelan Government will repay $250 million in principal owed to private foreign banks by mid-December, Finance Minister Hector Hurtado said today.
He told reporters the amount would be sent within 30 days from Monday as specified under terms of Venezuela's $20.3 billion rescheduling accord with private foreign banks.

New Life For Copper Industry
LEAD: In the desert mountain ranges dotted with creosote bushes and prickly pear cactuses, the Phelps Dodge Corporation has helped bring about a fundamental change in the economics of mining copper.


Arthur Miller Reading
LEAD: To mark the publication of his autobiography, ''Timebends: A Life,'' Arthur Miller will give a reading from the work on Monday at 8 P.M., at the Vivian Beaumont Theater, Lincoln Center.
The book is published by Grove Press, which is sponsoring the reading with Lincoln Center Theater.
Admission is free.


Zhao Ziyang, on Mao and China's Future
LEAD: Three days after becoming Secretary General of China's Communist Party, Zhao Ziyang relaxed over dinner at the leadership compound of Zhongnanhai in the Forbidden City and told how Deng Xiaoping, China's paramount leader, had insisted on stepping down ''before my mind becomes confused.''


Dr. Lehan K. Tunks  Law School Dean, 72
LEAD: Dr.
Lehan K. Tunks, a former dean of law at Rutgers University and the University of Washington, died of lymphoma and acute respiratory distress in a Seattle nursing home Monday.
He was 72 years old and lived in Seattle.


No Damage Is Seen to Homeless Plan
LEAD: Mayor Koch's program to remove mentally ill homeless people from the streets has not been damaged by the Joyce Brown decision, and New York City does not plan to broaden existing laws to gain wider latitude to pick them up for treatment, the city's chief assistant corporation counsel said yesterday.


ESCAPE TESTS SET ON SPACE SHUTTLE
LEAD: Small rockets that could eject astronauts through a hatch in the space shuttle and a telescoping pole on which they could slide through it will be tested later this month as possible escape systems, the space agency reports.


Girl Begged to Have Her Mother Killed, Document Reveals
LEAD: A Glastonbury woman was murdered in August after her 16-year-old daughter ''begged'' her boyfriend to do the killing and they discussed several nights on which to do it, according to an arrest warrant unsealed today.


Soviet to Let 2 Women Join Husbands in U.S.
LEAD: Two of three Soviet citizens who appealed to join their spouses in the United States have been given permission to leave the Soviet Union, one of the three said today.

Exchanges' Merger Bid Advances
LEAD: Efforts to combine New York's two biggest futures exchanges have moved one step closer to fruition, officials at the New York Mercantile Exchange and the Commodity Exchange Inc. said yesterday.


40 Are Killed in Mexico City As Bus Overturns Into Lake
LEAD: A city bus packed with schoolchildren and workers skidded off a dirt road and flipped onto its roof in a shallow lake today, killing 40 people and injuring 5, the authorities said.


Comings and Goings
LEAD: Elvis Franks, a defensive lineman who played seven National Football League seasons with the Cleveland Browns, the New York Jets and the Los Angeles Raiders, has pleaded guilty in Cleveland to conspiracy to distribute cocaine.
He was arrested July 20 when police confiscated from his car four ounces of a substance believed to be cocaine and seized six ounces of the powder at his residence.


Pretoria Reports 5 Died in Angola
LEAD: Pretoria announced today that five more of its soldiers had been killed in southeastern Angola, in a further indication of a growing South African role in the 12-year-old Angolan civil war.

'Pow! Right in the Kisser!'
LEAD: True, Ralph Kramden of ''The Honeymooners'' never did hit his wife, Alice.
But Jackie Gleason commonly punctuated episodes of the television show with a clenched fist and the threat: ''One of these days, Alice - Pow!
Right in the kisser!'' The routine and the laughter it elicited reflected wide public insensitivity to the violence that continues as terrible reality in millions of households.


Chief for Dow Chemical
LEAD: The Dow Chemical Company said today that its board of directors had appointed Frank P. Popoff as its chief executive officer, succeeding Paul F. Oreffice, who will remain chairman.
Mr.
Popoff has also been elected chairman of the board's executive committee, replacing Mr.
Oreffice, who remains on the committee.


Markets Welcome Smaller Trade Gap
LEAD: The trade deficit shrank in September, with the value of the nation's imports exceeding that of exports by $14.1 billion, down $1.6 billion from August.
The September number was at the low end of what had been expected and financial markets were pleased, especially when traders recalled that the ''October massacre'' began with the release of the August number on Oct.


Tickets on Sale Today For Pavarotti Classes
LEAD: Luciano Pavarotti will give two master classes at the Juilliard School, Thursday from 2 to 6 P.M. and next Sunday from 3 to 5:30 P.M.
He will work with singers presently studying at the school.


CORRECTION
LEAD: The gazetteer accompanying an article on Turtle Bay on Nov. 1 omitted the name of a New York City Council member who serves the neighborhood.
She is Carol Greitzer.


Choosing the Right Island
LEAD: THERE are more than three dozen Caribbean islands, stretching across a body of water one-third the size of the United States.
The choice presents a perennial problem: which island suits you best.


JAPAN: For Its Retirees, Tokyo Is Relying on Self-Reliance
LEAD: IT is not just in the United States that people worry about who is going to pay for social security.
Throughout the industrialized world, because of the baby boom's huge presence and low fertility rates, the classic demographic pyramid is narrowing at the base and swelling at the top.
The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development projects that in its 24 member nations the proportion of the population aged 65 and over will rise from 12 percent now to 22 percent in 2040.


WOMEN IN COMPETITION HAVE COME A LONG WAY
LEAD: YEARS ago, women's chess was generally stodgy, lacking aggression and combinational fireworks, but that's not true any more.


Correction
LEAD: A Travel Advisory report in the Travel section today about Dublin's 1,000th birthday lists an incorrect address for the Irish Tourist Board.
The correct address is 757 Third Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10017.

Family Court Is Struggling With Caseload, Experts Say
LEAD: New York City's Family Court, created 25 years ago to handle family matters and youthful offenders, is being overwhelmed by a new generation of children more abused and neglected than ever before, according to experts addressing a special seminar yesterday.


WHO WILL CONTROL POPULATION GROWTH?
LEAD: This letter is in response to the Oct. 25 Opinion Page article ''The Population Bomb Is Still Ticking.'' I agree with Diana Gerhardt's assessment that Long Island is overcrowded; we do have too much garbage, too much population and too many shopping centers being built.
Our traffic situation is deplorable during midday and the rush hours try the patience of many.


SPORTS AUTHORITY FACING SCRUTINY
LEAD: AS IF losing the vote to build a baseball stadium in the Meadowlands was not enough, the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority faces increased skepticism in the Legislature.


HOW TO INSTALL A WALL CABINET
LEAD: INSTALLING hanging cabinets against a framed wall is a task that many do-it-yourselfers view with trepidation.
Not only must the cabinet's horizontal surfaces be level and its vertical surfaces plumb, but also, for strength, at least some of the fasteners must penetrate the studs that make up the core of the wall.


REAGAN AND WRIGHT CAUGHT UP IN FEUD
LEAD: The relationship between President Reagan and Jim Wright, the Speaker of the House, has deteriorated so badly that it is complicating efforts to arrange compromises on domestic and foreign policy, officials in the White House and on Capitol Hill say.

Maryland Considering A Computer Photo File
LEAD: In an effort to keep drivers with excessive traffic violations off the road, the state of Maryland is considering storing photographs of drivers in a computer to prevent people from getting several licenses.


GATHERING TOGETHER
LEAD: ONE MAY OR may not feast on ham or lamb at Easter.
And a goose, or some other fowl, at Christmas is fit for a flip of the coin.
But the last Thursday in November without turkey is a cause for depression.

WHAT'S NEW IN RADAR DETECTORS
LEAD: THE radar detector business is not for the timid.
Makers of the little black boxes, which alert drivers to the presence of police radar and help them avoid speeding tickets, have come under fire from traffic safety organizations, politicians and police.
Their technological adversaries, the makers of police radar equipment, consistently find new ways to circumvent detectors.

LEAD: This classic French country dish sits proudly on my kitchen counter, ready to be served (Food: ''After Quiche,'' by Patricia Wells, Oct. 4).
Now I read that this brilliant marriage of the flavors of beef, red wine and herbs has become a culinary has-been.

BAKED VEGETABLES OF AUTUMN CELEBRATE THE HARVEST SEASON
LEAD: TURKEY may be the star of the Thanksgiving table, but vegetables play an effectual supporting role.
And since this holiday is the celebration of the harvest, I like to serve a selection.
I bake whole acorn squashes in the oven, not cutting them open until after they are cooked.
Then I slice them in half, scoop out the seeds and add a little butter, salt and pepper.

LEAD: The police here have been ordered to make arrests or seek warrants in all cases of domestic violence.

Saving a Cemetery For Famous Pets
LEAD: FRANCE'S oldest pet cemetery, one of the most lavish in the world, faced an uncertain future two months ago in Asnieres, outside of Paris.
The owner had locked its gate on an island in the Seine and was threatening to plow up the land and sell it to apartment builders.

LEAD:  Don Juan's a hero with a hundred faces:  For some he's mostly Mozart, or Moliere.
He shows up in a hundred different places,  He's profligate, Byronic, debonair.
He goes to Hell, so heavy his disgrace is,  In ''Man and Superman'' we see him there - A daring Shavian variant on the pattern;  So after that let's send him to Manhattan.

LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
LEAD: It's How You Play the Game Screaming and clapping, the home-team crowd was going wild in the balcony overlooking the college's tiny gymnasium.
The entire student body was on its feet. (Actually, they had to be, since there weren't any seats.) But euphoria was rampant, for it was the opening home basketball game and their team was winning, as in scoring more points than the opponent, a feat most students had only dreamed about.

It is carbon monoxide.

LEAD: ''Ye Olde Safer Sex Shoppe'' has opened at Stanford University, offering information and products aimed at slowing the spread of AIDS.

The theater doesn't mean to trip up any of its attractive inhabitants, of course.
It's just that in an activity so collaborative it's very easy to get some of the signals mixed.

Special Today: The World of New York/Magazine Part 2
LEAD: In the holiday World of New York, these special reports:


A THEORY OF EVERYTHING
LEAD: Recently, Edward Witten returned to his alma mater (Brandeis), where he received an honorary degree.

WESTCHESTER GUIDE
LEAD:  EARLY PAINE  Clive Phillpot, director of the library at the Museum of Modern Art in Manhattan, will give a talk about one of his countrymen - Thomas Paine - at the New Rochelle Public Library, 8 P.M.
Tuesday.
An emigre from England himself, albeit two centuries later, Mr.
Phillpot will explore Paine's early life in Thetford, Alford and Lewes, which is seldom discussed.


Bokassa Sentence Upheld
LEAD: The Supreme Court today rejected an appeal for a retrial by Jean-Bedel Bokassa, sentenced to death last June for crimes committed during his 13-year rule.
His lawyers had argued that a former head of state could be tried only on treason charges.

Comparing Costs to 24 Destinations
LEAD: PACKAGE tours are a good way to cut costs and save time arranging a vacation in the sun.
In addition to air fare and hotel accommodations, most include Federal departure tax and airport transfers.
Some, known as all-inclusive packages, include meals, drinks, recreational activities, taxes and tips.

Pronouncing on Moscow
LEAD: It's tempting to see the Boris Yeltsin story as the end of Soviet ''new thinking'' and a slide back to the days of Stalin's purges.
But caution is in order.
It's fine to applaud loosening of controls and to condemn the old Soviet ways.
It makes little sense, however, to draw profound conclusions about the fate of glasnost, or openness, and perestroika, or reform, on the basis of daily or even monthly events.

I bake whole acorn squashes in the oven, not cutting them open until after they are cooked.
Then I slice them in half, scoop out the seeds and add a little butter, salt and pepper.

LEAD: AFTER a long day in heavy traffic, it is easy for a bus driver's nerves to frazzle, and learning to deal with stress and not take it out on overbearing passengers takes training, say NJ Transit officials.


WINNING FRANCO-RUSSIAN ENTENTE
LEAD: WOODMERE can now boast one of the best new restaurants to open on Long Island in recent years.
The food at La Petite Maison Russe harks back to the old Franco-Russian alliance, when Russian Czars imported French chefs.
This small storefront restaurant has reversed those roles.
The chefs are Russian.

Jazz: Braff on Trumpet
LEAD: RUBY BRAFF objects to being called a jazz musician.
He is, he says, an entertainer with a horn.
He once made an album called ''Adoration of the Melody,'' and that is the way he approaches his music.


The Trouble With 'Freedom'
LEAD: Before he went to South Africa in 1983 to see for himself what life under apartheid was like, Sir Richard Attenborough was a self-described ''well-intentioned liberal,'' the sort who protests by not buying South African oranges.
His heart was in the right place.


Upstairs/Downstairs
LEAD: ON THE STREETS OF NEW York, it pays to look up and look down, and not always for the reasons you might think.
Some of the city's most colorful restaurants, shops, clubs and galleries are tucked away in basements or perched in second floors, where lower rents enable entrepreneurs to be more than usually inventive about whatever it is they purvey.

FLYING FISH FROM BARBADOS
LEAD: TO an American raised to revere the bald eagle, the notion of eating a national symbol might sound less than appetizing.
But in Barbados, the self-proclaimed land of the flying fish, the emblem that adorns all the tourist brochures turns up at lunch, dinner and even breakfast, steamed, sauteed, deep-fried and every which way but blackened.

Picking Out Handcrafts in the Markets of Acapulco
LEAD: ON those rare powder-gray days, or if the cornflower sky becomes too monotonous, many Acapulco vacationers turn away from pools and chaises to their second favorite pastime: shopping.
An impressive part of the population of this tropical resort, estimated at nearly one million, is involved in the production, promotion or sale of handcrafts.


A THEORY OF EVERYTHING
LEAD: K. C. Cole's informative essay on the latest developments in mathematical physics left out only an explanation of why physicists believe that the new and remarkable theory of strings is, as they call it, the theory of everything.
The history of science demonstrates that all progressive research programs not only explain the anomalies left unaccounted for by existing theories, but also reinterpret the domain of observable facts in the application of new conceptual models.


Music: 'Lost in the Stars,' at City College
LEAD: A GENERATION of consciousness-raising makes Kurt Weill's ''Lost in the Stars'' seem ponderous today.
Racial hostility's broad themes are too powerful and pervasive to need simple restatement anymore, making this musical version of ''Cry the Beloved Country'' an all too black-and-white rendering of recent social history.

CANDY THE WAY IT USED TO BE
LEAD: CHRISTMAS, LIKE MANY LESSER OCCASIONS at our house and sometimes no occasion, was marked with chocolate-dipped coffee beans and cats' tongues from Altman &amp; Kuhne, a Fifth Avenue candy shop.
Dolls came from grandmothers and books from my mother, but it was my father who brought home those chocolates in European-looking packages: the coffee beans for the adults - in theory at least - and the cats' tongues, finger-length spatulas of bittersweet, for me and my sister.

NONFICTION
LEAD:  AN URCHIN IN THE STORM: Essays About Books and Ideas.
By Stephen Jay Gould. (Norton, $18.95.) This collection of reviews is a perfect volume for fans of Stephen Jay Gould.
For everyone else serious about writing or thinking, ''An Urchin in the Storm'' is nearly a perfect study in method.
Mr.
Gould, a paleontologist with a bent for the subtleties in arguments about nature and nurture and the intricacies of evolutionary theory, teaches at Harvard.

IN EUROPE: The Bill's Due Next Century
LEAD: IT is not just in the United States that people worry about who is going to pay for social security.
Throughout the industrialized world, because of the baby boom's huge presence and low fertility rates, the classic demographic pyramid is narrowing at the base and swelling at the top.
The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development projects that in its 24 member nations the proportion of the population aged 65 and over will rise from 12 percent now to 22 percent in 2040.

IF I WERE A KEY, WHERE WOULD I BE?
LEAD: I'VE added a new activity to my morning routine.
I call it the key hunt.
After years of feeling that daily searching for my keys is an intrusion, I have given in and officially made room for hunting in between bathing and breakfast.
Now I have a full seven minutes of detective work before I begin to panic.

WHY NOT MORATORIUM ON DUMP CLOSINGS?
LEAD: I have just learned that because of the huge expense of carting Town of Oyster Bay garbage to Ohio, Wisconsin and perhaps farther west as time goes on, our taxes will be increased by 47 percent.
Why do those in charge not consider a moratorium on closing landfills, giving the towns an opportunity to build proper recycling and resource recovery plants?


Joseph H. McMahon, Wesleyan Professor, 57
LEAD: Joseph H. McMahon, Hollis Professor of Romance Languages and Literatures at Wesleyan University, died Thursday at Middlesex Memorial Hospital in Middletown, Conn., where he was hospitalized after a heart attack on Oct. 21.
He was 57 years old and lived in Middletown.


A NEWCOMER FOR AUTO-FOCUSING
LEAD: NO sooner do I finish complaining about the limitations of auto-focusing cameras than one camera maker makes me eat my words.
Specifically, I recently groused that auto-focusing sensors always aim dead center in the middle of the picture.
This forces picture takers either to frame their subjects accordingly, or to use the pesky ''focus hold'' feature (if the camera provides it).

Q &amp; A
LEAD:  Dissatisfied With Broker  Question: Earlier this year, we used a mortgage brokerage firm to get a loan.
Our broker told us that it would take about eight weeks to obtain a mortgage.
The agent who started our work became ill and a replacement took over.
He was incompetent and as a result four months later we had no mortgage.


AVOIDING CHRISTMAS
LEAD: THE 25TH OF DECEMBER WAS THE DAY on which I was born, but that's not the only thing I have against it.
Personally, I never believed in Mr.
Claus.
At least I have no recollection whatsoever of any traumatic moment of disillusionment with the myth.
When his name was finally scrubbed from the tedious list of people to whom I ought to be grateful and, worse, to whom I was compelled to write, I think I was relieved to be free of yet another part of that general collusion between children and parents by which all parties strive to keep alive the wilting hope that the young are guileless.

ELIZABETH GALASSO FINE ART TAKES A LOOK AT TRAGEDY
LEAD: GERICAULT'S ''Raft of the Medusa'' dominated the Paris Salon of 1819 but as the first work of art to deal with a topical outrage (the abandonment of shipwreck survivors) it nonplussed its viewers as much as it fascinated them.
This huge canvas, the artist's magnum opus, remains an oddity, being considered more than reportage but somehow less than high art.

A THEORY OF EVERYTHING
LEAD: I am impressed by Edward Witten's accomplishments.
However, I think he misses the point when he says: ''One lesson you can learn is don't make mistakes.'' The history of science is fraught with mistakes, made, in some cases, by eminent scientists, including Newton and Einstein.
It is from these mistakes, in most cases, that we learn.

About Men; A Fear of Lawyers
LEAD: WHEN MY SON DECIDED several years ago to turn his back on a budding career as a rock saxophonist and become a lawyer, the first question I, who had practiced law for three decades, asked myself was: ''Where have I gone wrong?'' He was accustomed to a profession in which every amplified blast of his horn, every adroit bit of body language on stage, was greeted by an adoring audience with hoots of pleasure and shouts for more.

'SPLIT SECOND' PERFORMED IN SOUTHPORT

WITH OUR MOVING WEAPNS, FIGHTING FOR TERITORY ALONG THE MERRIT
LEAD: LIKE most Americans, I own an advanced state-of-the-art weapons system.
Mine is a 1 1/2-ton missile propelled by a finely tuned, highly sophisticated, computer-controlled power plant that, with the slightest touch of the controls, is capable of generating forces several hundreds of times the force that I, alone, a normal mortal, unassisted, can produce.


More Bad Luck
LEAD: THERE'S no such thing as a good time for an injury, but Gary Stevens, the jockey, seems to find particularly bad ones.
In 1985, he suffered broken ribs in a spill three weeks before the Breeders' Cup and missed those races.
Then yesterday, Stevens suffered a broken ankle in an accident at the starting gate before the fourth race at Santa Anita, and will miss the Breeders' Cup races at Hollywood Park Saturday.

LEAD: BECAUSE they confront AIDS daily in their jobs, 700 New Jerseyans gathered here recently for an official update on the state's No. 1 health concern.


HOW TO INSTALL A WALL CABINET
LEAD: INSTALLING hanging cabinets against a framed wall is a task that many do-it-yourselfers view with trepidation.
Not only must the cabinet's horizontal surfaces be level and its vertical surfaces plumb, but also, for strength, at least some of the fasteners must penetrate the studs that make up the core of the wall.

Yugoslavia
LEAD: To the Editor: I traveled extensively in Yugoslavia, visiting the country more than 10 times since the early 70's.
Although, I must agree with the author that Yugoslavs are carnivorous, as much as Americans and most of the other Europeans, what struck me the most is the abundance of fruit, vegetables, cheese, yogurts and seafood along the Adriatic coast.


The AIDS Secret Worth Keeping
LEAD: Testing to help curb the AIDS epidemic can be either voluntary or compulsory, but that's a choice only in theory.
A compulsory program would drive underground the intravenous drug abusers and gay men who most need to be reached.
No wonder public health officials overwhelmingly prefer voluntary tests.

LEAD: BORIS N. YELTSIN seemed the quintessential new Soviet man, a chest-thumping advocate of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's openness and restructuring and an irrepressible critic of past party failures and hidebound ideology.

LEAD: EXCEPT FOR THE SPINDLY HIGH heels no Christmas shopper would wear, and the lack of a black mink coat, Gale Jarvis could be any of the frantic young upscale parents nervously pondering the goods at F.A.O.
Schwarz, racing from one department to another, ferreting out what's hot and what's not.
But instead of just reading the price tags, Gale Jarvis is changing them.


FICTION
LEAD:  KALEIDOSCOPE.
By Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $18.95.) In her 21st novel, Danielle Steel continues her forays into the life styles of the rich and heartsick.
This time, readers are led to war-torn Europe, where they witness the burgeoning friendship of two Americans, Sam Walker and Arthur Patterson, as well as the heady love affair between Sam and Solange Bertrand, an exquisite Frenchwoman.

Visions Shared By Britain's Artists and Poets In the Days Of Wordsworth
LEAD: TRY NOT TO MISS THE current exhibition at the New York Public Library, ''William Wordsworth and the Age of English Romanticism.'' It would be worth making the effort to see it for the sake of the Turners alone, or for the work of any one of half a dozen of the other artists on view.


Youth Killed in South Africa
LEAD: A 15-year-old youth was killed by fellow blacks as more political violence swept Natal Province in South Africa, the police said today.
A police statement said the boy was killed in the Pietermaritzburg township of Flangspruit on Friday night.
It gave no details.

She was 87 years old and lived in Manhattan and Middlesex.

Wintering On Florida's Panhandle
LEAD: RACHEL JACKSON, accompanying Andrew when he took control of Pensacola in 1821, prayed to be delivered from the ''vast, howling wilderness'' of the Florida panhandle.
Shortly after the Civil War, residents of Florida's peninsula seriously considered ridding their state of a nuisance by ceding its entire western arm to Alabama for a million dollars.

OPERA: CITY ENSEMBLE IN 'TURN OF THE SCREW'
LEAD: BRITTEN'S operas - ''The Turn of the Screw'' among them - test small opera companies but also reward the virtuous among them.
The orchestra parts are finely made, and their original touches speak most clearly through equally fine chamber groups.
Britten's words demand the same kind of clarity; they are meant to be heard and understood at close quarters.


Dance
LEAD: The New York City Ballet returns to the New York State Theater on Tuesday for its 87th season in the city.
The highlights of this first week of the new winter season include two revivals and performances by a new member of City Ballet and several newly promoted dancers.
A centerpiece of the opening-night gala benefit for the company is ''The Concert,'' that goofy but poetic evocation of concertgoing choreographed by Jerome Robbins and last performed by the company in 1984.

ABOUT LONG ISLAND
LEAD: THERE have been, heaven only knows, mountains of words devoted to family problems, to the stresses and strains that threaten the tight weave of the domestic fabric.
There have also been wise tomes issued on the effect of television as an isolating agent that can destroy togetherness in the home.
But none of them have touched upon the particular matter that comes between man and wife in our otherwise serene situation.

Yes I did.
I do it for a living.'' Even his less raffish roles are rarely saintly - a New York actor impersonating an ex-con, an ambitious attorney who ''wants to be Senator after he's President.

Venezuela's Island in the Caribbean
LEAD: CLEARLY a boom is underway on the Venezuelan island of Margarita, 24 miles off the mainland and half an hour by plane from Caracas.
As soon as you alight, you hear the humming, buzzing and slamming of construction work, and you see high-rise buildings that seem to have shot up overnight on near-desert terrain.

By Sheridan Morley.
Illustrated. 224 pp.
New York: Thames and Hudson. $29.95.


Good Values in Thrift Units
LEAD: FEW stock groups have as many handicaps to discourage investors as the savings and loan industry.
Accounting rules are quirky.
Regulatory burdens are onerous.
And a number of the group's bolder players are hip-deep in loans that may not be repaid.
If that were not enough, well-run savings units, selling at historically low valuations compared with their book values and earnings, are plentiful - more plentiful, in fact, than bargain hunters bidding for their stock.


Frankfurt
LEAD: To the Editor: I enjoyed ''What's Doing in Frankfurt'' (Travel, Oct. 18).
I do regret, though, that the article failed to mention two sites that I consider main attractions.
The first is the zoo, with about 6,000 animals.
It is one of the first zoos to attempt natural habitats, a children's zoo and a large house for watching nocturnal animals.

LEAD: In reply to the ''Population Bomb'' article: I suggest we first think of all the land improperly used because we grow tobacco.

HOW TO INSTALL A WALL CABINET
LEAD: INSTALLING hanging cabinets against a framed wall is a task that many do-it-yourselfers view with trepidation.
Not only must the cabinet's horizontal surfaces be level and its vertical surfaces plumb, but also, for strength, at least some of the fasteners must penetrate the studs that make up the core of the wall.

Too good.

BAKED VEGETABLES OF AUTUMN CELEBRATE THE HARVEST SEASON
LEAD: TURKEY may be the star of the Thanksgiving table, but vegetables play an effectual supporting role.
And since this holiday is the celebration of the harvest, I like to serve a selection.
I bake whole acorn squashes in the oven, not cutting them open until after they are cooked.
Then I slice them in half, scoop out the seeds and add a little butter, salt and pepper.

The Two-Woman Opposition in Bangladesh
LEAD: AFTER the police fired on anti-Government protesters here last week, the leading opposition party in Bangladesh scheduled a prayer service for three slain partisans.
But its leader was unable to attend.
Sheik Hasina Wajed, the Awami League's head, is a woman, and Moslem tradition dictates that women be barred from ceremonies for the dead.


STREETSCAPES: The Coney Island Parachute Jump; For the Boardwalk's 'Eiffel Tower,' Restoration or Regulating a Ruin?
LEAD: AMONG the many advances in military aviation in the 1930's was a tower to train paratroopers patented by Comdr.
James H. Strong in 1936.
He licensed one such six-chute tower for a Chicago amusement park.
But for the 1939-1940 World's Fair in New York, Commander Strong developed a 250-foot high version with 12 parachutes.


THE WORLD: Terrorism; With Latest Bomb, I.R.A. Injures Its Own Cause
LEAD: THE Irish Republican Army rarely second guesses itself about the violent attacks that have claimed hundreds of lives in Northern Ireland in the last 17 years.
But after one of its bombs killed 11 people at a memorial service for veterans in Enniskillen last Sunday, the outlawed organization issued its second apology in five years.


BREAKING THE CRACK MURDERS
LEAD: ON FEB. 15, THIS MAGAZINE published my article ''Crack Murder,'' the story of a veteran homicide detective, Albert E. Cachie, and his investigation of the killing of a Brooklyn crack dealer, James Baker.
Baker had been found dead in the passenger seat of his Mercedes with a bullet wound in his chest and four others from another gun in his head and neck.


FUNERAL HOMES ACCUSED OF BIAS ON AIDS
LEAD: IN a practice that has angered advocates for people with AIDS, some Connecticut funeral homes are charging up to $500 extra to handle the bodies of AIDS patients, while others are turning the bodies away.

While serving as a lay missionary in El Salvador in 1980, Jean Donovan and three close friends, the Maryknoll Sisters Maura Clarke and Ita Ford and the Ursuline Sister Dorothy Kazel, were murdered by the Government's security forces.

Boulez Forgets To Forget
LEAD: I KNOW IT ISN'T FAIR TO FOLLOW CELEBRATED thinkers around waiting for them to contradict themselves.
But who ever said critics were fair?
Of all living composers, perhaps Pierre Boulez has put the most stock in logical argument.
Even his famous polemics in behalf of his own works, though transparent propaganda of an elevated sort, have always had an air of indisputable rationality about them.


Unsafe Foreign Toys Are Seized by Officials
LEAD: Federal officials hoping to beat the Christmas rush have seized imported toys worth $1.35 million in a crackdown on products that fail to meet Federal safety standards.

LEAD: FROM time to time in recent years, it has been the fashion to talk of the depersonalization of dancers in the face of rapidly rising technical demands.
Some of that talk has been of the Joffrey Ballet, but the present company is filled with performers in whom expressive personality and technical expertise are merged.

Recognizing Gaddis
LEAD: I FIRST CAME TO KNOW WILLIAM Gaddis at a writers' conference in the Soviet Union in 1985.

AGENT ORANGE PANEL AIMING TO FINISH IN '90
LEAD: FOURTEEN years after American troops withdrew from Vietnam, a state commission continues to struggle with one of the most controversial results of the war.
The Vietnam Herbicides Information Commission was established by legislation in 1982 for what was to have been a five-year program.
Last July, the commission was reappointed under new legislation for three years to finish its work.

A THEORY OF EVERYTHING
LEAD: The article on Edward Witten and string theory excited the mystic in me.
As Malcolm W. Browne pointed out in the accompanying box, ''Mathematics and Magic,'' the 16th-century cabalists postulated that the world was created by an outpouring of divine emanations, 10 in number, called the Sefirot.
The ''vibrations'' of these realms are accessible to the human senses only in their lowest manifestations.

DO NEW LIMITS MEAN NEW TRAPS?
LEAD: WHEN the speed limit on some highways returned to 65 miles an hour earlier this year, manufacturers of radar detectors were more than a little concerned.
After all, while commercial radar detectors had been around for 20 years, their business came to life only in 1974, when the highway speed limit was cut to 55 m.p.h.

Gunman Surrenders After Detaining Former Wife
LEAD: A North Brunswick man ordered customers out of a post office at gunpoint and held his former wife hostage there for about eight hours today before releasing her and surrendering, according to the police.
The police said no one was injured.
The incident began shortly after noon when the man, Daniel Alfrey, 38 years old, apparently angry that his former wife had a boyfriend, walked into the post office, the authorities said.

LEAD: TURKEY may be the star of the Thanksgiving table, but vegetables play an effectual supporting role.
And since this holiday is the celebration of the harvest, I like to serve a selection.
I bake whole acorn squashes in the oven, not cutting them open until after they are cooked.
Then I slice them in half, scoop out the seeds and add a little butter, salt and pepper.

Question Of the Week; Will Free Agents Be Signed in Baseball?
LEAD: Definitely.
First of all, the owners were found guilty of collusion last season and a repeat performance on their part is highly unlikely.
Secondly, in our society, the name of the game is winning and several contending teams, including the Yankees, who desperately need frontline pitching, are a free agent or two away from capturing it all.

The New Allure of Treasury Securities
LEAD: WITH the continuing turmoil in the stock market, Treasury securities have taken on new allure.
The biggest attraction is their safety - Treasuries are backed by the full faith and credit of the United States.
But demand for the securities, especially those with maturities of six months or less, has become so strong that it has depressed yields.

A THEORY OF EVERYTHING
LEAD: Prof.
Edward Witten's new constructions may tie in to earlier, undisputed, findings.
In 1982, a team of researchers, led by Alain Aspect, found that it is possible for particles to communicate instantaneously over great distances.
This violates a long-held theory that nothing travels faster than light.
