BATTEN DOWN FOR THE COLD WEATHER
LEAD: THE lawn should be as short as possible for winter to eliminate the chances of disease, especially snow mold; if the grass was not cut before storing the mower, set the cutting blade at 1 1/2-inches or a bit lower, if possible, and mow one more time; if a few leaves remain, they will be chopped up by the blades and can remain as mulch, but rake off thick layers of leaf mulch.

HOW TO INSTALL A WALL CABINET
LEAD: INSTALLING hanging cabinets against a framed wall is a task that many do-it-yourselfers view with trepidation.

Classical Music
LEAD: When music followers talk about the good old days of instrumental performance, it is never quite clear what they mean.
In general, this is intended as a reference to the Romantic school and its progeny, but what was that?
After all, there are those who grew out of this 19th-century tradition with a taste for frank emotionalism and textual liberty-taking, and there also are those who favor removed, intellectualized interpretations.


Counting the Hungry - a Contentious Census
LEAD: EVEN after five years of economic expansion, there are reports of hunger in America, among farmers in Kansas, elderly people in the Ozarks and homeless people in big cities from Houston to New York.
But no one knows how many Americans are hungry, and attempts to estimate their number are highly controversial.


Pop Music
LEAD: It's a good week for New York bands with international tastes.
Saqqara Dogs, a trio that performs Monday and Tuesday at Dance Theater Workshop (219 West 19th Street), keep the world on a guitar string.
Their songs, mostly instrumentals, are built on repeating riffs that might come from Africa, the Middle East or the Bronx; the spiky, danceable tunes mix exotic instruments - especially dumbek (drum) and mbira (thumb piano) - with Western electronics, for sparse, minimal funk.

LEAD: English Colleges  Question:I am interested in attending the summer school sessions offered by Oxford or Cambridge University in England.
Where can I get information on classes and arrangements? - P. E., Woodside, Queens  Answer:There are several sources to approach - aside from writing to individual colleges in both cities.


THE WORLD: Terrorism; Army of Scholars Study Terrorists' Visions
LEAD: TERRORISM, since it burst anew on the international scene in the early 1970's, particularly in the Middle East, has spawned a small army of researchers and specialists, including government officials, political scientists, journalists, psychologists, and others, trying to understand its causes and the best ways of putting a stop to it.


The Imaginary Hero: Don't Leave Home Without Him
LEAD:  CAPTAIN VINEGAR'S COMMISSION  By Philip Glazebrook. 333 pp.
New York: Atheneum. $19.95.


Should Taxpayers Pay for the City's Political Campaigns?
LEAD: AFTER nearly two years of scandals, and more than a year of talk about reform, New York City's government is now likely to approve public financing of municipal election campaigns.


Vienna
LEAD: To the Editor: Your article on ''Vienna's Love of the Trolley'' (Travel, Aug. 23) reminded me of my own experience.
First of all it was very amusing to see official signs along the Ringstrasse track saying ''Warum so schnell'' (Why so fast).
At one point we were tooling along at a very comfortable speed when coming around the corner on a narrow street we were stopped by a small car parked halfway across the tracks.


MUSIC
LEAD:  Bobby McFerrin: Spontaneous Inventions  Directed by Bud Schaetzle. 1986.
HBO/Cannon Video. 48 minutes. $29.95.
Bobby McFerrin's array of vocal techniques - hums, clicks, hisses, glottal stops, chest thumps - enables him to mimic a cappella an entire jazz ensemble.
In each tune he seems to find a new way to accompany himself.


37,000-Unit Rise in Housing Seen in New York City
LEAD: New York City gained 37,000 units of housing between 1984 and 1987, according to city officials.


Bookshelf
LEAD: Additional titles of interest:


ACCOUNTANTS SEEK TO IMPROVE IMAGE
LEAD: ACCOUNTING, an industry whose expansion has mirrored that of Long Island's economy, continues to see a growing demand for its services.
But leaders in the field now fear that recent criticism of mistakes in the industry, as well as the increasing workloads brought on by the new tax law, will hinder their efforts to find enough qualified young recruits.


Irving Lazar Is to Auction Hite's New Book
LEAD: Shere Hite has retained the literary agent Irving Lazar to auction the paperback rights to her book ''Women and Love,'' which has come under increasing attack by academic specialists.


Rangers Halt Losing Streak
LEAD: For the first time in three weeks, the Rangers skated away from a game with something other than sinking spirits and a premonition of disaster.
In the locker room afterward, instead of sulking and guilt, there were handshakes and laughter and, at long last, cause for congratulations.

Accident at Denver Is Latest in a Series Of Blows for Airline
LEAD: The fatal accident involving a Continental Airlines jet in Denver yesterday represents another serious setback to the nation's third-largest airline, which has been plagued by a stream of consumer complaints and negative publicity all year.


Vast Cosmic Object Downgraded to a Mirage
LEAD: An enormous glowing blue arc in the distant universe, observed earlier this year and thought to be one of the largest objects yet detected in the cosmos, turns out to be an optical illusion caused by the light-bending effects of gravity, astronomers reported yesterday.


Converted Radioactive Waste Used to Fertilize in Oklahoma
LEAD: The Kerr-McGee Corporation, after years of tests and studies, is spraying thousands of acres of pastureland in eastern Oklahoma with a fertilizer recycled from radioactive wastes.


Music: Chamber Group
LEAD: PUTTING Franz Schreker and George Perle side by side on Saturday night's New York Chamber Symphony program at the 92d Street Y seemed at first a miniature history lesson in cause and effect.
The bond between them is Alban Berg.
Schreker's music early in this century opened Berg's imagination to the stage devices he would later use in ''Wozzeck''; Mr.


Tornadoes Hit Eastern Texas, Leaving 9 Dead
LEAD: Tornadoes swept across more than 200 miles of eastern Texas today, leveling scores of homes and buildings and leaving nine people dead and at least 132 injured.

LEAD: For baseball fans who went into a slump after the World Series, the start of the basketball and hockey seasons has brought the annual reawakening.
It is a sure sign, they know, that spring training is a mere three months away and the exhibition season just a few weeks beyond.

LEAD: The current revival of interest in the Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act of 1930 has been surprisingly widespread.

U.S. Diver Dies in Antarctica
LEAD: A 22-year-old California research assistant died Saturday in a diving accident under the ice of Antarctica, the National Science Foundation announced.
The diver, Mark T. Macmillan of San Jose, was pronounced dead by Navy doctors at McMurdo Station, the American scientific outpost on the continent.

Police Beat 4 Reporters Covering Nairobi Riots
LEAD:  Student demonstrators fleeing from the police yesterday during rioting at the University of Nairobi, Kenya.
Reporters from four news organizations, Associated Press, United Press International, the British Broadcasting Corporation and Deutsche Presse-Agentur, were beaten and detained by the police while covering the unrest, which began when five students were arrested at about midnight Saturday.


Iowa Poll Shows Simon and Dole as Leaders
LEAD: Senator Paul Simon of Illinois has emerged as the clear leader in Iowa in the contest for the Democratic Presidential nomination, according to a new poll that was made public today.


Robert D. Moss; Lawyer, 70
LEAD: Robert D. Moss, a trustee and assistant to the president of the New York-based F. W. Olin Foundation, died of cancer Tuesday at his home in Scottsdale, Ariz.
He was 70 years old.


Williams Leads Redskins By Lions
LEAD: Doug Williams, replacing an ineffective Jay Schroeder, threw first-half touchdown passes to Kelvin Bryant and Gary Clark today to spark the Washington Redskins to a 20-13 victory over the Detroit Lions.


Walter Frese, 81, Dies; Ex-Harvard Professor
LEAD: Walter F. Frese, professor emeritus at the Harvard Business School and an authority on government accounting systems, died Wednesday of pneumonia at the Sancta Maria Hospital in Cambridge, Mass.
He was 81 years old and lived in Belmont, Mass.

LEAD: Arturo Toscanini's influence on 20th-century orchestral works is assured; now, with the opening today of the exhibition ''Arturo Toscanini, 1915-1946: Art in the Shadow of Politics,'' the outspoken record of his anti-Fascism is fully documented.


G.M. Market Outlook for '88
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation will not regain the market share it lost last year in its 1988 model year, according to Lloyd E. Reuss, the company's executive vice president.

St.
John the Baptist of East Islip, L.I., upset top-seeded St.
Anthony's, 12-11, yesterday on the Friars' field in South Huntington, L.I.

EX-SPEAKER FACES SURGERY
LEAD: Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the former Speaker of the House of Representatives, left a Wash-ington hospital today and was admitted to a Boston hospital for rectal surgery., hospital officals said.
The 74-year-old Massachusettes Democrat is scheduled to undergo surgery of the rectum in several days, said Kathleen O'Donnell, a spokeswoman for Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston.

LEAD: Two months before the Defense Department blocked the Massachusetts Institute of Technology from obtaining a Japanese-made supercomputer, the Air Force installed a $33 million computer system built largely by the same manufacturer, according to Government and industry officials.

She was 78 years old and lived in Elizabethtown.

LEAD: BUDDY RYAN might as well have slapped Lawrence Taylor across the face with a glove.

STAGE: 'BREAKING THE CODE'
LEAD: ''BREAKING THE CODE,'' the new London import at the Neil Simon Theater, is yet another English drama about a sensitive genius whose homosexuality leads to his crucifixion by the hypocritical establishment.
But if Hugh Whitemore's flawed, discursive play shares many of the symptoms of its well-worn genre, it finally pulls away from the sentimentality of ''Another Country'' and ''Prick Up Your Ears'' and all the recent rest.

Apple Sets Repurchase
LEAD: Apple Computer Inc., like many other companies taking advantage of lower share prices, said Friday that it would repurchase up to an additional five million shares of its common stock.
Based on Friday's closing price, the repurchase would be valued at about $186.3 million.
Apple's stock closed down $1.50 a share Friday, at $37.25, in over-the-counter trading.

LEAD: Having suffered for months from a dearth of new bond issues and ruinous price-cutting, municipal bond departments on Wall Street predict a further contraction of the industry.

LEAD: TransCanada PipeLines Ltd., which has been seeking a greater presence in western Canada's energy exploration lands, said Friday that it planned to offer $8.75 a share, or $6.64 in United States currency, to acquire the Encor Energy Corporation.

LEAD: Lawyers for New Jersey and New York City worked down to the wire today to avoid going to court to settle their dispute over garbage that fouled the state's beaches in the summer.

LEAD: To mark the publication of his auto-biography, ''Timebends: A Lift,'' Ar-thur Miller is to give a reading from the work tonight at 8, at the Vivian Beaumont Theater, Lincoln Center.
The book is published by Grove Press, which is sponsoring the read-ing with Lincoln Center Theater.
Ad-mission is free.

LEAD: The announcement that Jerome K. Green, the 51-year-old president and chief executive of the J. I. Case Company would resign, effective Dec. 1, has surprised most industry analysts.

LEAD: Black Monday sent waves of apprehension around the globe.
But the shock caused only a rumble in official Washington.
After three weeks of deficit-reduction negotiations it's still politics-as-usual.
Instead of finding courage, almost everyone is scrambling to evade blame for raising taxes or paring popular programs.

LEAD: Lenin lies in his tomb on Red Square, and Stalin is interred at the Kremlin Wall.

LEAD: Solemn memorial services replaced demonstrations as the focus of attention here today as Northern Ireland marked the anniversary of a landmark treaty signed two years ago by Britain and Ireland in an effort to bring peace to this troubled province.

LEAD: At the headquarters of the Robeco Group, the largest group of investment funds under single management outside the United States, its managing director, Nicholas Veer, has decided that it is ''too late to be bearish'' on America, so he plans just to let the dust settle from the stock market collapse.


Petras P. Griskevicius; Lithuanian Chief, 63
LEAD: Petras P. Griskevicius, the longtime Communist Party leader in the Soviet Baltic republic of Lithuania, died suddenly Saturday, the official Tass press agency reported today.
He was 63 years old.
Tass did not give the cause of death.
The son of a tailor, Mr.
Griskevicius had been leader of the Lithuanian party since February 1974.


Beatrice Reassigning 4 Brands to West Coast
LEAD: Beatrice/Hunt-Wesson has reassigned four brands to its West Coast ad agencies that had been handled by the J. Walter Thompson Company, Chicago.
Beatrice and J.W.T. announced earlier last week that they had agreed to part company after five years.

LEAD: A prominent dissident active in the Democracy Wall movement in the late 1970's has been freed after a six-year jail term, Chinese sources said today.

LEAD: Pieter Nicolaas Menten, the most notorious Nazi war criminal in the Netherlands, died here Saturday in a nursing home, according to Dutch television.
He was 88 years old.
No cause of death was given.
Mr.

Payment by Venezuela
LEAD: The Venezuelan Government will repay $250 million in principal owed to private foreign banks by mid-December, Finance Minister Hector Hurtado said Friday.
He told reporters the amount would be sent within 30 days from Monday as specified under terms of Venezuela's $20.3 billion rescheduling accord with private foreign banks.

Major Decisions in Insider Trading Law
LEAD: Trading of securities by company executives based on inside information has been illegal throughout much of the history of corporate America.

Following are some of the major developments - before yesterday's Winans decision - in insider trading law.


CONCERT: NEW WAVE COMPOSERS
LEAD: ELLIOTT SHARP and Peter Zummo, the two composers who led ensembles last weekend at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Next Wave program, share a taste for Minimalism and guided improvisation; they're both grouped with downtown New York new music.
But the two halves of their shared program at Carey Playhouse were as different as a stroll in Central Park and a subway odyssey - one whimsical and ruminative, one visceral and noisy.

Concert: Pomerium Musices
LEAD: WILLIAM BYRD'S vast, legacy of Tudor music was the subject of a Sunday afternoon concert by Pomerium Musices and the New York Consort of Viols at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.
Five pieces for viols (or, in one case, reconstructed for viol consort from a keyboard piece) alternated with five Latin hymns and three English madrigals, and voice and viols combined for two larger concerted pieces: ''Out of the Orient Crystal Skies'' and the verse anthem ''Christ Rising Again.

Rock: Squeeze, At Garden
LEAD: EVERY few years, a band comes along to take up the Beatles' challenge: How much cleverness can be slipped between the lines of a catchy, concise rock song?
Since 1974, Squeeze's songwriters and guitarists, Glenn Tilbrook and Chris Difford, have been packing their songs with bright ideas.
Mr.
Tilbrook's music makes implausible chords, tricky melodic lines and even full-fledged dissonance sound natural; Mr.


Insider Trial Winds Down
LEAD: Closing arguments are expected to be heard today in United States District Court in Manhattan in the trial of David W. C. Clark, the New York lawyer implicated in the insider trading ring that included R. Foster Winans, a former columnist for The Wall Street Journal.


NEC Chip Output
LEAD: The NEC Corporation plans to start mass production of four-megabit dynamic random access memory chips, the next generation of computer chips, in late 1989, an NEC spokesman said.
It seems that NEC will be the first producer to be able to make the chips available commercially.
The company also plans to increase production of one-megabit D-RAM's from 500,000 units a month, to 2 million units a month by March 1988.


Yeltsin Is Hospitalized, Editor of Izvestia Says
LEAD: Boris N. Yeltsin, the former ally of Mikhail S. Gorbachev who was dismissed last week as head of the Moscow Communist Party organization, has been hospitalized, the editor of the Soviet Government newspaper Izvestia was quoted as saying today.

Cattle Prices Advance; Grain, Soybeans Mixed
LEAD: Cattle futures prices rose slightly yesterday as traders awaited a Government report that, when it was released after the close of trading, showed 11 percent more cattle on feed than a year earlier.


Israeli Writers at the Y
LEAD: Three Israeli writers - Amos Oz, Anton Shammas and Natan Zach -will read from their works at 8 P.M. on Dec. 7 at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue.
In addition to his writing, Mr.
Oz - who won Israel's Bialik Award for literature last year - also teaches English and works on a kibbutz.
Mr.
Shammas, an Israeli Arab who writes in Hebrew and Arabic, also produces television programs.


Head of School Accuses Police Of Mauling Her
LEAD: The principal of a small private school on the Lower East Side has complained that seven police officers seeking a 12-year-old robbery suspect forced their way into the school, arrested and manhandled the principal when she demanded to see a warrant, then conducted a classroom-to-classroom search, sending some students fleeing in fright.


Feedback In Typing Program
LEAD: IN the film ''Star Trek IV,'' the crew of a 23d century spaceship goes back in time, to Earth of the late 20th century, to save the whales.
To do so they need a computer, and they find one in a Bay Area factory.


Sunset Casts an Eerie Glow on a Bridge's Gossamer Threads
LEAD: As the sun made its inexorable way toward the horizon yesterday, its cloud-filtered rays illuminated a solitary worker silhouetted among the cables of the Brooklyn Bridge.
The South Street Seaport completed the autumn study of lower Manhattan. (NYT/Chester Higgins Jr.)

LEAD: A 25-year-old registered nurse, who officials said was trying to pose as ''a hero,'' was accused today of injecting fatal amounts of muscle-paralyzing drugs into several patients at a hospital here.

'Seeing' Inside Rocks
LEAD: A new acoustic scanning device developed by a Stanford University geophysicist is enabling scientists to ''see'' the internal structure of rocks.
The instrument is proving effective in predicting the fluid permeability of rocks, knowledge that can be useful in oil exploration, hydrology and the disposal of hazardous wastes.


Howard Fills Gap In Jets' Secondary
LEAD: By the start of the third quarter, the storm had completely engulfed Arrowhead Stadium in Kansas City, Mo.
Black clouds hung overhead and rain descended in sheets.
But for Carl Howard, the Jets' cornerback, the fog was just beginning to lift.


Cello-and-Piano Pieces By Bennington Teacher
LEAD: Lionel Nowak was born in 1911 and has taught for many years at Bennington College.
Mr.
Nowak is a composer as well - a fact his Bennington colleagues chose to honor at Merkin Hall Sunday night.


G.O.P. IRAN REPORT DEFENDS PRESIDENT
LEAD: The final minority report prepared by eight Republicans on the Congressional Iran-contra committees says the majority report of the panels reaches ''hysterial conclusions.'' It reads ''as if it were a weapon in the ongoing guerrilla warfare'' between Congress and the White House, the minority report says.

BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 17, 1987
LEAD:  The Insider-Trading Scandal


James C. Brennan, 77, Retired Bank Official
LEAD: Joseph Cantwell Brennan, a retired chairman and trustee of the Emigrant Savings Bank in New York and a prominent Roman Catholic layman, died last Thursday after a heart attack at his home in Manhattan.
He was 77 years old.


Mesa Reports Its Holdings
LEAD: Mesa Limited Partnership, the oil-and-gas concern headed by T. Boone Pickens, disclosed today that it was part of a group of investors that owned 4.8 percent of the Homestake Mining Company, a gold production company, at the end of September.

Steel Output Down 3.6%
LEAD: Steel production fell to 1.798 million tons in the week ended Saturday, a decrease of 3.6 percent from the previous week's 1.866 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
The industry's production was at 83.3 percent of capacity during the week, compared with 86.4 percent in the previous week.

Reagan-Wright Argument Grows On Central America Policy Role
LEAD: President Reagan and Jim Wright, the Speaker of the House, stepped up their angry argument today over the Administration's Central American policy and the Speaker's role in the region's delicate peace negotiations.


Campaign Scorecard
LEAD: For those who are ''having trouble keeping track of who's done what'' in the Presidential campaign, the Washington publication Roll Call is offering what it bills as a ''Moral Scorecard.''


O.E.C.D. Sharply Reduces U.S. Growth Forecast
LEAD: Economists at the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said today that they had substantially revised downward their 1988 growth forecast for the United States economy in the wake of last month's stock market plunge.


O'Neill's Doctors Confident as He Faces Surgery
LEAD: Former House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. will undergo surgery for rectal cancer on Wednesday, and his outlook is ''very favorable,'' his doctor said today.

Oil Rigs Increase in U.S.
LEAD: The number of operating rotary rigs, an indicator of the oil industry's health, rose by 33 last week, to 1,174 -a big jump over last year's 910 rigs, Baker Hughes Inc. said today.
In Canada, the weekly rig count fell by 38, to 277, compared with 113 a year ago, when oil prices touched bottom.


N.B.A. Notebook; Sparrow Fitting In With Bulls
LEAD: Players who have been traded often speak of the difficulty in making the transition from one team to another, especially in the midst of a season.


Simon Cites Character
LEAD: If this is the year of the character issue in Presidential politics, then Senator Paul Simon's first set of television commercials, which begin running in Iowa this week, suggest that he may be out to corner the market.

NEW YORK CITY TO SELL NOTES
LEAD: New York City plans to sell up to $325 million of short-term notes in a competitive sale between Nov. 24 and Dec. 15, city officials announced yes-terday.
In order to sell the notes when market conditions are most favora-ble, the city plans to give prospective underwriters 24 hours' advance no-tice of the bidding deadline.


Momentum in Dollar Eases
LEAD: The dollar ended substantially higher yesterday but below the day's highs after remarks by President Reagan reawakened worries among dealers over progress in the United States budget deficit talks.

New Storms Strike Gulf Coast; Death Toll at 12
LEAD: New storms with heavy rain and high wind struck the Gulf Coast from East Texas to Mississippi today, causing new damage and stalling efforts to clean up wreckage left by tornadoes.

Chun Says Violence Threatens Election
LEAD: President Chun Doo Hwan, formally announcing that South Korea's presidential election would be held Dec. 16, warned today that repeated incidents of campaign violence had created a ''serious threat to a fair election and a frontal challenge to development of genuine democracy.''


Bavarian Court Convicts American in AIDS Case
LEAD: A former United States Army cook with AIDS was sentenced to two years in prison today by a court in the Bavarian city of Nuremberg for attempting to inflict ''grievous bodily harm'' by practicing unprotected sex.


Zoos Act To Restore Bali's Birds
LEAD: IN an effort to replenish the population of Jalak Bali birds on their native island in Indonesia, 10 zoos in the United States have shipped 40 of the birds to Indonesia.


'Insider' Definition In New Law Urged
LEAD: The Supreme Court's 4-to-4 decision today on whether a former Wall Street Journal reporter, R. Foster Winans, had violated the nation's securities laws prompted members of Congress, securities lawyers and law professors to urge passage of legislation that would clearly define illegal insider trading.


Violin: Nathan Milstein Plays at Fisher Hall
LEAD: IT should come as no surprise that, at the age of 82, Nathan Milstein is not the steely-sure violinist he once was.
But if he struggled at various points during his recital Sunday afternoon in Avery Fisher Hall to keep the bow steady and the tone full and even, Mr.
Milstein got across the essential aspects of his artistic vision.

LEAD: Rudolph W. Giuliani, the United States Attorney in Manhattan, said yesterday that the United States Supreme Court's ruling against R. Foster Winans meant that his office ''was free to go ahead now'' with insider trading cases.


Modern Bride Sold For $50 Million
LEAD: Reed International, the British parent of the Cahners Publishing Company, said it had acquired Modern Bride from Diamandis Communications Inc. for $50 million in cash.
Additionally it agreed to pay Diamandis $13.7 million in consulting fees.

Susan Wagner Appeals
LEAD: Susan Wagner High School, which had the only undefeated football team in the Public School Athletic League, announced yesterday that it has appealed a decision by the league's commissioner that forced Wagner to forfeit eight of its nine victories this season because it used an ineligible player.


Problem at Seabrook Utility
LEAD: The Public Service Company of New Hampshire could face an involuntary bankruptcy petition at any time, the company acknowledged today, but a spokesman said that negotiations with creditors were continuing and that the utility was hopeful that it could reach agreement without bankruptcy.

Big Fund-Raisers Keep Gore Waiting
LEAD: At a recent political roast here, Senator Albert Gore Jr. was introduced by a comedian impersonating Nathan Landow, the leader of a group of Democratic fund-raisers that helped convince the Senator to run for President.


Three String Players Of Vienna Symphony
LEAD: The Vienna String Trio displays many of the best traits of musicians steeped in the Austro-German tradition.
The ensemble, made up of principal players in the Vienna Symphony Orchestra, gave a concert sponsored by the Austrian Institute Saturday evening in Weill Recital Hall.

LEAD: Three weeks before the scheduled meeting of President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, major verification issues remained unresolved today in talks aimed at wrapping up a treaty banning medium- and shorter-range missiles.

Harmonic Choir Offers A Musical Alternative
LEAD: David Hykes and the Harmonic Choir make music that encourages new modes of listening.
A number of recent musical developments have been leading in a similar direction.
Very long compositions, static compositions, and process compositions all suggest alternatives to the linear cause-and-effect mode of listening appropriate to classical music.


Safeguards Seen as Effective In Hospitals Despite L.I. Case
LEAD: The New York State Department of Health and the 280 general hospitals it regulates have safeguards to protect patients from mistakes by medical personnel, accidents and improper or inappropriate care, state officials said yesterday.

LEAD: Joseph M. White, a consultant to pharmaceutical companies for 30 years, died of congestive heart failure Thursday at his home in Alexandria, Va.

Runaway Locomotives Travel 30 Miles Before Being Stopped
LEAD: Six unmanned locomotives traveled more than 30 miles today at speeds up to 55 miles per hour before dispatchers were able to guide them onto a siding where they crashed into empty boxcars and stopped, officials said.


Joseph F. Heffernan; Opera Photographer, 64
LEAD: Joseph F. Heffernan, the photographer for the Metropolitan Opera House, died of lung cancer Thursday at St.
Vincent's Hospital.
He was 64 years old and lived in Manhattan.

NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 17, 1987
LEAD:  International A3-14


New Tiffany Strategy Pays Off for Chairman
LEAD: Since last month's stock market plunge, William R. Chaney, the chairman and chief executive of Tiffany &amp; Company, has watched his company's stock fall from more than $30 a share to under $20.


Fed Aide Sees Better Feeling
LEAD: The Federal Reserve Board's vice chairman, Manuel Johnson, said today that confidence in the financial system was returning after the stock market plunge of Oct. 19.


Measuring Knowledge
LEAD: REPORTS on what American students don't know always get top billing.
Adults, overlook what they themselves don't know, urge schools to get tough.
Lost in the process are proposals to make schools better rather than tougher.


Bonn May Let Deficit Rise
LEAD: The West German Government, under pressure from abroad to contribute to the world's economic growth, said today that it was prepared to risk a higher than projected 1988 budget deficit.


Webb Names Chief
LEAD: As expected, directors of the Del E. Webb Corporation today elected Philip J. Dion as chairman and chief executive of the gaming, real estate and recreation concern based in Phoenix.
Mr.
Dion, who is 42 years old and has been a Webb executive since 1982, succeeds Robert K. Swanson, who resigned unexpectedly for health reasons earlier this month.

Careers; Managers Found by Computer
LEAD: MOVE over, management recruiters.
Stanford University is going to poach on your territory with a computerized system to help companies find managers.


Beverly Hilton Sold Once More
LEAD: Merv Griffin may have signed off his last talk show, but he is back in the spotlight again, announcing today that he would buy the Beverly Hilton Hotel.


Kodak to Market New AIDS Test
LEAD: The Eastman Kodak Company said it would market what it called the first test ever that permits physicians to detect in their offices exposure to AIDS and other sexually transmitted diseases.
The tests will be marketed under the trade name Sure Cell.
Kodak said they are able to produce results in three to 15 minutes.


Turning Point Nears In Production of Fuel For Hydrogen Bombs
LEAD: WITH aging, faltering plants its sole source of supply, the Federal Government must soon decide whether to build expensive new facilities to produce tritium, a vital and perishable ingredient of nuclear bombs.


New York City Seeks to Acquire Times Sq. Hotel
LEAD: The Koch administration said yesterday that it would seek to acquire a 750-room hotel near Times Square as a long-term residence for the homeless, and as the site of a work-release program for New York City jail inmates.

Israel Says Arab Boat Taken
LEAD: A military spokesman said today that the Israeli Navy had intercepted a boat belonging to Al Fatah, a Palestinian guerrilla organization, forced it to dock at an Israeli port and arrested all of its passengers.
The 250-ton tugboat Nadija, flying a Honduran flag, was stopped last Saturday somewhere west of the Israeli coast, the announcement said.


Chemical Cuts Jobs At Credit Card Unit
LEAD: The Chemical New York Corporation said it would eliminate 575 jobs by transferring its credit card operations in Chicago to its main processing facility at Jericho, L.I. and by closing its unprofitable merchant credit card processing services in Chicago.
The company said it expects to begin consolidatng its credit card operations in January and to complete the process by March 31.

Expanding Oceans
LEAD: Two British scientists have predicted that the warmer global temperatures caused by the ''greenhouse effect'' will cause the world's oceans to rise in the next 40 years by at least four to eight centimeters (1 1/2 to 3 1/4 inches).
This would result purely from the expansion of the water caused by the higher temperature.

LEAD: Unilever P.L.C. said today that its third-quarter pretax earnings jumped 25 percent, to $:400 million, or about $696 million, helped by contributions from Chesebrough-Pond's Inc., which it acquired late last year.
Worldwide sales in the third quarter rose 11 percent from the period a year ago, to $:4.65 billion, or about $8.09 billion.

LEAD:  GENERAL ASSEMBLY


CNW Bid Raised $1, to $31 a Share
LEAD: The CNW Corporation, parent of the Chicago and North Western Transportation Company, said that after consultation with CNW's special committee of six independent directors, an investor group led by the buyout firm, Gibbons, Green van Amerongen of New York had increased its offer to buy the railroad company by $1, to $31 a share, or $578 million.

Thatcher Urges Budget Action
LEAD: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher today urged White House and Congressional budget negotiators to act decisively and said big cuts in United States deficits were needed to restore confidence to the world's financial markets.


When the Mind Dies But the Brain Lives On
LEAD: MIRACULOUS recoveries from prolonged comas are the stuff of movies and fairy tales.
But although medical advances have opened the way for more coma patients than ever to survive, most linger in a limbo state of unconsciousness, somewhere between life and death.
Few of these patients, even if they can be kept alive indefinitely and even if they appear to awaken and sleep regularly, have any hope of full recovery.

An Unlucky Lottery Winner
LEAD: A man who won $50,000 in the state lottery died the next day, officials said today.
Clarence Kinder, 77 years old, won the money Thursday on a televised lottery show.
He died Friday night of a heart attack, said his stepdaughter, Lucy Bell. ''Thursday was the greatest day of his life,'' she added.


G.M. Will Spin Off Diesel Engine Unit
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation said it would spin off part of its diesel engine manufacturing business to a joint venture it is forming with the Penske Corporation of Red Bank, N.J.
The venture, to be called the Detroit Diesel Corporation, will take over the heavy-duty diesel manufacturing business of G.M.


COCAINE TRIAL NEARS FOR WEST VIRGINIA MAYOR
LEAD: Jury selection began today in the drug trial of Mayor Mike Roark after the judge ruled that prosecutors could not present evidence of cocaine use unless it was included in the indictment.

Cyprus-LTV Steel
LEAD: The Cyprus Minerals Company said it had filed claims totaling $1.07 billion against the LTV Steel Company and alternate claims of $722 million against its parent company, the LTV Corporation.
Cyprus, based in Englewood, Calif., said the claims stem from LTV's Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing in July 1986 and its subsequent rejections of two long-term coal supply contracts.


Citizens Want to Know
LEAD: Whitty Cuninggim started by explaining what had first moved her. ''I was a bride in 1939.
My playhouse was disrupted and I didn't know why.
When my husband was sent off to war, my mother-in-law said: 'Don't worry.
God will send him back.' I wasn't satisfied.
He came back, but I decided by cracky, I may not be able to do anything about it but from now on I'm going to know why.

The Making of a Scholarly Best Seller
LEAD: Simon &amp; Schuster gave Allan Bloom a modest $10,000 advance and published an equally modest 10,000 copies of his scholarly and somewhat abstruse book.
Eight months later, ''The Closing of the American Mind'' has been a best seller for 29 weeks, has sold an astonishing 445,000 copies and is about to make its author a millionaire.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Q. Why doesn't the stomach digest itself?
A.
Cells lining the stomach and duodenum produce a mucous-like substance that separates the stomach wall from digestive enzymes and acids, according to Dr.
Averil Ma, a gastroenterology fellow at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center.


Business and Health; Kaiser Fears AIDS Influx
LEAD: FOR years Kaiser Permanente has proudly proclaimed that it could supply good medical care at a reasonable rate.
Its promotions have been wildly successful, and Kaiser has become by far the nation's largest prepaid-health-care organization, with more than five million members.


Kenya Shuts Campus After Battles With Students
LEAD: The Kenyan Government today closed the University of Nairobi, the country's main university campus, after two days of battles between security forces and students demonstrating over the arrest of their leaders.


Tokyo Journal; Like It or Not, Japan Has 20,000 Fugitive Guests
LEAD: Behind an unvarnished message that Japan is for Japanese, the Government is trying hard to shut the door on unskilled laborers who have flocked here from other Asian countries to find work.


Niwata and Tahmisian, Violinist and Pianist
LEAD: The violinist-pianist duo of Kaoru Niwata and Emma Tahmisian made a debut in Weill Recital Hall Sunday afternoon with a program of works by Debussy, Franck, Prokofiev and Toshiro Saruya.
Ms.
Niwata's string tone was big and pleasing, and her energetic phrasing was invariably correct; Ms.
Tahmisian presented a more restrained approach at the piano that was no less reasonable.

Swedish Train Crash Kills 9
LEAD: Nine people were killed and more than 100 were injured today when two trains crashed head-on in western Sweden and burst into flames, rescue workers said.
The crash occurred near the town of Lerum, about 12 miles east of Goteborg, when an express from Stockholm to Goteborg ran into a passenger train traveling on the same track in the opposite direction.

Bank Drops Eurobonds
LEAD: Toronto Dominion International, a unit of the Toronto Dominion Bank of Canada, has withdrawn from the Eurobond market, it said today.
Eurobonds are bonds that pay interest in a currency outside the country of issue.
Several banks have reduced Eurobond activity as unprofitable.

LEAD: Jim Brewer, a former star relief pitcher for the Los Angeles Dodgers, died of injuries suffered in an automobile accident here today, the National League club said.


Bass to Raise Stake In Bell &amp; Howell
LEAD: An investor group led by Robert M. Bass of Fort Worth said it intends to raise to 25 percent its large stake in the Bell &amp; Howell Company, the information services and publishing concern that is attracting much takeover interest.
In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, the group, which already holds 1.5 million shares, or 16.2 percent, repeated earlier statements that it plans to discuss its investment with company management.


Food Shortage Cited in 15 African Countries
LEAD: The World Food Program warned today that 15 countries in sub-Saharan Africa - a region suffering from widespread drought, crop failure and civil strife -need large shipments of food immediately.

LEAD: Doug Williams, the Washington Redskins' quarterback, has been granted his wish to start for a contender, and it did not take a trade to do it.

Coach Joe Gibbs repeatedly denied the request.

Recital: Anthony Newman Inaugurates a Church Organ
LEAD: THE Church of the Holy Trinity on East 88th Street inaugurated a new organ Sunday afternoon.
It is a 33-stop tracker instrument by Rieger Orgelbau of Austria, designed for a particular kind of versatility: registrations historically appropriate for French and North German Baroque music are accommodated, while string work for the French Romantics is available on the third manual.


Computer Bazaars
LEAD: THE silver-haired woman standing in line behind me turned to the man with her and said, ''You know, if I get that new card I'll be able to do a lot more with graphics.'' He agreed, a bit glumly, it seemed.
His wife was on a shopping trip.


A Sincere Form of Flattery
LEAD: Until recently I.B.M. and Apple, the big two of personal computers, have turned out models that were as different as a utilitarian Volvo and a sporty Porsche.
Now, they risk becoming as alike as a Pontiac and a Chevy.


Handouts of Cheese, Milk and Rice Face 50% Cut Next Year
LEAD: Government policies to reduce surpluses of cheese, milk and rice have succeeded so well that the Reagan Administration plans to cut distribution of these commodities in half in the coming year, Federal officials said today.


The Sexy Look: Why Now?
LEAD: Necklines plunge or open out in sweetheart effects not seen since the 1950's.
Shoulders are bared, waistlines snugly fitted, and skirts are rounded in an egg shape, tightly draped, or flared and poufed with myriad petticoats.
Some tops are translucent if not transparent, and some dresses look like lingerie, with slip tops and lacy edges.


Japanese Deny Tube Dumping
LEAD: Five Japanese television manufacturers denied today that they were exporting color picture tubes to the United States at unfairly low prices.


PRODUCTION ROSE 0.6% IN OCTOBER
LEAD: The nation's factories, mines and utilities raised their output by six-tenths of 1 percent in October, the strongest gain since July, the Federal Reserve reported today.

LEAD: SOMETIMES your dreams come true. And sometimes your nightmares do.

Treasury Bonds on Upside
LEAD: Despite unanswered questions about the outcome of negotiations to reduce Federal budget deficits, Treasury bond prices ended the day with gains of about 3/8 point and yields still in the 8 7/8 percent to 9 percent range that has prevailed for more than a week.


'HOOVER VS. THE KENNEDYS,' MINI-SERIES ON CHANNEL 11
LEAD: IT'S not the bad taste; it's the frivolity. ''Hoover vs. the Kennedys: The Second Civil War'' seems to be a face-off between two yuppies and old Scrooge.
President John F. Kennedy dallies, while Robert F. Kennedy pouts and J. Edgar Hoover has snits.
The two-part, four-hour mini-series, which begins on Channel 11 at 9 o'clock tonight, is a kind of gumshoe's view of the White House.

Thanksgiving meal-in-a-day.

LEAD: Mountain climbers, including sons of the first two men to reach the summit of Mount Everest, plan to scale the Himalayan peak next spring in the first attempt to plant equipment there for making precise measurements of its elevation, expedition organizers announced last week.

Jet in Emergency Landing
LEAD: A Northwest Airlines Boeing 727 jetliner made an emergency landing at Bismark Municipal Airport today after the pilot radioed that the plane's rear stairway might have lowered in flight, an airport official said.

IT'S NOT SO EASY FOR NAVRATILOVA
LEAD: All the computer points have been counted, thus assuring Steffi Graf of finishing the year as the No. 1 player.
But last night, Martina Navratilova began her quest for the popular vote at Madison Square Garden, hoping that winning the Virginia Slims championships would strengthen her claim that she is still the best player in the world.


Earnings Rise at 3 Retailers
LEAD: Three leading retailing chains yesterday reported improved earnings for the third quarter.

Trump Urged To Head Gala Of Democrats
LEAD: Donald J. Trump, the New York real estate magnate and a registered Republican, has been asked by Jim Wright, the Speaker of the House of Representatives, to be the host at the 25th annual Democratic Congressional dinner in Washington in March, Congressional officials said yesterday.


FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
LEAD: The GTE Corporation is offering $200 million of 10.3 percent debentures, due in 2017, at a price of 100, through underwriters led by Paine Webber Inc.


Ralph Rice Boyer; Former Nuclear Official, 83
LEAD: Ralph Rice Boyer, retired chief of contracts finance for the Atomic Energy Commission, died of a heart attack Thursday at his home in Sandy Spring, Md.
He was 83 years old.

Bruce's Ouster Is Questioned
LEAD: The president of Ohio State University declined yesterday to be specific about his reasons for dismissing Earle Bruce as the school's football coach, saying only that the decision was a ''personnel issue'' that had nothing to do with the team's record.


Kean Proposes A Cleanup Plan For Jersey Shore
LEAD: Governor Kean proposed today a 14-point, $200 million program to clean up the ocean off the Jersey Shore, but said local communities and Congress must also act if the effort is to succeed.

LEAD: Lawyers are accustomed to thinking about new legal angles.
Consider for example the diagramed deal which occurred in a social game.


Bookmaker Sets Odds On Cuomo Bid in '88
LEAD: A London bookmaking firm, William Hill, says it has succumbed to popular demand and included Governor Cuomo of New York on the list of favorites to win the White House next year.

Texaco Creditors Offer To Help Settle Dispute
LEAD: In a move that deepens the backstage maneuvering in the dispute between Texaco Inc. and the Pennzoil Company, a committee of Texaco creditors said yesterday that it would ask for a court-appointed examiner to help settle the dispute.


Amoco Raises Its Dome Offer
LEAD: The Amoco Corporation said its Canadian unit had raised its takeover offer for Dome Petroleum Ltd. to $5.5 billion Canadian, or about $4.2 billion in United States currency.
The previous bid was $5.1 billion Canadian, or about $3.9 billion.


Arthur E. B. Tanner; Legislator, 78
LEAD: Arthur E. B. Tanner, former speaker of the Connecticut House of Representatives and past president of the Waterbury Foundry Company, died Sunday at his home here.
He was 78 years old.


Anita Brielke Stafford; Executive, 61
LEAD: Anita Brielke Stafford, senior vice president of Hermes of Paris Inc., the North American subsidiary of the Paris-based fashion boutique, was killed Friday in a car accident near Newtown, Conn.
She was 61 years old and lived in Manhattan and in Bethlehem, Conn.


Shamir Has No Regrets on Israel's Iran Arms Role
LEAD: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said today that he had no regrets about Israel's involvement in American covert arms sales to Iran.

Legislators Seek Bistate Council On the Economy
LEAD: Three legislators from New York and New Jersey, calling for a ''cease-fire'' in the states' battle for business development, said yesterday that they would propose a new bistate economic cooperation council.

Let Reagan Lead
LEAD: To the Editor:


Greek Police Break Up An Anti-U.S. Protest
LEAD: The police fired tear gas and water cannon to disperse leftist demonstrators after an annual march on the United States Embassy here tonight to protest purported collusion between Washington and the colonels who ruled Greece from 1967 to 1974.


Koch Backs Unit to Fight Corruption
LEAD: Mayor Koch urged yesterday that broad prosecutorial powers be granted to a proposed state agency that would oversee the construction industry in New York City.


Ex-Head of Lotus Forms a Company
LEAD: A year after he left his post as chairman of the Lotus Development Corporation, where he helped to revolutionize the software industry, Mitchell D. Kapor says he is still nagged by the unnecessary complexity of current computers.


New York's New Culture Chief
LEAD: Dr.
Mary Schmidt Campbell, the first to admit she was ''brazen'' in seeking the job as New York City's Commissioner of Cultural Affairs, has now spent seven weeks in office, and she does not seem a bit daunted by the task. ''I am a political animal,'' she says, adding that she feels comfortable with the political system and intends to use it to help the arts, starting from the grass roots on up.


Donald Moss; Dance Manager, 38
LEAD: Donald Moss, the booking manager for the Feld Ballet and stage manager for a number of modern dance companies, including Alvin Ailey Dance Theater, died of heart failure on Sunday at his Manhattan home.
He was 38 years old.

Eating Well
LEAD: ADULTS who as children balked at downing their weekly ration of fish oil can't get enough of the stuff today: not cod-liver oil, mind you, but its modern-day successor - concentrates high in substances called omega-3 fatty acids.

Eating Out With Martina Navratilova; Pasta and Fruit: A Lunch of Champions
LEAD: AFTER winning the United States Open tennis championship this year in New York, Martina Navratilova declined numerous invitations to celebrate at the city's swanky restaurants.
Instead, she returned to her hotel room where a friend catered a private dinner party. ''It was all Czech food,'' she said.


Advertising; Agencies Greet New Business
LEAD: THREE good-sized advertisers announced new agency alliances yesterday.
The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company is returning to Young &amp; Rubicam, the agency that served it from 1945 to 1975.
DDB Needham, Chicago, is getting the Discover credit card from Sears, Roebuck &amp; Company.
And Grey Advertising and its subsidiary, Levine, Huntley, Schmidt &amp; Beaver, are getting big pieces of work from


Sports People; Griffin Relents
LEAD: Alfredo Griffin, the Oakland Athletics' shortstop who is being pursued by a number of teams, including the Yankees, has rescinded his demand for a trade.
So now there is a greater chance than ever he will be traded.
The explanation?
Last week, Griffin exercised a clause in his contract demanding a trade, presumably in an attempt to gain a lengthy contract extension but also making difficult any attempts by the Athletics to trade him by saying he would veto deals with the Yankees, Los Angeles, Mont-real, Philadelphia, Houston and Bos-ton.


Joseph C. Brennan, 77, Retired Bank Official
LEAD: Joseph Cantwell Brennan, a retired chairman and trustee of the Emigrant Savings Bank in New York and a prominent Roman Catholic layman, died Thursday after a heart attack at his home in Manhattan.
He was 77 years old.


Economic Scene; Stocks Fall, Business Rises
LEAD: HOW hard a blow has the stock market's collapse last month dealt to the real economy?


Bundesbank's Optimistic Chief
LEAD: When economic crises arise, Karl Otto Pohl can usually be found between the nearly irresistable Washington and the almost immovable Bonn - and looking for all the world as if he enjoys it.


Paul Derringer; Former Reds Pitcher, 81
LEAD: Paul Derringer, who won 161 games during 10 years with the Cincinnati Reds, died today in Sarasota, Fla., the team announced.
He was 81 years old.


Washington Talk: Briefing; With Kemp, Bork?
LEAD: Judge Robert H. Bork's hope of serving on the Supreme Court may not have ended with the rejection of his nomination by the Senate.

Wimbledon Profit At $12.5 Million
LEAD: This year's Wimbledon championships, the only Grand Slam tennis event played on grass, made a profit of more than $12.5 million.
The All England Club announced today that the profit was $12,592,782, which will go to the British Lawn Tennis Association for the benefit of the game in Britain.
The figure is up about 15 percent over last year's profit of $10,913,492.


Yields 5.20%-7.75% On Missouri Bonds
LEAD: A $120 million issue of Missouri general obligation bonds was offered yesterday through underwriters led by Chase Manhattan Capital Markets Corporation, with yields ranging from 5.20 percent for bonds due in 1988 to 6.60 percent in 1997, 7.55 percent in 2007 and 7.75 percent in 2010 through 2012.


EXECUTIVE CHANGES
LEAD: *
Baxter Travenol Laboratories, Deerfield, Ill., a developer of health care products, systems and services, named as a director Martha R. Ingram, director of public affairs and director at Ingram Industries.

No Stock Dealings For Rooney, Pace
LEAD: Rooney, Pace Inc. has agreed to leave the securities industry after the Securities and Exchange Commission found numerous violations in three of its public stock offerings.
The concern was once a leading underwriter of initial public offerings.
The S.E.C. also suspended Randolph Pace, chairman of the firm, from the securities business for nine months.


Clear Guilt, Unclear Law
LEAD: The Supreme Court's ruling in the case of R. Foster Winans was unclear concerning securities law and inconsistent concerning fraud law, yet it produced a roughly just result.
Now it's up to Congress to clarify both areas of the law.


Western Union Again Delays Vote
LEAD: The Western Union Corporation again put off a shareholder vote on its restructuring plan.
A shareholder meeting that had been set for Nov. 11 and then adjourned until today was adjourned again until Dec. 10, the company said.
Shareholders were to vote on merging the corporation with its principal subsidiary, the Western Union Telegraph Company.


Bid to Dismiss Silver Suit Fails
LEAD: A Federal judge yesterday rejected a motion to throw out a lawsuit brought in 1981 by a Peruvian commodities trading company against the Hunt brothers of Texas and leading brokerage firms.
The ruling means that the suit will be heard in Federal court beginning Feb. 3, 1988.


Insurance Consultant Gets Posts at USLife
LEAD: The USLife Corporation, a life insurance holding company, said yesterday that it had named James F. Betts president and chief operating officer, as well as a member of its board.


Jo Jo White Makes a Return at 41 With a Helping Hand as His Goal
LEAD: By WILLIAM C. RHODEN


Iran Says Iraqis Raided a Nuclear Plant
LEAD: Iranian news outlets reported that Iraqi warplanes raided an unfinished Iranian nuclear power plant today, and that an Iranian nuclear official said the attack could lead to a release of radiation across international borders.


Letters; The Best Bread
LEAD: To The Living Section:


SOVIET HINTS MOVE ON AFGHAN ACCORD
LEAD: A recent flurry of diplomatic activity has raised new speculation that the Soviet Union may be ready to compromise on a timetable for the withdrawal of the 115,000 troops it has stationed in Afghanistan.


Soviet Confirms That Yeltsin Is Ill and in Hospital
LEAD: The Government confirmed today that Boris N. Yeltsin, the high-ranking official who was purged from office last week, had been hospitalized but said his health was not a cause for concern.


HOUSING MEASURE BLOCKED IN SENATE
LEAD: Senate Republicans today delivered a surprising and potentially fatal blow to major housing legislation that was expected to be passed and sent to the President.


No Singer Bid From Allied-Signal
LEAD: Allied-Signal Inc. said it would not expand its military-contracting businesses, an announcement that analysts interpreted to mean that the company was no longer a potential suitor for the Singer Company.
Allied-Signal, of Morristown, N.J., had been rumored to be a possible bidder for Singer, the Stamford, Conn., military contractor that is the subject of a hostile takeover bid by the Florida investor Paul A.


Troubled Bronx School's Fate Now Rests With Students
LEAD: In what has become a fight to save Junior High School 123 in the Bronx from closing, parents led the opening charge.
But if the battle is to be won, it will be up to their children to finish the task.

LEAD: After years of on-again, off-again plans and renovations that have cost almost $200 million, yet another group of investors has announced the reopening of the Gotham Hotel - this time under the name Hotel Maxim's de Paris.

Music: Chamber Works By the Da Capo Players
LEAD: THE music of George Crumb is always threatening to break out of the concert hall and into the theater.
The orchestra is asked to take part in mysterious processionals in ''Echoes of Time and the River.'' In ''Ancient Voices of Children,'' the boy soprano is offstage until the last page of the score, when he joins the mezzo-soprano for a poignant vocalise.


METROPOLITAN DIARY
LEAD: CONVERSATION overheard by Hinda Gonchor going downtown on an M104 bus.


3 Hunters Killed and 3 Wounded at Start of New York Deer Season
LEAD: Three hunters were killed Monday and three others were treated for gunshot wounds in the first day of the deer hunting season in most of New York State.

Slaying Inquiry Builds Against L.I. Nurse
LEAD: Investigators focused their attention today on building what could become a multiple-murder case against Richard Angelo, the registered nurse accused of injecting fatal amounts of a muscle-paralyzing drug into one of his patients at Good Samaritan Hospital here.


At the Nation's Table; Boston
LEAD: THE Zagat Boston Restaurant Survey is almost ready for publication.
Like its counterparts in New York, Los Angeles and elsewhere, the survey is based on responses from committed diners-out.
More than 700 people in the Boston area offered opinions on some 325 restaurants.


Town's Outdoor Holiday Feast Draws 150 From Far and Near
LEAD: NESTLED in the northeast corner of Connecticut, about five miles from the Massachusetts border, Woodstock is so remote and so quiet that when the writer Theodore H. White flew over it in 1967, he said it was the only place between Washington and Boston where there were no lights at night.


Quake Hurts 3 in Nicaragua; Thousands Flee Their Homes
LEAD: A strong earthquake rocked Nicaragua, injuring at least three people and driving thousands from their homes, officials said today.

Nussbaum Is Taken To Another Hospital
LEAD: Hedda Nussbaum, who is accused of murder in the death of 6-year-old Lisa Steinberg, was transferred yesterday to the Presbyterian Hospital.


Wright, His Latin Role Contested, Signs a 'Peace' Pact With Shultz
LEAD: After four days of bitterness over the role of Jim Wright, the House Speaker, as a mediator in the Central American peace negotiations, Mr.
Wright and Secretary of State George P. Shultz signed a six-point agreement today pledging to work together and not to ''create unnecessary problems.''

LEAD: Last week's snowstorm here may have killed an audacious notion of the Nicaraguan President, Daniel Ortega Saavedra, to visit the Vietnam War memorial on Veterans Day last week.


Market Place; Street Weighs N.A.S.D. Plan
LEAD: AFTER an unsettled stock market closed on Oct. 22, managers of some of the top over-the-counter stock trading desks met at a private room above one of Wall Street's best-known watering holes, Harry's Bar, to air their grievances about widely perceived problems in their trading system.

The Dance: Showcase Of 11 Works
LEAD: THE ''Choreographer's Showcase'' that Evolving Arts Inc. presented Sunday night at Dance Space Inc. (622 Broadway, between Bleecker and Houston Streets) contained 11 dances by 12 choreographers.
The apparent discrepancy between the number of creators and the number of works created is explained by the fact that one of those dances had two choreographers.


Corrections
LEAD: A report in the New Jersey Guide column of the New Jersey Weekly on Sunday about a ''Teach-In on Homelessness'' sponsored by the Student Volunteers Council in Princeton misstated the dates.
The two-day program starts today, not tomorrow.


Knicks Change Course
LEAD: The original plan was to wait and see.
After joining the Knicks during the off season, Al Bianchi, the new general manager, and Rick Pitino, the rookie head coach, said changes would be made but only after every player had an opportunity to prove whether he could handle the new challenges and responsibilities.


Park Is Searched After Report About a Young Girl
LEAD: More than 50 police officers, including a scuba team and helicopter pilots, fanned out across a park on the Brooklyn-Queens border yesterday after three young children said they had seen a young girl carried into the park by a man who left her there.


Red Wings Win, 1-0
LEAD: Glen Hanlon made 32 saves for his eighth career shutout, and Steve Yzerman scored 33 seconds into the game tonight as the Detroit Red Wings defeated the Washington Capitals, 1-0.


Plan Blocked for Tower Atop Landmark
LEAD: The New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission yesterday rejected a proposal to build an apartment tower atop the Metropolitan Club on Fifth Avenue.

E.P.A. SEEKS DELAY IN USING SANCTIONS OF POLLUTION LAW
LEAD: The Environmental Protection Agency today proposed delaying economic sanctions against areas that will not meet a statutory Dec. 31 deadline for reducing smog and carbon monoxide levels.
It would be the third major delay since 1977.

LEAD: Three pillow companies have been charged with violating the state's Unfair Trade Practices Act, Consumer Protection Commissioner Mary M. Heslin said today.

LEAD: Lawyers for the Indian Government and the Union Carbide Corporation were scheduled to appear at a court hearing in India today, amid wide speculation that they were close to an agreement on compensation to be paid the victims of the Bhopal disaster.


U.S. Arrests 14 as Members of Cocaine Ring
LEAD: A ring that sold 220 pounds a week of cocaine was broken up today with the arrests of 14 people in New York and New Jersey, the authorities said.

LEAD:  BASEBALL


Toyota's Imports
LEAD: The Commerce Department said it had recommended that the Toyota Motor Company be granted a free trade zone in Louisville, Ky., enabling the Japanese concern to import parts for its Georgetown plant without paying a duty.


Helen Hallet Kennedy; Civic Leader, 80
LEAD: Helen Hallet Kennedy, a civic leader in Bedford, N.Y., died Sunday at her daughter's home in Bedford after a brief illness.
She was 80 years old.


The U.N. Today: Nov. 18, 1987
LEAD:  GENERAL ASSEMBLY


Nebraska Suffers Scouting Setback
LEAD: A seemingly insignificant agreement between members of the football coaching staffs at Nebraska and Oklahoma has apparently prevented the Cornhusker coaches from seeing film of Charles Thompson, the new Sooner quarterback, in his first game as a starter last week.

LEAD: Walter F. Thomas, a retired vice chairman of the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, died of cardiac arrest Nov. 7 in a nursing home in Boca Raton, Fla.
He was 77 years old and lived in Boca Raton.

Mr.

LEAD: HISTORIANS of the Holocaust appear to fall into one of two schools of thought these days.
The more traditional ''intentionalists'' see a direct connection between Hitler's ideology, expressed in his anti-Semitic speeches of the 1920's as well as in ''Mein Kampf,'' and the eventual implementation of the ''final solution'' during World War


Kasparov Puzzle: Why So Passive?
LEAD: What meaning did the 14th game of the world championship chess match in Seville, Spain, have for the titleholder, 24-year-old Gary Kasparov?
Why, with the slight advantage of the white pieces, should he not have made some attempt to avoid a toothless draw on Monday?


Gypsies Not Welcome! Romans Say
LEAD: In the suburbs where this city becomes an impoverished and ramshackle metropolis, old women blocked railroad tracks this week and young men set tires aflame at a highway toll station, all because they had heard a rumor that the government was going to build a settlement camp for gypsies in their neighborhood, or maybe just in a neighborhood nearby.

Ortega vs. Contra Aid: Sandinistas Near a Victory?
LEAD: As he returned to Managua Monday night from a trip to the United States, President Daniel Ortega Saavedra believed he was closer than ever to a goal he did not think was possible even a few months ago: a Congressional vote to cut off aid to the contras.


Foraging in the Refrigerator
LEAD: OUR refrigerator used to develop a nervous tic at Thanskgiving and Christmas.
Not because it was stuffed with food - which it was -but because my children were home from school for vacation and opened it every time they passed it.


Strong Quake in Alaska
LEAD: A major earthquake followed by dozens of aftershocks jarred portions of Alaska today and forced hundreds of coastal residents to flee their homes.
No serious injuries or damage were reported in the quakes, which began with a temblor measuring 6.9 on the Richter scale.
The quake was centered in the Gulf of Alaska, about 270 miles east-southeast of Anchorage and 90 miles southwest of Cape Yakataga, between Yakutat and Cordova.


From Just One Man, A Dynasty of Cellarers
LEAD: THE last thing Kevin Zraly had in mind in the old days was creating a dynasty.
But there they all were, kissing, hugging, ribbing their old mentor (well, he's 36), acting like any other alumni group whose members had not seen one another for a few years.


Life in the 30's
LEAD: SOME years ago my editors decided that I should write a story about the atmosphere on Wall Street.
This was fine except that all I knew for sure about Wall Street was how to get there on the subway.
So I sought out a writer who made it his business to know everything on the subject and asked him if he could spend an hour educating me.


Breakfast of Wimps
LEAD: Do Americans really eat breakfast cereal?
Grown-up, adult, mature, yuppie-age Americans, eating breakfast cereal?
And even old, worn-out, graybeard Americans born too late to be investment bankers, eating breakfast cereal?

LEAD: Ted Gregory, the Syracuse University nose guard who early in the season was considered a candidate for the Outland and Lombardi Trophies for outstanding linemen, has undergone arthroscopic surgery to remove torn outer cartilage from his left knee.
Dr.
Bruce Baker, the Syracuse team physician who performed the surgery on Monday, said he ''couldn't make a categorical statement'' about Gregory's availability if the Orangemen play in the Sugar Bowl at New Orleans on Jan.

LEAD: By his own admission James V. Trotta of the Throgs Neck section of the Bronx was a compulsive gambler until 10 years ago.
He has also spent some 24 of his 44 years in the magazine business, most of it on the circulation and distribution side.

Dollar Down Sharply Amid Budget Doubts
LEAD: The dollar fell sharply yesterday in selling that began on Asian and European foreign-exchange markets and carried over into New York.
Business was relatively quiet in all markets, currency dealers said, but sales of dollars were persistent enough to erase the gains made by the dollar on Monday.

LEAD: The nation's factories, mines and utilities operated at 81.3 percent of capacity in October, the highest operating rate in more than three years, the Government reported today.

Bern Police Fight Squatters
LEAD: Riot policemen firing tear gas, water hoses and rubber bullets stormed barricades of burning tires and furniture today to break up an illegal squatter camp in the center of the Swiss capital.
Earlier, officers ringed the so-called Zaffaraya Free State with barbed wire after settlers ignored repeated orders to close it for breaching building regulations.


Charleston, W.Va., Mayor Admits Cocaine Guilt
LEAD: Mayor James E. (Mike) Roark, on the morning his drug trial was to begin, pleaded guilty today to six misdemeanor counts of cocaine possession and agreed to resign.


Runaway Train Chief Left to Get Candy Bar
LEAD: Six unmanned locomotives that went out of control for 30 miles until they were deliberately crashed into a row of boxcars slipped away from their engineer when he left to buy a candy bar, a police officer said today.


N.A.S.D. Fills Top Board Job
LEAD: The National Association of Securities Dealers said yesterday that it had named Stephen L. Hammerman, a Merrill Lynch executive, to be chairman of its 31-member board of governors for 1988.


A Home-Style Thanksgiving That Avoids All the Fuss
LEAD: A THANKSGIVING to go is ideal for those who are short of time or have no inclination to prepare a dinner from scratch.
Traditional menus as well as vegetarian, French, Italian, delicatessen and low-calorie are available.
You can choose complete dinners or just the fixings to accompany the turkey.

LEAD: Actmedia Inc. of Westhampton Beach, L.I., has become a giant among companies that arrange for promotions within supermarkets -the last mile of consumer purchase decision-making.

LEAD: WHEN I was an apprentice chef in France many years ago, one of the first dishes I learned to create was sauteed chicken with tarragon.

LEAD: General Motors of Canada Ltd. said it would indefinitely lay off 200 employees at its Windsor transmission plant in January because of declining car sales.

LEAD: The Reagan Administration wants Mikhail S. Gorbachev to be allowed to speak to a joint meeting of Congress during the summit meeting next month only if Moscow permits President Reagan to address the Soviet people, a senior Administration official said today.


6 Victims From Connecticut Identified in Wisconsin Crash
LEAD: The eight people killed when a light plane broke up and crashed were identified today as six officials of a Connecticut company and executives of companies in Wisconsin and Illinois, company spokesmen said.


Sports People; Hearns-Hagler Near
LEAD: A contract for Thomas Hearns to defend his World Boxing Council middleweight title against Marvelous Marvin Hagler, the former undisputed champion, could be completed by the end of next week, according to the Hearns camp.
Emanuel Steward, Hearns's manager, said that negotiations with Hagler got under way last weekend and that there was a 95 percent chance for a fight this spring.

LEAD:  Additive-Free Turkeys


Gov. O'Neill Better; Will Undergo Tests
LEAD: Gov.
William A. O'Neill, described as feeling much better after being hospitalized Sunday with a temperature of 103 degrees, will undergo more tests today and tomorrow to try to find the cause of the fever, hospital officials said yesterday.


Bird Injured in Loss
LEAD: The Cleveland Cavaliers, exploiting the absence of the injured Larry Bird, outscored the visiting Celtics, 26-15, in the third quarter last night to send Boston to its first loss of the season.


Dun &amp; Bradstreet Withdraws Its Bid
LEAD: The Dun &amp; Bradstreet Corporation yesterday withdrew its offer for Information Resources Inc., a market research company, after the Federal Trade Commission said it opposed a merger.

LEAD: Commerce Secretary C. William Verity Jr. said today, before leaving for an official visit to Tokyo, that if Japan did not raise export prices to reflect the lower value of the dollar it could face new trade retaliation from the United States.


Film: 'La Vie Est Belle'
LEAD: ''LA VIE EST BELLE'' is a genial musical comedy film from Zaire, and there are two striking things about it: how very African it is, and how very African it is not.

LEAD: A convicted narcotics dealer who was mistakenly freed in 1978 from the state prison in Ossining, N.Y., was arrested yesterday in Flushing, Queens, Federal law-enforcement officials said.

Sanitizing a Novel for the Screen
LEAD: In the novel ''Less Than Zero,'' passionless Los Angeles rich kids, spaced out on drugs and affluence, drift from Ferraris to glitzy clubs, from cocaine to bisexuality.
In the movie made from Bret Easton Ellis's book, most of the sex is missing, and the earnest message is a warning that drugs can kill.


Sports People; Comings and Goings
LEAD: Micheal Ray Richardson, the guard formerly with the Knicks and Nets, has signed a contract to play for the Albany Patroons of the Continental Basketball Association.
He was banned from the National Basketball Association in 1986 for repeated drug use. . . .
The Philadelphia Flyers have signed Ron Hextall, the goaltender, to a new multiyear contract.


Directly From Italy to Broadway
LEAD: IF the expense makes you think twice about using an excellent extra-virgin olive oil with abandon, look for the Dal Raccolto brand.
The Fairway market at 2127 Broadway (74th Street) has begun importing olive oil and other Dal Raccolto items directly from Italy.


BOOKS OF THE TIMES
LEAD: HEY JACK! By Barry Hannah. 133 pages.


RUSSIAN PREDICTS ARMS ACCORD SOON
LEAD: The chief Soviet arms-control negotiator predicted today that a treaty banning medium- and shorter-range missiles would be completed within six days.
But important verification issues reportedly remained unresolved after two days of high-level talks here.


At the Nation's Table; Chicago
LEAD: MANY Chicagoans who appreciate fine food served in relaxing settings are starting to believe that they are victims of a conspiracy engineered in New York, Los Angeles and other culinary centers.


Harte-Hanks Sets Sale of Businesses
LEAD: Harte-Hanks Communications Inc. said it would sell six direct marketing units, along with a shopper publication in Florida.
Charles H. Everill, senior vice president of Harte-Hanks and chief executive of the Direct Marketing Sector, and Cal Ingram, a consultant to Harte-Hanks, plan to buy the direct marketing operations.


The Genetic Factor in Coronary Disease
LEAD: To the Editor:


No Warrants Needed To Give Urine Tests
LEAD: An appeals court ruled yesterday that police officers who believe suspects are under the influence of drugs can demand urine samples from the suspects without search warrants.


Terrence Des Pres, 47, A Writer and Professor
LEAD: Terrence Des Pres, a writer and college professor, died at his home in Hamilton, N.Y., on Monday.
He was 47 years old.
The cause of death is undetermined, pending completion of an autopsy, but Neal Rose, the Madison County District Attorney and Coroner, said the death appeared to have been accidental.

Greeks Show Basketball Skill
LEAD: Panos Fassoulas, Fanis Christodoulou, and Agamemnon Ioannou are not exactly household names - at least not in American households.
They are, however, heroes in Greece, where they form the nucleus of the national basketball team.
The aggressive and well-coached team, which beat the Soviet Union to win the European Cup this year, is in the midst of a one-week, six-game exhibition tour against


A Cult Champagne in Europe Comes to America at $100
LEAD: A PRESTIGE Champagne that sells for $100 a bottle is arriving at carriage-trade stores across the nation.
It is the 1979 A. Salon Le Mesnil blanc de blancs, a white wine from white grapes.
Its finesse rivals its price.


Boeing Pension Fund Shifting Out of Stocks
LEAD: The Boeing Company is selling a good deal of the stock held by its multibillion-dollar pension fund, and market sources say Rockwell International is doing the same.
The moves explain some of the selling pressure on the stock market in recent days.


To Cut the Deficit, Keep '87 Tax Rates
LEAD: If President Reagan is serious about everything being on the table, there are $50 billion in deficit reductions that the budget negotiators have left untouched and, indeed, undiscussed.
This $50 billion is not money that would be extracted from taxpayers but money that will be lost unless something is done.


Crude Oil Prices Fall To 7-Month Lows
LEAD: American crude oil prices shed between 4 cents and 25 cents a barrel yesterday, falling to their lowest levels in seven months on pressures from excess supplies and expectations that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries would not raise prices at its meeting on Dec. 9.


Japan Cuts Overseas Investment
LEAD: The flow of money from Japan, a stream that has helped to finance the United States budget deficit and to influence stock prices on Wall Street, is slowing dramatically as investors here wait to see what steps the United States will take to cut its budget and trade deficits.


U.S. Appeals Court Backs Schools in Drug Tests Without Suspicion
LEAD: A Federal appeals court ruled today that the public schools in the nation's capital may legally test certain employees for evidence of illicit drug use even if the school authorities had no reason to suspect the particular employees.


Citibank's Plan For Branches
LEAD: Citibank said it is reorganizing its branch organization in the New York metropolitan area, a move that might eliminate as many as 1,000 jobs.

2 White Racists Convicted in Killing of Radio Host
LEAD: A jury in Federal District Court here today found two white supremacists guilty and acquitted two others in the 1984 assassination of the host of a Denver radio talk show.

LEAD: Madeleine Kamman, a chef and cooking instructor, said she came to California because ''there is a much younger spirit, a sparkle out there.'' And the state was just right, she said, for her newest project: a ''finishing school'' for chefs.

China-Australia Project
LEAD: Australia and China signed a joint-venture agreement today to mine iron ore in Western Australia.
The project at Mount Channar, worth $250 million (Australian), or about $170 million (United States), is China's biggest overseas investment, Prime Minister Bob Hawke said after the signing ceremony here.

Howard Beach Witness Holds to Story of Attack
LEAD: Under intense cross-examination by defense lawyers yesterday, a 37-year-old black man vigorously stood by his story that he was attacked and severely beaten by a gang of whites who confronted him and two other black men in Howard Beach, Queens.


Yugoslav Devaluation
LEAD: Yugoslavia devalued the dinar by almost 25 percent today in an effort to expand exports.
The currency action followed recent price rises of 30 to 70 percent on fuel, food, transport and some raw materials, with a freeze at the new levels.
Prime Minister Branko Mikulic's Government also imposed limited wage controls.


Abused Boy's Mother Said to Want Custody
LEAD: The biological mother of Mitchell Steinberg, the 16-month-old boy found in the same Greenwich Village apartment where the police say Lisa Steinberg was beaten to death, is expected to seek custody of the boy today, according to a lawyer in the case.


Simon, Now a Credible Candidate, Still Faces an Issue of Electability
LEAD: Almost giddy from his poll numbers and his crowds as he campaigns across Iowa, Senator Paul Simon of Illinois has clearly crossed a major threshold of political credibility in the race for the Democratic nomination for President.


New York Quits Using An Ocean Dump Site
LEAD: New York City used an ocean dumping site 12 miles offshore for the last time yesterday.
It plans to use a site 106 miles out for dumping sewage treatment waste from now on.

Japan Air Lines Offering
LEAD: Japan Air Lines is being privatized after 34 years of Government control.

The 1970's Industrial Look: What Became of High Tech?
LEAD: High tech, the revolutionary design movement that brought the industrial style into thousands of American homes and apartments, seems to have vanished without a trace after a life span of less than 15 years.
The look that celebrated innovation and resourcefulness, it was expressed in the beauty of exposed pipes, the plainness of restaurant ware and the practicality of hospital equipment.

Death Sentence in Moscow
LEAD: A former Soviet police officer has been sentenced to death for his part in an armed raid on a Moscow department store, the newspaper Komsomolskaya Pravda said Wednesday.
A court was told that Valery Fineyev, 28 years old, led a gang that shot a policewoman, a driver and a cashier after seizing more than $470,000 from the store last November.

Strong Quake in Alaska
LEAD: A major earthquake followed by dozens of aftershocks jarred portions of Alaska Tuesday and forced hundreds of coastal residents to flee their homes.
No serious injuries or damage were reported in the quakes, which began with a temblor measuring 6.9 on the Richter scale.
The quake was centered in the Gulf of Alaska, about 270 miles east-southeast of Anchorage and 90 miles southwest of Cape Yakataga, between Yakutat and Cordova.

Stage: 'Blood Sports,' From England
LEAD: IN such provocative dramas as ''Destiny'' - before he adapted ''Nicholas Nickleby'' for the Royal Shakespeare Company - David Edgar revealed his intense social commitment.
