15% of People With AIDS Survive 5 Years
LEAD: Researchers studying AIDS patients in New York City found that about 15 percent of them survived at least five years after diagnosis with the disease, indicating a less dire outlook for some patients than is commonly assumed.


Waning Japan Labor Groups Will Join in a 'Super Union'

Much Too Quick
LEAD: The fast hands of Steve Largent, the Seattle Seahawk wide receiver known for his speed afoot, worked so quickly in the game against the Jets Nov. 9 that what had been scored as a 12-yard pass reception for Largent had to be erased.
On the play in the game's closing minutes, Largent leaped to catch a ball thrown by Dave Krieg, the Seattle quarterback.

Dawson Named M.V.P.
LEAD: Andre Dawson, who had neither a contract nor a team to play for last spring before he finally signed with the Chicago Cubs, was voted the National League's most valuable player yesterday, becoming the first member of a last-place team to win the award.


A Taxing Rule Sends Youths to Social Security
LEAD: Social Security Commissioner Dorcas R. Hardy looked out at the roomful of teen-agers and summed up in seven words why each youth must have a Social Security number: ''Every one of you is a deduction.''


PRINTS SET PRICE RECORDS IN 2 AUCTIONS
LEAD: Japanese and European bidding continued to help propel art prices to record levels at the auctions of Old Master, modern and contemporary prints held last weekend and this week at Sotheby's and Christie's.
When the gavels fell on the final lots, however, Americans had purchased the majority of prints at both houses.

San Marino Journal; East Meets West In Upscale Suburb
LEAD: The real estate brokers, that crafty breed, were the first to adapt to the influx of Chinese newcomers into this staid, wealthy suburb of Los Angeles.
If it seemed odd that Asian homebuyers would not touch a house facing East or West, or brought in spiritual advisers to pass on the dwelling's suitability, these were, well, cultural peccadillos that could be overlooked for clients who brought crisp cash to the closing and often offered more than the asking price.

LEAD: The house is peaceful as the college student, a mother's helper, feeds a premature baby her bottle of formula.

Transactions
LEAD:  BASEBALL


GRAF STRUTS HER NO. 1 STUFF IN 47 MINUTES
LEAD: The toughest part was the waiting, Steffi Graf said.
Chris Evert was already on the way home, Hana Mandlikova was forced to retire because of an injury and Martina Navratilova -No. 2 and not enjoying it one bit - had reaped the benefit of a competitive opening-round match.
Graf, meanwhile, was limited to practice sessions that were probably doing her more harm than good.

Dow Rises by 16.91 In Erratic Session
LEAD: Stock prices closed moderately higher yesterday, buffeted by rumors on the progress of the budget deficit talks in Washington and the performance of the dollar.
Traders also said that futures-related buy programs lifted prices across a broad front late in the session.


ARMS FOR CONTRAS: 38% PROFIT VS. NO PROFIT
LEAD: An influential contra leader was denied cash to purchase arms after he bought a weapons shipment from a European dealer rather than through Richard V. Secord, who ran the Iran-contra operation under the aegis of Lieut.
Col.
Oliver L. North.
General Secord was making a 38 percent profit on the arms deals, the report says, while the man who arranged the deal with the European dealer was taking no profit.

Tobacco Group Ad Spurs Rift With Cancer Society
LEAD: A tobacco trade group has offered to test air quality at the American Cancer Society's offices, saying it would show pollutants other than cigarettes foul the indoors.
But the society called the offer a ''public relations ploy.''


Manager Is Leaving Retirement Fund
LEAD: As investment manager of the $40 billion California Public Employees Retirement System, Greta E. Marshall, 50 years old, guides the investment policy of one of the largest pools of assets in the country.
But after two and a half years on the job, she has decided that the administrative responsibilities take too much time away from what she really likes best, investing.

LEAD: Ross Sandler, right, the Transportation Commissioner, and Consul General Joaquin Bernal of Mexico with a refurbished sign ready for installation above the Avenue of the Americas.
The 220 porcelain enamel emblems, representing the 36 member nations of the Organization of American States, have been polished and rustproofed at a cost of over $100 each.

LEAD: ''THIS is a very hard city to live in because everywhere you look, especially in winter, all you see is concrete,'' said Madi Heller, co-owner of Galerie Felix Flower.
She and her husband, Felix Blume, combat the grayness by surrounding themselves with dried flowers, long-lasting remnants of the natural world.

LEAD: Home building plunged in October to its lowest level in more than four years, the Government reported today.


Colorado's Troubled Banks Special to The New York Times
LEAD: A multimillion-dollar deficiency in Colorado's private deposit insurance fund has put thousands of savings accounts in jeopardy and forced state regulators to seize 13 of the 89 industrial banks in the state.


Court Allows Suffolk to Exhume Bodies
LEAD: Suffolk County authorities received court approval today to exhume the bodies of seven people feared to have been victims of a nurse at Good Samaritan Hospital who has admitted injecting powerful muscle-paralyzing drugs into patients.


Big Investors Defend Programmed Trading
LEAD: Several of the world's largest institutional investors defended computerized program trading today at a meeting in Washington.


Yes to Tibbetts Gardens
LEAD: The Board of Estimate votes today on Tibbetts Gardens, a 1,000-unit condominium to be built on vacant land in the Kingsbridge section of the west Bronx.
This expansion of middle-income housing deserves approval.


Designer Whispers, Fashion Listens
LEAD: GIVE Marc Audibet an inch and he'll make a dress.
Five years ago the Parisian designer began traveling to Italy, where he became a leader in the development of new stretch fabrics.
He took Lycra, which was first used in bathing suits in the 1950's and ski clothes in the 1960's, and blended it into fabrics with yarns like wool, cotton, cashmere or linen.


Police Still Searching Park for a Young Girl
LEAD: More than 30 police officers are to search a park on the Brooklyn-Queens border for a fourth day today in response to a report from three children that they had seen a young girl carried there and left by a man.

House Approves Plan To Raise V.A. Status

Lift the McCarran-Walter Lid
LEAD: For 35 years the McCarran-Walter Immigration Act has allowed Washington to exclude foreign visitors based on public statements they might make in the United States.
Sensibly, the Senate would change this practice, but some House members balk over technical issues.
Their fear of losing some jurisdictional authority pales beside the need to reform this destructive law.

Critic's Notebook; RAKED STAGES AND SCORELESS DANCE
LEAD: RECENTLY, while discussing Vaslav Nijinsky's choreography for ''Le Sacre du Printemps,'' Robert Joffrey remarked, ''I suspect it was done with a raked stage in mind.'' Now that I've seen this famous work of 1913, as reconstructed by Millicent Hodson and Kenneth Archer for the Joffrey Ballet, I know what he means.


A Lush Musical by Villa-Lobos
LEAD: ''Magdalena,'' the only Broadway musical with a score by the Brazilian musical giant Heitor Villa-Lobos, occupies a singular niche in the annals of music-theater history.
When the lavish folk operetta opened at the Ziegfeld Theater on Broadway on Sept. 20, 1948, after wildly successful engagements in Los Angeles and San Francisco, it was the most expensive show to have been produced on Broadway.

LEAD: AS of Jan. 1, New York State will require licenses for those who sell, trade or barter food fish they have taken from marine waters.

Market Place; Merck-Squibb Rivalry's Effect
LEAD: DESPITE the October market plunge, drug stocks have been big winners so far this year, thanks to promising new products, rising earnings and a falling dollar that enhances their income from overseas.
But what helps one company in this high-stakes business often works to the detriment of a competitor.


Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Q. We recently moved into a home that had carpet in the bathroom.
This carpet was held down with double-faced tape that has left a gummy residue on the floor.
I tried scrubbing this off with denatured alcohol, but it didn't work.
Do you have any suggestions?
A.
This residue can almost always be removed by rubbing with a rag moistened with rubber-cement thinner (sold in art-supply and stationery stores), then with a dry cloth.

Indians Rehire Edwards
LEAD: Doc Edwards, the bullpen coach who took over as manager of the Cleveland Indians after Pat Corrales was let go July 16, was rehired yesterday for the 1988 season by Hank Peters, the newly appointed president of the team who was putting in his first official day of work.
Edwards, 51 years old, who signed a one-year contract, turned in a 30-45 won-lost record as the Indians, considered a pennant contender by some preseason forecasters, turned in the worst record in baseball, 61 victories and 101 defeats.

PARENT &amp; CHILD
LEAD: HE was given three rules to live by when he was 4 years old.
Pick up your toys.
Clean up your room.
Don't talk with your mouth full.
Apparently he felt that one out of three was good enough.
His speech was clear, but his room was a mess and his toys followed the law of entropy and were scattered all over the house.

DESIGN TO HONOR SPACE PIONEERS
LEAD: IN 1980, the National Capital Commission in Washington staged a competition for the design of a Vietnam War monument.
Maya Lin, then a student at Yale University, won with a simple V-shaped form with the names of American casualties inscribed on its marble walls.
It was a controversial design, but today, as thousands visit the monument every week, few doubt its success.

LEAD: A planned Latvian nationalist demonstration in Riga, the capital of the Baltic republic, never got started as hundreds of policemen and civilian militiamen, standing shoulder to shoulder, cordoned off the central square today, according to reports from Riga.

Argentina Loan Plans
LEAD: As expected, Argentina has sent to the International Monetary Fund a list of economic adjustments it has designed to insure continued availability of a $1.4 billion I.M.F. loan.
Terms of the loan, originally agreed upon in February, were adjusted in July.
Since then, Argentina's deficit has mushroomed and inflation has soared, requiring the country to undertake additional economic adjustments to remain on favorable terms with the I.M.F.


House Panel Clears Bill On Family Leave Policy
LEAD: Legislation requiring large companies to allow their employees to take unpaid family or medical leave and return to their jobs has cleared a Congressional committee but has yet to achieve broad bipartisan support.

Smokers Hide and Drag Harder As Society Makes Them Outcasts
LEAD: Andrea Green, a marketing and promotion consultant for banks, was on the telephone with a man who helps companies develop programs for employees who want to quit smoking.
She lit a cigarette, quietly, she thought.
But she was not quiet enough.

SENATE APPROVES WATER PROJECTS
LEAD: The Senate voted today to spend $4.26 billion on Federal water projects this fiscal year, including $13.5 million for a dam repair that the Reagan Administration says could set a costly precedent.


Nomura No. 1 in Japan
LEAD: The Nomura Securities Company, Japan's largest brokerage firm, has surpassed the Toyota Motor Corporation as the nation's most profitable company, a Nomura official said today.
Nomura's pretax earnings in its fiscal year ended Sept. 30 rose 26.8 percent, to 493.8 billion yen, or $3.6 billion, topping Toyota's 488.3 billion yen, or $3.56 billion.

Encor Rejects Bid
LEAD: The Encor Energy Corporation said its board rejected a $980 million Canadian, or $742 million, bid from Transcanada PipeLines Ltd.
Encor, which is 42 percent owned by Dome Petroleum Ltd., called the offer ''inadequate from a financial point of view.'' An Encor director abstained from the vote because of a potential conflict of interest, the company said, but all of its other directors, including those representing Dome, were unanimous.


RUSSIANS GIVE U.S. MORE MISSILE DATA
LEAD: The Soviet Union gave the United States some detailed data today about the Russians' missile force as American and Soviet negotiators pressed to complete the treaty banning medium- and shorter-range missiles.

LEAD: The Yankees have begun preliminary talks with Doug Baldwin, the agent for Bill Gullickson, the right-hander who had a 4-2 record with a 4.88 earned run average in eight starts after he was acquired in a late-season trade with Cincinnati.
Baldwin said that he had spoken with Bob Quinn, the Yankees' vice president for baseball administration, although terms of a new contract were not discussed.

LEAD: AS part of its 100th anniversary celebration early next year, Notre Dame intends to display each of the Heisman trophies that its football players have won.
Asked to return his trophy for the exhibit, Paul Hornung preferred to bring it to the campus himself rather than risk shipping it.
So not long ago the 1956 winner was walking through the South Bend, Ind., airport, carrying the bronzed statue of a running back as if it were a football.

LEAD: Oct. 19, Black Monday on Wall Street, produced a lot of talk, if not much action, about fixing what's wrong with the economy.

Chrysler Raises Some 1988 Prices
LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation said it had raised the prices of its 1988 domestic car models an average of 1 percent over those of its comparably equipped 1987 models.
But prices were cut on the Dodge Daytona and Aries, the Plymouth Reliant and the Chrysler LeBaron coupe.
The price of its New Yorker model rose by more than $2,000, to $17,416.

Ford, who is 69 years old, underwent surgery on a carotid artery at the medical center on July 24.

Topics of The Times; Fashion Footnote
LEAD: The phrase ''de rigueur'' no longer applies to clothing styles - that's clear to anyone watching the eclectic parade on any city street corner, at any downtown movie house, at any urban cocktail party.
But in a small town in southern New England, the tyranny of fashion remains alive and well.


Record Federal Bailout For Texas Savings Unit
LEAD: Federal regulators pledged $1.3 billion today to resolve the difficulties of the Vernon Savings and Loan Association in Dallas, the largest such Government bailout of a savings institution.


Film: 'Boy From Calabria'
LEAD: LUIGI COMENCINI'S ''Boy From Calabria,'' opening today at the Carnegie Screening Room, is an inoffensively sentimental Italian movie about a poor peasant boy's efforts to become a marathon runner, much to the horror of his hard-pressed father.


Wherehouse Bid
LEAD: Shamrock Holdings Inc. said it planned a hostile tender offer of $12 a share, or $91.9 million, for the interest it does not already own in Wherehouse Entertainment Inc.
In addition, Shamrock, based in Burbank, Calif., sued Wherehouse in a state court over the company's anti-takeover plan.
Wherehouse, one of the nation's largest video, record and computer software chains, rejected an unsolicited $14.25-a-share bid from Shamrock last month.


1931 Bugatti Fetches Record Price in London
LEAD: A 1931 Bugatti 41 Royale, owned originally by the Bugatti family, was sold yesterday for $9.8 million, a record at auction for an automobile.
The buyer at the Christie's sale, held at London's Royal Albert Hall, was Nicholas Harley, a British vintage-car dealer.


Campus Rally for Yeltsin, a Rare Sight
LEAD: Several hundred students gathered Tuesday at Moscow State University in an unusual expression of public concern over the Soviet hierarchy's ouster of the popular Moscow Communist Party chief, according to a participant.


Art: Gothic Sculpture of Giovanni Pisano at Met
LEAD: ''GIOVANNI PISANO IN GENOA'' is a slightly smaller version of a show that took place this spring in Genoa.
It brings together the recently restored marble fragments of the last two works by Giovanni Pisano, the great Gothic sculptor who had never before had an exhibition in the United States.
There are around 20 works, some by Pisano's contemporaries and students.


Sports People; Paiement Demoted
LEAD: Wilf Paiement, who has not played in the minor leagues since 1974, was assigned yesterday to the Muskegon Lumberjacks of the International Hockey League by the Piitsburgh Penguins.


Report Doubles the Estimate Of U.S. Radiation Exposure
LEAD: New calculations of the average amount of radiation an American is exposed to in a year have doubled the estimate.
For the first time, the calculations include the effects of radon gas seeping into houses.


CONTRAS SPURNING BID FOR CEASE-FIRE
LEAD: Senior contra officials say that they reject a recent Sandinista cease-fire proposal and that they will probably make a counterproposal to an intermediary for the Nicaraguan Government sometime next week.


About Real Estate; A 20's Feature Returns: The Servants' Quarters
LEAD: Around the turn of the century, in a period of opulence somewhat similar to today's, it became customary for builders to include servants' quarters in middle-class houses in the growing industrial cities of the Northeast.
That practice continued until the Depression, when homes and living styles started to grow simpler.

LEAD: Gordie Lockbaum finished an incredible career, and Holy Cross finished its first unbeaten season since 1918 tonight.

LEAD: Stocks continued their seesaw course yesterday, falling broadly amid worries that a deficit-reduction plan would not be reached.
The Dow Jones industrial average, which rose nearly 17 points on Wednesday, plunged 43.77 points, or 2.26 percent, to close below 1,900.

LEAD: What the judicial authorities describe as a kidnapping-for-ransom network within the Argentine federal police force has come to light with the discovery in recent days of the bodies of three missing businessmen.

LEAD: An 11-member jury convicted six defendants on drug charges yesterday shortly after a Federal judge, in an unusual action, removed the lone juror who had been holding out for acquittal.

We just started singing, and working out the best way to proceed.

LEAD: After telling the Soviet television reporter what they knew about her country - it is part of both Europe and Asia and Moscow is its capital -the geography class at a school in the rural town of Litchfield had some questions.


College Drug Test Barred
LEAD: A Superior Court judge, declaring a National Collegiate Athletic Association drug-testing unconstitutional, today barred the N.C.A.A. from testing Stanford athletes for drugs, with the exception of the men's basketball and football teams, where limited testing, probably for cocaine and steroids, will be permitted.


Duro-Test Refusal
LEAD: The board of the Duro-Test Corporation said it had rejected a tender offer of $14 a share, or $66 million, from a partnership led by William P. Lyons, a Yale University professor, and said it was considering a sale of the company to a third party or in a leveraged buyout.
In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Duro-Test said it had provided information about the company to others who had expressed an interest in the light bulb manufacturer, based in North Bergen, N.J.


President Gets Compromise Military Measure
LEAD: The Senate today approved legislation establishing military programs, at a cost of up to $296 billion, that restricts President Reagan's space-based anti-missile program and halts missile deployments that exceed a 1979 treaty limiting strategic arms.


Bid for Tesoro
LEAD: The Tesoro Petroleum Corporation, already the object of overtures from a Hong Kong oil-trading concern, said it had received an unsolicited $15-a-share takeover offer from Pentane Partners L.P., a New York investment group.
The offer from Pentane, which owns 9.7 percent of Tesoro's stock, values Tesoro at $206 million.

LEAD: The Bundesbank, West Germany's central bank, made no announcement today about its short-term interest rates after a meeting of its central committee.

LEAD: A Catholic-Jewish conference scheduled to be held here next month to explore the role of the Roman Catholic Church in Europe during the Nazi Holocaust has been indefinitely postponed at the request of Jewish leaders who are angry about recent Vatican actions.

LEAD: The National Basketball Association and the Turner Broadcasting System have reached a two-year contract extension granting TBS exclusive national cable rights to games through the 1989-90 season for $50 million.
The fee is double that of the current contract, which expires at the conclusion of the present season.

LEAD: New York City's bond rating was raised yesterday to its highest level since 1975, despite concerns that recent declines in stock prices and employment at securities concerns would weaken the local economy and strain the city's financial condition.

Christopher Wilmarth, 44, Dies; Sculptor Is an Apparent Suicide
LEAD: Christopher Wilmarth, a critically acclaimed sculptor whose works are on permanent display at many of the nation's best-known museums, apparently hanged himself yesterday in his studio-home in Brooklyn, the police said.
He was 44 years old.

Bridge: Book by Australian Expert Is Filled With Good Advice
LEAD: If an intermediate player is considering buying a bridge book, he is entitled to ask, ''How much will it tell me that I did not know before?'' The answer may be, ''Nothing, a little, quite a lot or a great deal.''


Deaver's Client Tells of Business Call From Plane
LEAD: Three months after he left his post as White House deputy chief of staff in 1985 to become a private lobbyist, Michael K. Deaver apparently used the radio telephone on Nancy Reagan's official airplane to conduct his consulting business, witnesses at Mr.
Deaver's perjury trial said today.


Westfield Symphony
LEAD: The Westfield Symphony will give a free performance of works by Mahler and Tchaikovsky tomorrow at 2 P.M. at Carnegie Hall.
The symphony, based in Westfield, N.J., and conducted by Brad Keimach, will perform Mahler's Symphony No. 4 and Tchaikovsky's Violin Concerto.
The soloists are Peter Winograd, violinist, and Cheryl Parrish, soprano.


N.F.L. Matchups; Quarterback Is a Sore Spot
LEAD: Injured quarterbacks abound this week, many of them limited in practice or not able to make it at all.
They have hurt their ankles or shoulders or knees or egos.
So the backups will become major factors Sunday.
And that means teams with sophisticated defenses could fool some of the inexperienced second-stringers.


Orange Juice, Soybeans Advance as Grains Fall
LEAD: Prices of frozen concentrated orange juice futures soared yesterday on the Cotton Exchange in New York because of revised estimates of lower harvests in South America.

LEAD: The Communist Party U.S.A. is not likely to run candidates for President and Vice President next year to protest what it says is a ''very undemocratic electoral system'' in the United States, the party leader announced yesterday.

LEAD: L. Clark Heist, who has been with the Champion International Corporation for 30 years, has been named president and chief operating officer, effective Dec. 1.


Film: 'Last Emperor,' an Epic
LEAD: PU YI (1906-1967), the last Manchu emperor of China, came to the Dragon Throne at the age of 2 and some months.
Four years later, the prince regent, Pu Yi's father, was forced to abdicate all imperial authority to republican forces.
The boy-emperor continued to stay on in lonely, unreal splendor in Beijing's Forbidden City for another decade or so.

LEAD: Despite police raids and the advent of state lotteries and offtrack betting, numbers - a time-honored form of illegal gambling as easy as buying a pack of cigarettes - continues to thrive in poor neighborhoods of New York City.


Russians Tour U.S. Chemical Arms Stockpile
LEAD: Six Soviet scientists and diplomats toured a chemical weapons installation in the western Utah desert today, an event that some officials said could lead to a treaty banning the weapons.


1,155 G.M. LAYOFFS
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation said it would indefinitely lay off about 1,155 of its hourly employees in January, when it will slow auto production at three of its United States plants.
The cut would increase the company's list of indefinitely laid-off workers by 2.5 percent.
A Lansing, Mich., plant that makes the Buick Skylark and Oldsmobile Cutlass will lay off 850 of its 4,350 workers.


Fire Damages Church in Massachusetts
LEAD: The Rev.
William Huegel, left, pastor of First Baptist Church in Winchester, being comforted after fire damaged the church yesterday.
With him are the Rev.
L.
Stanley Manierre and the Rev.
Veronica Lanier of the American Baptist Churches.
No injuries were reported.
Part of the building was being converted into condominium apartments.

LEAD: Elizabeth Corday, the longtime executive producer of the daytime drama ''Days of Our Lives,'' died of respiratory failure Monday at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center here.
She was 75 years old.

LEAD: Mexico's Finance Minister appealed for confidence in the economy today as the peso fluctuated in chaotic trading after Wednesday's plunge.


NEW LAWYERS: WHERE THEY WORK
LEAD: The growth of large law firms and the salaries they pay is having a logical effect: in a survey of 1986 law school graduates, the National Association for Law Placement has found that 61.6 percent entered private practice, the highest percentage since the association started keeping records in 1974, when 52.2 percent went into private practice.

Samuel Engle Burr Jr., a former professor of education at the American University in Washington, died Monday at the Princeton (N.J.) Medical Center.

Art: Paintings and Drawings by Andre Derain
LEAD: IT has never been easy to make an exhibition of Andre Derain that validates the very high regard in which he was held by those who knew him.
Derain the man was clearly a man of good will, a marvel of intelligence and the best of companions in the Louvre.
As a young man, he wrote some of the most vivid and amusing of all artists' letters.


At the Bar
LEAD: The money might come from drug trafficking or insider trading or loan sharking or embezzlement.
But until recently, two things about it were always true.
First, no matter how ill-gotten it might be, the wrongdoer was always free to spend it on a lawyer.
Second, that lawyer was always free to accept it - and keep it.

LEAD: SCULPTURE is so abundant in New York art galleries these days that it may well qualify as the season's dominant art form.
Nowhere is it more plentiful than at Metro Pictures in SoHo, where Martin Kippenberger's exhibition threatens to spill out onto the street.
Mr.
Kippenberger, a 34-year-old artist who lives in Cologne, West Germany, has exhibited paintings and sculpture in Europe for nearly a decade.

Films From the 30's
LEAD: Two films from the 1930's by the French director Pierre Chenal - an adaptation of Dostoyevsky's ''Crime and Punishment,'' and ''The Man From Nowhere,'' a comedy based on Pirandello's ''Late Mathias Pascal'' - will be screened through Thursday at Film Forum 2, 57 Watts Street.
The actor Pierre Blanchar was featured in both films; at the 1935 Venice Film Festival, he was named best actor for his role as Raskolnikov in ''Crime and Punishment.


Hill Samuel Withdraws
LEAD: Hill Samuel &amp; Company said today that its brokerage would no longer act as a primary market maker in gilt-edged securities, as British Government bonds are called.
Several other British brokerages have pulled out of the unprofitable gilts market in recent months.
Hill Samuel said the move was part of a plan to sell or close its debt-trading activities.


Starting Children on a Lifelong Reading Habit
LEAD: To the Editor:


CREDIT MARKETS Treasury Prices Up Slightly
LEAD: Prices of Treasury debt issues moved slightly higher yesterday in what dealers described as the slowest session of an uncommonly dull week, as market participants continued to wait for the Administration and Congress to resolve their differences over the Federal budget deficit.


Art People
LEAD:  Glasnost for Lunch


Senate Waste Proposal Upsets House Panels
LEAD: Influential House committee chairmen are upset over Senate legislation that would scuttle a plan establishing two dump sites for the accumulating tons of high-level nuclear waste.


Violin-Piano Duo
LEAD: Avram Weiss, a violinist, and Joseph Seiger, a pianist, will perform works by Handel, Grieg, Bach, Kreisler, Bloch and others on Sunday at 8 P.M. in Merkin Concert Hall (129 West 67th Street).
Tickets are $12, or $6 for students and the elderly.
Information: 362-8719.


Uganda Reports a Clash
LEAD: Ugandan Government forces killed 30 rebels Wednesday when the guerrillas ambushed a military convoy near the eastern town of Mbale, army sources said.
They said nine soldiers guarding the 21-vehicle convoy and seven civilians were also killed.


Talks Held By Bell &amp; Howell
LEAD: The Bell &amp; Howell Company disclosed yesterday that it was negotiating with an investor group headed by Robert M. Bass of the wealthy Texas family on a management buyout of the publishing and information services company.


Money Fund Assets Up
LEAD: Assets of the nation's 411 money market mutual funds increased $1.54 billion, to $262.91 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
Assets of the 111 institutional funds were up $781.2 million, to $74.37 billion.
Assets of the 207 general-purpose funds were up $294.5 million, to $79.12 billion.


Rangers Lose To Stars
LEAD: Marcel Dionne was correct: The Rangers should not have assumed that they could reproduce the work ethic that brought them out of their slump just by writing it into their game plan.


Lee Byung Chull, 77, Industrialist of Korea
LEAD: Lee Byung Chull, chairman and founder of the Samsung Group and one of the fathers of modern industrial South Korea, died of lung cancer today.
He was 77 years old.
Mr.
Lee started his business in 1938 and rebuilt it after the Korean War into a high-technology manufacturer and South Korea's first major trading company.

LEAD:  BASEBALL


Restaurants
LEAD: A SPLENDID Provencal flower has taken root in the craggy industrial terrain of TriBeCa.
Called Bouley, it is the creation of the French-schooled David Bouley, who made his mark at nearby Montrachet.
The three-month-old restaurant has the potential for greatness, although a wobbly kitchen prevents it from reaching its potential.


Louisiana Governor-Elect Acts Early
LEAD: Louisiana's Governor-elect, Buddy Roemer, faced with a four-month waiting period before he takes office and with a budget crisis that he said would empty state coffers by Inauguration Day, moved this week to try to get control over state policy and spending.


Washington Talk: Briefing; Not Off the Record
LEAD: When William E. Brock 3d took over as chairman of Senator Bob Dole's Presidential campaign two weeks ago he stressed the need for an ''open campaign.''


Our Towns; Amid Growling, 14 Neurotics Try To Defeat Angst
LEAD: ''This kind of neurotic behavior is not usually handled in groups,'' Dr.
Perry Frantzman explained.
His 14 patients were in a circle.
The doctor had agreed to take them on because he knew otherwise it might mean death.


Jets Will Get a Close Look at Bennett
LEAD: Cornelius Bennett wishes people would stop comparing him with Lawrence Taylor.
But Kurt Sohn, who will run against Bennett on Sunday, said today there wasn't any comparison.


Economic Scene; Assumptions Of U.S. Growth
LEAD: HOW valid are the assumptions that underlie the relatively hopeful forecast of most American economists and the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development in Paris that the United States economy will continue growing slowly next year?


Diner's Journal
LEAD: NOT many restaurants serve the rustic French appetizer called rillettes de canard, which is a spread made with shredded duck and spices.
At six-week-old L'Ecluse, a snug French bistro on Avenue of the Americas at King Street, a ramekin of delicious rillettes (this one combines duck and pork) comes as an appetizer along with grilled garlic toast and a little green salad.


O'NEILL STABLE AFTER SURGERY
LEAD: Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the former Speaker of the House, was alert and in stable condition today after undergoing surgery that removed a cancerous tumor, hospital officials said.
The 74-year-old Massachusets Democrat un-derwent nearly seven hours of surgery for cancer of the rectum at Brigham and Women's Hospital on Wednesday.


Washington Talk: The Iran-contra Hearings; ALL OVER BUT THE CLEARING-OUT OF PIECES OF HISTORY
LEAD: For the 181 lawyers, investigators, clerks and secretaries on the staffs of the Iran-contra Congressional committees it is all over but the cleanup - a 10-month whirlwind in which strangers came together and shaped a piece of history, ''It's a once in a lifetime experience - once you do this, what could ever be as exciting again?


McCann Gets Studio Work
LEAD: McCann-Erickson, New York, has been assigned the retail media account of Columbia Pictures for the New York region.
The billings are around $10 million.


Sports People; Alcohol Awareness
LEAD: A series of mandatory lectures on drinking and driving is being lined up for Minnesota Vikings players by General Manager Mike Lynn after the arrests of several players for drunken driving.


Rosario Hopes Stock Keeps Rebounding
LEAD: In August 1980, Wilfredo Gomez, the World Boxing Council superbantamweight champion, knocked out Derrik Holmes in five rounds in a nationally televised bout.


Views From Miami
LEAD: As everyone knows, Miami is an odd place.
It is definitely part of the United States, but it is also the capital of a misty Latin American republic called Exilia, Refugia or Nostalgia, according to choice.
It lives steadily preoccupied with Cuba, some 90 miles and a world away, but Cuba can be approached from various directions.


Dance: Armitage Ballet
LEAD: ''STRETCH your arm no farther than your sleeve,'' as the old French saying goes.


KNICKS BEATEN AS NETS RALLY
LEAD: As the Knicks broke out of their timeout huddle with 4 minutes 56 seconds remaining in the fourth period tonight, holding a lead of 101-93 over the Nets, Coach Rick Pitino's final words were, ''Forget the score, keep playing offense.''


18th-Century Music
LEAD: The Orchestra of the 18th Century will perform at the Fine Arts Center of the State University campus at Stony Brook, L.I., tomorrow at 8 P.M.
Tickets are $14 to $18.
Information and directions: (516) 632-7235.


William A. Sutherland; Law Firm Founder, 91
LEAD: William Anderson Sutherland, a founding partner of Sutherland, Asbill &amp; Brennan, an Atlanta and Washington law firm, died Nov. 7 of a heart attack at his home in Washington.
He was 91 years old.


Lives of Amerasian Children Studied on ABC's '20/20'
LEAD: A father and daughter, strangers to each other, are united on ABC's ''20/ 20'' tonight.
The father had fought in Vietnam; the daughter, in a way, was one of the war casualties.
The program, on Channel 7 at 10 P.M., is touching.


SAVINGS ENVISIONED IN HOME AIDS CARE
LEAD: The cost of caring for some AIDS patients could be reduced to less than $100 a day from about $800 a day if public and private health insurance plans would pay for home care of AIDS patients, health care officials say.


News Corp. Profits Rise
LEAD: The News Corporation, the media group headed by Rupert Murdoch, today reported a 31 percent jump in after-tax profits for the first quarter, ended Sept. 30.


Auctions
LEAD:  Egyptian Goddesses


DYNAMIC ACTING DUOS ON NEW YORK STAGES
LEAD: One of the great joys of Laurence Olivier's professional life was watching John Gielgud and Ralph Richardson act together onstage.
Seeing those two knights in tandem was ''a dream,'' observed Lord Olivier, ''a brilliant double act'' with ''all guns blazing.'' In modern theatrical history, there have, of course, been other twinned performances of the highest caliber, though perhaps not with the astonishing symbiosis - and contrast of opposites - of these theatrical eminences.


Crazy Eddie Deficit In Inventory Found
LEAD: The new managers of Crazy Eddie Inc. said yesterday that they had discovered an inventory shortfall estimated at $45 million and that the consumer electronics retailer expected a ''substantial'' third-quarter loss.


Reagan and Democrats Split On Using Pressure on Haiti
LEAD: The Reagan Administration and a small group of Democratic Congressmen are divided over how the United States should use its leverage to insure a free and fair election in Haiti this month.


Official Support Growing for Haitian Election
LEAD: With 10 days remaining before the scheduled date for presidential elections in Haiti, election officials say the Government has finally begun lending its support, and concern about a possible postponement appears to be fading.


Tourists Face Mixed Picture
LEAD: Americans traveling to Mexico may not see hotel rates or air fares reduced immediately by the plunging value of the peso, but they will be able to find shopping bargains, travel agents said yesterday.


De Larrocha Recital
LEAD: The pianist Alicia de Larrocha will perform works by Schumann, Mompou and Granados tomorrow at 8 P.M. at the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College, one block from the intersection of Nostrand and Flatbush Avenues.
Tickets are $10 to $20.
Information: (718) 434-1900.


If Reagan Were F.D.R.
LEAD: The immediate economic outlook hinges on confidence.
Will consumers, businesses and investors continue their healthy patterns of spending and investment or will Black Monday and its aftermath frighten them into retrenchment and bring on recession, or worse?


Godfrey Bloch; Manufacturer, 86
LEAD: Godfrey Bloch, a former carpet manufacturer, died at Lenox Hill Hospital on Wednesday.
He was 86 years old and lived in Manhattan.


Mr. Gorbachev and Congress
LEAD: It's certainly arguable whether inviting Mikhail Gorbachev to address a joint meeting of the United States Congress is a good idea.
But indisputably the confused squabble between the White House and Congressional leaders over that invitation is a shameful global embarrassment.


EXECUTIVE CHANGES
LEAD: *
Atlas Corp., Princeton, N.J., a natural resources company, appointed Keith R. Hulley president of the mineral division.


Film: Prince in 'Sign o' the Times'
LEAD: ''SIGN O' THE TIMES,'' which opens today at the Warner and other theaters, is mostly a concert film, but it also plays like science fiction: a visit to the Prince planet, where life is strange indeed.
And madly, viscerally exciting, peopled by red-hot, inexhaustible Princelings whose onstage excesses become the perfect backdrop for the star's own antics.


CITING BIAS ORDER, U.S. CURBS YONKERS ON AID TO BUILDERS
LEAD: A Federal judge yesterday barred Yonkers from aiding ing commercial and residential development until the city complies with his desegregation order by planning new public housing.


Corrections
LEAD: An article on Oct. 25 about a program to assign police liaison officers to some New York City hospitals incorrectly described the history of the program at Bellevue Hospital Center.
A liaison officer has been assigned to Bellevue for many years.


Advertising; Lintas's 'Hot' Idea For Lipton
LEAD: ''WE'RE out to make hot tea hot,'' exclaimed Susan Read, effusive executive vice president and executive creative director of Lintas:New York, as she turned to the VCR to bring the new campaign for Lipton tea to the screen.
It was, she promised, a big idea.
In any event it was big enough to supplant Don Meredith, the one-time Dallas Cowboys quarterback who had been spokesman for the flow-through tea bags for more than a decade.


Film: Streisand In 'Nuts'
LEAD: IN ''Nuts,'' Barbra Streisand has the kind of downscale role that has been known to win Oscars, a role in which a star forsakes her usual cocoon for the mud streaks, the tattered clothes, the rude invective that prove she has grit.
Luckily, Miss Streisand's performance is better than that, but it's the showboating aspects of '


Wayne Newton Libel Award Is Cut to $5 Million by Judge
LEAD: A Federal district judge has reduced to $5.3 million the $22.8 million libel judgment that the entertainer Wayne Newton won against NBC, ruling that the evidence did not support Mr.
Newton's assertion that television broadcasts linking him to organized crime figures had hurt his reputation or income.


Sports of The Times; Cup Running Over With Lasix?
LEAD: MORE than anyone else, the nation's horse breeders should care about the medication crisis in thoroughbred racing.
Instead, when they present their $10 million Breeders' Cup extravaganza at Hollywood Park tomorrow, they will be perpetuating the sport's most unsavory aspect.


Washington Talk: Briefing; I.R.S. Snips Snacks
LEAD: It's now official.
The Internal Revenue Service had ruled that Election Night parties, assuming they are given by a candidate's campaign committee for the candidate's campaign workers, are an ''exempt function'' under Section 527(e)(2) of the tax code.


British Gas Drops Bow Valley Offer
LEAD: British Gas P.L.C. called off its bid of $940 million (Canadian), or $717 million (United States), for a controlling interest in Bow Valley Industries.
But British Gas said it would try to modify its offer to satisfy shareholders and the Canadian Government, and analysts said the Canadian energy company was still vulnerable to a takeover by another suitor.


From Courtroom Wars, Battle Fatigue
LEAD: John Martel has stalked the courtrooms of America for 28 years, compiling a record other lawyers admit places him in the upper realms of America's top corporate trial lawyers.
In an era when few cases reach final trial, Mr.
Martel has battled nearly 100 to conclusion, representing such major clients as the Bank of America and the Hearst


F.T.C. PURSUING TRUMP
LEAD: The Federal Trade Commission has asked the Justice Department to prosecute Donald J. Trump, the New York developer and investor, for making use of a ''parking'' agreement to facilitate an acquisition.

LEAD: A Federal judge yesterday barred ''Elizabeth Taylor's Passion'' perfume line.

LEAD: Governor Cuomo last night criticized and refused to participate in a ''sweeping review'' of the New York City school system by the State Board of Regents.

LEAD: The most accurate kickers in National Football League history are playing right now.
And two of them are performing for New York teams.


Pressure On Broker Fees Seen
LEAD: At a closed-door meeting in New York this week, executives controlling several hundred billion dollars of corporate pension funds vowed to take steps to reduce the amounts they pay Wall Street brokers and investment management organizations.


S.E.C. Submits Plan On Insider Trading
LEAD: Three days after an inconclusive Supreme Court decision on insider trading, the Securities and Exchange Commission and prominent securities lawyers today submitted a proposal to Congress to define illegal trading in securities using confidential corporation information.

MARCOVICCI: ESSENCE OF ROMANCE
LEAD: ''THERE is a Portuguese word, saudades, that means nostalgia for people, places and things that may never have existed,'' Andrea Marcovicci said the other day. ''In my singing, I've stretched that to mean nostalgia for a time we never lived in.
My father was 63 and my mother 29 when I was born.
Because he was a creature from another era, I grew up surrounded by musical influences that were not of my own time.


Lincoln Journal
LEAD: Lettered high on the tall facade of Nebraska Stadium here is a noble tenet: ''Courage, generosity, fairness: These are the true awards of manly sport.''


The Board of Education Plays Truant
LEAD: School may be the only source of stability in the lives of New York City's homeless children.
Yet the city's Board of Education has lost track of several hundred school-age children in emergency hotels and shelters.
No one checks up on them to make sure they go to class.
Children already ''at risk'' are thus put in further jeopardy.


Bid Fails to Block Custody of Boy
LEAD: An appellate judge in Manhattan strongly rejected a bid yesterday by Joel B. Steinberg and Hedda Nussbaum to prevent the biological mother of 17-month-old Mitchell Steinberg from taking custody of him.

LEAD: Mayor Koch yesterday scaled back his proposal for 1,000 new apartments for middle-income New Yorkers in the Kingsbridge section of the Bronx, in the hopes of winning the Board of Estimate's approval for the disputed plan.

LEAD: The Allegis Corporation, parent corporation of United Airlines, has agreed to prepay a $700 million convertible note issued by the Boeing Company last spring when United placed an order for 36 Boeing jets.
Boeing said Allegis would be required to pay the $700 million plus accrued interest of $50 million before Jan.

Gorbachev, but that doesn't mean the university would mind having some of its experts in Soviet culture be used as press sources.

LEAD: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that the number of shares sold short and not yet covered in the month ended Nov. 13 decreased from the previous month by 44.7 million shares, or 8.8 percent, to 465.5 million.

Taylor Remains A Question Mark
LEAD: Will he or won't he?
Will Lawrence Taylor, despite an injured hamstring, be well enough to play for the Giants Sunday against the Saints in New Orleans?


Film: 'Teen Wolf Too,' Family Curse
LEAD: WHEN a clean-cut college student turns into a werewolf, he does unspeakable things.
Nothing violent, but this monster cuts classes!
He starts hanging around with a frivolous crowd - oh, no! college students who like to dance! - so his jilted girlfriend confronts him in biology class. ''They don't like you, only the wolf,'' she warns.

They range from ''sweet'' to ''wholesome'' to ''cold.

REAGAN PLANNING TO CUT SPENDING ON DEADLINE TODAY
LEAD: The White House said today that President Reagan would put $23 billion in automatic spending cuts into effect to reduce the Federal budget deficit even if Administration and Congressional negotiators agree on alternatives before the Friday deadline.

Savvy Record Chief for Sony
LEAD: As one of the world's largest manufacturers of consumer electronics, the Sony Corporation knows plenty about the hardware side of the music business.
But it has had little experience with the recording side, which includes the delicate task of handling temperamental artists.

Occidental in Joint Deal To Build Plant in Soviet
LEAD: The Occidental Petroleum Company, in a consortium with an Italian chemical company and a Japanese trading house, signed an agreement today with Moscow to build a petrochemical plant near the Caspian Sea that could cost as much as $6 billion.


Dollar Off in Quiet Day; Gold Climbs Slightly
LEAD: The dollar edged lower in quiet trading yesterday as traders eyed faltering budget negotiations in Washington with increasing pessimism that they said could spark a selloff of the currency.

Corrections
LEAD: An article in Business Day yesterday about the high level of oil imports incorrectly described the Institute for International Economics.
The Washington-based group is a nonprofit research organization, financed by foundations, corporations and government.


Union Pacific Bids for USPCI
LEAD: The Union Pacific Corporation, the railroad holding company, said yesterday that it would make a $327.5 million tender offer for USPCI Inc., an Oklahoma-based hazardous waste management company that had rebuffed a better offer in June, before stock prices fell.


Doubles Match Steals Show
LEAD: This was one night when the sneak preview took top billing over the featured attraction.
What a pair of quarterfinal matches of the Virginia Slims championships lacked in intrigue, drama and excitement was more than compensated for in a doubles confrontation between the team of Steffi Graf and Gabriela Sabatini against Martina Navratilova and Pam Shriver.


New Intimidation in Chile
LEAD: Fourteen years after Gen.
Augusto Pinochet's military coup destroyed democracy in Chile, his reign of terror not only is continuing but has noticeably worsened in the last month.


TV Weekend; Three Wimsey Dramatizations, on 13
LEAD: PUBLIC television's ''Mystery!'' series, broadcast on Channel 13 Saturdays at 9 P.M., is heading into the stretch this weekend of what has turned out to be a first-rate Dorothy L. Sayers festival.
Dramatizations of three of her Lord Peter Wimsey novels have been scheduled back to back, the collection recounting, even as assorted mysteries have to be solved, Lord Peter's persistent wooing of Harriet Vane, herself an Oxford-educated writer of mystery novels.

DE LARROCHA RECITAL
LEAD: The pianist Alicia de Larrocha will perform works by Schumann, Mompou and Granados tomorrow at 8 P.M. at the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College, one block from the intersections of Nostrand and Flatbush Avenues.
Tickets are $10 to $20.
Information: (718) 434-1900.


WEEKENDER GUIDE
LEAD:  Friday  ONCE UPON A TIME, ETC.


Singer in Talks
LEAD: Pressing its defense against a $1.1 billion takeover bid from Paul A. Bilzerian, the Singer Company said it had begun preliminary discussions with a number of domestic and foreign companies.
Singer added that it could not give any assurance that anything would develop.
Singer said it had begun talking to suitors ''as a possible alternative'' to the Florida corporate raider's $50-a-share tender offer and had been furnishing these suitors with confidential data on Singer.


IN THE NIGHT
LEAD:  Choir in the Park


Seizing of Truants Upheld
LEAD: Detaining suspected truants is among the duties New York City police officers can legally carry out, the state's highest court ruled today.
In a 6-1 decision written by Chief Judge Sol Wachtler, the Court of Appeals said the city's charter gives officers in New York City responsibility for guarding the ''public health'' and preventing ''the violation of all laws and ordinances in force in the city,'' Judge Wachtler wrote.


Topics of The Times; Cruelty in the Name of Life
LEAD: Several years ago, having listened hard to America's right-to-lifers, the Reagan Administration found a way to throw them a bone.
The Agency for International Development would not renew its contract with Planned Parenthood unless the birth control agency pledged not to help any overseas programs that also offer abortion services.


Forced Migration at the Zoo
LEAD: Two pelicans waiting in a van at the Bronx Zoo yesterday before they were taken to their winter quarters indoors.
It took a dozen zookeepers, some in waders and some in boats, to capture the four pelicans on the zoo's Cope Lake and bring them in for the season. (NYT/Ruby Washington)


Delta Jet Lands in Honolulu After Losing Power in Engine
LEAD: A Delta Air Lines jet with 112 people aboard lost power in an engine over the Pacific but landed safely after flying 400 miles on its two remaining engines with a military escort, officials said today.


Lebanese Suspect Linked to '85 T.W.A. Hijacking
LEAD: A Lebanese citizen awaiting trial in the United States on charges that he took part in the June 1985 hijacking of a Jordanian airliner was also involved in the hijacking of a Trans World Airlines jet the same month, Reagan Administration officials said today.


What the Iran-Contra Committees Wish They Had Done Differently
LEAD: While most members of the Iran-contra committees think their inquiry was a success, many of the lawmakers and their staff assistants say in hindsight that various aspects of the investigation should have been done differently.


The U.N. Today; Nov. 20, 1987
LEAD:  GENERAL ASSEMBLY


Simon Discovers It's Lonely at the Top
LEAD: Senator Paul Simon of Illinois found today that the problem with becoming a front-runner is that competitors start snapping at your heels.


Gas Company to Cut Rates
LEAD: The Brooklyn Union Gas Company has agreed to lower its rates by $8.2 million or 1.6 percent a year, Governor Cuomo's office announced today.
The agreement, worked out between the utility and state officials, will mean a savings of about $1.20 a month through Oct. 1, 1989 for the typical Brooklyn Union customer, the Governor's office said.


The Quarterback Who's Now Crucial
LEAD: STILL breathing hard after a practice last week in Norman, Okla., Charles Thompson was saying that nothing had changed in his existence as a quarterback for the football team at the University of Oklahoma.


Peru Extends Emergency
LEAD: The Government extended a 60-day state of emergency in 18 provinces in the southern Andes today to combat Maoist guerrillas.


TIFFANY TREASURES AND HOMEY WARES IN MODERNISM SHOW
LEAD: FORESTS of Tiffany lamps cast a color-pulsing glow on Bauhaus chromed metal tables, Art Deco frosted-glass vases and vehemently Victorian carved desks.
The bazaar called ''Modernism: a Century of Style and Design, 1860 to 1960,'' one of New York's youngest and liveliest antiques and decorative arts fairs, returned yesterday for its second visit to the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue at 66th Street.


Starting Children on a Lifelong Reading Habit; Television's Influence
LEAD: To the Editor:


Piedmont Orders Warning Devices for Airliners
LEAD: Piedmont Airlines today became the first airline to order devices for its planes to warn against collisions.
The Government has said it will require the equipment on all large airliners by 1991 or 1992.


Former Belfast Councilman Critically Hurt in a Shooting
LEAD: A former Protestant city councilman who once said Roman Catholics should be burned was shot in the head and critically wounded today, the police said.


Biden Says Final Vote on Court Nominee Is Unlikely Until February
LEAD: The chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee said today that, although he expected the confirmation process for Judge Anthony M. Kennedy to ''move pretty swiftly,'' the full Senate was unlikely to vote on his nomination to the Supreme Court until early February.


20 ACCUSED OF PLAN TO IMPORT COCAINE FROM SOUTH AMERICA
LEAD: Twenty people were arrested yesterday at their homes in Brooklyn and Queens and charged with conspiring to import large amounts of cocaine from South America, officials said.


British Plan Inquiry Into Subway Fire
LEAD: As transportation experts and opposition politicians pointed to possible safety lapses, the Government announced today that it would hold an inquiry into a fire that killed 30 people at London's busiest subway station.


Corrections
LEAD: A picture caption yesterday about a rehearsal for a concert production of Heitor Villa-Lobo's ''Magdalena'' misidentified the woman standing at left.
She was Dona D. Vaughn, co-col-laborator and director of the musical.


Season of Worry for El Paso Stores
LEAD: The $14 slacks and blue jeans are stacked high at the Starr Western Wear store here, a few blocks from the Mexican border, in preparation for the annual rush of holiday shoppers.


For Most Smokers, a Choice
LEAD: The nation's 46.8 million smokers had a choice between abstinence and defiance yesterday on the Great American Smokeout Day.


Corrections
LEAD: An article yesterday about a mur-der suspect who was fatally shot in a struggle with two New York City Po-lice detectives misidentified the sus-pect and the detective who shot him.
The suspect was Stephen Randol; the detective was Mark Hembury.


New Attack on Iranian Nuclear Plant Is Reported
LEAD: Iran said today that Iraqi warplanes had raided an unfinished nuclear power plant for the second time this week, and Iraq said it bombed three tankers in Iran's waters and shot down two enemy planes.

LEAD: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority recommended yesterday the repeal of the Federal law that introduced one-way tolls last year on the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge between Staten Island and Brooklyn.

Officer Leaving Pacific Post
LEAD: James S. Gallagher, president of the Pacific Stock Exchange since 1981, said today that he would resign Jan. 19.


Met Opera: 'Traviata,' With Two Stars Out With the Flu
LEAD: When undertaking a trip in a car with two flat tires, just getting out of the garage is something of an accomplishment.
Viewed in that light, a concertgoer might be inclined to look sympathetically on the Metropolitan Opera's bumpy traversal of Verdi's ''Traviata'' Thursday evening.


Colgate Coach Quits
LEAD: Fred Dunlap, who played fullback at Colgate in the late 1940's and later returned to direct a Red Raider football resurgence, announced his resignation as head coach on Friday.
Dunlap, 59, has been athletic director and head coach since Jan. 10, 1976.
He will continue in the former position, university officials said.


Consumer Prices Up By 0.4%
LEAD: The Consumer Price Index climbed four-tenths of 1 percent last month as the cost of shelter, new cars and clothing rose, the Labor Department reported today.


Four More Banks Fail
LEAD: State banking regulators have closed four banks, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said.
The closures bring the number of American bank failures to 164 so far this year, compared with last year's total of 138, the F.D.I.C. said.
The banks that were closed were the Republic Bank of Oklahoma City; the Peoples Bank and Trust of Iberia Parish, New Iberia, La,; the Timken State Bank in Timken, Kan., and the Alexander State Bank in Alexander, Kan.


ANSWERS TO QUIZ
LEAD: Questions appear on page 15.


PLANE'S ENGINES HAD NORMAL POWER
LEAD: Both engines of the Continental Airlines DC-9 jet that crashed while taking off in a snowstorm in Denver Sunday produced normal power until the plane hit the ground, officials with knowledge of the inquiry said yesterday.


Judge Denies Bail for Nurse Suspected in L.I. Hospital Deaths
LEAD: A nurse suspected of killing several patients at a West Islip hospital was ordered held without bail on assault charges today.


Moderate Governor Pleases New Mexico
LEAD: To the west in Arizona is Evan Mecham, the beleaguered first-term Republican Governor facing efforts to oust him from office that appear likely to lead to a special election.

Learning Style Of Minorities To Be Studied
LEAD: The New York State Board of Regents has appointed a special panel of three of its members to explore whether black and other minority-group students have distinct ''learning styles'' that may call for teaching techniques that are different from those used for whites.


Stung on Yeltsin, Gorbachev Renews His Call for Change
LEAD: Faced with an unexpectedly strong public backlash against the recent dismissal of one of his political allies, Mikhail S. Gorbachev today renewed his call for change in the Soviet Union.


Dance: At Joyce Theater, American Ballroom Group
LEAD: The American Ballroom Theater swept into the Joyce Theater (175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street,) on Tuesday night to open a two-week season.
And that is reason to cheer, for the company is one of our most unusual and delightful dance groups.


Treasury Bond Prices Climb
LEAD: Treasury bond prices advanced yesterday as traders expressed relief that Administration and Congressional leaders had reached an agreement on ways to reduce the Federal budget deficit.
The most pronounced gains came among bonds with longer maturities.


Big Texas Bailout Seen As Start of Aid Effort
LEAD: A $1.3 billion Federal bailout for the Vernon Savings and Loan Association, the costliest in the nation's history, is a step toward dealing with ailing savings institutions in Texas, analysts said today.


Figure In Winans Case Guilty
LEAD: David W. C. Clark, a former New York lawyer implicated in the insider trading circle that included R. Foster Winans, a former Wall Street Journal columnist, was found guilty yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan on all but one of 17 counts of fraud, tax evasion and perjury.


U.N. Passes Measures to Combat Apartheid
LEAD: The United Nations adopted a package of anti-apartheid resolutions today that call for an oil embargo against South Africa and criticize Israel for doing business with the Pretoria Government.


Music: Bernstein Conducts Mahler and Schubert
LEAD: Leonard Bernstein speaks several musical languages fluently, but Mahler is to him like a native tongue.
Though that is hardly news by now, his conducting of the Mahler Symphony No. 1 Thursday evening with the New York Philharmonic reminded one how effortlessly he seems to slip under that composer's skin.

LEAD: The Pennzoil Company has proposed a provisional settlement of its longstanding dispute with Texaco Inc., but Texaco yesterday called the amounts involved ''clearly unreasonable.''


Reagan Opposes Indoor Clean-Air Bill
LEAD: The Reagan Administration said today that it opposed pending legislation intended to protect the public from indoor air pollution.


Saints Try to Limit Euphoria
LEAD: In their 20 previous seasons in the National Football League, the New Orleans Saints never finished with a winning record.
They have never made the playoffs.
They have never won four games in a row.

LEAD: Anyone who thinks that New Yorkers are parochial about the importance of their own racing should spend a few days at a California track.
By comparison, New Yorkers seem positively broad-minded.

LEAD: Deficit-reduction negotiators delivered the anticipated turkey yesterday amid reports that Congressional Republicans would refuse to choke down even this scrawny, pallid bird.


AIDS Test Is Weighed In Sex Cases
LEAD: New York's City's Health Commissioner said yesterday that the AIDS epidemic may require the city to consider mandatory AIDS testing for prostitutes and sex and drug offenders, as well as a heavy crackdown on all forms of prostitution.

Navratilova Out In 6-4, 7-5 Upset
LEAD: The applause began when Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina was still 4 points away from perhaps the biggest victory in her career.
This would be her second opportunity of the match to end Martina Navratilova's four-year reign in the Virginia Slims championships, and most in the crowd of 13,854 at Madison Square Garden sensed that she would not fail.


Silent 1925 'Phantom' At Donnell Library
LEAD: The auditorium at the Donnell Library Center, 20 West 53d Street, has reopened after six months of renovation.
The hall is now called the Bankers Trust Company Auditorium.

LEAD: A kidnapped 5-year-old girl was freed unharmed and one of her abductors was wounded today when the police stormed a hideout on the Costa del Sol.

Yes, with the cooperation of the schools.

Mexican Holiday Calms Peso Chaos
LEAD: After four days of turmoil, calm returned to Mexico's foreign-exchange and stock markets today, thanks to a national holiday that closed all banks, Government offices and businesses until Monday.


TV for Cowboy Fans
LEAD: A cable television network has agreed to buy the remaining tickets to the Sunday night game between the Miami Dolphins and the Dallas Cowboys.
The action will keep the game from being blacked out in the Dallas-Fort Worth area.


Your Money; Tax-Swapping Confusion
LEAD: THE technique of municipal bond tax swapping traditionally reaches its peak this time of year.
But the mid-October stock market plunge and a proposal in Congress to change the way certain bonds are taxed has added substantial confusion to the process this year.

LEAD: William H. Webster, the Director of Central Intelligence, said today that the Reagan Administration would oppose legislation to restrict the Central Intelligence Agency in the aftermath of the Iran-contra affair, according to Congressional officials.


Merger at Tulane University
LEAD: The faculties at Tulane University and Newcomb College, separate institutions for 100 years, are to merge.
While Newcomb will maintain its campus and remain a school for women, the merger of the faculties will enable conflicts on tenure, promotion and other issues to be resolved.

LEAD: South Africa announced today that it was expelling an American news photographer, accusing him of sending ''biased photo material'' overseas.
The Government said the photographer, David Turnley of The Detroit Free Press, must leave when his work permit expires on Nov. 30.
Mr.
Turnley is the 11th foreign journalist expelled since President P.

Betty Ford Has Surgery For the Heart and Neck
LEAD: Betty Ford underwent six hours of heart and neck surgery today but was expected to be well enough to be home for Thanksgiving, officials said.


Hallmark Adds Univision
LEAD: Hallmark Cards Inc. and a Chicago investment concern, as expected, have agreed to acquire Univision, the nation's largest supplier of Spanish-language television programs, for nearly $300 million.


Marian Van Tuyl, A Dancer, Educator And Writer, Is Dead
LEAD: Marian Van Tuyl, a noted dance educator, writer and performer, died of cancer at her home in San Francisco on Nov. 10.
She was 80 years old.


For a Broader New York Policy on AIDS
LEAD: The New York City Department of Health has increased dramatically its projection of AIDS cases for 1991 and its official count of the cumulative number of AIDS cases in the city.
Unfortunately, those revisions, while welcome, come as no surprise because they are long overdue.

LEAD: The Fall National Championships of the American Contract Bridge League began here this afternoon, with more than 2,000 players from all parts of North America assembled for 10 days of events ranging from national championships to one-session side games.

Music: Gunnar Idenstam
LEAD: Gunnar Idenstam, a young organist from Stockholm, played a brief recital at the Park Avenue Christian Church Wednesday night.
Mr.
Idenstam's program was easy to digest.
Indeed, its mix of Bach, Schumann, Vierne, and contemporary Swedish music, with some improvising at the end, all seemed aimed at the organ-shy listener rather than the experienced colleague.

LEAD: Guinness P.L.C., the scandal-plagued brewer, said it would seek shareholder approval to repurchase up to 10 percent of its stock. British Airways Revises Offer
LEAD: In a revised offer, British Airways said yesterday that it was willing to pay about $260 million to buy British Caledonian Airways.
The new bid, which involves a swap of stock, is considerably less than the $417 million that was offered originally.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  N.B.A.  76ers 116, Celtics 85: Charles Barkley had 22 points and 14 rebounds as Philadelphia routed Boston last night, the Celtics' worst loss to the 76ers in 21 years.
The last time Boston lost by as many as 31 points to Philadelphia was Nov. 29, 1966, when the 76ers won, 138-96.
Reggie Lewis and Mark Acres, two rookies, each had 14 for the Celtics, who were playing without the injured Larry Bird.(AP)


Bid for Encor
LEAD: TransCanada Pipelines Ltd. has enough support from shareholders of the Encor Energy Corporation to proceed with its hostile bid of $980 million (Canadian), or about $745 million (United States), even though it was rejected by the company as too low, Gerald Maier, TransCanada's president, said.
Several institutional holders of Encor stock have indicated they are satisfied with the $8.75-a-share (Canadian) offer, Mr.

LEAD: The Ford Motor Company has changed the way it compensates its salaried employees by increasing the role of profit-sharing, replacing some health-care benefits with cash allowances and tightening the rules on overtime pay, the company said.

Chess Game Adjourned
LEAD: The 15th game of the world chess championship between Gary Kasparov and Anatoly Karpov was adjourned today after 42 moves.


Entitlements Do Not Equate With Welfare
LEAD: To the Editor:


Brand Blanshard Is Dead at 95; Teacher and Writer of Philosophy
LEAD: Brand Blanshard, a philosopher, writer and Sterling Professor Emeritus of Philosophy at Yale University, died after a long illness Thursday at his home in New Haven.
He was 95 years old.


The Danger of Debt: How Much Is Too Much?
LEAD: Installment debt can creep up at this time of year, endangering your credit rating.
Credit-card companies and lenders will not extend credit to consumers in the danger zone whose payments amount to 20 percent to 30 percent of their gross income.
Consumers, moreover, cannot get a mortgage if their total debt payments exceed 36 percent of their gross income.


Japanese Call Move on Budget an Important Step
LEAD: Japanese officials today welcomed the news of an agreement to cut the United States budget deficit as an important step that might calm troubled world markets.

Norton &amp; Company. $22.95.


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: The At the Movies column in Weekend on Nov. 13 misidentified the producer and director of ''Heart of Midnight.'' They are Andrew Gaty and Matthew Chapman.

LEAD: Conversation between a teamsters' union official and a developer putting up an office tower in Lower Manhattan:


For Soviet Mezzo, Politics And Music Aren't in Tune
LEAD: ''It's a pity that stupid politics can prevent artists from performing,'' Elena Obraztsova said last week. ''Politics are politics and art is art.
The two shouldn't be mixed.'' The Russian mezzo-soprano was in New York to prepare for her Carnegie Hall recital Monday night, her first appearance in the city in eight years.


Further Revival Of Jets' Regulars
LEAD: This is the time of year the Jets are supposed to be going the other way - to the hospital.
The club has a history of damaging injuries in the second half of the season.

Harry Liman, Dress Manufacturer, 89
LEAD: Harry Liman, a retired New York dress manufacturer, died of complications after surgery Thursday at New York University Medical Center.
He was 89 years old and lived in Lawrence, L.I.


NORTHEAST OPENS DRIVE TO CUT BACK OZONE POLLUTION
LEAD: Impatient with Federal efforts to control smog, New York, New Jersey and the six New England states are starting a major effort to reduce ozone by requiring changes in gasoline sold in the region in warmer months, beginning next summer.

TV: 'King of the Birds' Offered on Channel 13
LEAD: As African birds go, the hammerkop, or hammer-headed stork, is not prepossessing.
It is dull brown and middle-sized, and wears, as George Page, the narrator, says, ''a guilty look.'' So, why is it called the king of the birds? ''Nature,'' on Channel 13 at 8 o'clock tomorrow night, tries to explain why.

This Year in Moscow, a Kosher Feast
LEAD: For the first time in more than 50 years, kosher food is available again in Moscow, imported in regular shipments from Hungary and served up with the care and reverence that come of long decades of attacks on the traditions of Soviet Jews.


U.S. AND HAVANA AGREE TO RESTORE IMMIGRATION PACT
LEAD: The Cuban Government, in a policy reversal, has agreed to restore an immigration understanding with Washington that will allow the deportation of nearly 2,600 Cubans from the United States, State Department officials said today.

LEAD: Jessica McClure, her right foot in a cast, leaving hospital in Midland, Tex.
The 19-month-old had been hospitalized since her rescue Oct. 16.
It took rescuers 58 1/2 hours to free her from an abandoned well. (AP)

Bank of New York Trims Bid for Irving
LEAD: The Bank of New York Corporation yesterday reduced its bid for the Irving Bank Corporation to $68 a share in cash and stock from $80 a share.
Analysts said the new offer would do little to reduce the Irving board's opposition to a takeover.

LEAD: The Daily News and the Newspaper Guild have reached a tentative agreement that would reduce the newspaper's editorial and commercial staff by 64, including 10 of the paper's approximately 120 reporters.

Army Tank Contract
LEAD: The Army has awarded a $605.4 million contract to the General Dynamics Corporation for 624 M-1A1 Abrams tanks.
The award, the latest installment in a four-year, fixed-price deal announced last spring, calls for delivery of the tanks by March 1990.

Concert: Dresden Orchestra
LEAD: The Dresden Staatskapelle, which traces its history to 1548 and hence can claim to be the world's oldest orchestra, arrived in Carnegie Hall Thursday night for the first of three Manhattan concerts. (The two others, conducted by Colin Davis, will be Wednesday at Carnegie and Thursday at Avery Fisher Hall.) For this first program, the orchestra was led by Hans Vonk, who comes from the Netherlands and who became the Staatskapelle's principal conductor two years ago.

Carlesimo Retiring
LEAD: Pete Carlesimo, who is credited with revitalizing the National Invitation Tournament, the oldest postseason basketball competition, announced his retirement yesterday as the tournament's executive director, effective June 30.
The announcement came several hours before the start of the Big Apple N.I.T.


DEC. 14 HEARINGS SET ON JUDGE KENNEDY
LEAD: The Senate Judiciary Committee decided today to begin confirmation hearings on Dec. 14 for President Reagan's latest nominee to the Supreme Court, Judge Anthony M. Kennedy.

Nebraska Will Try to Stay No. 1
LEAD: The bus was waiting to leave the Orange Bowl.
It was about 1:30 in the morning on that memorable night in Miami nearly 16 years ago.
The cheering had stopped, if only temporarily.
And the football players and the coaches at Nebraska had reached that quiet moment when celebration turns to exhaustion and giddiness to satisfaction.


Europe Is Hopeful on Plan
LEAD: Nigel Lawson, Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, welcomed the American budget plan today and said the industrialized nations should now prepare their response and call a meeting.


Carnegie Hall Tower On Its Way
LEAD: On a lot just to the east of Carnegie Hall, city officials and representatives from the hall gathered yesterday afternoon to break ground for the construction of a 59-story office tower.
The building will provide the concert facility with an additional area of 25,000 square feet in which to create new rehearsal spaces, dressing rooms and an enlarged backstage.


COPING: With Personal Records
LEAD: This is the time of year when many Americans feel as if they are drowning in a sea of paper, as dresser drawers and shoe boxes overflow with the year's accumulation of sales receipts, canceled checks and assorted other financial scraps.


Two Novelists Awarded Strauss Livings for '88
LEAD: Diane Johnson and Robert Stone have been named the 1988 recipients of ''The Mildred and Harold Strauss Livings.'' Each will receive $50,000 annually for five years, for purposes of allowing them to devote their time exclusively to writing.


Brooklyn Man Is Held In Killing of a Doctor
LEAD: A Brooklyn man was arrested yesterday in the slaying of a Queens obstetrician during an unsuccessful robbery Wednesday afternoon, the police said.


Tax Rises Expected Primarily for Corporations and the Rich
LEAD: The $9 billion of tax increases included in the budget package announced today were not designated, but they will likely be relatively limited in scope, with corporations and wealthier individuals shouldering most of the burden, according to Congressional tax writers.

Cuts Seen at N.Y.U. Business School
LEAD: In a move that could affect thousands of New York business people, including hundreds on Wall Street, New York University will reduce by nearly a fourth the part-time student body at its Graduate School of Business Administration, according to faculty members at the school.

Circus: Big Apple Version, In 1 Ring at Lincoln Center
LEAD: Still flashing only one ring, like any faithful spouse after a decade of living together, the Big Apple Circus is celebrating, up at Lincoln Center, its 10th anniversary.
It is a pretty splashy affair for the modest circus, not in terms of large-scale Madison Square Garden three-ring splashiness maybe, but certainly big and bold for the radiant blue and yellow tent in Damrosch


BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 21, 1987
LEAD:  The Economy


Officials Arrest Six In Crack-Selling Ring
LEAD: Law-enforcement officials have arrested six people who reportedly sold an average of 12,000 vials of crack a week in the Albany region over the last two years, according to a spokesman for the Capital District Drug Enforcement Task Force.


Timerman Did Not Link His Arrest and Imprisonment to Anti-Semitism
LEAD: To the Editor:


Two Salvador Rebels Plan to Return Home To Test Latin Treaty
LEAD: The two senior leaders of the civilian wing of the Salvadoran rebel movement say they will return to El Salvador from exile in the next few days to test the the Central American peace treaty.

AIDS Virus in Pregnancy Studied
LEAD: One in 50 pregnant women was found to have antibodies to the AIDS virus in tests on 602 pregnant women at Kings County Hospital Center in Brooklyn, according to a report in the Journal of the American Medical Association.


N.C.A.A. to Proceed With Drug Testing
LEAD: The National Collegiate Athletic Association said yesterday that it would begin drug tests next Monday for athletes at all championship events despite a California judge's ruling that the tests generally violate both the California and United States constitutions.


U.S. and Laos in Accord on the Missing
LEAD: The United States and Laos announced today that Washington would begin considering the ''humanitarian problems'' of this isolated country as Laotians step up the search for Americans missing since the Vietnam War.
