Quotations of the Day
LEAD: ''A balanced package.'' - Representative Jim Wright, Democrat of Texas and Speaker of the House.  [ 48:1. ]


Belem Journal; An Amazon Tribe Braves the Wilds of City Life
LEAD: Chief Poropot and 96 other Kaiapo Indians had come to the big city and stunned everyone with their body paint, their war clubs and their headdresses.
But they found the townsfolk pretty strange, too.


Officials Criticize New Plan For a Task Force on Schools
LEAD: A New York Board of Regents plan to name a task force to study the New York City school system has been criticized by state officials as a needless effort that would only delay solutions to the problems of the city's schools.


Stage: At American Place, 'That Serious He-Man Ball'
LEAD: In ''That Serious He-Man Ball,'' three old friends from high school meet on a suburban basketball court and compare the failed game plans of their lives.
Graduating with high ambition, each has, in a different fashion, pursued a path toward failure.
In common, the three are black men, and ethnicity remains a principal issue.


Tears In the Ruins
LEAD: Arriving in New York, I was amazed to find the streets still clogged with ultimate driving machines.
News reaching the hinterland had led me to believe that the fall of the stock market had wiped out 97 percent of the great city's famous yuppie population, and I could not believe they would have gone to the final wipe-out without taking their beloved ultimate driving machines with them.


Actors Get 3-Year Pact
LEAD: Representatives of the League of Off Broadway Theaters and Producers and the Actor's Equity Association have negotiated a three-year contract that will increase earnings for some actors and stage managers by more than 20 percent over the next three years.


Lagos Patrolled After Riots
LEAD: The police patrolled the city center and the old section of the capital today after three days of rioting by gangs of youths.
The riots started on Tuesday, but residents said no incidents had been reported since Thursday afternoon.
The police arrested 60 people during the clashes, touched off by the killing of two brothers who tried to mediate between the police and a motorist arrested by a traffic officer.


Dollar Little Changed; Precious Metals Climb
LEAD: The dollar was little changed yesterday in a session marked by wild, erratic swings, as market participants fell prey to trading on remarks by politicians about what had - and what had not - been achieved in cutting the Federal budget deficit.


Pentane May Add To Tesoro Offer
LEAD: Pentane Partners, a New York-based investment partnership, said that it would be prepared to raise its $15-a-share offer for the Tesoro Petroleum Corporation ''if additional value can be demonstrated.''

About New York; Getting Personal And Eating Tripe Among the Stars
LEAD: The celebrity interview used to be a simple affair: the interviewer published or broadcasted any self-serving thing the interviewee chose to pass along.
Then the rules changed.
The gaga press concluded, and rightly so, that vigorous, aggressive reporting turned up material with more pizzaz.


Radiation Level Is Cut Outside Plant in Queens
LEAD: A radium supply company in Queens has all but totally reduced radiation outside its plant to what the state regards as a safe level, state officials said yesterday.

Here's Where the Ax Will Fall Today
LEAD: While the mandatory spending cuts ordered by President Reagan today could affect a wide range of domestic and military programs over the course of the current fiscal year, they will immediately lower Government payments to doctors and dairy farmers and raise the price that students pay for Government-subsidized loans.


Malaysian Car for U.S.
LEAD: Malaysia's money-losing national auto manufacturer, Proton, signed an accord today to distribute its Proton Saga car in the United States.
Proton America Inc., headed by Malcolm Bricklin of Bricklin Industries, will import the car. ''Production of the models bound for the United States will begin in October 1988, once modifications to meet U.S.


Verity Warns Japan on Curb
LEAD: The United States could retaliate if Japan continues to bar American companies from participating in public works projects, Commerce Secretary C. William Verity Jr. said today.


Yonkers Unsure How to Satisfy Judge's Ruling
LEAD: City officials expressed confusion and anger today over a Federal judge's decision to bar the city from assisting developers until it complies with a court order calling for the construction of public housing.

Copies of Popular Toys Are Often Hazardous
LEAD: Imported toys that resemble popular brand-name products can pose serious safety hazards, toy experts say.
These toys can even find their way onto the shelves of reputable stores across the country.


Haig, the Old Warrior, in New Battles
LEAD: Alexander M. Haig Jr. has been working hard to become a politician.
But sometimes the soldier in him shines through.

Devils and Rangers Come Out on Top; RANGERS 4, JETS 3
LEAD: The score was tied, 3-3, which was acceptable to the Rangers, but instead of relaxing, they used the final two minutes to bear down and avoid the strain of an overtime session so close after Thursday night's loss in Minnesota.


N.B.A. Building Code
LEAD: The heat is on the Miami Heat, a National Basketball Association franchise due to begin play in the 1988-89 season.
Heat officials were told this week by the N.B.A. that the number of bathrooms in its new arena now under construction must be increased from the present 76 to 125 or the city could lose the franchise.

Bruce Would Return
LEAD: Earle Bruce, who will apparently end his career as head football coach at Ohio State this afternoon when the Buckeyes close their season against Michigan, has admitted that he could be talked into returning as coach of the Buckeyes.
Bruce, who was dismissed on Monday by Edward Jennings, the university president, said


Volkswagen to Shut U.S. Plant
LEAD: Volkswagen, the first foreign automobile company to build cars in the United States since the end of World War II, announced today that it will close its American assembly plant by next autumn.


Pitching of a Different Sort for a Central Park Baseball Field
LEAD: With his feet together in the required stance of a petanque player, a visitor to Central Park threw his ball toward a marker as he enjoyed a game with three friends yesterday on a baseball field near 62d Street.


Chavez Takes Lightweight Crown
LEAD: Julio Cesar Chavez won the World Boxing Association lightweight title tonight when he stopped Edwin Rosario, the defending champion, at 2 minutes 36 seconds of the 11th round of a scheduled 12-round fight at the Las Vegas Hilton outdoor stadium.

Who's In Charge Here?
LEAD: TO HIS SUPPORTERS in the early 1980's, Army Col.


A Motley Extended Family For Annual Giving of Thanks
LEAD: THREE years ago in a modest ceremony in Manhattan, a Methodist from Texas married a Jew from Ohio.
It was the second marriage for both.
Both had lived and worked in the city for more than a dozen years.
Both had happily stored Christmas tree balls and Hanukkah candles in the rarely opened little cabinets above their separate fridges.

Joanne Cestone Marries
LEAD: Joanne Cestone, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs.
Angelo Cestone of East Hanover, N.J., was married there yesterday to Michael Farrell McHugh, a son of Mr. and Mrs.
Thomas McHugh of Brick Town, N.J.
The Rev.

Fashion; JEWELED ARTISTRY
LEAD: BARRY KIESELSTEIN-CORD RE-members being ''somewhat taken aback, even apprehensive,'' at being ushered into the private vault of an investment banker client.
Assembled there in radiant profusion were some 35 pieces of jewelry he had designed.
When Kieselstein-Cord expressed his astonishment, the client replied, ''Your work is part of my investment portfolio.


60 Protesters Stalk Connecticut Deer Hunters
LEAD: Some 60 animal rights protesters, many of them carrying flash cameras and grisly photographs of freshly shot deer, stalked hunters in the Yale-Myers Forest today in an effort to disrupt the start of Connecticut's annual controlled deer hunt here.


Sloppy Knicks Get Their 2d Victory
LEAD: It won't be very often this season that the Knicks benefit from such charity.
Last night, they found themselves matched against the Golden State Warriors, a team that was both drained from a road trip and debilitated by injuries.
Still, it was three full periods before the Knicks could manage their second victory of the season.


Homeless Group Is Scattered From the Grounds of M.I.T.
LEAD: The police rousted more than a dozen homeless people from their makeshift shelters and tents on Massachusetts Institute of Technology property today, arresting several when they balked at leaving in the rain, school officials said.
A spokesman for the institute, Robert C. DiIorio, said people at the tent city had been warned since last month that they could not stay.


JOANNE KING WEDS
LEAD: The Roman Catholic Church of the Presentation in Upper Saddle River, N.J., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Joanne K. King, a daughter of Ruth Glener of Hawthorne, N.J., and Carl J. King of Chicago, to Dr.
Kambiz Noruzi, a son of Sonia Noruzi of Upper Saddle River and the late Naghi Noruzi.


THE CONTRADICTIONS OF BOB DOLE
LEAD: I want to correct a misimpression created by the remarks attributed to me in the article on Republican Presidential candidate Robert Dole (''The Contradictions of Bob Dole,'' by Martin Tolchin and Jeff Gerth, Nov. 8).
The remarks quoted in the article were accurate - as far as they went.
What was left out were my other remarks, on Bob Dole's great strength: his ability to bring together opposing sides and mold a consensus on tough issues.


Oh, for the Spice of Eccentricity
LEAD: IN ''NUTS,'' BARBRA STREISAND PLAYS A WOMAN who curses frequently, exhibits violent mood swings and lashes out angrily at those she loves.
This behavior is supposed to convince an audience that a judge might find her certifiably insane, but by some latter-day, urban standards, it's really all in a day's work.


From Kim Young Sam, Appeal for the Safe Road
LEAD: As he demonstrated today before a thin crowd in front of the Chonju rail station, Kim Young Sam is no stem-winding orator.


Two Suspected Prostitutes Slain in New York
LEAD: Two women believed to be prostitutes were killed in separate incidents in New York City yesterday morning and Friday evening, the police said.

Rock: John Lydon and Public Image Ltd.
LEAD: JOHN LYDON could not believe the audience response when Public Image Ltd., his band, played Wednesday at the Beacon Theater.
The sold-out house stood and watched him perform, then applauded each song warmly - but it neither joined in on choruses nor sneered back at Mr.
Lydon's taunts.
As Johnny Rotten, the voice of the Sex Pistols, and then as the cynical, corrosive leader of Public Image Ltd., Mr.

INSIDE
LEAD:  Ex-Gov.
Folsom Dies at 79  James E. Folsom, a colorful figure in Alabama politics for nearly five decades, was a Democrat with a reputation as a moderate on race issues who twice served as Governor.
Page 52.
Koch Faults School Board  Mayor Koch has accused the Board of Education of taking too long to pick a new schools chancellor.


SOUTH AFRICA LOOKS EAST, AND EXTENDS ITS MARKETS
LEAD: ALTHOUGH trade with its customary partners is slackening under pressure from economic sanctions, South Africa has managed an overall gain in commerce so far this year, the Government reports.
Experts here say that the country's recent 45 percent drop in exports to the United States, which was its largest trading partner, has been offset by trade with other nations, particularly in Asia.

LEAD: THE autumn winds bring fierce whitecaps to Haverstraw Bay.

On the wild days, the whitecaps transform the smooth precision of rowing to a delicate balancing act that slams spray over the bow and threatens to overturn my slender craft.

You can't help thinking about ''All Quiet on the Western Front'' while watching ''Westfront 1918.'' Both are antiwar movies from the point of view of German troops in the World War I trenches; both were made in 1930, ''All Quiet'' in the United States, ''Westfront'' in Germany.

CRIME
LEAD: You finish THE JERICHO RUMBLE by Christopher Murphy (Walker, $16.95) and then turn back to the first page.
Facing it is a Xerox copy of a ''brevet d'invention'' from the French patent office dated Feb. 12, 1965.
It appears to be the real thing. (Later in the book an English translation is provided.) It is the patent of an invention that can scramble brains and destroy buildings by an ultrasound device.

FOR BRIGHT BLOOMS
LEAD: THIS would be a good week to apply fertilizer to dogwood trees; rake up remaining leaves and discard them, do not compost, as a precaution for disease control; scatter acid-type fertilizer on the ground around the root zone according to rates on bag label; rain and melting snow will seep nutrients in during winter.

ON FINANCIAL BRACKET OF PRESCHOOLERS
LEAD: I read your article, ''Baby Boom Hitting Nursery Schools''  [ Nov. 1 ] , with great interest.
I would like to make one important correction.
The article states that in the Prekindergarten Program of New Rochelle ''all 215 children fall below the income guidelines to qualify.'' This is inaccurate and was probably a misunderstanding; 10 percent of the 215 children do exceed the financial guidelines.


MOVIES
LEAD:  River's Edge  Starring Crispin Glover, Keanu Reeves, Dennis Hopper.
Directed by Tim Hunter. 1987.
Embassy Home Entertainment. 99 minutes. $79.95.
The first scenes of ''River's Edge'' evoke a horrifying triptych: a doomed baby doll, a tattered sex doll and a dead teen-ager.
The group connected with their fates is the crux of this harrowing vision of adolescence.

St. Lucia's Gallic Flair
LEAD: EVERYONE on St.
Lucia seems to be a charter member of the Chamber of Commerce, led by the cabdrivers.
Rarely does one meet drivers so in love with their country, so knowledgeable - and yet so willing to charge the correct fare.
They will tell you about the hiking trails that wind through the interior's rain forest, about the orchids and Amazon parrots, and the volcanic range that rises to more than 3,000 feet and includes the pyramidical cones of the twin peaks called the Pitons.

Indulging A Passion For Piazzas
LEAD: AGE, the weak dollar and Italian intransigence have conspired, happily, to change our travel strategy for good.
Late in life, my husband and I have learned to shape the days to our new interests and lesser energies, and thereby discovered a new and even nicer Italy.
We've exchanged the cities, with their rudely expensive hotels and restaurants, raucous traffic and endless ''chiuso's'' (''closed'') for the quieter pleasures of its hill towns, seductive landscapes and, above all, its piazzas.


Corrections
LEAD: An article on Nov. 1 about stock market risk incorrectly explained a trading strategy.
As the value of stocks falls below the value of matching futures indexes, portfolio insurers sell stock index futures.
This strategy can inadvertently lead to further stock declines, because it may create an opportunity for program traders to buy index futures and sell the corresponding stocks.

Can the Giants And the Jets Still Make The Playoffs?
LEAD: No they can't.
The Jets will be inconsistent as usual.
The Giants will come on strong.
They will come into their final game 8-6.
They will play to a 10-10 tie.
The Jets appear to be headed for victory, but Mark Gastineau roughs Phil Simms and the Giants drive for the tying field goal.
In overtime, Ken O'Brien is picked off three times.

'THE WILD ONE' TAMED
LEAD: PLEASE take your seats, students of fashion, because we are ready to discuss this week's mixed metaphor.

This jacket has a well-earned tough-guy reputation, but pair it with a miniskirt or baggy trousers, and it looks positively chic.

THEATER: STOPPARD DUO OF ONE-ACT RADIO PLAYS
LEAD: IF it takes one man, working alone, eight years to paint a railway bridge, the bridge will need repainting by the time he has completed his task.
Therefore, the authorities decide, it would be more efficient to hire 1,800 men to do the project in a single day.
Naturally, the structure cannot support the weight of an army of painters, and, with a loud cracking, the bridge collapses.

GOONS AND GINKS AND COMPANY FINKS
LEAD: William Safire missed a chance to deal with the grammar problem of the Donna Rice campaign.
The jeans are labeled ''No Excuses''; therefore, the phrase ''No Excuses'' is synonymous with the product.
Ms.
Rice doesn't manufacture the product, does she?
Therefore, to be accurate, the copy line should read, ''I don't make No Excuses.

Leaving His Imprint On Broadway
LEAD: WHEN LLOYD Richards was 9 years old, in the early 1930's, his father died of diphtheria.
It suggests something of the trauma of the event that Richards, a man with precise memories of childhood, can conjure up few of the details surrounding Albert Richards's passing.
The elder Richards had been a strong and secure man, a follower of the black nationalist Marcus Garvey, a breadwinner who moved from Jamaica to Toronto to Detroit in search of a $5-a-day wage on which to raise his family of seven.

Shaping the Dialogue of Mind and Matter
LEAD: IN A NOVEMBER LOADED WITH sculpture, there are three solo shows concentrated around 57th Street that are particularly worthy of attention.
All three sculptors make discrete objects.
Their approaches, however, and the complex issues with which they are concerned, are very different.
Each challenges prevalent ways of thinking.

THE FAT MAN'S GARDEN AND OTHER LANDMARKS
LEAD: NEW YORK CITY is a treasure trove of ''X-marks,'' even though the term is, to put it mildly, not very well known.
The reason for its lack of familiarity is that I have never used it since inventing it on a tour of Europe 25 years ago with a party of city planners.

A MAGAZINE JUNKIE
LEAD: I thought I was the only such magazine junkie.
I, too, have classics and fine books waiting to be read - someday.
They wait on the end table beside my bed, but stacked on the floor is an even taller pile of magazines.
I subscribe to 11 regularly and buy four more each month.


Copter Crashes in Colombia
LEAD: Two American soldiers were injured when their Army CH-47 Chinook helicopter crashed and burned Friday in Colombia, the Pentagon said today.
The helicopter's pilot reported engine failure while it was returning to its base in Panama from a refueling mission.
The soldiers suffered first- and second-degree burns over about 30 percent of their bodies when the Chinook crashed near the city of Monteria, Colombia, the Pentagon said.

LEAD: SEVEN HUNDRED feet above street level, steel workers will soon begin bolting beams into a crazy-quilt of angles to form the crown of a skyscraper at 60 Wall Street.

LEAD: THREE aircraft operated by the Army Corps of Engineers were bought for use in emergencies, but when the Army Audit Agency checked, it found that ''virtually all of the flights were for routine matters and could have been accomplished with commercial aircraft.''

Franken: ''I'm referring to your long history of going into supermarket express lanes with more than 10 items.''

LEAD: LEFTOVERS are not, by nature, inferior foods.
In a professional kitchen, for instance, a good chef finds a use for nearly every bone, morsel and scrap.
With a little imagination, the home cook can transform those foods that remain at the end of a meal into festive, serendipitous dishes the day after.

MOVIES
LEAD:  Defense of the Realm  Starring Gabriel Byrne, Greta Scacchi and Denholm Elliott.
Directed by David Drury. 1986.
Embassy Home Entertainment. 97 minutes. $79.95.
If moodiness was all that counted, this film might be a blockbuster.
It captures, with great success, the gray, somber, claustrophobic atmosphere that characterizes the best British espionage films.

A MAGAZINE JUNKIE
LEAD: I was surprised and pleased to read James Atlas's article ''A Magazine Junkie'' (Guest Observer, Nov. 1).
I thought I was alone in my affliction.
There is a pile of Penguin classics sitting atop my coffee table, and on a bookshelf.
I've even stopped buying magazines.
But can I help it if every day, when I arrive home from work, my mailbox is crammed with mail-order catalogues?

LEAD: THREE years after the Federal Government gave New York City 13 housing grants worth nearly $30 million, the city has spent less than $2 million of it and faces the possibility of losing almost half of what is left unless construction can start on several projects by Nov. 30, a prospect city officials consider unlikely.

From the Start, the Rules Weren't Clear
LEAD: THE controversy at the Columbia University Business School is now big news.
It stems from an offer of $100,000 made by Adjunct Prof.
Asher B. Edelman to the students in his class who provide him with information that leads to a successful corporate takeover.
The offer, which the Columbia administration asked him to withdraw, presents an opportunity for ethical rumination.


State's Role in Religious Pluralism
LEAD: THIS bicentennial year of our Constitution comes at a time of sharp public debate over the appropriate role of religion in American life.
There is much discussion about the meaning of the First Amendment's religion clause.
Did it, as some say, merely prohibit the establishment of an official state religion, or did it erect an impenetrable wall between church and state?

A Killer Nurse?
LEAD: ''I had to prove myself to the staff and to myself,'' Richard Angelo was quoted as telling Suffolk County prosecutors last week as they began exhuming the bodies of patients he may have killed in the course of his duties at Good Samaritan Hospital in West Islip.
According to the authorities, the 25-year-old registered nurse admitted injecting powerful muscle-paralyzing drugs into patients, then working frantically to revive them.

It was 127 percent.

AN UGLY FEELING
LEAD: I believe I understand Sam Toperoff's ugly feeling and its source.
The key for me was his repeated use of the word ''umbilical.'' What could be more reminiscent of the fetal situation than his hard-hat dive, and what more evocative of primal fears of being left alone without a basic life support?

They're Still Cheating Housing
LEAD: A badly needed housing bill, the first in seven years, blew up in the Senate last week after passing the House, 391-1.
The charge of budget-busting did it.
Reducing the budget deficit is Washington's primary goal at the moment, but housing, whose share of Federal spending has shrunk substantially in the last eight years, is no place to look for residual extravagance.

LEAD: Georgetown University must provide homosexual student groups with the same privileges given other campus organizations, an appeals court here has ruled.

SCHOOLS EXTENDING KINDERGARTEN DAY
LEAD: THE State Education Department thinks that for kindergartners, two and a half hours is not enough.
The department, with a grant of $1 million, has helped 17 local school boards to start or to expand a variety of extended kindergarten programs this year beyond the two and a half hours a day that many districts offer and plans to ask the legislature for more money to start or expand such programs next school year.

LEAD: THE company's plans are ambitious and more than a little curious.
There's the idea for a ''Nostalgicize'' exercise video, featuring young women performing aerobic routines to a 1940's beat.
There's the Memory Lane Club of America, ''a basic service'' for collectors of old records and movies, to be specially marketed to retirement communities in Florida and other parts of the nation.


Genteel Playwright, Angry Voice
LEAD: IN CARYL CHURCHILL'S VITRIOLIC NEW COME-dy, ''Serious Money,'' greed, corruption and self-interest share equal billing.
Venality is a way of LIFFE (an acronym for the London International Financial Futures Exchange).
Money is the key to more money - and to power - and on this boardroom battlefield even sex takes a holiday.

LEAD: DAVID WARRILOW, WHO HAS made a career of interpreting the compressed poetry of Samuel Beckett's minimalist dramas, is currently assuming the challenge of a play by a Revolutionary-era Russian poet that has words enough to spare, including those of the author's invented language.

GOONS AND GINKS AND COMPANY FINKS
LEAD: I fail to see much humor in William Safire's column ''Goons and Ginks and Company Finks'' (On Language, Nov. 1).
Perhaps Mr.
Safire is not aware that Fink is also a surname - one, I might add, not always easy to live with.
In the Manhattan telephone directory alone, you'll find almost 200 people listed, to say nothing of the Finck or Finke variety.

Can the Giants And the Jets Still Make The Playoffs?
LEAD: The owners' use of replacements and the counting of substitute games has raped and ruined the reputation of the N.F.L.
Their arrogance is sickening.
Therefore, I don't care if the Jets or the Giants make the playoffs.
Nor do I care if there are playoffs or the Super Bowl.
There is as much integrity in the N.F.L.

LEAD: MUSICIANS TEND TO dislike being categorized and labeled; many resist it strenuously.
How harmful can such pigeonholing be?
Consider the cases of two composer-pianists, men of extraordinary talent and originality who were misperceived, dismissed as derivative early in their careers and lived out the remainder of their lives in frustrating obscurity.

CHILDREN
LEAD:  Classic Tales Retold  Hi-Tops Video. 90 minutes. $29.95.
This is an amiable collection of a dozen animated (and in some cases abridged) familiar stories, originally produced by BFA Educational Media.
The voiceover narrator credits the origin of the individual stories - ''Jack and the Beanstalk'' is English, ''The Little Match Girl'' and ''Thumbelina'' come from Hans Christian Andersen, ''Hansel and Gretel'' from the Brothers Grimm, and so on.

PLAZAS, LIKE COMPUTERS, ARE BEST IF USER-FRIENDLY
LEAD: NO BUILDING IS STATIC; ALL OF them change over time, both in their physical reality and in our perceptions of them.
And buildings take a long time to settle in, to find their natural relationship to their users and to their surroundings.
Sometimes years of use can bestow a depth and a resonance to a building that had seemed thin and facile when new, and just as often those years can see initial promise turn sour.

Let Banks Sell Securities
LEAD: Does the stock market crash undermine the case for allowing commercial banks to compete in the securities business?
No, say two financial heavyweights, William Proxmire, chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, and Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve.
They conclude that the potential benefits of a careful liberalization far outweigh the risks to the stability of the banking system.

The penguins, visiting from Sea World, are here for the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade, which will be held on Thursday. (NYT/Chester Higgins Jr.)


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: An article on Nov. 7 about organizations that prepare students for Scholastic Aptitude Tests misstated the policy of the Stanley H. Kaplan Educational Center.
Students in the Kaplan preparatory course may retake the course free for up to a year regardless of their scores on the test.


Hanover's Mutual Fund Role
LEAD: The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation is expected to announce today that it will begin distributing some 20 different mutual funds, including products from Dreyfus, Federated, Franklin and Putnam, through 10 of its New York area branches.


Greek Cypriot Women Cross Turks' Line
LEAD: Hundreds of Greek Cypriot women bearing white banners stormed and scrambled across the line dividing their country today, scuffling with armed Turkish soldiers in protest against the division of the island.


Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''It is like running a town.
The only difference is, rather than providing normal municipal services, we are also providing food, clothing, shelter and all the basic necessities of life.''  William J. Grinker on New York City's homeless shelter program.  [ B6:3. ]


Beyond the Budget Compromise
LEAD: The world economy is headed in the right direction.
Galvanized by the stock market plunge, the Administration and Congress have begun to agree on cuts in the budget deficit.
American and West German interest rates have fallen.
Domestic demand in Japan had already turned up smartly.

LEAD: A high Angolan official says 3,000 South African soldiers remain in southern Angola after the fiercest fighting in a decade between Angolan troops and South African and guerrilla forces.

LEAD: Four years ago, a 27-year-old named Sophie Mirman had a silly idea for a new business here: shops that sold only women's tights, stockings and socks.


Concert: Alvin Lucier
LEAD: ALVIN LUCIER, who opened the Alternative Museum's music series Wednesday night, composes scores that combine true Minimalist austerity (devoid of the kinetic impetus of a Philip Glass or Steve Reich) with conceptual-art ingenuity and a fascination for acoustical experimentation.

LEAD: Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the former Cambodian head of state, plans to meet Prime Minister Hun Sen, the most powerful figure in the Vietnamese-backed Communist Government in Phnom Penh, around Dec. 10 in Paris in a new peace effort, according to Cambodian and other Asian diplomats.

LEAD: Alan Pesky will leave Scali, McCabe, Sloves at the end of the year - the third of the five founding partners to do so.


State Attorney General Seeks to Abolish Westchester Child Abuse Prevention Society
LEAD: Charging that members of the Westchester County Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children have abused their powers as peace officers, State Attorney General Robert Abrams is seeking a court order to dissolve the society.


Sports World Specials; No Stopping Him
LEAD: Most skiers are happy if they can ski every day during a week-long vacation or every day for a few weekends each season.
Paul Schipper was not content with that.
Every day that Sugarloaf/USA in Maine was open over the past six seasons, he has skied.
On Saturday, a week into a seventh season, his streak reached 1,000 days.

LEAD: The Government freed 985 political prisoners nationwide today as one of its moves to comply with a regional peace plan.

Graf Hold Off Sabatini
LEAD: There was an occasional sign of frustration as Steffi Graf muttered to herself in German, swatted a ball or two in annoyance and all but abandoned attempts to coax her backhand slice over the net.

Cetus Gene System
LEAD: The Cetus Corporation, a biotechnology company based in Emeryville, Calif., has introduced an automated gene amplification system as part of its joint venture with the Perkin-Elmer Corporation.
The system, which represents the first commercial introduction of Cetus-developed technology, relies on an enzyme to make as many as a million copies of a specific gene sequence, allowing the amplification of a DNA sequence in hours rather than the days or weeks typically required.

Nussbaum Withdraws Right to Boy
LEAD: Hedda Nussbaum said yesterday that she was surrendering all rights to custody of the 17-month-old boy she and Joel B. Steinberg had raised as Mitchell Steinberg.
She said the child's place was with his biological mother, Nicole Smigiel.


Dear Judge Kennedy
LEAD: When Federal judges have questions about their ethical duties they ask the ''Dear Abby Committee,'' the informal name for the Committee on the Codes of Judicial Conduct of the Judicial Conference of the United States.


Business and the Law; A Green Light In Boesky Suit
LEAD: A MAMMOTH civil lawsuit by shareholders against Ivan F. Boesky, the fallen Wall Street speculator, is expected to proceed expeditiously now that the United States Supreme Court has decided a securities case that had threatened to delay the Boesky matter.


Music Noted in Brief; Seraphim Trio Offers Bela Varkonyi Works
LEAD: Bela Varkonyi was a much-played young composer in turn-of-the-century Hungary, but this early reputation seems to have been swallowed up by his move to and subsequent life in the United States.
Even as exhaustive a reference as the New Grove Dictionary of Music makes no mention of him.

Gov.
Bobby Freeman in the Louisiana runoff election Saturday, while the state's Attorney General, William Guste, won a fifth term.

LEAD: A newly formed electrical equipment company called Asea Brown Boveri has named Klaus E. Agthe president and chief executive for United States operations.


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: A report in the Company News column of Business Day on Thursday, about Chrysler's 1988 model cars, misstated their price change from the previous year.
Prices have been cut 1 percent, on average, on comparably equipped cars made in the United States.


Nixon Skips Conference, but the Enigma Attends
LEAD: The issue under debate here for three days was one of the central political questions of the age: What was the true meaning of Richard M. Nixon's Presidency and how will he be judged before the bar of history?


Music: Schiff and Oslo Philharmonic
LEAD: PIANOPHILES were especially well represented in the audience that gathered for the Oslo Philharmonic concert at Carnegie Hall Friday evening: Andras Schiff, guest soloist for the Grieg Piano Concerto, has established a real following among the listeners who know and care most about the piano literature.


Mexico's Border Plants Thrive on Weak Peso
LEAD: The rapid spread of foreign-owned assembly plants along the Mexican border will likely be sustained because of the latest plunge in the peso's value, industry officials here said.


Homeless Man Found Frozen to Death on S.I.
LEAD: A 66-year-old homeless man living under an oceanfront boardwalk on Staten Island died, apparently of exposure, in the frigid temperatures over the weekend, the police said.


Cerrillos Journal; A Prospector's Search For an Elusive Dream
LEAD: For perhaps 1,000 years, the windswept mesa here has drawn dreamers.
First came the Indians, then the Spanish explorers, then 19th-century American miners, all drawn by what the Indians called ''the sky in the stone,'' the delicate turquoise mined here.


A Better Place for the Cyclist to Sit
LEAD: One bane of a bicyclist's existence - the seat that begins to feel like a concrete slab 15 minutes into a ride - may not be worth complaining about anymore.
A marriage of technology between the Spenco Medical Corporation and Avocet Inc., a producer of cycling components, has come up with a bike saddle that has thick gel at its core.


Reinstated '84 Plan Provided For Return of 2,700 to Cuba
LEAD: The immigration agreement that set off the riot by Cuban inmates at a detention center in Louisiana reinstated an understanding between the two countries that was reached in December 1984.
The State Department announced the reinstatement Friday.


S.A.S. May Bid For Caledonian
LEAD: The Scandinavian Airlines System is expected to make a counter offer for the British Caledonian Group, which received a revised offer of $:147 million (about $262 million) on Friday from British Airways P.L.C.


George L. Perry Wed To Dina Needleman
LEAD: Dina Needleman and George L. Perry were married yesterday at the Lotos Club in New York by Acting Justice Richard Lee Price of State Supreme Court.


Few New Airlines Survive
LEAD: When the airline industry was deregulated in 1978, the unfettered market was expected to give rise to scores of low-cost carriers that would create a bonanza for consumers, put the existing companies on the defensive and even run some of them out of business.

Judson.

A Survey of the Troubled
LEAD: A new survey of the single men and women in the city's shelter system conducted for the city by the New York State Psychiatric Institute, and based upon interviews with a cross section of shelter residents, depicts a deeply troubled population, in which most people may never be capable of living entirely on their own.


Mother May Not Have Saved Lone Survivor of Plane Crash
LEAD: Documents made available during a hearing on the Aug. 16 crash of a Northwest Airlines jetliner suggest that its sole survivor, 4-year-old Cecelia Cichan, was not saved by her mother, as had been believed.

LEAD: A bunch of bouncing business.


Concert: Orchestra Of 18th Century at Tully
LEAD: LIKE the early-music movement as a whole, the Orchestra of the 18th Century is fast outgrowing its name.
Frans Bruggen's Amsterdam-based, internationally assembled ensemble played a concert yesterday afternoon in Alice Tully Hall that marked the most significant advance thus far in this city of highly skilled, large-scaled playing of the standard repertory.

LEAD: For months, there have been rumblings that President Reagan might pardon Lieut.
Col.
Oliver L. North, Rear Adm.
John M. Poindexter and Robert C. McFarlane, key participants in the Iran-contra affair.


Susan Rosenholtz Becomes a Bride
LEAD: Susan I. Rosenholtz and Assemblyman Arthur J. Kremer were married last evening at the Plaza in New York.
Rabbi Morris Friedman and Cantor Charles Ritter officiated.


What Congress Didn't Ask
LEAD: Lieut.
Colonel Oliver L. North said during the Congressional hearings into the Iran-contra affair that he has fought in two American wars, Vietnam and Angola.
During his examination by the Iran-contra committees, he proudly offered information about his service in Vietnam but never mentioned what he was doing in Angola.


Music: Stern, Ax and Ma at Carnegie
LEAD: THOUGH it hardly seems possible, Emanuel Ax, Isaac Stern and Yo-Yo Ma were making their New York debut as a trio Saturday evening in Carnegie Hall.
They have played together elsewhere in this country as well as abroad, but they had not yet not done so here.

'Rhapsody in Blue'
LEAD: A rare 1926 concert version of Gershwin's ''Rhapsody in Blue'' is among the works to be performed by the Harmonie Ensemble on Dec. 8 at 8 P.M. at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street.
The program, called ''Americans and Paris,'' also features Ravel's ''Bolero''; Poulenc's ''Aubade for Piano and 18 Instruments''; Ibert's ''Paris Suite'' and Milhaud's ''Creation of the World.

LEAD: To the Editor:


17 Cubans Escape Texas Center; 14 Recaptured
LEAD: Seventeen Cuban inmates escaped from a detention center early today by climbing through a steel roof grating, but all but three were recaptured within hours.


Music: Chamber, at Merkin
LEAD: FOR THE LOVE OF MUSIC, a chamber music society directed by the violinist Richard Sortomme, gave four trios at Merkin Concert Hall yesterday afternoon.
One was a classic - Schubert's expansive Op. 100, attacked with big-boned vigor by Mr.
Sortomme, Semyon Fridman (cello) and John Klibonoff (piano).


DUARTE DEMANDS RETURNING REBELS DISOWN FIGHTERS
LEAD: President Jose Napoleon Duarte strongly criticized returning rebel civilian leaders today and demanded that they break their links with the military wing of the guerrilla front.


COMPANY BRIEFS
LEAD:  AM International Inc. said it had reached a four-year standstill agreement with Komuri Printing Machinery Co., which holds 6.7 percent of AM's common stock.
Komori agreed to limit its ownership to less than 8 percent of AM's stock in the next six months and to less than 5 percent for the duration of the agreement.


Sports World Specials; Gambling Racquets
LEAD: No sooner had the high-stakes Skins Game become a golfing fixture than you could almost hear the wheels of copycat creativity grinding.
If it works for golf, why shouldn't it work for tennis?


Mexican Rightist Party Chooses Candidate
LEAD: In an unexpectedly decisive vote, Mexico's principal opposition party today chose a wealthy rancher with a reputation for aggressive oratory as its candidate for President in next July's general election here.


Elephant Kills Moped Rider
LEAD: A wild elephant trampled a school teacher riding a moped and sat beside the man's body until chased away by the police, the United News of India reported today.
The elephant, which had strayed from a herd in Orissa State in eastern India, killed the teacher, Prabhakar Sahu, 45 years old, on a highway Saturday then squatted beside the body until it was forced back into the forest.


A Push for International Market Rules
LEAD: In the wake of last month's stock market plunge, world financial regulators have intensified their effort to change outdated national regulations to cope with an increasingly global market.


College Football; Unfinished Business in East
LEAD: Although most of the East's college football players took their helmets off for the last time this season on Saturday, there are playoffs and bowl games ahead for some.


Sports World Specials; Update on Sticks
LEAD: Five years after the introduction of sticks with aluminum shafts ushered in the era of high-tech hockey, wood is still king in the National Hockey League.
Only about 80 players have adopted the aluminum sticks, but the number has been rising, for an obvious reason: several sharp-shooters claim that since switching to aluminum they are stick-handling better, shooting harder, and playing a more consistent game.


Deficit Pact Called a 'First Step'
LEAD: Some Congressional leaders today called the proposed deficit-reduction package a starting point, while others said they were disappointed and would seek modifications.

Stamford Rail Center Opens, Off Schedule
LEAD: The Stamford Transportation Center, a structure often ridiculed by Amtrak and Metro-North rail commuters as a monument to miscalculation, started service today, three years after its first projected opening date and still only partly completed.


Pressmen Ratify Contract
LEAD: The pressmen of The New York Times voted yesterday to ratify the tentative contract settlement negotiated earlier this month by management and their union, New York Printing Pressmen's Union Local 2.
The president of the union, Lenny Higgins, said that the pressmen voted 216 to 44 to accept a 33 percent increase in wages over six years and a 10-year agreement on staffing levels.


Montana and Rice: A Winning Recipe
LEAD: Joe Montana threw for 304 yards and Jerry Rice caught three touchdown passes today to lead the San Francisco 49ers to a 24-10 victory over the Tampa Bay Buccaneers.

LEAD: More than 1,000 Cuban inmates, outraged at the prospect of being deported under a new immigration agreement, took over a Federal detention center here Saturday night, seized about 30 hostages and set fire to most of the prison.

Trainer Appeals
LEAD: An appeal hearing sought by Peter Ferriola, the thoroughbred racing trainer, of a 120-day suspension imposed by the New York State Racing and Wagering Board began yesterday in the board's offices in Manhattan.
Earlier this month, three of Ferriola's horses tested positive for Lasix, a diuretic thought to improve performance.


SITTING LESSON
LEAD: When the wearer is standing or striding down the street, above-the-knee skirts look great.
Sitting, when the skirt is at midthigh, can be another matter.
One of the sidelights of the recent showings of 1988 spring styles in Milan, Paris and New York was watching the audience of fashion professionals and celebrities deal with sitting in short skirts.

LEAD: A New York City law that ordered the owners of vacant single-room-occupancy hotels to rehabilitate them and rent the rooms to low-income tenants is unconstitutional, a State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan ruled yesterday.

Joseph C. Palamountain Jr., 66, Ex-President of Skidmore College&gt;
LEAD: Joseph Cornwall Palamountain Jr., who retired in June after 22 years as the fourth president of Skidmore College, died of cardiac arrest yesterday in Saratoga Springs, N.Y.
Dr.
Palamountain, who had triple bypass surgery within the last year, lived in Saratoga Springs and was 66 years old.

Steinberg Won't Try to Maintain Custody of Boy
LEAD: Joel B. Steinberg said yesterday that he would not try to seek custody of the 17-month-old boy he had been raising as Mitchell Steinberg, who was returned last week to the baby's biological mother.


Futuristic Treatments For the Hair and Skin
LEAD: DERMATOLOGISTS are developing futuristic treatments for some widespread and distressing conditions previously thought to be beyond their help.
The experimental treatments may restore natural color to graying hair, prevent poison ivy rashes and restore even skin tone to patients with the pale patches of vitiligo.

LEAD: The world's largest assembly of historic ships lies rotting and covered with rust along the waterfront here, a victim of inadequate maintenance that officials attributed to insufficient Federal financing.

The Stage: '3 Lives of Lucie Cabrol'
LEAD: IN the Talking Band's theatrical collage ''The Three Lives of Lucie Cabrol,'' the usually demure Tina Shepard plays the title role of a dwarflike French peasant woman whose family cruelly nicknames her ''the cocadrille,'' after a mythical animal born in a dungheap.
Ms.
Shepard strikingly transforms herself into a hunched, thick-skinned beast of burden who speaks in harsh, guttural cadences and survives through a combination of native shrewdness and a mystical attunement to the natural world.


Contra Fund-Raisers: Dispute Over Payment
LEAD: Just how much is a meeting with President Reagan worth?


Collisions on Foggy Road
LEAD: Dozens of vehicles collided today in separate accidents on a fog-bound stretch of Interstate 215, and at least seven people were injured, a California Highway Patrol commander said.
Estimates ranged from 30 to 40 vehicles involved in the crashes, said Capt.
Ralph Limon.
He said several accidents had occurred, some involving six to eight vehicles and another with as many as 15 to 20.

LEAD: The trustees of the City University named Tilden J. LeMelle as acting president of Hunter College yesterday.
Dr.
LeMelle, provost and vice president of Hunter, will succeed Donna E. Shalala, when she resigns Jan. 1 to become chancellor of the University of Wisconsin.
Dr.
LeMelle is not a candidate for the Hunter presidency.

Soviet Jews Ponder Exit-Visa Denials
LEAD: About 100 Soviet Jews, united by their inability to emigrate, crowded into a two-room apartment today to discuss state secrets: the secrets that keep them from leaving the Soviet Union, the secret process by which the holders of secrets are identified, and the reason the secrets themselves are secret.

Topics of The Times; Village Life in the Big Apple
LEAD: The mother of a family that recently moved to New York City from a smaller city in the heartland finds herself defending the Big Apple to folks back home.
To them, New York means bustle, crime, noise and anonymity. ''Not true,'' the new immigrant protests. ''We've found that family life in New York comes closer to old-fashioned small-town America than little-city life does - at least in some ways.


Precious Metals Rise; Signs of Inflation Cited
LEAD: Gold led a modest increase in the prices of precious metals futures yesterday as investors interpreted a weaker dollar and higher crude oil prices as signs of future inflation.


New York Housing Chief Quits; Finance Head Named Successor
LEAD: Paul A. Crotty, New York City's Housing Commissioner, resigned yesterday, and Mayor Koch appointed the Finance Commissioner, Abraham Biderman, to succeed him.


'88 Japan Car Limits Debated
LEAD: Skirmishing over next year's limits on Japanese car exports to the United States is already under way.
Some top executives of Detroit's auto companies are arguing that the Japanese Government should take into consideration the increasing output from Japanese-owned plants in the United States in setting the limits.


U.S. BEGINS SEARCH OF WAR CRIME FILES
LEAD: The war crimes archives of the United Nations were fully opened to a member nation for the first time yesterday as Justice Department historians began methodically poring over files containing 40,000 names of accused or suspected war criminals.

Music: Jersey Symphony in Bernstein
LEAD: LEONARD BERNSTEIN is becoming 70 years old for an awfully long time this season.
The actual birthday isn't until late next summer, but the list of celebrations is long.
Nearly at the head of the queue stands the New Jersey Symphony, which played an all-Bernstein program at Carnegie Hall Sunday night.


Stock Plunge Expected To Cut Banks' Income
LEAD: A month after the stock market collapse, a growing number of banking analysts believe that commercial banks will suffer from its impact.


Role Seen For Boron In Curbing Bone Loss
LEAD: BORON, a mineral long considered inessential to nutrition, apparently affects blood levels of certain hormones and may play a major role in preventing bone loss, Government scientists have reported.


Washington Talk: Briefing; Mining Under the Sun
LEAD: There may be strippers in Nevada, but the last time anyone looked there were few, if any strip mines.
That did not stop the Interior Department's Office of Surface Mining, which regulates strip mining, from holding its semi-annual conference for state and Federal regulators at a hotel outside Reno last week.

A Shultz Puzzle on Arms
LEAD: What a strangely confusing message Secretary of State Shultz sends from Geneva about a strategic nuclear arms treaty.
He says he wants one next year to cut long-range missiles and bombers.
But then he also opposes the best way of moving in that direction, an interim agreement in principle.

Steel Output Up 0.6%
LEAD: Steel production rose to 1.809 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, an increase of six-tenths of a percent from the previous week's 1.798 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
The industry's production amounted to 83.8 percent of capacity during the week, compared with 83.3 percent in the previous week.

LEAD: THE New York City Ballet surprised dancegoers on Saturday afternoon at the New York State Theater by offering an unscheduled debut in a major work.

Music: American Symphony in Strauss
LEAD: PERHAPS it is the upshot of enduring decades of serialist music, but audiences today look on Richard Strauss's orchestral works with a more sympathetic eye than did many listeners when they were written.
The American Symphony Orchestra's concert Sunday afternoon in Carnegie Hall, which concluded with Strauss's ''Also Sprach Zarathustra,'' put one in a bygone frame of mind.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Q.What makes leaves change color in the fall?
A.The bright colors of an autumn woods result from growth-regulating hormones in leaves, said Anne Dorrance, a plant pathologist at the Vermont State Department of Agriculture.
These hormones regulate respiration, food production and other functions related to the metabolism of the tree.


U.S. Laws Put Imprisoned Cubans In Legal Limbo With Few Rights
LEAD: Behind the riots by Cuban prisoners in Atlanta and Louisiana lie months or years of frustration at being in a state of legal limbo, with very few rights under American law.


First, a First-Rate Chancellor
LEAD: Mayor Koch of New York rightly feels impatient with the Board of Education: it is taking far too long to name a successor to Schools Chancellor Nathan Quinones, who retires on Jan. 1.
But the Mayor's proposal for an acting chancellor is unacceptable.
The board's first priority ought to be the selection of the best permanent chancellor a rigorous national search can provide.

LEAD: Because Idaho State finished 3-7-1 with a 53-37 loss Saturday to Weber State, Jim Koetter, the coach, was dismissed yesterday, barely a year after being inducted into the school's sports hall of fame.
With him went his five assistants.
Koetter, 49, compiled a 23-32-1 record in five seasons.
He was not aware of the decision when he attended the weekly luncheon with fans earlier in the day.

Risks of 'Learning Disabled' Label
LEAD: CHILDREN, like adults, have individual ways of learning, and educators who do not recognize them can undermine their chance for success or even wrongly label them as learning disabled, according to a new book by Thomas Armstrong, a psychologist. ''We're shutting the door to millions more who possess untold inner riches,'' he said.

Carbon Dioxide Census
LEAD: The rate of increase of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere matches the rate of global population growth with precision that is ''amazing,'' two paleontologists have found.
Dr.
Norman D. Newell and Dr.
Leslie Marcus, both of the American Museum of Natural History in New York City, cited data gathered from 1958 to 1983 for their study.


Washington Talk: Social Affairs; Tales of a Black-Tie Town
LEAD: Robert Keith Gray, a fixture on the Washington political and social scene since the Eisenhower Administration, wears out one each year.
Ambassador Allan E. Gotlieb of Canada is on his second since coming here.
Many senators keep one at home and one in the office.

Advertising; Some New Celebrities For BVD
LEAD: AMONG kids of a certain age group - very young - the easiest way to get a laugh is just mention the word ''underwear.'' It's joke and punchline both in a single word.


INSECTICIDE ASSIGNED
LEAD: S. C. Johnson, after a five-agency competition, is assigning Raid insecticide to Mingo-Jones Advertising, specialists in advertising to the black community.
It is the first time the brand will be getting such advertising, and the budget, according to the agency, is about $1 million.


Overnight Line for 'Phantom' Tickets
LEAD: ''The Phantom of the Opera,'' the new Andrew Lloyd Webber musical, doesn't open until late January and is nearly sold out to groups and mail-order ticket buyers through September.
Nevertheless, at 10 P.M.
Sunday, people began lining up outside the Majestic Theater on West 44th Street, blanket-wrapped against subfreezing temperatures and eager to invest $50 each (no one seemed interested in anything less than the top tickets) in a show they wouldn't see for nearly a year.

Banco de Bilbao
LEAD: Spain's banking community speculated that Banco de Bilbao might revise its takeover offer for the nation's second-largest bank, Banesto, which Friday rejected its first offer.
In announcing that the bid by the smaller bank had been turned down, a spokesman for Banesto, whose formal name is Banco Espanol de Credito, said that the bank was prepared to consider another offer if one were made.


Washington Talk: Briefing; Success of Fruits
LEAD: Every Thursday morning at 9 o'clock, the House Democratic whip holds a meeting of his deputy and regional whips to plan for the next week's floor votes.
That's early by Congressional standards, so a succession of whips have developed various enticements to promote regular attendance at these sessions.

Market Place; Higher Returns Found Abroad
LEAD: THE five-year bull market that scaled record heights by the end of August proved a bonanza to United States investors.
But in hindsight, these investors would have fared considerably better had they ventured abroad with their dollars, especially to the Tokyo stock market.

LEAD: The Reagan Administration promised today to give at least $90 million to the United Nations next month so that it could avoid insolvency and continue to pay its 6,500 employees in New York.

Drug-Case Extradition Put Off by Colombia
LEAD: Colombia's Justice Minister said today that a man believed to be a major cocaine smuggler will not be extradited immediately to the United States, where he is wanted on drug charges.


U.S. Asked to Release Secret Nuclear Report
LEAD: Representative Ted Weiss of New York said today that a secret Congressional report on the deployment of nuclear weapons aboard ships at a naval center under construction on Staten Island should be made available to a Federal court that is hearing a lawsuit against the project.


AT LEAST 14 DEAD IN ALASKA CRASH
LEAD: A commuter aircraft crashed while landing at Homer, Alaska, tonight killing at least 14 people and injuring seven others, the authorities said.

James Atherton Dies; A Tenor and Director
LEAD: James Atherton, a Metropolitan Opera tenor and, more recently, an operatic stage director, died of an AIDS-related illness last Friday, according to his manager, Dorothy Cone.
He was 44 years old and lived in St.
Louis, where he served as artistic director of the opera studio at the St.
Louis Conservatory.

Lasers 'Weld' Damaged Arteries
LEAD: RESEARCHERS in California have successfully tested a new method to repair damaged blood vessels, closing the ripped arteries with lasers, rather than the traditional stitches.
Dr.
John Crew of the Seton Medical Center in San Francisco and Dr.
Rodney White of Harbor U.C.L.A.
Hospital in Los Angeles reported at a recent meeting of the American Heart Association that they had successfully used ''laser welding'' in 15 patients.


Concert: U. V. Khan, Sitarist
LEAD: ONE of North India's most distinguished sitarists, Ustad Vilayat Khan, gave his first New York performance since the late 1970's on Saturday at the Triplex Theater.
Mr.
Khan, who is 59 years old, brought exultant technique and a playful spirit to the occasion.


Corrections
LEAD: An article from Geneva yesterday about arms negotiations involving Secretary of State George P. Shultz misstated his assessment of the prospects for an agreement on long-range nuclear weapons.
He has said such an accord could be concluded and approved next year, not this year.

Linguists Dig Deeper Into Origins of Language
LEAD: PALEONTOLOGISTS ponder their fossils, archeologists turn over ancient stones, and now scholars of linguistics are joining the search for human origins with a systematic analysis of the roots of the world's known languages.
They are seeking ultimately to reconstruct the primordial language, the mother tongue of all humans.

Lost Score By Liszt To Be Sold
LEAD: A major and previously unknown score by Franz Liszt is to be auctioned at Sotheby's in London on Friday.
The work for piano bears no title, date or signature but has been identified by Liszt experts as having been written by the composer between 1830 and 1832, when he was in his late teens and early 20's and was active throughout Europe as a concert pianist.

LEAD: The Iranian Navy opened fire on two ships in the gateway to the Persian Gulf today, setting both ablaze and wounding three crewmen, gulf-based salvage executives said.


Elizabeth Kray, Patron and Friend Of Poets and Their Art, Dies at 71
LEAD: Elizabeth Kray, a friend and patron of poets for more than 30 years, died of cancer Saturday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center.
She was 71 years old and lived in Manhattan.


GOODEN CONTRACT TALKS
LEAD: The Mets will open contract negotiations with Dwight Gooden today in West Palm Beach, Fla., with preliminary talks between James Neader, the pitcher's agent, and Al Harazin, senior vice president of the team.
The Mets have said that money will not be discussed until the length of the contract has been set, but they are expected to suggest one year in the vicinity of the $1.5 million that Gooden is being paid this year.

Topics of The Times; Banner Therapy in Moscow
LEAD: First-time travelers to Moscow or Leningrad are always struck by the banners.
Huge letters, usually red, are strung across the road or hung from windows proclaiming love of party and country: ''Glory to the Communist Party!'' ''Our Policy, the Policy of Peace!'' But recent visitors found a new variation on the upper-floor windows of the unfinished United States Embassy office building.

LEAD: Governor Cuomo, who has been criticized by some Democrats and political analysts as being disingenuous when he says he is not seeking the Presidency, has taken a number of steps recently to discourage talk of his candidacy, including rejecting out-of-state political appearances.

Piniella Wears New Uniform And It Is Suiting Him Fine
LEAD: The man behind the desk is talking on the telephone.
He is talking trade, or at least it seems that way to a visitor standing outside in the empty hallway at Yankee Stadium.
But the conversation is not about names; it is about numbers - about batting averages, home runs, runs batted in, age.


U.S. Oil Rigs Fall by 22
LEAD: The number of oil drilling rigs operating in the United States fell by 22, to 1,152, in the latest week but was still above the 952 working in the comparable week a year ago, Baker Hughes Inc. said today.


Tournament Is Expanded to 12 Teams
LEAD: The national collegiate hockey tournament will expand this year from its Northeastern and Midwestern base in what Herb Hammond, the Brown coach, called an ''important step for college hockey.''


Raymond D. Mindlin, Engineering Professor
LEAD: Raymond D. Mindlin, professor emeritus of civil engineering at Columbia University, died after a long illness Sunday at Mary Hitchcock Hospital in Hanover, N.H.
He was 81 years old and lived in Grantham, N.H.


Military Bank Accord Signed
LEAD: Merchants National Bank of Indianapolis has signed a $26.8 million contract with the Defense Department to provide banking services to American servicemen in West Germany, the Netherlands and Greece for at least two years.


Gorbachev Meeting Is Seen
LEAD: The Soviet Union tentatively plans to invite leading United States business executives to meet with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, when he visits Washington next month, a group promoting American and Soviet trade said today.

LEAD: Three defendants, after hearing a jury find them guilty of murder charges, pulled out hidden razor blades and a sharp piece of metal and battled with court officers in Brooklyn yesterday, leaving 11 of them injured, none seriously.

CUBANS IN 2D JAIL RIOT OVER FEARS OF DEPORTATION
LEAD: Cuban inmates fearing deportation seized hostages and set fires in a riot that left one person dead at a Federal prison in Atlanta yesterday, while a tense siege of other Cubans holding 28 hostages at a riot-scarred detention center in Louisiana continued for a third day.

LEAD: The owners of the landmark building that houses B. Altman's department store in midtown Manhattan announced plans yesterday for a multimillion-dollar renovation that would include adding six floors of office space to part of the structure.


NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 25, 1987
LEAD:  International A3-13  Agreement on an arms treaty banning medium- and shorter-range missiles was reached between the United States and the Soviet Union in negotaitions in Geneva.
The treaty is scheduled to be signed in two weeks in Washington.

ALL-AMERICA HONOR DOES NOT APPEASE OHIO STATE LINEBACKER
LEAD: Chris Spielman of Ohio State has always been an emotional football player, one who relied on extreme intensity more than physical prowess to become one of the best inside linebackers in college football.
But this last week has been an emotional roller coaster that has had too many turns even for Spielman.

Rock: Aztec Camera
LEAD: AZTEC CAMERA, a group led by the singer and songwriter Roddy Frame, brought a brisk, surprising show to the Ritz last Friday.
The fragile, introspective lyricism that has been such a fundamental ingredient in Mr.
Frame's recordings was overshadowed by slick, unsubtle pop-soul arrangements and relentless pacing.

Crash Near an Alaska Airport Leaves 17 Dead and 5 Injured
LEAD: A Ryan Air commuter plane crashed and skidded through a fence while trying to land, killing 17 people and injuring the four others aboard, the authorities said today.


Jacob Schulman, Accountant, 72
LEAD: Jacob Schulman, senior partner of the accounting firm of Jacob Schulman &amp; Co., died Monday at Albany Medical Center.
He was 72 years old and lived in Gloversville, N.Y.


Keeping Most Likely Dropouts in School
LEAD: For 95 dropout-prone students here, high school is in a hidden corner of a downtown department store and important lessons are as likely to come from a salesperson as from a teacher.


G.N.P. Rises 4.1%; Profits Up Sharply
LEAD: The economy expanded faster than had been thought in the months before the October stock market crash and corporate profits surged, the Commerce Department reported today.


WINE TALK
LEAD: WHAT is all the fuss over Burgundy?
According to an article in the Oct. 31 issue of The Wine Spectator, a paper for wine buffs, American consumers are boycotting Burgundy wines. ''Burgundy Boycott Is Working,'' the article's headline read.


Contras Give Cease-Fire Response to Papal Envoy
LEAD: Nicaraguan rebels delivered their first official response to President Daniel Ortega Saavedra's cease-fire plan today to the Papal Nuncio in Costa Rica, after two of their senior leaders were unable to fly to the Nicaraguan capital to hand over the document.

China Names Acting Prime Minister
LEAD: Li Peng, a 59-year-old Soviet-educated engineer, was named Acting Prime Minister of China today.
He succeeds Zhao Ziyang, who gave up the post to devote himself full time to his duties as head of China's 46-million-member Communist Party.

First Options Lays Off 130
LEAD: First Options of Chicago Inc., the nation's largest options clearing firm, has laid off about 130 employees or 10 percent of its staff, cut salaries and slashed bonuses.
The layoffs occurred late last week, affecting floor brokers, runners and clerks on the floor of the Chicago Board Options Exchange.

Thousands of Estates in New York Are Mismanaged, a Report Says
LEAD: The New York State Attorney General and the State Comptroller yesterday accused New York City's public administrators of ''significant deficiencies and questionable practices'' in handling the estates of people who die without wills.

LEAD: Prices of precious metals closed slightly lower yesterday, ending a brief rally.


Fruit Fly Quarantine Lifted
LEAD: The Agriculture Department has lifted an agricutural quarantine imposed in July to prevent the spread of Oriental fruit flies from parts of Los Angeles County and Orange County in California, the department said today.
Department officials said recent trapping surveys indicated that the areas were free of the flies, which can destroy fruit and vegitable crops.

Adele Miller, Advertising Executive, 91
LEAD: Adele Miller, who with her late husband, Samuel, founded the Miller Advertising Agency in 1919, died Monday of complications from Alzheimer's disease at Beth Israel Hospital.
She was 91 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: The World Bank, which has just laid off 10 percent of its staff in its deepest restructuring of the last two decades, is now putting out a ''help wanted'' sign to fill certain specialty posts, for example in environmental protection.
But, according to its president, the bank is having trouble filling vacancies.


Second Quake Hits California; Damage Slight
LEAD: A strong earthquake rocked residences and injured about two dozen people in Southern California near the Mexican border this morning, just hours after the desert region was hit by a comparable tremor Monday night.

Ben C. Birdsall, Retired Arizona Judge, 64
LEAD: Ben C. Birdsall, a retired judge who presided over two of Arizona's most publicized criminal cases, died Sunday of cancer.
He was 64 years old.


Stage:'Puta Vida Trilogy,' One-Act Plays by Povod
LEAD: IT isn't as easy as it once was for white middle-class theatergoers to get a quick fix of guilt, so there may well be a crying need for ''La Puta Vida Trilogy,'' the Reinaldo Povod bill of one-act plays at the Public Theater.
In the evening's prologue, a hostile young Hispanic monologuist (Michael Carmine) waves a knife at the audience, accuses us of hating ''spics,'' and threatens to commit a random murder, possibly in our privileged neighborhoods, if his ailing offstage mother is allowed to die.

LEAD: The National Enquirer, which spends between $15 million and $20 million a year to sustain and increase its 4.5 million circulation, has put that advertising assignment in the hands of D'Arcy Masius Benton &amp; Bowles, according to Patrick N. Linskey, the publisher.


Deaths of Unattended Children Spur Day Care Bills in Congress
LEAD: A year ago this month two Miami children, 3 and 4 years old, were left unattended at home while their mother worked.
They climbed into a clothes dryer with tumbling laundry, closed the door and burned to death.

The Stage Is Bare as Iran-Contra Hearings Slip Into History
LEAD: Staff members preparing to leave the darkened office from which the Senate inquiry into the Iran-contra affair was conducted.
Boxes of copies of the report, at right, stood in mute testimony to the far-ranging investigation that evoked much drama as it traced arms deals and ideals from the White House to Nicaragua by way of Iran, uncovering a cast of characters even a playwright would be tested to invent.


LIFE IN THE 30'S
LEAD: WHILE I was away on a business trip, my husband introduced prayer in the home.
I returned to find that the bedtime routine had been altered, that sandwiched between the drink of water and the hugs and kisses was a short conversation with the Almighty.
It even included the sign of the cross, although as performed by my children, the sign of the cross looks more like one of those fraternal lodge handshakes.


Major Contributor to Cuomo To Testify at a Bribery Trial
LEAD: A major contributor to Governor Cuomo's 1982 election campaign, who is also a law client of the Governor's son Andrew, will play a key role in a complicated conspiracy and bribery trial that began in Manhattan yesterday, a defense attorney said in his opening statement to the jury.


U.S. Hints It Will Ease Cuban Deportation Plan
LEAD: Reagan Administration officials today signaled a willingness to relent on sending some Cuban prisoners back to Cuba.


Economic Scene; Opportunities And Dangers
LEAD: DID Black Monday plunge the economy into a black hole, or did it just represent the bursting of a speculative bubble that has not seriously impaired the business outlook?

About New York; For Boat Owner, An Ill Wind On the Hudson
LEAD: There is a theory that the two happiest days in a man's life are the day he buys a boat and the day he sells it.
Doug Ashley got only the first satisfaction.
His vessel sank.
Then, as he tried to raise it, the Government towed it off to be burned.


William King, Photographer, 48
LEAD: William King, a fashion photographer, died of AIDS on Thursday at Beth Israel Hospital.
He was 48 years old and lived in Manhattan and Paris.


Real Estate; Ad Firms' West Side Migration
LEAD: FOR decades advertising agencies were a mainstay in the office towers on the East Side of midtown Manhattan.


Corrections
LEAD: A report in the Company Briefs column of Business Day yesterday incorrectly described an acquisition involving the Adams-Russell Company and the Cablevision Systems Corporation.
Cablevision is acquiring Adams-Russell.


Gooden's Request Rejected by Mets
LEAD: The Mets opened contract talks with Dwight Gooden yesterday and immediately ruled out any long-term deal at this time.
They insisted on a one-year contract for next season but left the door open for negotiating a long-term contract after 1988.


License Is Suspended At Dorrian's Red Hand
LEAD: The New York State Liquor Authority voted yesterday to suspend the liquor license of an Upper East Side bar, Dorrian's Red Hand Restaurant, for 10 days and fine its owner $1,000 for serving alcohol to minors.


Antiques Shops Open With Period Buffet
LEAD: EDIBLE art objects in 18th-century French style were the center of attraction last week at a gala cocktail party for the opening of the Place des Antiquaires.


Film: 'Three Men and a Baby'
LEAD: IT'S even clearer in the big, splashy, good-humored American version of ''Three Men and a Baby'' that it was in the French original (entitled ''Three Men and a Cradle'') that this story is about four babies, not just one.
Aside from the infant girl left on their doorstep, the three fun-loving bachelors who grudgingly adopt her are children too.


Holiday Tomorrow
LEAD:  Thanksgiving is tomorrow and closings vary.
Following are holiday schedules.
NEW YORK  Parade: Begins at 9 A.M. at 77th Street and Central Park West.
Proceeds down Central Park West to Columbus Circle and then down Broadway to 34th Street.
Parking: Sunday rules in effect.

Basic Costs Up For Cable Use
LEAD: Deregulation of cable television rates has resulted in higher prices for basic service and a small drop in the cost of premium channels, an industry group survey has shown.

LEAD: The procedures for hiring teachers for the New York City public schools are so archaic and bureaucratic that only a handful of new teachers started in the classroom last year fully licensed, according to a report by a civic group that monitors education.

WASHINGTON TALK: Briefing; Senator Smoke
LEAD: Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, the top Republican on the Budget Committee, used to vow with each passing budget that he would give up smoking.
He hasn't yet, and during the four weeks of tense negotiations that led to the budget-cutting compromise last Friday, he blew his smoke into a tiny machine designed to suck up nasty fumes.

INSIDE
LEAD:  The Education Page


Dollar Falls on Report of Deficit Plan Criticism
LEAD: The dollar ended lower in active New York trading yesterday after a West German central banker reportedly said the deficit-reduction plan reached Friday fell far short of American commitments to its trading partners.


EATING WELL
LEAD: TOMORROW'S Thanksgiving turkey could contain more than the bread stuffing with onions and herbs.
It could also have salmonella, a microbiological contamination that can be hazardous but is easily rendered harmless through sound food-handling methods and cooking techniques.


Of Time and Professors And the Cost of College
LEAD: Higher education in this country is a $124-billion-a-year industry built around the free exchange of ideas.
But there is one idea, frequently discussed by executives of other large industries, that is rarely debated in faculty clubs.
That is productivity.


In Italy, Walnuts Are Prized by Home Cooks
LEAD: Each fall, the harvesting of walnuts generates nearly as much excitement among Italians as the hunt for wild porcini mushrooms.


End of an Era Nears
LEAD: A Sky Crane helicopter dropping electronic gear onto the Ambrose Light tower off New Jersey.
The light, which has been manned for 164 years, will be run by computer starting in January. (Ralph Ginzburg)


Irving Levitas Is Dead; Jewish History Scholar
LEAD: Irving Levitas, a scholar and lecturer in Jewish history, died yesterday of lung cancer at the Rosary Hill Home in Hawthorne, N.Y.
He was 77 years old and lived in Yonkers.


Koch Asks Agencies to Prepare Budget Cuts
LEAD: Citing the recent stock market collapse and fears of a slowdown in the national economy, Mayor Koch yesterday asked the heads of all city agencies to propose budget cuts for the next fiscal year.

LEAD: The Bell Atlantic Corporation, wrapping up an extensive restructuring, named Raymond W. Smith yesterday to the newly created positions of president and chief operating officer and Philip A. Campbell as vice chairman and chief financial officer.

LEAD: THE 1987 Beaujolais nouveau, a sprightly potion so tantalizingly scented that it deserves to be sold at perfume counters, is gushing all over the United States.


Judge Prohibits News Cameras At Murder Trial
LEAD: The judge in the Howard Beach trial yesterday said he would not allow television and still cameras at the trial when an experimental state program permitting cameras at trial begins next Tuesday.


First Chicago In Acquisition
LEAD: To strengthen its position in consumer banking, the First Chicago Corporation said today that it had signed a letter to acquire the Gary-Wheaton Corporation for $136.4 million in First Chicago common stock.

Horner May Return
LEAD: Bob Horner, the former Atlanta Braves slugger who played baseball in Japan this year, might be coming home next season.
The 30-year-old Horner said on Monday that he has been offered a contract to return to the Braves and that he no longer wants to play in the Japanese league. ''You grow up with an idea of what baseball should be,'' he said.

Queens Man Guilty In the 1986 Slaying Of a Rookie Officer
LEAD: A 34-year-old man described by the police as a low-level drug dealer was convicted yesterday of killing a rookie police officer in a gun battle in Queens last year.


RECORDS AT THE MET DISPROVE CHARGE OF ACQUIRING 5 PAINTINGS IMPROPERLY
LEAD: Officials of the Metropolitan Museum of Art yesterday disproved a suggestion that the museum illicitly acquired five paintings that had been stolen by the Nazis in World War II.
The museum acknowledged that one of the paintings had once been stolen by Nazis, but said it had legally and properly acquired that painting and two others from the rightful owners and had never owned the remaining two at all.

Duro-Test Resists Tender Offer
LEAD: The Duro-Test Corporation has urged shareholders not to tender shares to a group led by Prof.
William P. Lyons of Yale University.
The light-bulb maker, based in North Bergen, N.J., said a $14 a share offer from the TCA Acquisition Corporation, a subsidiary of TCA-IV Limited Partnership that is headed by the professor, was inadequate.


St. Joe Gold Buyout
LEAD: The holding company of the Australian businessman Alan Bond said it intended to take the St.
Joe Gold Corporation private by buying the three million shares it does not already own for $17 each.
Dallhold Investments Proprietary Ltd. now owns about 90.3 percent of St.
Joe Gold's common stock.


Woman Dies in Ansonia Fire
LEAD: A 91-year-old resident of the Ansonia Hotel died in a fire in her apartment last night, according to authorities.
The woman, identified as Susan Breisach, was a long-time resident of the landmark building at 2107 Broadway, between 73d and 74th Streets.

LEAD: An article yesterday about the Metropolitan Museum of Art discussed paintings looted by the Nazis during World War II and strongly suggested that the museum had obtained some of them illicitly.
The suggestion - based on information provided by a Rutgers University professor - was wrong.

LEAD: James Cheeks, president of Howard University, says that the school is going to sue the National Collegiate Athletic Association because it was passed over for postseason play despite having the second-best record in Division I-AA football.

Centennial of Edison Laboratory Honors the Man Behind the Machines
LEAD: Michael Sloane and his sister, Lizabeth Sloane Taraskewicz, great-grandchildren of Thomas A. Edison, with one of the inventor's early phonographs at laboratory he built in West Orange, N.J.
Ceremonies marked the 100th anniversary of the research center where Edison not only perfected the phonograph and invented the motion picture camera, but instituted the concept of research and development.

MAPPING OUT ETHNIC MENUS
LEAD: THE savory ingredients of New York's melting pot have been assembled in a new book called ''The Food Lover's Guide to the Real New York'' by Myra Alperson and Mark Clifford (Prentice Hall Press, $12.95).
This borough-by-borough guide explores the ethnic neighborhoods from the venerable Lower East Side of Manhattan to a newly established pocket of Cambodian settlements in the Bronx.

LEAD: Absolut Vodka and TBWA Advertising, the Swedish company's New York ad agency, are relying on technology to strike the right note with their Christmas magazine advertising.
Readers of New York magazine who open Absolut's two-page Christmas display this week will be greeted - some might say assaulted - by tinny-sounding but unmistakable fragments of
