Karpov Evens the Score
LEAD: Gary Kasparov lost the 16th game of his world championship chess match in Seville, Spain, yesterday and let Anatoly Karpov get back into contention.


LEVER'S 14 ASSISTS HELP DEFEAT NETS
LEAD: Lafayette Lever scored 21 points and had 13 rebounds and 14 assists tonight as the Denver Nuggets routed the New Jersey Nets, 132-104.


Panama Journal; A Justice Is Slain: Did Regime Turn a Blind Eye?
LEAD: The mysterious shooting death of a Supreme Court Justice here has become a cause celebre that has raised questions about the ability of a military Government already accused of political assassination, election rigging and vast corruption to administer justice impartially.

Jazz: Jobim and Bossa Nova
LEAD: ANTONIO CARLOS JOBIM, the composer who virtually invented the bossa nova, led an auspicious gathering of Brazilian pop musicians at Avery Fisher Hall on Monday evening.
When first planned, the concert, celebrating the 10th anniversary of the Brazilian Cultural Foundation, was to have reunited the composer with the tenor saxophonist Stan Getz, who was instrumental in popularizing the bossa nova in the United States 25 years ago.


Connecticut Governor Leaves Hospital
LEAD: Gov.
William A. O'Neill as he left St.
Francis Hospital in Hartford.
He had been there since Nov. 15 when he was admitted with a 103-degree fever.
He was diagnosed as having diverticulitis, an inflammation of small pockets protruding from the side of the colon.
Colon polyps were also discovered.
He said he would remain on antibiotics before making arrangements to have the polyps removed, probably in a month.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  Basketball  Soviet Team Loses in Finale: Winston Bennett sank two free throws with 17 seconds left last night to lift Kentucky to a 75-72 victory over the Soviet National team in Lexington.
The loss marked the end of a 10-game tour by the Russians, who compiled a 6-4 mark against American college teams.

LEAD: Everybody loves a good David and Goliath story, so they should doubly love the story of Our Saviour Lutheran High School.

LEAD: Last Saturday was a busy day for sports on television, and according to Arbitron Ratings of 13 metered markets, these were the five highest- rated sports programs for the day, with network, rating and share (the rating is a percentage of households with televisions tuned into a program and the share is the percentage of households with televisions in use tuned in): 1 - Nov.


Market Place; High Returns Of Junk Bonds
LEAD: ARE junk bonds a better deal than ever?
The author of a new study on the high-yield securities thinks so.

AIDS CHIEF WEIGHS QUITTING U.S. POST
LEAD: Dr.
Robert C. Gallo, a leading Federal AIDS researcher, today confirmed reports that he was exploring the possibility of leaving the Government to establish a virus research laboratory at an academic center with industry backing.


PENTAGON PLANS FIRST LASER TEST IN SPACE IN 1990'S
LEAD: Defense Department officials said today that they planned to conduct the first test of a laser weapon in space in the early 1990's, as part of one of the costliest and probably most disputed experiments in the Reagan Administration's effort to build a defense against nuclear missiles.

5 ARE CONVICTED IN TERROR SCHEME
LEAD: A Federal jury convicted five members of El Rukns street gang today of conspiring to blow up airplanes and government buildings in hopes of gaining up to $2.5 million from Libya.


76ers Sign King
LEAD: The Philadelphia 76ers signed Albert King, the free-agent guard who last played for the Nets, to a two-year contract yesterday.
The Nets, who agreed not to exercise their right of first refusal, received a second-round draft selection in 1988 and a conditional second-round choice in 1990 from the 76ers.


ACCORD IS REACHED ON MISSILE TREATY BY U.S. AND SOVIET
LEAD: The United States and the Soviet Union said today that they had resolved their remaining differences over a new treaty banning medium- and shorter-range missiles that President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev are due to sign in Washington in two weeks.


Latest Quakes Differed From One at Los Angeles
LEAD: The two earthquakes that shook southern California late Monday and early yesterday differed basically in nature from the quake that struck the Los Angeles area on Oct. 1, scientists believe.

Recital: Elena Obraztsova, Mezzo
LEAD: ONLY when the official part of her program was done and she had begun the encores did Elena Obraztsova give her fans at Carnegie Hall what they most wanted.
Singing ''O mio babbino caro'' from ''Gianni Schicchi,'' ''Voi lo sapete'' from ''Cavalleria Rusticana'' and the Habanera from ''Carmen,'' the Russian mezzo-soprano provided the kind of visceral, flamboyant vocalism that she had kept pretty much under wraps during the bulk of her recital


Concert: Villa-Lobos's 'Magdalena'
LEAD: SIFTING through the detritus of history in hopes of turning up neglected masterpieces is an activity for which only congenital optimists need apply.
The success rate is guaranteed to be between low and nil.
However, even the slimmest hope of excavating a deserving old work is often enough to rally a dedicated band of musical archeologists.


Smoking Ban in Pittsburgh
LEAD: The City Council approved a bill Monday to ban or restrict cigarette smoking in restaurants, offices and public buildings.
Mayor Richard Caliguiri, who as a Councilman 12 years ago failed to win passage of a similar bill, said he would sign the measure into law.


A Feeling Of Betrayal For Cubans
LEAD: Expecting that her husband would soon be freed from the Federal detention center here, Marsha Martinez had started preparing to move to this small isolated town in central Louisiana.


Odorless Garlic: Admiration Isn't Universal
LEAD: Two Japanese companies say they have a method of treating garlic so it does not linger on the breath, but some domestic growers say they are not impressed.





61 Groups given Hunger Aid
LEAD: A $3.8 million final installment of money raised by the cross-country ''Hands Across America'' charity drive has been distributed to 61 groups aiding the hungry and homeless in 28 states and the District of Columbia, USA for Af-rica, the parent foundation, said Mon-day.
The money was raised in the May 25, 1986, Hands Across America drive in which an estimated six million peo-ple joined hands in symbolic support of the nation's hungry and homeless.

Hyundai Duty Set by Canada
LEAD: Cars made by South Korea's Hyundai Motor Company are being dumped in Canada at unfairly low prices, Canada's Revenue and Customs Department said today in a preliminary ruling that puts an import duty on future imports.
A department spokesman said that at current prices the duty would result in a 36 percent price increase on the cars.

New Security Measures Planned After Court Melee
LEAD: New York City correction officials said yesterday that they were planning additional security measures for inmates brought to court as a result of a melee in Brooklyn Monday during which three prisoners took out hidden razor blades and a makeship knife and injured 11 court officers.

Arab Novelist Falls in Love With French
LEAD: Tahar Ben Jelloun approves of polygamy - with languages, not women, he hastens to add. ''My wife is Arabic,'' the 43-year-old Moroccan novelist explained, ''and my mistress is French, and I maintain a relationship of betrayal with both of them.''


WASHINGTON TALK: Interior Department; At the Wildlife Service, an Extinction With Irony
LEAD: The Office of Endangered Species has gone the way of the dusky seaside sparrow and the Sampson's pearly mussel.
Like six of the species that it was created to protect in 1973, it has become extinct.

LEAD: After a long manhunt, the Japanese police have arrested a leader of the Japanese Red Army, the terrorist group responsible for the massacre at Lod Airport near Tel Aviv in 1972.

WASHINGTON TALK: BRIEFING
LEAD: No Joke For the last several years, creators of some of the best-known comic strips have marked Thanksgiving Day by giving those strips a serious message about people who are hungry.
The effort moved off the funny pages today, with a number of prominent editorial cartoonists using their spots on the nation's editorial pages to deliver a Thanksgiving message about the homeless.

Dr. Edgar Berman Is Dead at 68; Writer and Humphrey Confidant

He was 68 years old.

LEAD: Two people were killed Tuesday in separate accidents involving Amtrak trains in Massachusetts and the body of a tow-truck driver was recovered in Arkansas after his vehicle was struck by a train.
In Florida, an Amtrak passenger train struck a tractor-trailer snagged on the tracks yesterday, slightly injuring 24 people.

G.M. Discounts
LEAD: Three divisions of the General Motors Corporation announced new buyer incentive programs, with discounts ranging from $550 to $900 on selected models.
The Pontiac division said buyers of Pontiac 6000's, Firebirds, Fieros, Safari wagons and Bonnevilles may choose either free air-conditioning or a $600 cash allowance; buyers of Pontiac Grand Ams qualify for discounts of $550 to $775, depending on the options package.


Connecticut Official To Challenge Weicker
LEAD: State Attorney General Joseph I. Lieberman, a Democrat, said today that he would run for the United States Senate seat now held by Lowell P. Weicker Jr.
Mr.
Lieberman did not formally declare his candidacy, saying he would do that early next year.
Instead, he announced the formation of a committee that will let him start raising funds for the 1988 campaign.

Comings and Goings
LEAD: Terry Bross, a 6-foot-9-inch senior center for St.
John's, suffered a ligament sprain of his right ankle during practice Monday and will be sidelined for a minimum of three weeks.
Bross started 29 games last season, averaging 4.2 points and 3.6 rebounds per game. . . .
The Air Force Academy has suspended indefinitely three of its basketball players - Eric Kjome, a junior forward; Chad Kimble, a junior center, and Jeff Bowling, a sophomore guard - for what Coach Reggie Minton called internal reasons.

LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the United States and its allies had decided to stop deployment of American missiles in Europe as soon as a Soviet-American treaty is signed in two weeks in Washington.


CBS Gives Mornings Another Try
LEAD: The last time around, there was a golden retriever named Daisy, a fake country kitchen set with a fireplace, a ''personals'' dating match-up service, a stand-up comic and a co-host whose persona was described by one network executive as that of the wacky suburban wife who pushes someone in the pool at a party.


Bogota Moves Drug Suspect
LEAD: A reputed drug baron, Jorge Luis Ochoa, was secretly transferred from one army barracks to another on Tuesday night for fear that his lieutenants might try to help him escape, the Colombian press said.
Since his capture on Saturday, the Colombian police say they have detected the arrival in Bogota of a large number of people linked to the Medellin cartel said to be responsible for 80 percent of the cocaine exported from Colombia.

Sudan Seeks Write-Off
LEAD: The Sudan said today that it had called on creditors to write off foreign loans or ease repayment terms in a new bid to reduce its $11 billion debt and a growing threat of mass starvation.
Finance Minister Beshir Umar Muhammad said the impoverished African nation, which has been unable to meet debt repayments in full since the early 1980's, wanted all loans by foreign governments canceled.

Avram Weiss Plays Handel, Grieg and Bach
LEAD: The first notes of Avram Weiss's violin recital at Merkin Concert Hall Sunday evening - the vaulting arpeggio that opens Handel's familiar D major sonata - bespoke musical confidence and authority, and these qualities stayed with him through the evening, even though it quickly became apparent that technical problems would limit his expression.

Corrections
LEAD: An article from Denver yesterday about President Reagan's drive to win Senate approval for a treaty banning medium- and shorter-range nuclear missiles misstated the scope of the treaty.
It would ban all such weapons in the American and Soviet arsenals, not just those based in Europe.


U.S. Panel Removes Obstacle to Nuclear Plant
LEAD: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission today voted 4 to 1 to remove a major obstacle to the preliminary licensing of the Seabrook nuclear plant in New Hampshire.


U.S. Envoy Assails Cuba on Rights at U.N.
LEAD: The American chief delegate to the United Nations told the Security Council today that riots by Cuban prisoners were an ''action of despair'' that described ''louder than any words'' the poor human rights situation in Cuba.


Chess Game Adjourned; Draw Likely
LEAD: The 17th game of the world chess championship between Gary Kasparov and the challenger, Anatoly Karpov, was adjourned today after 42 moves.


Ultrasound Held to Detect Down's Syndrome
LEAD: Doctors say they have found a way to use ultrasound tests to spot fetuses with Down's syndrome.
But other experts warned that the technique should still be considered experimental.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Q. I once saw an advertisement for door hinges that raise the door slightly as it opens so that it won't rub against carpeting or where there is weatherstripping along the bottom edge.
Can you tell me where to find these hinges?
A.
You should be able to find them in some of the better hardware stores and lumberyards.

His transition on the ice has been quietly fluent.

COMPANY BRIEFS
LEAD: *
Barnett Banks Inc., Jacksonville, Fla., said it had extended its $70-a-share tender offer for the common shares of First Fulton Bancshares Inc. through Jan. 8.


PERSONAL HEALTH
LEAD: A sleekly dressed woman in her 30's thought it odd when the physician she consulted about her frequent headaches asked if she usually tried to hold in her stomach.
The resulting muscular tension, he told her, could cause the pain in her head.
She has since allowed herself to show a little belly and, much to her surprise, has been virtually headache-free.


Philippine Typhoon Devastates Province; Toll Is Put at 1,600
LEAD: A typhoon struck the main Philippine island today, and a Roman Catholic priest said that local authorities and church groups put the number of dead at 1,600 in the province hit hardest.

Jazz: Tribute to Lopez
LEAD: ISRAEL (CACHAO) LOPEZ made lasting contributions to Latin music beginning in the late 1930's, when he helped introduce the hot Afro-Cuban rhythms of the mambo into the more urbane dance idiom known as the danzon.


Fire Halts Service at Grand Central
LEAD: Stranded commuters resting on an idle escalator last night as they waited for train service to resume out of Grand Central Terminal.
A track fire beneath Park Avenue interrupted Metro-North and Amtrak service for more than two hours during the evening rush hour.

The Stage: 'Memories,' A Comedy
LEAD: PEARL CLEAGE'S ''Come and Get These Memories,'' which opens the repertory season of the Billie Holiday Theater in Brooklyn, is a type of comedy once popular in theater (it still is on television), in which the happy ending is everything, never mind how you get there.
This one is much less than the sum of its parts, and when it works, it does so only because director and cast concentrate on the characters and treat the muddle of incident as a distraction best ignored when it can be.


Ex-Manhattan,inc. Aide Joining Alfred A. Knopf
LEAD: Jane Amsterdam, a founding editor of Manhattan,inc., will join Alfred A. Knopf as a senior editor, according to an announcement yesterday from Sonny Mehta, president of Knopf.

Chicago's Mayor Washington Dies After a Heart Attack in His Office
LEAD: Harold Washington, the first black Mayor of Chicago, the nation's third largest city, died today of a heart attack.
He was 65 years old.


Jog Away Jet Lag? Maybe?
LEAD: Humans suffering from jet lag, their nervous systems battered by the unreasonable sunlight of a new time zone, may want to consider the recent experience of 20 hamsters at the University of Toronto.
A single three-hour round of exercise - running on a wheel in a cage - allowed hamsters to adjust to a severe case of jet lag surprisingly fast, within a day and a half.


Neediest Cases Fund Aids Woman's Fight
LEAD: Sometimes the public assistance checks did not come, the young mother remembered, and sometimes her children did not eat.


U.S. Judge Steps Aside In P.L.O. Office Case
LEAD: Citing a possible conflict of interest, Federal District Judge Stanley Sporkin today stepped down from a case on whether the Government should be allowed to close an information office for the Palestine Liberation Organization here because the organizastion advocates terrorism.


ARCHITECT TRIES ON NEW SHOES
LEAD: AT a recent lecture he delivered, the Princeton architect Michael Graves found that his shoes were attracting more than their share of interest.
Not surprising, since Mr.
Graves is appearing in an advertisement citing ''the significance of classic structures,'' in which footwear by the Dexter Shoe Company of West Newton, Mass., is paired with the architect's post-modernist ideas.


Incomes Rose 1.7% In October
LEAD: A surge in farm subsidy payments helped drive Americans' personal incomes up 1.7 percent in October, the Commerce Department said today.

Investigation Continues
LEAD: The Southwest Conference is investigating reports that Randy Thornton, a safety for the University of Houston, played in two football games this month while he was ineligible.
Fred Jacoby, the conference commissioner, said yesterday that he could not say whether Houston would have to forfeit victories over the University of Texas and Temple University because of Thornton's possibly illegal participation.

LEAD: Is it possible to imagine a North Korea whose leaders admit their economic difficulties, acknowledge South Korea's successes and disavow the dream of reuniting the peninsula under their strange brand of Communism?
That's the remarkable portrait painted by Selig Harrison, an American writer, in The New York Times last Sunday, after a recent stay in


Irish Aid Funds for Ethiopia
LEAD: Ireland announced today that it would provide $375,000 in emergency aid for Ethiopia.
The Irish Foreign Ministry said the funds would be chaneled through Red Cross and United Nations relief agencies. ''Indications are that the situation could be as bad as in the 1984-1985 famine when an estimated one million people died,'' it said.

ASHES OF GARBAGE ARE FOUND TOXIC
LEAD: Ashes from incinerated garbage contain significant amounts of lead, cadmium, dioxin and other toxic substances that can threaten health and the environment, according to a report prepared for the Environmental Protection Agency.


HOME IMPROVEMENT
LEAD: WOBBLY chairs are more than just annoying; a weakened chair can lead to accidents.
Most wobbly chairs have broken glue joints.
Either the glue holding the pieces together has deteriorated with age, or so much strain has been placed on the glue that the seam it forms between the pieces fractures.

Korea in Airline Talks
LEAD: South Korea's Transport Ministry said today that it had held talks with several airlines that want to start service here before the 1988 Seoul Olympics.
The interested airlines include British Airways, Air Canada and Dragon Air, which is based in Hong Kong, the officials said.
In addition, All Nippon Airways of Japan, Gulf Air of the United Arab Emirates and Air-India are conducting studies on service to Seoul, the officials said.

Moscow Journal; At Co-op Cafe, More From Lenin Than Escoffier
LEAD: For years Andrei Anatolyevich Fyodorov could only fantasize beyond the steam tables of the state restaurant he ran, directing a staff of 380 workers through a vast, noisy operation.
He was yearning, he says, for the comforts of crisp napery, subtle ambiance and the ''dirty capitalist principles'' he now fondly emulates.

LEAD: The Bell &amp; Howell Company said yesterday that it had received an all-cash takeover offer of $602 million, or $64 a share, from a group led by the Texas investor Robert M. Bass and several key Bell &amp; Howell executives, including Gerald E. Schultz, the president and chief executive.

LEAD: The food in the snack bar sold out, not to mention the beer.
The power failed, and the passengers sat in darkness.

Holly Reconsiders
LEAD: The Holly Sugar Corporation, after agreeing to a merger proposal from an investor group before the stock market's plunge, said it was discussing renegotiating terms of the $95-a-share, or $106.4 million, deal.
Last month, Holly, based in Colorado Springs, had rejected a proposal from Plum Associates to lower the price of the acquisition to $85 a share in light of stock market volatility.

LEAD: ARTHUR ANDERSSON faced a formidable challenge when he and Charles Moore bought their sloped, woody site in Austin, Tex.

There were also ''some unwritten rules,'' said Mr.
Andersson, who runs Mr.
Moore's Austin studio.


PARENT &amp; CHILD
LEAD: NORMAN ROCKWELL'S famous painting of a Thanksgiving dinner makes a lot of children uncomfortable.

LEAD: Tamil rebels said today that they killed 12 Indian soldiers in a major clash in eastern Sri Lanka, while officials said 9 militants had died.

LEAD: Bob Knight received a standing ovation from 2,700 Indiana University basketball boosters yesterday after saying he was wrong to pull his team off the floor in an exhibition game against the Soviet Union last Saturday.
The Indiana coach did not mention the reprimand issued by the university the day before, nor was he asked about it when he took questions from the audience.

LEAD: A New York court issued a ruling yesterday that could mean a return to the big-boat era in America's Cup yacht racing and force the next series to be held in 1988, three years earlier than expected.

LEAD: The John Fluke Manufacturing Company, which makes electronic test and measurement instruments, said yesterday that George Winn had been named chief executive.

A DOCTOR TREATS ANTIQUE RADIOS

Thomashow is a psychiatrist who is also an artist, and his latest project has a twofold purpose.

Critic's Notebook; Making the Best of Less at the Met
LEAD: THE casting problems that have vexed the Metropolitan Opera this season did not arise in an instant and are not likely to be solved without pain in the foreseeable future.
Most are not unique to the Met.
They demand hard thought from all who hope to pass on opera's traditions to the 21st century with some preservation of standards.

LEAD: Amid rising criticism of the leadership of the New York City schools, the president of the Board of Education and two board members called yesterday for the abolition of the board on which they sit.

Rangers Are in Control As They Defeat Leafs

In the course of winning just twice in their previous 12 games, they had rarely been in charge of any contest.
Last night at the Garden, however, a sense of composure characterized their play against the Toronto Maple Leafs and helped them put together their first two-game winning streak after more than a month of unhappiness and, at least in the standings, regression.

County Ordered to Pay For Prisoner Abortions

Bilson and Nelson In Early-Music Series
LEAD: The ghost of ''early music'' as a semi-amateur activity descended now and then at the sometimes fine concert in Merkin Concert Hall's ''On Original Instruments'' series Monday evening.
In the last section of Schubert's ''Shepherd on the Rock,'' Malcolm Bilson hit a left handful of wrong notes on his replica of an 1815 Dulcken piano, Judith Nelson hit a tentative sounding high note and looked uncomfortable about it, and Lawrence McDonald flubbed the final flourish on his early 19th century clarinet.

LEAD: C. Gordon Lamude, a lawyer, died of bronchial pneumonia Saturday at Community Hospital in Glen Cove, L.I.

2 Killed by Tornado in Texas
LEAD: Two people were killed and two others were injured by a tornado that swept across a rural area of the central Texas coast today, ripping the roofs off houses, tearing apart trees and pushing cars off roads.
Officials said a 10-year-old girl and a 23-year-old woman died when the tornado struck a mobile home about six miles east of Bay City.

Prices Up in Europe
LEAD: Consumer prices in the European Community jumped five-tenths of 1 percent in October, pushing the annual inflation rate to a provisional 3.4 percent, its highest since June 1986.
The community's annual inflation rate is below the 4.5 percent rate of the United States but well above Japan's rate of 1.6 percent.

WEEKENDER GUIDE
LEAD:  Friday  ARBOREAL CHORALE


Grief and Politics Mingle in Chicago
LEAD: At Thanksgiving Day church services and prayer vigils today, Chicago mourned the death of Mayor Harold Washington, even as his longtime supporters and politicial rivals quietly began positioning themselves for the battle over his succession.


Eyewitness Is Disputed On Alaska Air Crash
LEAD: Disputing a witness' account, investigators today said the landing gear appeared to have been down on a commuter plane that crashed short of a runway here, killing 18 people and injuring three.

Reason to Be Thankful
LEAD: Marty Lyons spent today with the family of the Jets' equipment manager, Bill Hampton.
But the big defensive lineman said he didn't mind being apart from his family.
He was glad they were able to have a Thanksgiving celebration at all.


Art: Alison Wilding, Sculptor, at the Modern
LEAD: THE first British artist to be included in the Museum of Modern Art's continuing ''Projects'' series is a 39-year-old sculptor called Alison Wilding.
Though she was shown in 1983 and 1986 at the Salvatore Ala Gallery in New York, this is her first solo appearance in an American museum.
In its thoughtful, reticent, nuanced and strikingly individual way, it is a great success.

Texas A&amp;M Wins And Goes to Cotton
LEAD: A freshman quarterback for Texas A&amp;M, Bucky Richardson, came off the bench tonight to score the winning touchdown with 4 minutes 33 seconds to play in a 20-13 victory over Texas that gave the Aggies their third straight Southwest Conference title and the host berth in the Cotton Bowl.


Syria-Based Group Says It Staged Israel Raid
LEAD: A Syrian-based Palestinian guerrilla group took responsibility today for an attack on Israeli Army positions by two Palestinian guerrillas flying motorized hang gliders.


WASHINGTON TALK: Veterans' Affairs; War of Words Over the New V.A.
LEAD: Particularly among conservatives, who remember fondly when President Reagan strode into office promising to deflate what he deemed a bloated Federal bureaucracy, the question echoes: How can one justify elevating the Veterans Administration to Cabinet status?


EMBARGO STRAINS IRAN FINANCIALLY
LEAD: A tightening embargo on purchases of Iranian oil by the United States, France and to some extent Japan has been choking Teheran's exports and straining its financial lifeline in recent weeks.

And on Wednesday night, ''La Sonnambula'' acquired a nearly all-new cast at the top when Carlo Merlo, Heather Watts and Otto Neubert appeared for the first time, respectively, as the Poet, the Sleepwalker and the

Sri Lanka Emergency Stays
LEAD: Sri Lanka's Parliament voted today to extend the state of emergency for a further month as Indian troops continued their drive to disarm Tamil guerrillas in northern and eastern areas.
Members supported the extension after Acting Parliamentary Affairs Minister M. D. Premaratne said political assassinations were on the increase in the south and rebel violence still flared in Tamil-dominated areas.

LEAD: The fight between Congress and the Administration is trickier even than it seems.
Modest last-minute budget compromise isn't yet assured of adoption.

EAST BERLIN RAIDS STAGED ON CHURCH
LEAD: East German security agents, making raids on unofficial Christian advocates, detained at least 21 people and broke into the homes of several others in a three-day crackdown, church people said today.

Advertising;
LEAD: John Emmerling Inc. has been named the agency for Holsten Bier, a beer that Mr.
Emmerling calls ''the Budweiser of West Germany.'' He said the client was planning to spend more than $1 million for advertising.
At first it will all be in print - magazines probably - but before the end of the year there could be some dabbling in radio.


2 Salvador Rebels Threatened
LEAD: Two senior Salvadoran rebel civilian leaders said today that they had been threatened with death by telephone callers this morning.

LEAD: Responding to a published report of merger talks between Chiat/Day and Tatham-Laird &amp; Kudner, of Chicago, Robert Wolf, president and chief executive of Chiat/Day's Los Angeles office, said that get-acquainted conversations had indeed been held after the competition for the Nissan account that Chiat-Day won.


2 Youths Quit School in S.A.T. Tampering
LEAD: Two students withdrew from a private boys academy after admitting that they had broken into a school and opened sealed copies of a college entrance exam the day before it was to be administered, officials said today.


Japan Steps Up Security After Arrest of Terrorist
LEAD: The Japanese police intensified security for the imperial family and other prominent figures today after the arrest this week of a leader of the Japanese Red Army.


Vandals Hit Church And Country Club
LEAD: Satanic symbols were spray-painted on a church, and anti-Semitic slurs were painted on the walls of a country club in unrelated incidents in the last week, Nassau County police said yesterday.

Wrong Assumption on Abusers and Social Class

Cruise Missile Launched
LEAD: An Air Force B-1B bomber has successfully launched a cruise missile for the first time, the Pentagon said Wednesday.
In the test, conducted Tuesday at the Utah Test Range outside Salt Lake City, the plane fired the weapon from its bomb bay while flying at low altitude.
The missile's warhead had been removed and replaced with an instrument test package.


Question To a Judge
LEAD: I used to see Joyce Brown almost every day but I never knew her name.
She would be lying huddled on the sidewalk on Second Avenue, across the street from my apartment.
I would look at her, stop sometimes, but usually just walk on, restless in my mind about what it told about the city, about the woman, about myself, that a person could lie amid the rubbish of the street and her own filth, day after day, night after night, for a full year, and nothing done.


New Face: James Wilby; The Vision of a Gay Hero
LEAD: E.M.
FORSTER'S vision of the hero for his novel of homosexual love was a man quite unlike himself: ''someone handsome, healthy, bodily attractive, mentally torpid and rather a snob.'' Except for the ''mentally torpid,'' James Wilby, the relative unknown who plays the title role in the movie adapted from Forster's ''Maurice,'' fits the description to a T.

Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts.
They know who the real Duke was.

L.I. School District Strives to Integrate
LEAD: Education officials here have approved magnet programs for three high schools in an effort to satisfy the state's demands to integrate the schools while keeping local control over the suburban district.


Money Fund Assets Dip
LEAD: Assets of the nation's 411 money market mutual funds decreased $665.2 million, to $262.05 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
Assets of the 111 institutional funds were down $224.3 million, to $74.15 billion.
Assets of the 207 general purpose funds fell $256.8 million, to $78.86 billion.


A Deal to Release Prison Hostages In Atlanta Collapses at Deadline
LEAD: A tentative agreement negotiated by three prominent Cuban-Americans to release some of the 94 hostages being held at the Federal Penitentiary here was reached Thursday night but fell apart shortly after midnight.


Dawkins Traded Again
LEAD: For the second time in less than two months, Darryl Dawkins, who was with the Nets before the season began, has been traded.
The Utah Jazz sent Dawkins to the Detroit Pistons yesterday for second-round draft picks in 1988 and 1990 and an undisclosed amount of cash.


Economic Scene; Taking a Look At P/E Ratios
LEAD: THE wild swings in the stock market last month, with a threatened ''meltdown'' on Black Monday and Terrible Tuesday, force attention to the question of what can be done to prevent crisis-born pessimism from jeopardizing the economy's real growth.


Closings for the Holiday
LEAD: The nation's stock and commodity markets were closed Thursday in observance of Thanksgiving Day.
Government offices, banks and most businesses were also closed.
All stock exchanges and most commodity markets will be open today, as usual.
However, the New York Mercantile Exchange and the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange will be closed.

6 Children Killed in Maryland Fire
LEAD: Firefighters outside a house in Seat Pleasant, near Washington, after a Thanksgiving Day fire left six children dead and six adults injured.
The children, ranging from 10 years to 9 months, were trapped in upstairs bedrooms by the blaze, which spread too rapidly to allow firemen a chance at a rescue.

Art: The Apprenticeship Of Stuart Davis as a Cubist
LEAD: IT might be said that Stuart Davis's career was a protracted love affair with Cubism that began well and ended better.
The end is well known: the bright conglomerations of jagged forms, meandering lines and cursive writing that Davis painted in the decade before his death in 1964 are among the last masterpieces built upon a Cubist foundation.

Pop/Jazz; Judy Collins, A Concern And a Bond
LEAD: FOR the contemporary pop singer who must woo and win the ear of a new generation every few years in order to survive, career longevity is a rare blessing.
Judy Collins, who celebrates her 25th anniversary of concertizing in New York at Carnegie Hall this evening, is certainly one of the blessed, having recorded continuously since 1961, beginning in folk music, and branching out into rock, country, theater and art songs.


Determined Nelson On Steady Course Back
LEAD: The letters are stacked by the hundreds in his six-bedroom house in Montvale, N.J.
They generally come from two groups of people: those who have had a similar illness and those who just want to wish him good health and a speedy recovery.


New Jersey Fights the Trash Tide
LEAD: People enjoying the sea and sand along New Jersey's shore one day last August had a nauseating surprise.
From Sandy Hook to Cape May, a 50-mile slick washed ashore carrying used hospital syringes, bags of household trash and thousands of empty crack bottles.
The gruesome garbage was just one of many incidents that closed New Jersey's beaches a record number of times.

METRO DATELINE;
LEAD: A Great Neck, L.I., man charged with molesting boys enrolled in his computer school was ordered held on $1 million bond or $500,000 cash bail in a hearing yesterday at which his son was ordered jailed on similar charges, the authorities said.


'We're Going to Vote Anyway, 'Haitians Insist
LEAD: By nightfall, the streets of this city rapidly drain of their bustle and traffic, giving way to an eerie stillness, as Haitians abandon public places to avoid the violent death that each night claims more victims.


Army to Pay Town For Contamination Of Its Water Supply
LEAD: The Army has agreed to pay $9.1 million in damages and build and operate an $8.8 million filtration system for this city, whose water supply was contaminated by chemicals from an ammunition plant.


Vikings Win in Overtime
LEAD: A 24-yard touchdown run by Darrin Nelson with 7 minutes 51 seconds gone in overtime gave the Minnesota Vikings a 44-38 victory over Dallas today and severely damaged the Cowboys' playoff hopes.

Tulane Aide Recovering
LEAD: Jeff Seal, the sports information director at Tulane University, was in stable condition after surgery yesterday at Tulane Medical Center for wounds he suffered after he was kidnapped, robbed and shot through the lower back, the police said.
Three men were later arrested by the police in downtown New Orleans and charged in the incident.


Saudi Princess Burned
LEAD: Shoaa Al-Farhan, a Saudi princess and cousin of the late King Faisal, was in critical condition today with third-degree burns over 93 percent of her body, a hospital spokesman said.
The princess, who is believed to be in her early 40's, was flown here by private jet Wednesday night and taken by ambulance to the Baltimore Regional Burn Center at Francis Scott Key Medical Center, Lee Kennedy, the spokesman said.


Advertising; Publication From Omni Is Aimed at Physicians
LEAD: Omni magazine, published by Penthouse International Ltd., is bringing out a special edition for physicians this week that will carry only health-care advertising.

LEAD: THERE are mitigating circumstances surrounding the unexpected demise of the Giants that will comfort their fans in the long off season ahead.
The National Football League players strike obviously played a key role, affecting the Giants more than most teams.

LEAD: Honor guard of police officers carrying the coffin of Mayor Harold Washington into City Hall.
His body will lie in state there until tomorrow night.
Funeral will be held Monday.
Mr.
Washington, the first black to be Mayor of Chicago, died of a heart attack on Wednesday. (AP)

3 Players Banned
LEAD: Three football players at Northeast Louisiana University have been suspended for violation of team rules, Coach Pat Collins said yesterday.
The announcement came a day before Northeast Louisiana faced North Texas State in the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division I-AA playoffs.
The three seniors are the starting strong safety, Perry Harper; the second-team fullback, Kenneth Johnson, and the third-team defensive end, Rick Upshaw.

Shopping Hours at Stores and Malls
LEAD: More than 20 million shoppers will troop into stores and malls in the metropolitan area in the next month.


Aides Say Reagan Is Briefed for Talks
LEAD: White House officials, who received some criticism for having poorly prepared President Reagan for a summit conference last year with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, say the President is ready for his meeting with the Soviet leader next month.


U.N. Chief Frustrated Over Gulf Peace Effort
LEAD: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar is frustrated by Iran's delay in sending an envoy for talks on the Iran-Iraq war but he will continue trying to bring peace to the area, his spokesman said today.


TV: 'Next President,' With David Frost
LEAD: David Frost begins a 13-part series tomorrow night with the men who would be President.
The first program, however, on Channel 9 at 11 o'clock, is about what happens to a candidate after he is elected.
Mr.
Frost speaks with President Reagan and former Presidents Jimmy Carter and Gerald R. Ford.

Passing the Test
LEAD: In 265 drug tests administered at random to athletes competing in track and field events throughout Britain over the last 18 months, two positive results were obtained, according to an announcement yesterday in London by the British Amateur Athletics Board.
Sue Howland, an Australian javelin thrower, was suspended after testing positive for steroids at a meet in Belfast, Northern Ireland, last summer, and Jayne Andrews, a British sprinter, tested positive for a stimulant, but appealed successfully because she was taking the drug for a chest infection.


West Held Immune To Gulf Oil Shocks
LEAD: New realities affecting world oil supplies have put the industrial countries in a position to withstand even a major disruption of the flow of petroleum from the Persian Gulf, according to senior officials in the United States and other Western countries.

LEAD: The dollar continued to slide and gold prices advanced in quiet trading yesterday.


Hyundai Duty Protested
LEAD: Trade Minister Rha Woong Bae protested today to Canada about a preliminary anti-dumping ruling against South Korea's popular Hyundai cars, a ministry spokesman said.
Canada's Revenue and Customs Department decided earlier this week that the Hyundai Motor Company was selling cars in Canada at unfairly low prices.

Pop: Rosanne Cash Sings
LEAD: Rosanne Cash's warm, tremulous voice and her taste for intelligent lyrics have raised hopes that she will emerge as Nashville's answer to the 1970's Linda Ronstadt - someone who will win country, pop and rock listeners with well-written songs.
In her early set Tuesday at the Bottom Line, the material was carefully chosen as always: nearly every song had something telling to say about jealousy or longing or suppressed rage.

Lillian B. Phipps, 81, Active in Horse Racing
LEAD: Lillian Bostwick Phipps, who was active in horse racing and the performing arts in New York for several decades after World War II, died yesterday at her home in Summerville, S.C.
She was 81 years old.

Air Canada Halts Flights
LEAD: Air Canada began a systemwide shutdown today after the Government-run carrier was crippled by a ground workers strike, stranding thousands of passengers from Vancouver to Montreal.
The airline's 8,500 ground workers have been holding rotating walkouts throughout the country because they have been without a contract since June.


Regina Garruto Is Wed To Edward W. Nugent
LEAD: At Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church in Rumson, N.J., Regina Rose Garruto, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs.
Anthony R. Garruto of Monmouth Beach, N.J., was married yesterday to Edward William Nugent, a son of Mr. and Mrs.
Edward E. Nugent of Old Bridge, N.J.
The Rev.
Frank Bruno performed the ceremony.


Life-Size Puppets
LEAD: The Famous People Players, a troupe of Canadian puppeteers who use life-size puppets of Barbra Streisand, Michael Jackson, Liberace and other celebrities, will perform at the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Whitman Hall of Brooklyn College at 2 P.M. tomorrow.
The 13-member company uses classical and popular music, black lights and other props for an eclectic program of musical revues and fairy tales called ''A Little Like Magic.


Bond Ready to Sail
LEAD: In 1983, Alan Bond led the Australian challenge that wrested the America's Cup from the United States after 132 years of domination by the New York Yacht Club.
Bond said yesterday in Perth that in view of the decision this week by the New York State Supreme Court to allow America's Cup races to be contested by yachts longer than the models used exclusively for the last 30 years, the San Diego Yacht Club should abide by that finding and announce its intention to conduct a multinational and multichallenger series.


Thomas G. Lanphier Jr., 71, Dies; U.S. Ace Shot Down Yamamoto
LEAD: Thomas G. Lanphier Jr., the World War II fighter pilot who shot down the Japanese airplane carrying the architect of the attack on Pearl Harbor, died Thursday at the San Diego Veterans Administration Hospital at La Jolla, Calif.
He was 71 years old.

Four in Inquiry Were Lauded On Arrest Rate
LEAD: The commander of four New York City transit police officers suspected of making scores of false or improper arrests in the subways used a rating system to reward those who made the most arrests and issued the most summonses with the best assignments and work schedules.


Businesses Don't Need Rent Control
LEAD: As markets for office space tighten up, local governments are tempted by talk of commercial rent control.
In New York City, 19 members of the City Council have succumbed: they offer a bill allowing commercial rents to be set by arbitrators.
The potential for damage to the city's economy from such a restriction on the free market far outweighs any conceivable benefit.

LEAD: John F. Scileppi, a former associate justice of the New York State Court of Appeals, died of a heart attack Thursday at University Hospital in Stony Brook, L.I.
He was 85 years old.

LEAD: Sandra Gasser, a Swiss runner who was banned from competition for two years by the International Amateur Athletic Federation on Sept. 29 after failing a test for steroids at the world track championships in Rome, has filed an appeal that seeks to overturn that penalty as well as the revocation of her bronze medal in the women's 1,500-meter race at the world competition in Rome.

Fate of Homeless Woman Is Debated in Court
LEAD: The Koch administration urged an appellate court yesterday to permit it to continue to hospitalize Joyce Brown, the first person picked up under a new city program for the mentally ill homeless.


Chopped to the Bone at State
LEAD: The cliche has it that the State Department has no domestic constituency and is therefore vulnerable to ruinous Congressional budgetary cuts.
But the department does have a constituency, though it's amorphous and diffuse.
Every traveler is a constituent; so is every travel agent and every international airline.


Forwood Wiser Jr., Aviation Executive Who Led 3 Carriers
LEAD: Forwood C. Wiser Jr., an aviation executive whose career included stints as president of three airlines, died of Alzheimer's disease Monday at Foothill Acres Nursing Home in Neshanic, N.J.
He was 66 years old and lived in Princeton, N.J.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  Skiing  Italian Wins Special Slalom: Alberto Tomba of Italy opened the men's World Cup ski season by scoring his first World Cup victory yesterday in the special slalom in Sestriere, Italy.
Jonas Nilsson of Sweden and Guenther Mader of Austria finished second and third.
Felix McGrath, Alexander Williams, Tiger Shaw and Troy Watts, all Americans, all dropped out in the first heat.


Newark Rips Down Its Projects
LEAD: The Scudder Homes are gone.
The Columbus Homes are going.
All told, Newark is on the way to demolishing nearly one-third of its public housing, even as waiting lists carry the names of 11,000 families.

Losses Seen At Allegheny
LEAD: Allegheny International Inc. today estimated its net losses at $215 million for the third quarter and $285 million for the first nine months of 1987.
The company also said it would pay no dividends for the sixth consecutive quarter.

LEAD: Mike Sanders scored a career-high 29 points tonight as the Phoenix Suns beat dealt the New Jersey Nets their fourth consecutive loss, 113-107.


MALAYSIA TO ISSUE NEW PRESS CURBS
LEAD: The Government has proposed a bill prescribing bans on publications that alarm public opinion and the suspension of journals that run articles judged to be against Malaysia's national interest.


Just the Trimmings
LEAD: Paul Dugal's relatives had come from as far as Texas for Thanksgiving dinner, but dinner did not go quite as planned. ''I proceeded to roast my turkey on the barbecue pit and I was about ready to dig in,'' Mr.
Dugal said. ''I came in to freshen up and went out to baste it one last time, but when I did the turkey was gone.

Transactions
LEAD:  COLLEGES


Turkey Hunter, 17, Is Slain
LEAD: A 17-year-old hunter was shot to death by a 12-year-old who heard a turkey call made by the older boy, the police said.
The authorities are witholding the names of both boys.
No charges have been filed in the shooting, which has been called an accident.


No Settlement in Bhopal Case
LEAD: District Judge M. W. Deo said today that he would consider a request for interim relief to help surviving victims of the 1984 gas leak from a Union Carbide plant in Bhopal that killed more than 2,800 people and injured more than 200,000.

Richard Attenborough On Art and the World
LEAD: ''I don't want to preach to the converted,'' said Sir Richard Attenborough, whose film, ''Cry Freedom'' -about the friendship between the slain South African black leader Stephen Biko and Donald Woods, a white newspaper editor - opened in New York this month. ''But I do want to reach the unknowing and the uncaring.


Carol Vaness Debut
LEAD: Carol Vaness, the Metropolitan Opera soprano, will make her New York recital debut at 3 P.M. tomorrow at Alice Tully Hall.
Miss Vaness, who made her New York City Opera debut in October 1979 and her Met debut four years later, will sing the New York premiere of a song cycle written for her by John Kander, the Broadway composer, as well as works by Richard Strauss, Rossini, Tosti and Chausson.


About New York; Hail to the City: A Media Show Hits Hard Times
LEAD: About five million people have seen ''The New York Experience'' since the tribute to the city opened in 1973, and lately some have been complaining that the sound and light blitzkrieg is getting a little long in the tooth.
This is perfectly understandable, says a spokesman for the enterprise; extensive, expensive updating was planned, but lease troubles have taken priority.

Howard Loses Injunction Bid
LEAD: A Federal judge today denied Howard University's request that Saturday's Division I-AA football playoff games be halted while Howard sues the N.C.A.A. over its exclusion from postseason play.

Patents; Balloon Used in Clamp For Vascular Surgery
LEAD: Dr.
Howard C. Baron of New York received a patent this week for a vascular balloon clamp to be used in surgery involving arteries and veins.
He explains that it is necessary to set clamps above and below an operation site, but hard-jaw metal clamps now in use can injure the artery wall.


More Wheat for Soviet
LEAD: United States farmers will be able to sell an additional 2.35 million metric tons of wheat to the Soviet Union under an expanded export program announced today by the Agriculture Department.
The Government had previously given farmers approval to sell nearly 6.4 million metric tons of wheat to the Soviet Union.


TALKS ARE PUT OFF
LEAD: A tentative agreement was reached today to free 26 hostages held by Cuban detainees here, but it fell apart at the last minute.

Officers Vow to Tighten Security In Courts, Even if It Slows Cases
LEAD: Officers assigned to guard prisoners in New York State courts will adopt stricter security procedures, their union leaders said yesterday.
They acknowledged the move may greatly increase the time needed to process cases.


Israeli Army Assailed Over Glider Raid
LEAD: The army is traditionally viewed here as a national symbol above reproach, but today its command came under harsh criticism from Israeli newspapers for its failure to stop a Palestinian guerrilla on a motorized hang glider from penetrating the northern border and attacking a military base.

MET OPERA: MOZART'S 'ENTFUHRUNG'
LEAD: The return of Mozart's ''Entfuhrung aus dem Serail'' Thursday night does not add to the Metropolitan Opera's season.
Jocelyn Herbert's two-dimensional cutouts against a bright blue sky must have had charm when fresh.
Today they look frayed and shabby.
The production is eight years old and has not aged well.

Economists Caution on Risks In Continued Drop of Dollar
LEAD: Despite widespread support within the United States for a deeper and deeper depreciation of the dollar, many economists are beginning to warn that, along with the potential benefits, there are significant costs and some substantial risks.

Seoul Bars Electioneering in Military
LEAD: The South Korean Defense Minister told his top commanders today not to interfere in next month's presidential election and to allow their soldiers to vote by secret ballot for the candidate of their choice.

Illinois Got a Third of U.S. Road Repair Fund
LEAD: Illinois got one-third of all the Federal money earmarked for interstate highway repairs in the last two years, a statistic that its officials attribute to the state's old roads and its ability to ''work the system.''

LEAD: In sharp and insistent terms, the Presidents of eight Latin American countries today condemned what they characterized as intransigence on the part of the United States and other ''rich countries'' and called for concessions on the region's spiraling foreign debt.

A Purist's Pursuit Of Cross-Country
LEAD: The sky was clear, the night bright in Alamosa, Colo., when Pat Porter went to bed Wednesday evening.
When he awoke at 5 o'clock the next morning, a blizzard had hit and 10 inches of snow had fallen.
Not surprisingly, his flight to New York was in jeopardy.
Typically, his morning run was not.

FOR ZIMBABWE MISSIONARIES, A NIGHT OF TERROR AND DEATH
LEAD: All those who have seen the blood-drenched bedroom at Olive Tree Farm - where eight people, missionaries and their children, were hacked to death - come away grim and tight-lipped.


East Berlin Journal; Strange Bedfellows: Marxists Embrace Nietzsche
LEAD: A re-evaluation of the 19th-century philosopher Friedrich Nietzsche has begun here with the endorsement of the Communist authorities, despite Nietzsche's reputation as one of the principal spiritual fathers of Nazism.


Earthquake Felt in Virginia
LEAD: A minor earthquake registering 3.7 on the Richter scale occurred today in southwestern Virginia, the United States Geological Survey reported.
The quake was centered near Pennington Gap, Va., about 20 miles southeast of Harlan, Ky.
Residents in Harlan and in Wise and Lee Counties in Virginia reported feeling tremors, the Federal agency said.


New York F.B.I. Chief Plans to Retire
LEAD: After only 14 months as head of the flagship office of the F. B. I., Thomas L. Sheer said yesterday that he would retire at the end of the year as assistant director in New York to take a better-paying position as a private security consultant.

LEAD: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission is looking into reports of possible manipulation of a sparsely traded stock index futures contract, the Major Market Index, during last month's market collapse, officials of the agency said today.

U.S.

Bridge; Players From Accord, N.Y., Win the Blue Ribbon Pairs
LEAD: The Blue Ribbon Pair Championship, one of the most prized titles in the annual calendar, was won here Thursday night by two quiet men from Accord, N.Y.
Playing in the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals, this pair, Fred Stewart and his stepson, Steve Weinstein, scored 62 percent in the final session and surged past the leaders.

Greyhound Deal
LEAD: The Greyhound Corporation said it expected to complete its $390 million purchase of the in-flight catering and terminal concessions businesses of Carson Pirie Scott &amp; Company on Sunday.
Under the deal, announced in May, Carson Pirie Scott shareholders will receive for each current share $30 in cash and a share in a newly formed company that would hold the retailing operation and other business lines.

Less Strain, More Gain
LEAD: WITHIN THE EVER-WIDEN-ing stylistic spectrum of modern dance, the art of Erick Hawkins remains steadfast.
Although his dances are charged with variety, their underlying esthetic and physical premise never alters.
For Mr.
Hawkins, whose company begins a six-day engagement at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday, to dance is to move naturally, without strain, without tension and without artifice.

The price range is $5 to $600, and 35 vendors are participating this year.

They saw only masked gunmen.

E. F. Hutton Goes on the Block
LEAD: E. F. Hutton is for sale.
The stock market collapse last month and the likelihood of a downgrading in its credit rating were the final blows to a securities firm that has been struggling since it pleaded guilty two years ago to a check-kiting scheme that defrauded banks of millions of dollars.
Last year, when most of Wall Street was awash in profits, Hutton had a loss of $90.3 million.

Smoking-Rule Smoke
LEAD: When New York's highest court last week upheld two previous court rulings, it did not uphold smoking in public.
It said that the State Public Health Council had gone too far in issuing new rules on public smoking.
The council, said six of the seven judges on the Court of Appeals, had ''usurped'' legislative power.

INVESTOR PROFILES: Yields Improve the Quality of Life; Payouts For Social Concerns
LEAD: RUTH SHEREFF, now 44 years old, bought stock on her own for the first time just two years ago.
Her father, who had been managing her money until then, said that it would have been better had she lost money the first time out so she would learn caution and humility.
Instead, she made a killing.

Simple Fruit Pies From Tuscany
LEAD: THE dough that is the basis of the Tuscan crostata, a shallow one-crust pie usually topped with fruit or homemade fruit jam, is to an Italian what pate a foncer fine is to a French pastry chef, a classic sweetened crust for a tart.
Any Italian knows know to make pasta, mixing eggs into a mound of flour, but only the most able cooks can create the flaky, butter-laden base that is the truth of a celestial crostata.

LEAD: FOR many of Wilton's town employees, it's a nice place to serve, but they can't afford to live there.


DEMYSTIFYING POP-UP DRAINS
LEAD: POP-UP drains in bathroom basins may seem mysterious, but actually they are simple to repair.
Knowing how they operate is useful.

40% of Americans Fear They Will Contract AIDS, a Poll Indicates
LEAD: More than 40 percent of American adults are concerned that they will contract AIDS, and fear of having the deadly disease is prompting many people to change their sexual behavior and take other precautions, the latest Gallup poll indicates.

The name rings bells that evoke a theme park more than a first-class restaurant.

Whose Words?
LEAD: To the Editor:


SIGHS OF ANOTHER CONNECTICUT WINTER
LEAD: CHANGE is not merely in the air, it is here.
Just look at what happened Oct. 4.
Talk about a harbinger of worse things yet to come!
I get depressed enough between November and April.
I don't need a freak snowstorm in the first week of October to remind me that winter is on its way.


SOUTHERN SUMMIT REKINDLES OLD DREAMS OF LATIN UNITY
LEAD: FOR the first time, the presidents of eight Latin American nations are meeting without a United States presence to discuss solutions to their regional problems.
The agenda for the conference, which is to conclude today, ranges from the conflicts in Central America to the region's foreign debt of nearly $400 billion.

Sondheim's Winding Paths
LEAD: ''THERE'S SOMETHING ABOUT A WAR'' goes the title of a song that was written for, but never used, in Stephen Sondheim's first musical as a Broadway composer, the 1962 ''A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum.'' There's something about a Stephen Sondheim musical that's something like a war - and, until the arrival of his latest and perhaps most tranquil show, ''Into the Woods,'' that war had threatened to rival the Thirty Years' War in duration.

LEAD: King Lear.
Pygmalion.
The Old Testament.
Greek tragedies.
If you substitute the nouns and verbs, you could write the family business owner's story. . . .
His problems are the problems of humanity, and the business funds and fuels them.
It's a family passion play, with the business founder center stage, usually alone.

The complete sentence is as follows: The time has come to switch places if we are to move effectively into the 21st century: The builder must think like an environmentalist and the environmentalist must think like a pragmatic business person.

On the Phone?
LEAD: Jackie Presser, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, made a point of keeping the Federal Bureau of Investigation up to date on certain Teamster activities for more than a decade, according to documents filed in Federal Court in Cleveland last week.
Mr.
Presser, who has headed the Teamsters since 1983, was said to have kept the bureau informed of ties between union officials and organized crime groups since 1974.

LEAD: King Olav V of Norway says he is thrilled to be making his sixth visit to Minnesota, where one-sixth of the state's residents are of Norwegian descent. ''I have been enormously impressed by the unfailing interest in Norway here in this country,'' the King said at a dinner in his honor Friday night.

TAP DANCE TO SCIENCE
LEAD: Crossroads Africa Dec. 2 - Since its founding in 1957, Operation Crossroads Africa has sent more than 8,000 young Americans to rural African and Caribbean communities to work on development projects in medicine, agriculture, education and construction.
And over the past 23 years, more than 3,200 young African political leaders and professionals have visited schools and other institutions in the United States.

IN SHORT: FICTION
LEAD:  WHITE LIGHT.
By Patricia Volk. (Atheneum, $18.95.) This inventive if flawed first novel is half comic strip, half yuppie spiritual crisis.
When 35-year-old May Graves, an art director at a magazine for teen-agers, makes an ill-received comment at a meeting, trouble begins.
A month away from New York City is what she needs, and soon May is in a hotel in the Adirondacks trying desperately to return to a simpler state.

LEAD: SOME day one of our advanced business schools will offer a graduate course in how to become a chief executive.
It will probably attract armies of the brightest of the bright.
But of course it will not work because in no office in the business universe is the crucible of experience more essential.
Nor is experience itself the answer.

Collecting Art? Beware the Wrinkles
LEAD: COLLECTING art requires a great deal of faith.
One has to trust one's tastes, the art dealer and the market.
But even with art prices soaring - a trend underscored earlier this month by the astronomical $53.9 million that Van Gogh's ''Irises'' brought at auction - faith can take you just so far.
Increasingly, buying and selling is being regulated through legislation and case law, and consumers need to be aware of their rights to negotiate better deals.

LEAD: ALTHOUGH there has been an improvement in the spawning of striped bass in many of the rivers entering Chesapeake Bay, the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission announced earlier this fall that it would continue its current recommendation for a 33-inch minimum-length limit for migratory coastal stocks of the species.

Luggage
LEAD: To the Editor: Apropos your Practical Traveler ''Finding Lost Luggage'' (Travel, Sept. 27), I would like to share our experience with your readers.
On Sept. 24 we checked in at the Eugene, Ore., airport bound for Kennedy International Airport by way of San Francisco.
The cheerful, courteous United Airlines clerk agreed that the layover of half an hour might be too short if there were a delay at Eugene and rerouted us to Denver where the layover was a bit longer.

LEAD: ALTHOUGH no President since Franklin Delano Roosevelt has been able to appoint more judges than Ronald Reagan, the Federal court system has not yet become the conservative bastion that he and his supporters had intended.
It has not been for lack of trying.
By the end of his term, Mr.
Reagan will probably have named more than half of the nation's 743 Federal judges.

WHEN TO KEEP AND WHEN TO DISCARD
LEAD: LAST weekend I attended a conference of photography curators and archivists.
They were not exactly a typical bunch of photo buffs even though many were carrying point-and-shoot cameras.
But one of the most hotly contested topics of conversation involved a question that every photographer has to face at one time or another: how to decide which pictures to keep and which to throw out.

LEAD: THE death of a 5-month old baby in New Britain after he spent the night in a car with his homeless parents has focused attention once again on the plight of Connecticut's homeless and the fear that winter will bring more tragedy.
Typically in winter, there is more attention focused on the homeless, a group whose number appears to be increasing as the state's stock of low-income housing and residential hotels diminishes.

Corrections
LEAD: An article on Sept. 27 about Chicago misidentified the architect of Lake Point Tower.
The architects were Schipporeit-Heinrich Associates, not Mies van der Rohe; George Schipporeit and John Heinrich, principals at the time of design, were students of Mies.

Li, who is assured of being named Prime Minister on a permanent basis at the National People's Congress next spring, is a 59-year-old Soviet-educated engineer who, in the eyes of some Westerners, has not enthusiastically supported the economic policies of China's senior leader, Deng Xiaoping, and might even have ''pro-Soviet'' leanings.

IN SHORT: FICTION
LEAD:  CIRCLES OF DECEIT.
By Nina Bawden. (St. Martin's, $14.95.) The British novelist Nina Bawden's latest work is aptly named, since most of its characters are deceiving someone, not infrequently themselves.
The unnamed narrator, a painter, has even elevated the practice to an art.
He makes finely detailed copies of important works by the masters - always for legitimate purposes - and uses the income to finance his smaller output of originals.

About Men; A Case of Colic
LEAD: THE TIGHTER I HELD HER, THE more she stiffened, arching her back and pummeling her heels into my midsection.
And her continuous high-pitched shriek made my skull reverberate.
It had been going on for nearly five hours.
Seldom in my life had I felt so rejected by anyone.
My 6-week-old daughter had colic.

Correction
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article about Iceland in today's Travel section incorrectly gives the times of sunrise and sunset on the winter solstice, Dec. 21.
The sun rises at 11:23 A.M. and sets at 3:34 P.M., resulting in about 20 hours of darkness.


IN SHORT: FICTION
LEAD:  THE BERKUT.
By Joseph Heywood. (Random House, $18.95.) Adolf Hitler killed himself in the spring of 1945 as the Red Army advanced on his bunker in Berlin.
Or did he?
Groan.
Not another novel about how Hitler or one of his henchmen survived to sin another day.
But don't despair.
Joseph Heywood's second novel isn't your run-of-the-mill Nazi-hunting twaddle.

In New Mexico, Pinon Fires And Pueblo Dancers
LEAD: ON Christmas Eve at the San Juan pueblo in northern New Mexico, every family puts up a small pile of logs in front of their home.
As the sky darkens over the pueblo, the wood is ignited into fires called luminarias.
Dancers known as Matachines appear, in many-colored silk capes and streaming ribbons, led by a blanket-draped figure holding a cross.

Gospel: McIntosh Shouters
LEAD: THE McIntosh County Shouters, who gave their first New York concerts Friday and Saturday at Washington Square Church under the auspices of the World Music Institute, perform ring shouts, an archaic black music tradition that was long thought to be extinct.
The ring shout, which was first described by visitors to plantations in the deep South as early as the 1840's, seems to have survived longest in isolated island communities off Georgia and South Carolina.

IN SHORT: NONFICTION
LEAD:  STEAL THIS URINE TEST: Fighting Drug Hysteria in America.
By Abbie Hoffman with Jonathan Silvers. (Penguin, Paper, $5.95.) Drug abuse is a serious national problem, but part of that problem is public and governmental misunderstanding and over-reaction: that is the important theme of ''Steal This Urine Test,'' and it's one that the book documents thoroughly.


THE CONTRADICTIONS OF BOB DOLE
LEAD: I read with astonishment that Senator Dole whispered to me, during a House-Senate conference, that I should ignore his pronouncements on austerity and press for expansion of Medicaid coverage of prenatal care.
No such conversation took place.


VICTORIAN HOUSE IS A PRODUCT OF CHANGE
LEAD: Maria Stieglitz suggests painting our old houses in bright San Francisco colors  [ ''Why Victorian Drab?
Try Tangerine Gables!'' Opinion Page, Nov. 1 ] .
It might be a good idea.


INVESTOR PROFILES: Yields Improve the Quality of Life; Funding An Active Retirement
LEAD: BARBARA and Joseph Suarez started life with very little money.
But late last year, when they decided to retire and move to Florida, they found that their house in Westchester County - for which they had paid $50,000, 20 years before - was worth close to $300,000.
Between that and some savings, they had a lump sum of $325,000.


Using Plastic to Rev Up Revenues
LEAD: SOME consumers have recently received solicitations for ''affinity cards'' - bank credit cards offered in conjunction with a nonprofit charity or association.
The sponsoring bank promises to help the organization every time the customer charges a purchase with the card.


Practical Traveler; What You Can Expect From a Travel Agent
LEAD: YOU'RE a smart person; do you really need a travel agent for your vacation trip?
An agent is probably not going to save you a lot of money on an air trip, unless you are shy about calling a lot of airlines on 800 numbers and asking what the cheapest fare is to that place.
But if you would rather do something other than this research, you probably need a travel agent.


The Stakes Are Too High
LEAD: THE kinds of investments that get the most publicity are often the least appropriate for the average investor, say the experts.
Because they involve too much risk, have poor potential for return or require the time and attention that only the most sophisticated professionals can devote to them, these investments are best avoided by anyone whose primary attention is elsewhere, for instance, on a demanding job.


U.S. ACTS TO PROTECT ISLAND TERN
LEAD: THE roseate tern, which nests in the Stewart B. McKinney National Wildlife Refuge off southwest Connecticut, has been declared an endangered species by the U.S.
Fish and Wildlife Service, effective Dec. 2.


PORTENTS OF TURNS FOR THE WORSE-OR THE BETTER
LEAD: EVER since the Oct. 19 stock market collapse, most analysts have been saying that the economy would slow down as a result, perhaps enough to send the nation stumbling into recession.
They argue that consumers, who account for two-thirds of the gross national product, have lost both wealth and confidence and will pull in their horns accordingly.

LEAD: THE celebration of the New Year is usually here today and gone tomorrow, except in Scotland, where the joys of the season and the pleasures of the flask linger a full two days.
Scots allow Jan. 2 as well as Jan. 1 for a double measure of oblivion, and count their blessings twice over.

CORRECTIONS
LEAD: A picture caption on Nov. 1 with a guide to cruises misidentified a ship off Grand Cayman.

WHAT ARE WE DOING WITH A UNIFORM IN THE HOUSE?
LEAD: THE 7-year-old boy can not sleep tonight.
His uniform is laid out beside his bed, and he keeps getting up to put on his blue and yellow cap, to finger the engraved buckle of his blue webbed belt, to gaze at the insignias decorating his brand-new blue shirt.
My husband had bought the entire outfit, including the yellow kerchief and various metal buttons, for more money than he had paid for his own fall jacket.


NEW YORKERS, etc.
LEAD: ACCORDING to a certain genre of romantic novel, there's a ''no better than she should be'' seductress simmering inside many a discreet black dress, and an adventurous swashbuckler lurking behind a lot of blue pin-stripe suits.
Stick with these romances and inevitably passion flares, a volcano erupts.

MUSIC VIEW
LEAD: WOULD ANYONE ARGUE AGAINST THE proposition that the ear is the body's most important organ in the perception and evaluation of music?
Not likely.
Even the more presumptuous opera directors might concede, at least in principle, that there is more to music than meets the eye.
But it is also true that seeing while listening can sometimes add a dimension to a problematical work and make a believer of a skeptic.

Photography
LEAD: Mitch Epstein and Len Jenshel are leading members of a generation of photographers who are not afraid of the sensual, picturesque qualities of color film.
Because their pictures are lush and luminous, they are often paired in their audience's mind.
But as their shows on opposite sides of Spring Street this month suggest, their styles and their sensibilities are quite distinct.

THE BEST WOMAN IN THE HALL
LEAD: The Women's Professional Billiard Association was pleased with Roger Starr's article on women's pocket billiards and Jean Balukas (''The Best Woman in the Hall,'' Oct. 18).


LIVING AND WRITING THE PEASANT LIFE
LEAD: NO one goes to the Vallee du Giffre.
In the Michelin Guide to the French Alps, it is mentioned only in passing, a place to get around or quickly through.
There are no curiosities in its tiny villages, and its mountains - its jagged, hulking mountains - offer few gentle slopes for le ski moderne.
It is one of those parts of the region known as the Haute-Savoie that time has left to the Savoyard peasants; and that, I was told more than once in Paris, where I was to get my train to the Alps, was reason enough to stay away.

LEAD: A QUIET intensity marks the atmosphere at Tyler Graphics Ltd., the industrial-sized workshop in Mount Kisco where editions of prints by some of America's leading artists are produced.

Recently, on entering Thailand, I was asked to be specific.
What is the proper way of answering this question? - D. W., White Plains  Answer: The correct response is to name the city, the passport division of the United States Bureau of Consular Affairs says.

WE OWE THE WILD THINGS A WARMER WELCOME
LEAD: AN extraordinary sight met my eyes one evening in late summer.
My two cats were on the lawn facing something sitting between them.
That ''something'' was black with white stripes.
All three animals were frozen into immobility; the cats weren't taking their eyes off the skunk and the skunk wasn't certain just where to turn or what to do next.

DID MADAME BOVARY DO DISHES?
LEAD: DID Madame Bovary take arsenic to avoid doing dishes?

Question Of the Week; Who Should Win the Heisman Trophy?
LEAD: Don McPherson of Syracuse wins hands down.
He accounted for well over half of the Orangemen's touchdowns and total yardage this season.
When McPherson's game was on, (as was the norm), the team won easily.
When he struggled (as in the West Virginia game) so did the team.
Overall, he combined great running with great passing to lead Syracuse to an undefeated season.

Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number.
We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

LEAD: A man that authorities said had been impersonating a nurse at a Harlem hospital for three months has been arrested, setting off a review by the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation of the credentials of about 3,500 nurses registered with a referral agency, officials said yesterday.

Kevin Roche Finishes a Trio And Changes His Tune
LEAD: WHEN KEVIN ROCHE'S 1 United Nations Plaza, the hotel and office tower at the corner of First Avenue and 44th Street, was finished in 1976, the most notable thing about it was the extent to which the tower's shimmering glass-and-metal form broke rank with everything around it.
The building is an exquisite minimalist sculpture; its abstract form has nothing to do with any of the buildings near it, except for the allusions its blue-green glass makes to the United Nations Secretariat building across First Avenue.

The Falling Dollar
LEAD: To the Editor:


Food; WINTER VEGETABLES
LEAD: FOR ME, FALL IS A TIME OF nostalgia.
Cascading leaves and a nip in the air remind me of the impending holidays and the comfort of home.
It is a season for moving indoors, crackling fires and celebration of robust fare.
Tables laden with juicy roasted game birds, thick soups and stews laced with hearty winter vegetables reflect our need to stave off the cold.

Salzburg
LEAD: To the Editor: In two articles on Salzburg and environs (Travel, July 5 and Aug. 16), Oscar Millard correctly described what the females wear as Dirndls.
What the men wear he called flannel.
The stuff is Loden.
The only resemblance is that both are gray.
PAUL SINGER  Summit, N.J.

For months during early 1986 he was haunted by ''Mack the Knife,'' written by Kurt Weill and Bertolt Brecht for ''The Threepenny Opera'' and a No. 1 hit for Bobby Darin in l959.
What made the song stick was its irresistible connection to one of his biggest clients, the McDonald's Operators Association of Southern California - and, of course, to the Big Mac.

LEAD: United States factory sales of electronic equipment, components and related products during the first nine months of the year increased 6.7 percent over the corresponding period last year, an industry association said Friday.

Stunned silence. ''I think that's the first time in my life I've heard him shut up,'' Jack Nicklaus said. ''He was speechless.
For once, he was at a loss for words.'' But the silence didn't last.
Lee Trevino - who watched in something like disbelief today as his 6-iron shot trickled into the cup for a hole-in-one - began bounding about the 17th tee, hopping into the air, waving his cap.

Nansi emerged from his monthly tontine meeting with $35,000 in cash.

LEAD: A Belgian Air Force Hercules transport plane arrived in Ethiopia today to airlift emergency food to drought victims in the northern province of Tigre, where rebel ambushes are hindering transport by road.
Jean-Jacques Fresard, the delegate of the International Committee of the Red Cross in Ethiopia, said the plane would start work Monday, ferrying more than 70 tons of food each day from Asmara, the capital of Eritrea province, to Mekele, the capital of Tigre.

Recital: Carol Vaness
LEAD: THE thoughtfulness of Carol Vaness's recital at Alice Tully Hall yesterday afternoon began with her choice of music.
There were such tender little Rossini masterpieces as ''La Promessa'' and ''L'Invito''; then four Strauss lieder of solid substance followed by three elegant desserts by Tosti.
Nowhere in French song is despair so eloquent or nostalgia so touching as in Chausson's ''Temps des Lilas'' and ''Colibri.

Bridge: Player From Bombay Leads In Fall National Title Event
LEAD: Until this year no foreign player had ever won a major American team title, but that barrier was broken four months ago at the American Contract Bridge League's summer nationals in Baltimore.
And the successful player, Jaggy Shivdasani of Bombay, India, was on track to repeat the success when the final day's play began at the fall nationals here today.


Rehabilitate Bukharin, Widow Asks Moscow
LEAD: Nikolai I. Bukharin's widow has asked Mikhail S. Gorbachev for the political rehabilitation of her husband, who was executed in 1938 after he was ousted from the Kremlin hierarchy by Stalin, a journal appearing today reported.


A Rite Is Going Wrong Way
LEAD: A few years ago, Harold Ballard, owner of the Toronto Maple Leafs, outraged many Canadians when he passed the word that a female reporter would be welcome in the team's locker room if she joined the hockey players in removing her clothes.
Nobody could be sure that the 84-year-old Ballard, who has made a career of cantankerousness, was joking.


Dresser's Energy Focus Emphasized by New Bid
LEAD: John J. Murphy, president, chief executive and chairman of Dresser Industries, has underscored his company's focus on the energy industry with the announcement that Dresser plans to acquire the N. W. Kellogg Company.


Irene Handl Dies at 85; Comedienne in Britain
LEAD: Irene Handl, one of Britain's best-loved actresses and comediennes, who perfected the role of a slightly eccentric cockney old lady, died today at her home here, according to her agent, Peter Graham.
She was 85 years old.


Why the Watergate Break-In?
LEAD: H. R. Haldeman shrugged. ''To this day I still don't know why that was done,'' Richard M. Nixon's former chief of staff told a questioner at Hofstra University the other day. ''And I don't know anybody who does.
Why they would hit the National Headquarters is beyond me, because nobody in that place knows anything anyway.
