OUTDOORS: NO DEER BAGGED, JUST LEFTOVER GROCERIES
LEAD: HAD there been snow for tracking, had the deer that walked past my son, Steve, been a buck instead of a doe, had the season on black bear not been closed, had moose been legal game, the six of us who recently journeyed to the northeastern tip of New Hampshire for two and one-half days of hunting could have come back with more than a box of leftover groceries.


Dollar Hits New Low; Stocks Drop in Tokyo
LEAD: The dollar fell to a record low today on the Tokyo foreign exchange market.
Stock prices also declined.


Bronx Grand Jury Critical of No-Bid Towing Pacts
LEAD: A system of no-bid contracts for emergency towing on limited-access allowed to continue despite a 1981 City Comptroller's audit that showed it had engendered widespread fraud, a Bronx grand jury has asserted.

LEAD: Well, why not?


Blazers Hand Nets 5th Straight Loss
LEAD: Clyde Drexler and Steve Johnson scored 28 points each tonight, leading the Portland Trail Blazers to their fifth consecutive victory, a 125-104 decision over the Nets.
It was the fifth straight loss for New Jersey.


France Lets Bombing Suspect Go In Step to Restore Ties With Iran
LEAD: France allowed an Iranian sought for questioning in terrorist bombings to leave the country today, a step in restoring relations between Paris and Teheran after their bassies and diplomats have been under police siege for nearly six months.


Social-Service Breakup Is Suggested by Perales
LEAD: The New York City Human Resources Administration has become mired in bureaucracy and should be broken into smaller, localized units with more accountability, the State Commissioner of Social Services said in a television program aired yesterday.


Author Turns 80 With Roman Timelessness
LEAD: ''I always live in the present, and so it seems that my life is always the same and that my age is always the same.''


Corporate Profitability Rising, Reversing 15-Year Downturn
LEAD: After 15 years of decline, the profitability of American business - measured as a return on investments - is rising again, and the future health of the economy is riding on whether the turnaround can be sustained.


Esposito Timetable Moving Too Slowly
LEAD: PHIL ESPOSITO, a man who admits he is in a hurry but contends he does not feel rushed, has found himself under the burden of a skewed timetable ever since he assumed control of the Rangers last year in midsummer.

FIVE BODIES FOUND AFTER JET CRASH
LEAD: Search teams pulled five bodies from the Indian Ocean today in the area where a South African Airways jet crashed with 159 people aboard.

Clemson Defeats Pesky Rutgers, 3-2
LEAD: Bruce Murray of Clemson, proving he possesses the characteristics of an efficient striker, found the right time to get free inside the opposing penalty area as the Tigers scored a 3-2 victory today that eliminated Rutgers from the National Collegiate Athletic Association soccer tournament.


Running Strong
LEAD: Six months have passed and Sean Nelson can still hear the gunfire.
The 17-year old football player was walking home from his girlfriend's house on a Friday night in May when six shots rang out.
One of the bullets hit him in the back.
By the time he was taken to a hospital, Nelson realized he was lucky to be alive, but he had another dread - that he would never play football again.


Columbia Contenders
LEAD: The last time Columbia won an Ivy League basketball championship was in the 1967-68 season.
Since then, Penn and Princeton have dominated the league, while Columbia's fortunes have sagged.

Dance: The City Ballet in a Pair Set to Gounod
LEAD: THE New York City Ballet presented audiences with a generous sampling of varied works from its repertory at weekend performances at the New York State Theater.


Top Afghan Offers New Charter; Insurgents Answer With Rockets
LEAD: Invoking Islam, but interrupted by Islamic guerrilla rockets, Afghanistan's Communist leader, Najibullah, introduced a new constitution today in an effort to legitimize his shaky Soviet-backed regime.


Talks Seek to Avert Milk and Trash Hauler Strikes
LEAD: Labor negotiations in two industries - milk distribution and private refuse carting - were scheduled today in an effort to avert strikes tonight that would halt the delivery of milk and the collection of all commercial garbage in New York City and many suburban areas.

Bills Clobber Dolphins
LEAD: Buffalo limited Miami to 229 yards - just 23 on the ground - and stopped Dan Marino's streak of 30 straight games with at least one touchdown pass as the Bills beat the Dolphins today, 27-0.


Taiwan Studies Joining GATT
LEAD: Taiwan is considering applying to rejoin the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade 37 years after withdrawing from GATT membership, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said Friday.


Washington Talk: Court Politics; Nursing the Wounds From the Bork Fight
LEAD: A month after the Senate's defeat of Judge Robert H. Bork, life has yet to return to normal for many of the conservative Southern Democrats who voted against President Reagan's Supreme Court nominee.


The U.N. Today: Nov. 30, 1987
LEAD:  GENERAL ASSEMBLY


Bombing in Manila
LEAD: A bomb went off tonight behind the Philippine International Convention Center, where leaders of Southeast Asian nations are to meet from Dec. 14 to 16, the police said.
There were no reports of casualties.
The police said the blast damaged a fire hydrant and broke the building's windows.
Three weeks ago, the police found more than 80 sticks of dynamite inside the building.


A Poor Parish Strains To Help the Homeless
LEAD: Most of the people who worship at St.
Luke's Church in the South Bronx have very little money to spare.
But yesterday, as they filed out after the service, they were asked to give to a group that is even poorer than they are - the homeless.


Trial of Crime Boss to Open
LEAD: Jury selection begins Monday for the trial of Nicodemo Scarfo, the reputed head of organized crime in Philadelphia and southern New Jersey, on charges of masterminding a multimillion-dollar drug ring.
Selection of the 12 jurors and four alternates is expected to take most of this week.
They will be sequestered in a hotel until the trial is over, which the authorities hope will come before Christmas.
